Also i. q. xabarN [both of which words are generally held to be syn., as meaning A tradition, or narration relating or describing a saying or an action, &c., of Moḥammad]: (M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, the former signifies what is related as received from [one or more of] the Companions of Moḥammad; (TA;) but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet; (Kull p. 152;) and the latter, what is from Moḥammad himself; (TA;) or from another; or from him or another: (Kull p. 152:) or the former signifies i. q. sun-apN [a practice or saying, or the practices and sayings collectively, of Moḥammad, or any other person who is an authority in matters of religion, namely, any prophet, or a Companion of Moḥammad, as handed down by tradition]: (Ṣ, A:) pl. MvaArN. (Ṣ, M.) You say, wajadotuhu fiI AlOavari [I found it in the traditions of the practices and sayings of the Prophet;, &c.]: and fulaAnN mino Hamalapi AlMvaAri [Such a one is of those who bear in their memories, knowing by heart, the traditions of the practices and sayings of the Prophet;, &c.]. (A.)
A man's origin; as in the sayings, maA yudoraI lahu Oayona OavarN It is not known where was his origin; and maA yudoraI lahu maA OvarN It is not known what is his origin. (Ks, Lḥ, M.)

The term, or period, of life: so called because it follows life: (Mṣb, TA:) or from the same word as signifying the print of one's foot upon the ground; because when one dies, his footprints cease to be seen. (TA.)
[For the former of these two reasons,] MvaArahumo in the Ḳur xxxvi. 11 means The rewards and punishments of their good and evil lives. (M, L.)
MvaArN is also a pl. of vaOorN, q. v.; formed by transposition from OavoMrN. (Yaạḳoob, and M in art. vOr.)

entry.sense: OavurN A man who chooses for himself [in preference to his companions] (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) good things, (Ḳ,) in partition, (M, TA,) or good actions, and qualities of the mind; (ISk, Ṣ;) as also OavirN↓ (M, Ḳ.)
OavirN: see OavurN.
OuvurN: see OuvorN, in two places:
and see OavorN.
OavorapN: see OavaArapN.

hom.sense: OuvorapN: see OavaArapN.

A mark which is made by the Arabs of the desert upon the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot; as also taOovuwrN↓, and, accord. to some, tuWovuwrahu↓, whence one says, raOayotu Ouvoratahu, and tuWovuwrahu↓, I saw the place of his footsteps upon the ground: (M:) or the abrasion of the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot with the instrument of iron called miYovarap and tuWovuwr, in order that his footprints may be traced. (Ṣ.) [See also OuvorN.]
See also OavorN.
And see maOovurapN.

Preference. (A.) You say, lahu EinodiI OuvorapN He has a preference in my estimation. (A.) And huwa cuw OuvorapK Einoda AlOamiyri He has a preference in the estimation of the prince, or commander. (A.) And fulaAnN cuw OuvorapK Einoda fulaAnK, (TA,) or OavarapK↓, (T,) Such a one is a favourite with such a one. (T, TA.) See also OavarapN, in two places.
Ouvorapa ciI OaviyrK: see MvirN.
Dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility, (jadobN [in the CK jacob],) and an unpleasant state or condition. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: UivorapN: see OavarapN.
UivorapF: see MvirN.
OavarapN: see OavaArapN.

A subst. [signifying The appropriation of a thing or things to oneself exclusively: the having a thing to oneself, with none to share with him in it:] from AisotaOovara biAlX-aIoCi. (Ṣ, M.) And, as also OuvorapN↓ and UivorapN↓ and UuvoraI↓, The choice for oneself [in preference to his companions] of good things, (M,* Ḳ,* TA,) in partition; (M, TA;) the choice and preference of the best of things, and taking it, or them, for oneself: (TA:) the pl. of the second is OuvarN. (TA.) You say, Oaxacahu bilaA OavarapK, and blA OuvorapK↓, [&c.,] He took it without a choice and preference of the best of the things, and the taking the best for himself. (T, TA.) And a poet says,
faqulota lahu yaA ciYobu halo laka fIi OaxK
yuWaAsiI bilaA Ouvoray↓ Ealayoka walaA buxoli
[And I said to him, O wolf, hast thou a desire for a brother who will share without choice of the best things for himself in preference to thee, and without niggardness?]. (M, TA.) See also OuvorapN.
OuvoraI: see OavarapN, in two places.

hom.sense: OaviyrN: see OavarapN.

[That makes a large footprint, or the like.] You say, daAb-apN OaviyarpN A beast that makes a large footprint upon the ground with its hoof, (AZ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or with its soft foot, such as that of the camel. (AZ, Ṣ.)
A man possessing power and authority; honoured: pl. OuvaraMCu: fem. OaviyrapN. (M.)
fulaAnN OaviyriI Such a one is my particular friend: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or is the person whom I prefer. (A.) fulaAnN OaviyrNEinoda fulaAnK Such a one is a favourite with such a one. (T.)
Mvira ciI OaviyrK, and Oaw-ala ciI OaviyrK, &c.: see MvirN.
XaIoCN kaviyrN OaviyrN [A thing very abundant, copious, or numerous]: Avyr is here an imitative sequent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) like baviyrN. (Ṣ.)

AlOaviyru [ὁ αἰθήρ, The ether;] the ninth, which is the greatest, sphere, which rules over [all] the other spheres: [said to be] so called because it affects the others (yuWaviru fiI gayorihi). (MF.) [It is also called falaku AlOaTolasi, and falaku AlEaroXi; and is said to be next above that called falaku AlkurosiI-i.]

entry.sense: OavaArapN: see OavarN. You say, saminati AlUbilu EalaI OavaArapK, (Ṣ, M,*) or ElI OavaArapK mino XaHomK, (A,) The camels acquired fat, upon, or after, remains of fat. (Ṣ, M,* A.) And gaDiba EalaI OavaArapK qibola caAka He became angry the more, having been angry before that. (Lḥ, M.) And OagoDabaniI fulaAnN EalaI OavaArapi gaDabK Such a one angered me when anger yet remained in me. (A.) And OavaArapN mino EilomK, and OavarapN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and OuvorapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) or OavorapN↓, (T,) the first of which is the most approved, (M,) and is [originally] an inf. n., [see Oavara AlMHadiyva,] (T,) signify A remain, or relic, of knowledge, (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, and Jel in xlvi. 3 of the Ḳur,) transmitted, or handed down, (Ḳ, Jel,) from the former generations: (Jel:) or what is transmitted, or handed down, of knowledge: (Zj, M:) or somewhat transmitted from the writings of the former generations: (TA:) by the knowledge spoken of [in the Ḳur ubi suprà] is meant that of writing, which was given to certain of the prophets. (I’Ab.)

MvirN One who relates, or recites, a tradition, narrative, or story, or traditions, &c., as received, or heard, from another, or others; a narrator thereof. (T, Ṣ,* L.) The saying of ʼOmar, on his being forbidden by Moḥammad to swear by his father, maA Halafotu bihi caAkirAF walaA MvirFA, means I did not swear by him uttering (the oath) as proceeding in the first instance from myself, nor repeating (it) as heard from another particular person. (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, TA.)

OafoEalu hcaA MvirFA m-aA, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and MvirFA without mA, (IAạr, T,) and Mvira ciI OaviyrK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) mean I will do this the first of every thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And in like manner, after laqiytuhu [I met him, or it], one says, MvirFA m-aA, [and Mvira ciI OaviyrK↓,] and Oaw-ala ciI OaviyrK↓, (M, Ḳ,)
and Mvira caAti yadiI, (M,) or caAti yadayoni, (Ḳ,) and ciI yadayoni, (IAạr, M, Ḳ,) and Oaviyrapa ciI OaviyrK↓, and Uuvorapa↓ ciI Oviyrayoni↓, (Ḳ,) and Mvira ciI Oaviyrayoni↓, (M, as from Lḥ,) or Oavara↓ ciI Oaviyrayoni↓, (Ḳ,) and Uivora↓ ciI Oaviyrayoni↓ and UivorapF↓ m-aA: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ:) or, as some say, AlOaviyru↓signifies the daybreak, or down; and cuw OaviyrK↓, the time thereof. (M, TA.) Fr says that AibodaOo bihcaA MvirFA m-aA, and Mvira ciI OaviyrK↓, and Oaviyra ciI OaviyrK↓, signify Begin thou with this first of every thing. (TA.) One says also, AifoEalohu MvirFA m-aA, (T, M, TA,) and UivorFA↓ m-aA, (M, TA,) meaning Do thou it [at least], if thou do nothing else: (T, M, TA:) or, as some say, do thou it in preference to another thing, or to other things: mA being redundant, but [in this case] not to be omitted, because [it is a corroborative, and] the meaning of the phrase is, do thou it by choice, or preference, and with care. (M, TA.) Mbr says that the phrase xuco hcaA MvirFA m-aA means Take thou this in preference; i. e., I give it thee in preference; as though one desired to take, of another, one thing, and had another thing offered to him for sale: and mA is here redundant. (T, TA.)
taOovuwrN: see MuvorapN.
tuWovuwrN: see MvorapN, in two places: and see miYovarapN, in two places.

maOvurapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and maOovarapN(Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OuvorapN↓(M, Ḳ) A generous quality or action; (AZ, Ṣ;) so called because related, or handed down, by generation from generation: (Ṣ:) or a generous quality that is inherited by generation from generation: (M, Ḳ:) a generous quality, or action, related, or handed down by tradition from one's ancestors: (A:) a cause of glorying: (AZ:) and precedence in OuvorapN [or grounds of pretension to respect,, &c.]: pl. of the first and second, Hasab. (AZ, T.)

miYovarapN and tuWovuwrN↓ An iron instrument (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with which the bottom of a camel's foot is marked, in order that his footprints upon the ground may be known: (M:) or, with which the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot is scraped, in order that his footprints may be traced: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or tWvwr↓has a different meaning, explained above, voce OuvorapN. (M.) The miyvarap of a horse's saddle is without hemz. (Ṣ.)

maOovuwrN A camel having a mark made upon the bottom of his foot with the iron instrument called miYovarap, in order that his footprints upon the ground may be known: (T:) or having the inner [i. e. under] part of his foot scraped with that instrument, in order that his footprints may be traced. (Ṣ.)

A sword having in its maton [or broad side; or the middle of the broad side, of the blade,] diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, or lustre or glitter: (M, Ḳ: [in some copies of the latter of which, instead of OavorN, I find OavarN:]) or having its mtn of female, or soft, iron, and its edge of male iron, or steel: (Ḳ:) or that is said to be of the fabric of the jinn, or genii; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ*) and not from AlOavor, as signifying Alfirinod: (Ṣ, M:) so says Aṣ: (Ṣ:) [ISd says,] mOvwr is in my opinion a pass. part. n. that has no verb: (M:) or it signifies an ancient sword, which has passed by inheritance from great man to great man. (A.)
A tradition, narrative, or story, handed down from one to another, from generation to generation. (T, Ṣ, A.)

hom.sense: 1. Oavafa Alqidora: see 2.
Oavafahu, aor. _i {yaOovifu}, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OavofN, (T, M,) He followed him. (Ks, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
He drove away, or drove away and pursued closely, or hunted, him; syn. Taradahu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
He sought, or sought after, or pursued after, him, or it: in which sense the aor. is Av-f AlqidNra, (AA, Ḳ) and taOoviyfN also. (So in some copies of the Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Av-f Alqidora, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoviyfN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He put the cooking-pot upon the OavaAfiI [pl. of Ouvofiy-apN, q. v.]; (T,* Ṣ, M,* Ḳ;) as also OavafahaA↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. OavofN; (TA;) or MvafahaA↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ in art. vfI,) inf. n. UiyvaAfN; (TA in that art.;) the first of which is a dial. var. of vaf-aAhaA, inf. n. tavofiyapN; (Ṣ;) and OavofaAhaA↓, whence qidorN muWavofaApN. (M.)
4: see 2.

hom.sense: 5. taOav-fati Alqidoru The cooking-pot was put upon the OavaAfiI. (TA.)
taOav-afuwhu They surrounded him, or it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) they became around him, or it, like the Ouvofiy-ap [or rather like the OavaAfiI]: (M:) they collected themselves together around him, or it. (A, TA.)
tOv-f AlmakaAna, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or biAlmakaAni, (M,) He (a man, Ṣ) kept to the place; (T, Ḳ;) remained in it; (M;) did not quit it. (AZ, T, Ṣ, M.)

tOv-fhu also signifies He followed after him, and pressed or importuned him, and ceased not to incite him. (T, Ḳ.) In my opinion, [says Az,] this is not in any way derived from AlOuvofiy-apu; but from Oavafotu Alr-ajula, meaning “I followed the man.” (T.)
And tOv-fwA EalaI AlOamori They aided, or assisted, one another to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair. (M, L.)

entry.sense: Q. Q. 1. OavofaI Alqidora: see 2. [But accord. to Az, in the T, yuWavofiI, as aor. of OavofaI, is yuvofiI reduced to its original form; and the like is said in the Ṣ and M in art. vfI. If this be the case, muWavofaApN, q. v., may be muvofaApN reduced in the same manner, i. e., to its original form.]
OavifN [probably a mistake for MvifN↓] Continuing, permanent, constant, firm, or established: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the Moḥeeṭ. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or MvifN↓, [agreeably with analogy, and therefore more probably the correct form,] (so in other copies of the Ṣ and in the T,) Following. (Ks, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Ouvofiy-apN and Uivofiy-apN [the former of which is the more common, and this only I find in copies of the T,] The stone [which is one of the three] whereon the cooking-pot is placed: (AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ:) it is, with the Arabs, a stone like the head of a man: (T:) the pl. is OavaAfiy-u and OavaAfK; (T, Ṣ, [in which latter it is written differently in different copies, with the article prefixed, AlOavaAfiy-u and AlOavaAfiI, but in both manners in art. vfI,] M, Ḳ;) the latter being allowable; (T,) or, accord. to Akh, the latter only is used by the Arabs; (M;) applied to the three stones mentioned above: (TA in art. sfE;, &c.:) upon these the cooking-pot is set up; but what is of iron, having three legs, is not called Avfy-p, but minoSabN; (T;) [and this is what is meant by Oavofiy-apN mino HadiydK in art. sfE in the Ḳ;] i. e. an iron trivet upon which a cooking-pot is set up. (TA in art. nSb.) Ouvofy-apN may be of the measure fuEoluwyapN [from Avf], and it may be of the measure OufoEuwlapN [from vfI; in either case originally OuvofuwyapN]. (A, L.) vaAlivapu AlOavaAfiI signifies The part, not detached, of a mountain; by the side of which, two pieces are put [for the cookingpot to be set thereon]. (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ.) And hence the saying, (AʼObeyd, T,) ramaAhu Qll-ehu bvaAlivapi AlOavaAfiI (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ) May God smite him with the mountain; meaning, with a calamity; (Th, TA, Ḳ in art. vfI;) with a calamity like the mountain [in greatness]; (Th, M;) for when they do not find the third of the AvAfI, they rest the cooking-pot [partly] upon the mountain: (M, Ḳ, in art. vfI:) or, with difficulties, or troubles, or calamities: (Aṣ, T:) or, with all evil; evils being likened to one Avfy-p after another, and the third being the last: (T, Ḳ:) so says Aboo-Saʼeed: (T:) or, with the last of evil; and the last of everything hateful: (AO in Ḥar p. 84:) or, with a great calamity. (Ḥar ib.) One says also, AlOavaAfiI fulaAnN vaAlivapu, meaning ‡ Such a one is the heaviest, most burdensome, or most troublesome, of the people. (Ḥar ubi suprà.)

[Hence also,] AlOavaAfiI is a name applied to † certain stars [accord. to Ideler, as mentioned by Freytag in his Lex., the stars σ and τ and υ Draconis] over against the head of the qidor; which is the name of certain stars disposed in a round form. (AḤát, Ḳ.) [Also] a name given by the vulgar to † [The three chief stars in the constellation called] AlX-aloyaAqu [i. e. Lyra]. (Ḳzw.)

The sing., (Ḳ,) i. e. each of the two forms thereof, but written in the copies of the Ṣ with damm [only], (TA in art. vfI,) or [only] the latter, with kesr, (M, and so in the Ḳ in art. vfI,) also signifies † A number, (M,) or a great number, (Ḳ, and so in the Ṣ in art. vfI,) and a company, or congregated body, of men: (M, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (M.) You say, humo Ealayohi Ouvofiy-apN waAHidapN† [They are against him one band]. (TA.) And baqiyato mino baniI fulaAnK Ouvofiy-apN xaXonaMCu There remained of the sons of such a one a great number. (Ṣ in art. vfI.)
MvifN: see OavifN, in two places.
muWav-afN † Short, broad, plump, and fleshy. (Ḳ.)

And, with p {muWav-afapN}, ‡ A woman whose husband has two wives beside her; she being the third of them: they being likened to the OavaAfiI of the cookingpot. (M.) [See also muvaf-aApN, in art. vfI.]

qidorN muWavofaApN A cooking-pot put upon the OavaAfiI
[pl. of Ouvofiy-apN, q. v.]. (M, and Ḳ in art. vfI: in some copies of the latter, mWovafaApN.) [See Q. Q. 1.]

UivokaAlN and OuvokuwlN i. q. XimoraAxN [A fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree, upon which are the dates]; like EivokaAlN and EuvokuwlN: the hemzeh in each is a substitute for E; but by J [and others] it is held to be augmentative, and the words are mentioned in art. Xkl, q. v. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Oavala, aor. _i {yaOovilu}, inf. n. OuvuwlN, It (anything, M) had, or came to have, root, or a foundation; or it was, or became, firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; as also tOv-l↓. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, inf. n. as above, It (dominion) was, or became, great; (TA;) and so ↓the latter verb. (M, Ḳ.*)
And Oavula, inf. n. OavaAlapN, said of high rank, or nobility, It was, or became, old, of ancient origin, or of long standing. (TA.)
See also 5.

2. Ov-lhu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoviylN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made it (his wealth, or property, M, Ḳ, and so applied it is tropical, TA) to have root, or a foundation; or to become firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; syn. OaS-alahu (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.)

He (God, T, M,* TA) made it (a man's dominion, T, M, Ḳ) to be, or become, firm, firmly established, stable, or permanent: (T:) or great: (M, Ḳ:) and he (a man) made it (a thing) lasting, or permanent. (TA.) IAạr the following verse,
tuWav-ilu kaEobN EalaI-a AlqaDaA
farab-iI yugay-iru OaEomaAlahaA [app. meaning Kaab would oblige me to make payment, or the like, (as though establishing against me the duty of doing so,) but my Lord changes their actions,] explaining it by saying, i. e. tulozimuniI; but (ISd says,) I know not how this is. (M.)
He (God, M) made it (a man's wealth, or property,) to increase; or put it into a good, or right, state, or condition; syn. zak-aApa. (M, Ḳ.)
Oat-alotuhu birijiAlK I multiplied him [meaning his party] by men. (TA.)
Oav-alotu Ealayohi Ald-uyuwna I collected against him the debts. (TA.)
Ov-l Oaholahu He clad his family with the most excel-lent of clothing: (M:) or he clad them (M, Ḳ) with the most excellent of clothing, (Ḳ,) and did good to them, or acted well towards them. (M, Ḳ.)
Ov-l, [used intransitively,] (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man, Ḳ) became abundant in his wealth, or property. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tOv-l: see 1, in two places.
Also It (a thing) became collected together. (Ḳ.)
He took for himself, got, or acquired, what is termed Oavolap, i. e. miyrp [meaning victuals, or provision]; (M, Ḳ;) baEoda HaAjapK [after want]. (M.)
He took for himself, got, or acquired, a source, stock, or fund, (OaSolK,) of wealth, or property. (Ṣ, TA.)

And tOv-l maAlFA He collected, or gained, or acquired, wealth, or property, (M, Ḳ,) and took it for himself: (M:) [said in the TA to be tropical:] or he collected wealth, or property, and took it for himself, or got it, or acquired it, as a source, stock, or fund: (Mgh:) and Oavala↓ maAlAF, inf. n. OuvuwlN, signifies the same as tOv-lhu. (TA.)
hump yataOav-aluwna Aln-aAsa They take OuvaAl, i. e. wealth, or property, from men. (TA.)
tOv-l biYorAF He dug a well (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) for himself. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: OavolN A kind of trees; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a species of the TarofaMC [or tamarisk; so applied in the present day; termed by Forskål (Flora Aeg. Arab. p. lxiv.) tamarix orientalis]; (Ṣ, TA;) or a kind of trees, (T, M,) or a certain tree, (Mgh,) resembling the TrfMC, (T, M, Mgh,) except that it is of a better kind, (T,) or except that it is larger, and better in its wood, (M,) of which are made yellow and excellent [vessels of the kind called] OaqodaAH, and of which was made the Prophet's pulpit; it has thick stems, of which are made doors and other things; and its leaves are of the kind called Eabal, like those of the TrfMC: (TA:) AḤn says, on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád, that it is of the kind termed EiDaAh, tail, and long in its wood, which is excellent, and is carried to the towns and villages, and the clay houses of these are built upon it; [app. meaning that its wood is used in forming the foundations of the walls;] its leaves are of the kind called hadab, [syn. with Eabal,] long and slender, and it has no thorns; of it are made [bowls of the kinds called] qiSaAE and jifaAn; and it has a red fruit, like a knot of a rope: (M:) or a kind of large trees, having no fruit: (Mṣb:) or i. q. TrfMC, having no fruit: (Bḍ in xxxiv. 15:) n. un. with p {OavolapN}; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) explained in the A as the samurap [or gum-acacia tree]: or a tall, straight [tree such as is termed] EiDaAhap, of which are made the like of OaqodaAH: (TA:) the pl. [of OavolN] is OuvuwlN (M, Ḳ) and [of OavolapN] OavalaAvN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA [in the CK AavolAtN].)
[See also OavolapN, below.]
fulaAnN Oavolu maAlK Such a one is a collector of wealth, or property. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

entry.sense: OavolapN n. un. of OavolN, q. v. (Ṣ, M, &c.) Because of the tallness of the tree thus called, and its erectness, and beauty of proportion, the poets liken thereto a woman of perfect stature and erect form. (M.)

Metaphorically, (Mṣb,) ‡ Honour, or reputation; or grounds of pretension to respect on account of the honourable deeds or qualities of one's ancestors,, &c.; syn. EiroDN; (Mṣb, TA;) or HasabN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) So in the saying, fulaAnN yanoHitu OavolatanaA, or yanoHatu, (Ṣ accord. to different copies, and so in the O, but in the copies of the Ḳ, incorrectly, yanoHatu fiI OavolatinaA, TA,) ‡ Such a one speaks evil of, (Ṣ, O,) or impugns, or speaks against, (Ḳ,) our honour, or reputation,, &c. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And naHata Oavolatahu ‡ He detracted from his reputation; spoke against him; impugned his character; censured him; blamed him. (A, Mṣb.) And fulaAnN tunoHatu OavalaAtuhu ‡ [Such a one's grounds of pretension to respect,, &c., are impugned]. (TA.) And huwa laA tunoHatu Oavolatuhu ‡ He has not any vice, or fault, nor any imperfection, or defect. (Mṣb.)

The root, foundation, origin, source, stock, or the like, syn. OSolN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) of a thing, and of a man; (T;) of anything; (M;) [a source, stock, or fund,] of wealth, or property: (Mgh, TA:) pl. UivaAlN. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, lahu Oavlapu maAlK [He has a source, or stock, or fund, of wealth, or property]. (TA.)
Victuals, or provision; syn. miyrapN (M, Ḳ.)
The goods, furniture, and utensils, of a house or tent; as also OavalapN↓. (M, Ḳ.*)
Apparatus, accoutrements, implements, or the like. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) So in the saying, Oaxacotu Oavolapa AlX-itaMCi [I took the apparatus,, &c., of, i. e. for, the winter]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
OavalapN: see OavolapN, near the end.

OavaAlN, (T, Ṣ, M,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) or OuvaAlN, with damm, (Mgh,) or both, (Ḳ,) ‡ Glory, honour, dignity, nobility, or high rank. (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, lahu OuvaAlN kaOan-ahu OuvaAlN ‡ He has glory, or honour,, &c., as though it were the mountain called Othál. (TA.) [But the next signification seems to be here more appropriate.]
‡ Wealth, or property. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: OaviylN A place of growth of trees of the kind called OaraAk [perhaps a mistranscription for Oavol]: mentioned by Th, from IAạr. (T.)
Abundant, and luxuriant, or long, hair. (TA.)
See also maWav-alN in two places.

entry.sense: MvilN: see muWav-alN.

muWav-alN Having root, or a foundation; or firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded: (Ṣ:) or having a permanent source, or firm foundation: (Munjid of Kr:) or of old foundation or origin: or collected together so as to [become stable or permanent, or] have root or a foundation: (T:) or old; of ancient origin; or of long standing: (M, TA:) or permanent: (IAạr:) ‡ applied to glory, honour, dignity, nobility, or high rank; (T, Kr, Ṣ, M, TA;) and so OaviylN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) and to wealth, or property: (Kr, Ṣ:) and to anything; (T, M;) and so OaviylN↓, and mutaOav-ilN↓: (M:) and MvilN↓, also, has the first of these significations, applied to dominion. (T.)
Prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a right or good state. (AA.)
mutaOav-ilN: see muWavalN.

Also Taking for oneself, getting, or acquiring, a source, stock, or fund, (OaSol,) of wealth, or property: (Ṣ, TA:) or collecting wealth, or property, (T, Mgh,) and taking it for oneself, or getting it, or acquiring it, as a source, stock, or fund. (Mgh.) So in a trad. on the subject of a charge respecting the orphan, yaOokulu mino maAlihi gayora mutaOav-ilK maAlFA [He may eat of his wealth, or property, not taking for himself a source, stock, or fund, of wealth, or property: or, not collecting, &c.]: (T, Ṣ, Mgh:*) or, accord. to Bkh, not acquiring abundance of wealth: but the former explanation is more correct lexically. (Mgh.)

hom.sense:
1. Oavima, (Lth, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _a {yaOovamu}, (Lth, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UivomN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or OavamN, the former being a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and maOovamN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,)
He fell into what is termed UivomN [i. e. a sin, or crime,, &c.]; (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ *;) [he sinned; committed a sin, or crime;] he did what was unlawful: (M,* Ḳ:) and taOoviymN↓ signifies the same as UivomN: (Ḳ:) it may be either an inf. n. of Oavama↓, which [says ISd] I have not heard, or, as Sb holds it to be, a simple subst. like tanobiytN: (M:) and is said to be used in the sense of Uivom in the Ḳur lii. 23 [and lvi. 24]. (TA.) [It should be added also, that tOovaAmN↓, like takocaAbN, is syn. with tOoviymN and UivomN; and, like tOvym, may be an inf. n. of Oav-ama↓, or a simple subst.: see an ex. voce baruwqN.] In the dial. of some of the Arabs, the first letter of the aor. is with kesr, as in tiEolamu and niEolamu; and as the hemzeh in UivomN is with kesr, the radical hemzeh [in the aor.] is changed into I; so that they say Uiyvamu and tiyvamu [for Mvamu and taOovamu.] (TA.) In the saying,
lawo qulota maA fiI qawomahaA lamo tiyvami
yafoDulahaA fiI HasabK wamiysami
the meaning is, [Shouldst thou say, thou wouldst not sin, or do wrong, in so saying,] There is not, among her people, any one who excels her [in grounds of pretension to respect, and in impress, or character, of beauty]. (M.)

Oavamahu Qll-ehu fiI kacaA, aor. _u {yaOovumu} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _i {yaOovimu}, (Ṣ,) or _a, (Ḳ,) but there is no other authority than the Ḳ for this last, nor is there any reason for it, as the medial radical letter is not faucial, nor is the final, and in the Iktitáf el-Azáhir the aor. is said to be _i and _u, (MF, TA,) [God reckoned him to have sinned, or committed a crime or the like, in such a thing; or] God reckoned such a thing against him as an Uivom: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or Oavamahu, aor. _i {yaOovimu} (Fr, T, M, Mṣb) and _u {yaOovumu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. OavomN (Fr, T, Mṣb) and OavaAmN (Fr, T, TA) and UivaAmN, (Fr, TA,) He (God) requited him, (Fr, T,) or punished him, (M,) for what is termed UivomN [i. e. sin, or crime,, &c.]: (Fr, T, M:) [see also OavaAmN below:] or he (a man) pronounced him to be Mvm [i. e. a sinner, or the like]: (Mṣb:) [or] Mvamahu↓, aor. yaWovimuhu, has this last signification, said of God; and also signifies He found him to be so. (T.)
You say also, Oavamati Aln-aAqapu AlmaXoIa, aor. _i {yaOovimu}, inf. n. OavomN, The she-camel was slow. (M.)
2. Ov-mhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoviymN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He said to him Oavimota [Thou hast fallen into a sin, or crime,, &c.; hast sinned,, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also 1, first and second sentences.

entry.sense: 4. Mvmhu He made him, or caused him, to fall into what is termed UivomN [i. e. a sin, or crime,, &c.], (Zj, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or what is termed canobN. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

5. tOv-m He abstained from what is termed UivomN [i. e. sin, or crime,, &c.]; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like taHar-aja meaning “he preserved himself from what is termed HarajN:” (Mṣb:) or he did a work, or deed, whereby he escaped from what is termed UivomN: (TA:) and he repented of what is so termed, (M, Ḳ,) and begged forgiveness of it; as though he removed the Uivom itself by repentance and by begging forgiveness; or sought to do so by those two means. (M.) You say also, tOv-m mino kacaA He abstained from such a thing as a sin, or crime; syn. taH-anava, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. Hnv.)

UivomN [accord. to some, an inf. n.; see Oavima: accord. to others, only a simple subst., signifying] A sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, syn. canobN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for which one deserves punishment; differing from canobN inasmuch as this signifies both what is intentional and what is unintentional: (Kull:) or [so accord. to the M, but in the Ḳ “and,”] an unlawful deed: (M, Ḳ:) or a deed which retards from recompense: or, accord. to Fr, what is exclusive of the [punishment termed] Had-: accord. to Er-Rághib, it is a term of more general import than EudawAnN: (TA:) maOovamN↓ [which is originally an inf. n. of Oavima] is syn. with UivomN; (T,* Mgh;) and so, too, is OavaAmN↓, (Mṣb,) or UivaAmN↓, signifying a deed retarding recompense: (TA:) the pl. of UivomN is MvaAmN: (M:) and the pl. of maOovamN↓ is maMvimu. (T.)
[Sometimes it is prefixed to a noun or pronoun denoting its object:]
[and sometimes it means † The punishment of a sin, &c.: see explanations of a passage in the Ḳur v. 32, voce baMCa.]
Wine: (Aboo-Bekr El-Iyádee, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) sometimes used in this sense; (Ṣ;) but tropically; not properly: (IAmb:) I think, [says ISd,] because the drinking thereof is what is thus termed. (M.)

[And for a like reason,] † Contention for stakes, or wagers, in a game of hazard; syn. qimaArN; (M, Ḳ;) which is a man's destruction of his property. (M.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 216, respecting wine and the game called Almayosir], qulo fihiymaA UivomN kabiyrN wamanaAfiEu liln-aAsi [Say thou, In them both are great sin and means of profit to men]: and Th says, when they contended in a game of this kind, and won, they gave food and alms, and these were means of profit. (M.)
OavaAmN: see UivomN.

Also The requital, or recompense, of Uiv-m [i. e. sin, or crime,, &c.]: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) so says Zj, (T, M,) and in like manner say Kh and Sb: (T:) or punishment (Yoo, Lth, T, M, Ḳ) thereof: (Lth, T, M:) and UivaAmN↓ and maOovamN↓ signify the same; (M, Ḳ;) the latter like maqoEadN. (TA. [In the CK this is written maOvim.]) So in the Ḳur [xxv. 68], yaloqa OavaAmaA [He shall find a requital, or recompense, or a punishment, of sin]: (T, Ṣ, M:) in my opinion, [says ISd,] the correct meaning is, he shall find the punishment of MvaAm [or sins]: but some say, the meaning is that which here follows. (M.)
A valley in Hell. (M, Ḳ.)
UivaAmN: see UivomN:
and OavaAmN.

hom.sense: OaviymN: see MvimN.
Also The commission of Uivom [sin, or crime,, &c.,] much, or frequently; and so OaviymapN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OaviymapN: see OaviymN.
OavaAmN: see MvimN.

MvimN Falling into what is termed UivmN [i. e. a sin, or crime,, &c.]; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;*) [sinning; committing a sin, or crime;] doing what is unlawful: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but having an intensive signification, (Mṣb,) OaviymN↓, and OavuwmN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Oav-aAmN↓: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ: [in the CK, erroneously, without teshdeed:]) the pl. of the first of these three is OuvamaMCu; that of the second, OuvumN; and that of the third, Oav-aAmuwna. (M.) See also OaviymN.

MvimapN, (Ṣ,) and MvimaAtN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, AavimAtN.]) A she-camel, (Ṣ,) and she-camels, slow, or tardy; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) weary, fatigued, or jaded. (Ḳ. [In the CK, we find muEiyobAtN erroneously put for muEoyiyaAtN.]) Some pronounce it with t. (Ṣgh.) [In like manner,] muWaAvimN↓ signifies That is slack, or slow, in pace, or going; Aal-aciI yakocibu fiI Als-ayori. (Ṣgh, Ḳ. [In Golius's Lex., as from the Ḳ, Aal-aciI yukac-ibu Als-ayora. Both are correct, signifying the same.])
taOovaAmN: see 1.
taOoviymN: see 1.
maOovamN: see UivomN, in two places:
and see OavaAmN.
maOovuwmN [Reckoned to have sinned, or the like;] having a thing reckoned against him as an Uivom: (Ṣ:) or requited for what is termed UivomN. (Fr, T.)
muWaAvimN: see MvimN.
AivonaAni and AivonataAni: see art. vnI.

hom.sense: 1. Oaj-ati Aln-aAru, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yaOojuju} (Ṣ, Mṣb) and _i {yaOojiju}, (M, TA,) [the former contr. to analogy, and the latter agreeable therewith, in the case of an intrans. verb of this class,] inf. n. OajiyHN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly, or fiercely, (Mṣb,) blazed, or flamed, or blazed or flamed fiercely; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tOj-jt↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and AYtj-t↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaj-at]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or made a sound by its blazing or flaming. (ISd, TA.)

Oaj-a,, aor. _u {yaOojuju}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) and _i, (Jm, TṢ, L, Ḳ,) but this is rejected by AA, (MF,) inf. n. Oaj-N (Ṣ) and OajiyHN, (TA,) ‡ He (an ostrich) ran, making a [rustling] sound, or noise, such as is termed HafiyfN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.) And, aor. _u {yaOojuju}, (T, A,) inf. n. Oaj-N, (T, TA,) † He hastened, or was quick, in his pace; walked quickly; or went a pace between a walk and a run; (T, Nh;) said of a man; (Nh, from a trad.;) and of a camel: (IB:) or ‡ he made a sound, or noise, in his pace or going, like that of the blazing, or flaming, of fire. (A.) You say, Oaj-a Oaj-apa AlZ-aliymi
‡ [He made a rustling sound in going along, like that of the ostrich]. (A.) And Oaj-a, aor. _i {yaOojiju}, [so in the TA,] inf. n. OajiyHN, † It (a camel's saddle) made a sound or noise [produced by his running]. (AZ, TA.) And OajiyHN signifies also † The sounding of water in pouring forth. (TA.)
Oaj-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaOojuju}, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. OujuwHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (water) was, or became, such as is termed OujaAH. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Oaj-ahu He rendered it (namely water) such as is termed OujaAj. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Oj-j Aln-aAra, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOojiyHN, (Ḳ,) He made the fire to [burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, (see 1,)] blaze, or flame, or blaze or flame fiercely. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] Oj-j bayonahumo Xar-aA † He kindled evil, or mischief, among them. (TA.)
5: see 1.
Hence tOj-j also signifies It gave light; shone; or shone brightly. (TA, from a trad.)
See also 8, where a contracted form of this verb is mentioned.
8: see 1.
[Hence,] AYtj- Aln-ahaAru [written with the disjunctive alif Aiyotaj-a] The day was, or became, intensely hot, or fiercely burning; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also taOaj-a↓ and tOj-j. (Ḳ.)

Oaj-apN Intenseness of heat, and its fierce burning; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OajiyHN↓ [inf. n. of 1], and OajaAjN↓, and QYostijaAjN↓ [inf. N. of 8]: pl. UijaAjN. (Ṣ.) You say, jaMto Oaj-apN AlS-ayofi The intense heat, or fierce burning, of summer came. (TA.)
The sound of fire; as also OajiyHN↓. (ISd, TA.)
‡ The sound, or noise, and commotion, of an ostrich running, and of people walking or passing along. (A.) You say, Oaj-a Oaj-apa AlZaliymi [explained above: see 1]. (A.)

† Confusion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as also OajiyHN↓, the confusion arising from the talking of a people, and the sound, or noise, of their walking or passing along. (L.) You say, Alqawomu fiI Oaj-apK The people are in a state of confusion [&c.]. (Ṣ.)
OajaAjN: see Oaj-apN.

OujaAjN Anything burning to the mouth, whether salt or bitter or hot. (MF.) [Hence,] maMCN OujaAjN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) and UijaAjN↓, (Mṣb,) Water that burns by its saltness: (A:) or salt water: or bitter water: (TA:) or salt, bitter water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or very salt water: (I’Ab:) or bitter and very salt water: (Mṣb:) or very salt water, that burns by reason of its saltness: or very bitter water: or water very salt and bitter, like the water of the sea: (TA:) or water of which no use is made for drinking, or for watering seed-produce, or for other purposes: (El-Ḥasan:) or very hot water: (TA:) the pl. is the same [as the sing.; or OujaAjN is also used as a quasi-pl. n.]. (TA.)
UijaAjN: see OujaAjN.
OajuwjN Giving light; shining; or shining brightly. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OajiyjN inf. n. of 1, which see: and see also Oaj-apN, in three places.
hajiyrN Oaj-aAjN [A vehemently hot, or fiercelyburning, summer-midday]. (A.)
Mjuwju: see yaOojuwju, below.
Als-amaAYimu AlOawaAjiju [The fiercely-burning hot winds; the latter word being pl. of Mj-apN↓, fem. of Mj-N↓, which is the act. part. n. of Oaj-a;] is used by poetic licence for AlOawaAj-u. (TA.)
QYotijaAjN inf. N. of 8, which see {8}: and see also OajapN.
maOojuwju: see what follows.
yaOojuwjN One who walks quickly, and runs, in this and that manner. (Ḳ,* TA.)

yaOojuwju and maOojuwju↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) imperfectly decl., (Ṣ,) [Gog and Magog;] two tribes of God's creatures; (TA;) or two great nations; (Mṣb;) or two tribes of the children of Japheth the son of Noah: or, as some say, the former, of the Turks; and the latter, of the Jeel [meaning Jeel-Jeelán, said in the TA in art. jyl, on the authority of ISd, to be a people beyond the Deylem; and on the authority of Az, to be believers in a plurality of gods; (the Geli and Gelœ of Ptolemy and Strabo, as observed by Sale, in a note on ch. xviii. v. 93 of the Ḳur, on the authority of Golius in Alfrag. p. 207;)]: (Bḍ in xviii. 93:) [said by the Arabs to be Scythians of the furthest East; particularly those on the north of the Chinese: (Golius:) or, as some say, the descendants of Japheth, and all the nations inhabiting the north of Asia and of Europe: (Freytag:)] said in a rad., (TA,) on the authority of I’Ab, (Mṣb,) to compose nine tenths of mankind: (Mṣb, TA:) or yOjwj is the name of the males, and mOjwj is that of the females: (Mṣb:) he who pronounces them thus, and makes the O a radical letter, says that the former is of the measure yafoEuwlu, and the latter of the measure mafoEuwlu; as though from Oajayju Aln-aAri; (Akh, Ṣ, Mṣb;*) or from maMCN OujaAjN; (TA;) or from Oaj-a said of an ostrich; and imperfectly decl. as being determinate and fem.: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) he who pronounces them without C, making the A in each an augmentative letter, says that the former is from yajajotu, and the latter from majajotu: (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) this is the case if they be Arabic: (TA:) but some say that they are foreign names; (Mṣb, TA;) their being imperfectly decl. is said to indicate this; (Bḍ ubi suprà;) and if so, the A in them is similar to that in haAruwt and maAruwt and daAwuwd and the like; and the C, anomalous, as that in EaOolimN and the like; and their measure is faAEuwlu. (Mṣb.) Ru-beh used to read Mjuwju↓ and maAjuwju [in the CK mOjuwj]; and Aboo-Mo'ádh, yamojuwju. (Ḳ.)

1. Oajarahu, aor. _u {yaOojuru} and _i {yaOojiru}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter form of the aor., though known to most of the lexicologists, is disacknowledged by a few of them, (TA,) inf. n. OajorN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and Mjrhu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a form disacknowledged by Aṣ, but said by some to be the more chaste of the two, of the form OafoEala, not faAEala, as IḲṭṭ by evident inadvertence makes it to be by saying that its aor. is yuWaAjiru, (TA,) inf. n. UiyjaArN; (Ṣ;) He (God, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, and a man, Mgh) recompensed, compensated, or rewarded, him, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) EalaI maA faEala for what he had done. (A.) [See OajorN, below.] Oujira fulaAnN xamosapF mino waladihi [Such a one became entitled to a reward for five of his children, by their death, (for it is believed that the Muslim will be rewarded in Paradise for a child that has died in infancy)], (Ṣ,) and Oujira waladahu, (A,) and Oujira fiI OawolaAdihi, (Ḳ,) mean that his children died, and became [causes of] his reward. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
Oajarahu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaOojuru}, (Ṣ,) [He served him for hire, pay, or wages;] he became his hired man, or hireling. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur xxviii. 27. (TA.)

Oajarahu, aor. _u {yaOojuru}, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _i, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OajorN, (L, Ḳ,) He let him (namely his slave) on hire, or for pay, or wages; (L,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also Mjrhu↓, inf. n. UiyjaArN; (ʼEyn, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Mjrhu↓, inf. n. mWAjrp: (Ḳ:) all these are good forms of speech, used by the Arabs: (L:) or Mjrhu↓ having for its inf. n. mWAjrp signifies he appointed him (namely another man) hire, pay, or wages, for his work; (Mj, Mgh;) or he engaged with him to give him hire, pay, or wages; (A, Mgh, Mṣb;) and can have only one objective complement: whereas, ↓when it is of the measure OafoEala it is doubly trans.; (Mgh, Mṣb;) so that one says, Mjaraniy↓ mamoluwkahu He let me his slave on hire. (Mgh.) One also says, Oajara Ald-aAra, aor. _u {yaOojuru} and _i {yaOojiru}, inf. n. OajorN, He let the house on hire; and so Mjr↓ Ald-aAra, [inf. n. UiyjaArN:] (Mṣb, TA:) and Mjrhu↓ Ald-aAra, [inf. n. UiyjaArN,] He let to him the house on hire: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) the latter verb being of the measure OafoEala, not of the measure faAEala: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) and the vulgar say, waAjara: (Ṣ:) some, however, say, Mjarotu↓ Ald-aAra, inf. n. muWaAjarapN, making the verb of the measure fAEl: (Mṣb, TA:) some also say, Mjarotu↓ Ald-aAra zayod-aA [I let the house to Zeyd], inverting the order of the words: (Mṣb, TA:) and the lawyers say, Mjarotu↓ Ald-aAra mino zayodK [in the same sense, like as biEotu mino zayodK Ald-aAri means the same as biEotu zayodAF Ald-aAra]. (Mṣb: [but in the Mgh, the like of this is said to be vulgar.])

3. Mjr, inf. n. muWaAjarapN: see 1, latter half, in three places: and see 1. One says also, of a woman, (Ḳ,) or a whorish female slave, (TA,) Mjarato, [of the measure faAEalato, not OafoEalato, (see muWojirN, below,)] meaning She prostituted herself for hire. (Ḳ.)
4. Mjr, inf. n. UiyjaArN: see 1, first sentence:
and see the latter half of the same paragraph {1}, in seven places.

8. AYtjr [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytajara] He gave alms, seeking thereby to obtain a reward [from God]: (L, Ḳ *:)
and AYtjrbihi He gave it as alms, seeking thereby a reward. (L.) Qt-ajara for AYtjr is not allowable, because C cannot be incorporated into t: [or, accord. to some, this is allowable, as in Qt-azara for AYtzr, and Qt-amana for AYtmn, &c.:] Hr allows it; and cites an ex. in a trad.; but IAth says that the proper reading in this instance is yaOotajiru, not yat-ajiru; or, if the latter be allowed, it is from Alt-ijaArapu, not from AlOajoru. (L.)

Auwtujira Ealayohi bikacaA [in which the radical C is changed into w because the alif preceding it is made disjunctive and with damm, (in one copy of the Ṣ, and in the L and TA, erroneously written Aiyotajara,) He was hired to do it for such a sum or thing, (see muWotajarN, below,)] is from AlOujorapu. (Ṣ, L.)

10. AstOjrhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Mjrhu↓, (Ḳ,) [the latter of the measure faAEala, as has been clearly shown above, from the A and Mgh and Mṣb,] He hired him; took him as a hired man, or hireling. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say also, AstOjr Ald-aAra [He hired the house; took it on hire]. (A, Mgh,)

OajorN A recompense, compensation, or reward, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) for what one has done; (Ḳ;) i. q. vawaAbN; (Ṣ;) as also UijaArapN↓ and OajaArapN↓ and OujaArapN↓, (Ḳ,) of which three forms the first is the most generally known and the most chaste, (TA,) and OujorapN↓: (TA:) or, as some say, there is a distinction between OajorN and vawaAbN: El-ʼEynee says, in the Expos. of El-Bukháree, that what is obtained by the fundamental practices of the law, and by obligatory religious services, is termed vwAb; and what is obtained by supererogatory acts of religion, Ajr; for vwAb is properly a substitute for a thing itself; and Ajr, for the profit arising from a thing; though each is sometimes used in the sense of the other: (TA:) it is well known that Ajr signifies a recompense, or reward, from God to a man, for righteous conduct; (MF;) and UijaArapN↓, recompense, compensation, hire, pay, or wages, from one man to another, for work; (Mgh, MF;) and hence AlOajiyru; (MF;) and OujorapN↓ also has this latter signification, (Mgh, TA,) and is syn. with kiraMCN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) [signifying likewise rent for a house, and the like;] but OajorN is used [sometimes] in the sense of UijaArapN and in that of OujorapN: (Mṣb:) the pl. of OajorN is OujuwrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and MjaArN; (Ḳ;) but the latter form was unknown to MF: (TA:) the pl. of OujorapN↓ is OajarN and OujuraAtN and OujaraAtN. (Mṣb.) [One says, Oajoruka EalaI Qll-ehi Thy recompense is due from God. And, to console a person for the death of a relation or friend, EaZ-ama Qll-ehu Oajoraka fiyhi May God largely compensate thee for him! i. e., for the loss of him.] By the expression OajorK kiriymK in the Ḳur xxxvi. 10 is said to be meant Paradise. (TA.)
‡ A dowry, or nuptial gift; a gift that is given to, or for, a bride: (Ḳ:) pl. OujuwrN: so in the Ḳur xxxiii. 49 [&c.]. (TA.)
† Praise; good fame. (Ḳ.) So, as some say, in the Ḳur xxix. 26. (TA.)
OajurN and OujurN: see Mjur-N.
OujorapN: see OajorN, in three places.
Uijoriy-aA and Uijoriy-aMCu: see Uij-iyraI.
OajuwrN: see Mjur-N.

OajiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) A hired man; a hireling: (L:) or of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEalN, i. e. a man with whom one has engaged to give him hire, pay, or wages: (Mgh, Mṣb:*) pl. OujaraMCu. (L, Mṣb.)
UijaArapN and OajaArapN and OujaArapN: see OajorN, in four places.
UijaArapN also signifies The giving of usufructs for a compensation. (Mgh.)
And Land which its owners have let to him who will build upon it: so explained by the lawyers. (Mgh.)

Uij-aArN (Ṣ, M, IAth, Mgh, Ḳ) and Uij-aArapN↓ (M) and UinojaArN↓ (Mgh, Ḳ) The flat top, or roof, of a house, (Ṣ, M, IAth, Mgh, Ḳ,) that has not around it anything to prevent a person's falling from it: (M,* IAth:) of the dial. of the people of Syria and of El-Ḥijáz: (Ṣ:) pl. [of the first and second] OajaAjiyru and OajaAjirapN; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [of the third] OanaA jiyru. (Mgh, Ḳ.)
Uij-aArapN: see Uij-aArN.

Uij-iyraI (ISk, Ḳ) and Uijoriy-aA↓ and Uijoriy-aMCu↓ (Ṣ in art. hjr) A custom; a habit. (ISk, Ḳ, and Ṣ ubi suprà.) The hemzeh is said to be a substitute for h [in hij-iyraI, &c.] (TA.) You say, maA zaAla celika Uij-iyraAhu That ceased not to be his custom, or habit. (ISk.)
MjarN and MjurN and MjirN, and the pls. Mjuruwna and Mjiruwna: see what next follows.

Mjur-N (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Mjur-N↓ (AA, Ks, Ḳ) and MjuwrN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OajuwrN↓ and yaAjuwrN↓ (Ḳ) and OajurN↓ (as in some copies of the Ḳ) and MjarN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) or OujurN↓, (as in other copies of the Ḳ,) and MjirN↓ [to which is erroneously added in the CK MjirapN] and [the pls.] Mjuruwna↓ and Mjiruwna↓ (Ḳ) are syn., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of Persian origin, (Ṣ,) [from MGuwro or MGuro,] arabicized, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) signifying Baked bricks; (Mṣb;) baked clay, (Mgh, L,) with which one builds: (Ṣ, L:) Mjur-N and Mjuwr-N and MjurN [&c.] are pls., [or rather coll. gen. ns., except the two forms ending with w and n,] and their sings. [or rather ns. un.] are with p, i. e. Mjur-apN, &c. (L.)
MjuwrN: see Mjur-N.
UinojaArN: see Uij-aArN.
muWojarN [A slave, or] a house, let on hire; (Akh, T, Mṣb;) as also maOojuwrN↓; (L;) and some say, muWaAjarN↓. (Akh, Mṣb.)

muWojirN One who lets on hire [a slave, or] a house: one should not say muwaAjirN↓; for this is wrong with respect to the classical language, and abominable with respect to the conventional acceptation and common usage; a foul reproach being meant thereby [as is shown by the explanation of Mjarato, given above: or, accord to some, it is allowable when it relates to a house: (see Oajarahu:) it seems to be disallowed only when used absolutely]. (A, Mgh.)
maOojuwrN: see muWojarN.
muWaAjarN: see muWojarN.
muWaAjirN: see muWojirN.

muWotajarN [part. n. of Auwtujira]. Moḥammad Ibn-Bishr El-Khárijee, not [as is said in the Ṣ] Aboo-Dahbal, says, (L,)
yaA layota Oan-iI biOavowaAbiI waraAHilatiI
EabodN liOaholika hecaA AlX-ahora muWotajaru
[O would that I were, with my clothes and my riding-camel, a hired slave to thy family, this month]: (Ṣ, L.) i. e., maEa OavowaAbiI. (Ṣ.)
yaAjuwrN: see Mjur-N.

Uij-aASN [The plum;] a certain fruit, (Ḳ, TA,) of the description termed faAkihap, (TA,) well known; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) cold and moist; or, as some say, of moderate temperature; (TA;) which facilitates the flow of the yellow bile; (Ḳ;) i. e., its juice, or water, does so, when drunk with sugar-candy (Tabarozac) and manna (taranojubiyn) added to it; (TA;) and allays thirst, and heat of the heart; (Ḳ;) but it relaxes the stomach, and does not agree with it; and it generates a watery mixture; and its injurious effect is repelled by the drinking of sugary sikanojubiyn [or oxymel]: it is of several kinds: (TA:) [the most common is the Damasc, or Damascene, plum:] the best is (Ḳ, TA) the Armenian, (TA,) that which is sweet and large: (Ḳ, TA:) the sour, or acid, is less laxative, and more cold: (TA:) the n. un. is with p {Uij-aASapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you should not say UinojaASN; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ;) or this is a word of weak authority, (Ḳ, TA,) and you say Uij-aASN and UinjaASN like as one says Uij-aArN and UinojaArN: (TA:) in the dial. of the Syrians, the Uij-aASN [or UinojaAS or UinjaAs accord. to common modern usage among them] is the [pear which they formerly called] miXomiX and [which others call] kum-avoraI: (Ḳ:) it is of the growth of the country of the Arabs: (AḤn:) Aj-AS is an adventitious word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or arabicized, (Mṣb,) because j and S do not both occur in any Arabic word: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Az, they do so occur; as, for instance, in HaS-aSa, and in Saj-N. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Oajila, aor. _a {yaOojalu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OajalN, (Mṣb,) It (a thing, Mṣb, [as, for instance, a thing purchased, and the price thereof, and a thing promised or threatened or foretold, and also payment for a thing purchased, and the fulfilment of a promise or threat or prediction, and any event,]) was, or became, delayed, postponed, kept back; [and therefore, future;] syn. taOax-ara; (Ḳ;) and Oajala, aor. _u {yaOojulu}, inf. n. OujuwlN, signifies the same. (Mṣb.) [See MjilN and OajalN. The primary signification seems to be, It had a term, or period, appointed for it, at which it should fall due, or come to pass.]

Oajalahu, aor. _i {yaOojilu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OajulN; (TA;) and Oj-lhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taOojiylN; (TA;) and Mjlhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muWaAjalapN; (TḲ;) He confined, restricted, restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the phrase, OajaluwA maAlahumo They confined, restricted,, &c., their cattle from the pasturage. (TA.)

Oajala Ealayohimo Xar-FA, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or AlX-ar-a, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaOojulu} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaOojilu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. OajolN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He committed against them evil, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and drew it, or procured it, to them: (Mṣb:) and (Ṣ, in the Ḳ “or”) he excited it, stirred it up, or provoked it, against them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to AZ, Oajalotu EalayohimN, inf. n. as above, signifies I committed a crime against them: and AA says that jalabotu Ealayohimo and jararotu and Oajalotu have one and the same signification. (TA.)

And Oajala liOaholihi, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He gained, acquired, or earned, and collected, and brought, or purveyed, and exercised skill in the management of affairs, for his family. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Oaj-ala AlOajala, (TA,) inf. n. taOojiylN, (Ḳ, TA,) He defined the term, or period; (Ḳ,* TA;) assigned, appointed, or specified, it. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [vi. 128], wabalagonaA OajalanaA Ql-aciI Oaj-alota lanaA [And we have reached our term which Thou hast assigned, or appointed, for us;] meaning, the day of resurrection; (Bḍ,* Jel;) or the term of death; or, as some say, the term of extreme old age. (TA.) And Oaj-alotuhu, inf. n. as above, signifies I assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a term, or period. (Mṣb.)

Oaj-alaniI He granted me a delay, or postponement. (TA.) You say, AisotaOojalotuhu↓ faOaj-alaniI OilaI mud-apK (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) I desired, asked, demanded, or requested, of him a term, or period, [of delay, or postponement,] and he granted me a delay, or postponement, to a certain term, or period. (TA.)
See also 1.
3. Mjlhu, inf. n. muWaAjalapN: see 1.

5. tOj-l i. q. AstOjl↓; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. He asked, or requested, that a term, or period, should be assigned, appointed, or specified, for him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mek-hool, kun-aA maraAbiTiyna biA ls-aAHili fataOaj-ala mutaOaj-ilN [We were keeping post on the frontier of the enemy, in the tract on the sea-coast, and] a person asked, or requested, that a term, or period, should be assigned, or appointed, or specified, for him, and that permission should be granted him to return to his family. (TA.)
10: see 2 and 5.

OajolN is originally the inf. n. of Oajala Xar-FA “he committed evil;” and is used to indicate the causation of crimes; and afterwards, by extension of its application, to indicate any causation: (Bḍ in v. 35:) one says, faEalotuhu mino Oajolika, and mn Uijolika↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and faEalotuhu Oajolaka, and Uijolaka↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and mn OajolaAlika, and mn UijolaAlika, (Ḳ, [belonging to art. jlw, in which also they are mentioned,]) and mn OajolAlika, and mn UijolaAlika, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA, [belonging to art. jl,]) i. e. [I did it] mino jar-aAka, (Ṣ,) which means [originally] in consequence of thy committing it: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) [and then, by extension of its application, as shown above, because of thee, or of thine act, &c.; on thine account; for thy sake; as also liOajolika, which is more common in the present day:] or mno jalalika: (Ḳ:) and mino Oajolihi kaAna kacaA, i. e. bisababihi [Because of him, or it, it was thus, or such a thing was]. (Mṣb.) An instance of its occurrence without mino [or li] is presented by the saying of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd,
Oajola Oan-a Qll-eha qado faD-alakumo
[Because that God hath made you to have excel-lence, or hath preferred you]. (TA.)
UijolN, whence faEalotuhu mino Uijolika, and faEalotuhu Uijolaka: see OajolN, in two places.

Oajalo, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) with the l quiescent, (Mughnee,) is written with kesr and with fet-ḥ [to the medial letter, i. e. Oajilo↓ as well as Oajalo] like nEm [which is written naEimN as well as naEamo]: (TA:) it is a particle (Mughnee) denoting a reply; like naEamo; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) importing acknowledgment of the truth of the speaker, to him who gives information; and the making a thing known, to him who asks information; and a promise, to him who seeks, or demands; (Mughnee;) i. e. It is as thou sayest [in the first case; and yes, or yea, in the same, and in the other cases]; (Ḳ voce basalN;) therefore it occurs after such sayings as “Zeyd stood” and “did Zeyd stand?” and “beat thou Zeyd:” but El-Málakee restricts the information to that which is affirmative, and the saying expressive of seeking or demanding to that which is without prohibition: and it is said by some that it does not occur after an interrogation: (Mughnee:) Er-Raḍee says, in the Expos. of the Káfiyeh, after Z and others, that it is to denote acknowledgment of the truth of information, and does not occur after a saying in which is the meaning of seeking, or demanding: (TA:) or, accord. to Z and Ibn-Málik and others, it relates particularly to information: and accord. to Ibn-Kharoof, it occurs mostly after information: (Mughnee:) in the Expos. of the Tes-heel, it is said to be for denoting acknowledgment of the truth of information, past or other, affirmative or negative, and not to occur after an interrogation: (TA:) Akh says that it is better than naEamo (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ *) after information, (Mughnee,) in acknowledging the truth of what is said; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) and nEm is better than it after an interrogation: (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ:) so that when one says, sawofa tacohabu [Thou wilt, or shalt, go away], thou sayest Oajalo [Yes]; and it is better than nEm: but when one says, Oatacohabu [Wilt thou go away?], thou sayest nEm; and it is better than Ajl. (Ṣ.)

OajalN The term, or period, of a thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) its assigned, appointed, or specified, term or period: this is the primary signification: (TA:) or the term, or period, and time of falling due, of a thing: (Mṣb:) pl. MjaAlN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Hence, The period of women's waiting, before they may marry again, after divorce: as in the Ḳur ii. 231 and 232. (TA.)

The period, or extremity of time, in which falls due a debt (Ḳ, TA) and the like. (TA.) You say, baAEahu Uiy-aAhu UilaI OajalK [He sold it to him for payment at an appointed period]: and sal-ama Ald-aAraAhima fiI TaEaAmK UilaI OajalK [He delivered the money for wheat, or the like, to be given at an appointed period]. (Mṣb in art. klO.)

The term, or period, of death; (Ḳ;) the time in which God has eternally decreed the end of life by slaughter or otherwise: or, as some say, the whole duration of life: and its end: a man's life being thus termed: and his death, by which it terminates: (Kull p. 17:) the assigned, or appointed, duration of the life of a man. (TA.) One says, danaA Oajaluhu, meaning His death drew near; originally, QsotiyfaMCu AlOajali the completion of the duration of life. (TA.) In the Ḳur vi. 128, (see 2, above,) the meaning is, The term of death: or, as some say, the term of extreme old age: (TA:) or the day of resurrection. (Bḍ,* Jel.) The words of the Ḳur [vi. 2] vum-a qaDaI OajalFA waOajalN masam-aI Einodahu mean [Then He decreed a term,] the term of death, and [there is a term named with Him,] the term of the resurrection: or the period between the creation and death, and the period between death and the resurrection; for Ajl is applied to the end of a space of time and to the whole thereof: (Bḍ:) or the meaning is, the period of sleep, and the period of death: (Bḍ, TA:) or the period of those who have passed away, and the period of those who remain and those who are to come: (Bḍ:) or the period of remaining in this world, and the period of remaining in the world to come: or in both instances death is meant; [accidental, and natural;] for the Ajl of some is by accidental means, as the sword, and drowning, and burning, and eating what disagrees, and other means of destruction; while some have their full periods granted to them and are preserved in health until they die a natural death: or the Ajl of some is that of him who dies in a state of happiness and enjoyment; and of others, that of him who reaches a limit beyond which God has not appointed, in the natural course of this world, any one to remain therein; and to both of these, reference is made in the Ḳur [xvi. 72 and] xxii. 5. (TA.)

Sometimes, also, it means Destruction: and thus it has been explained as occurring in the Ḳur [vii. 184], where it is said, waOano EasaI Oano yakuwna qadi Q qotaraba Oajaluhumo [And that, may be, their destruction shall have drawn near]. (TA.)
Oajilo: see OajalN.
OajilN: see MjilN.
OajiylN Having a delay, or postponement, granted to him, to a certain time; i. q. muWaj-alN↓ UilaI waqotK. (Lth.)
See also MjilN.

hom.sense:
MjilN Delayed; postponed; kept back; syn. mutaOax-irN; [but in some copies of the Ḳ, for MjilN, we find OajilN↓;] as also OajiylN↓, of which the pl. is OujolN: (Ḳ:) and therefore, (TA,) not present; future; to come; contr. of EaAjilN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:)
and mutaOaj-ilN↓, also, signifies delayed, deferred, or postponed, to the time of the end of a period; originally, contr. of mutaEaj-ilN. (Mgh.) [See also OajiylN.]
[Hence,] AlMjilapu The [future,] latter, ultimate, or last, dwelling, or abode, or life; the world to come; syn. AlMxirapu; (Ḳ, TA;) contr. of AlEaAjilapu. (Ṣ, TA.)
Committing a crime; or a committer of a crime. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: muWaj-alN Determined, defined, or limited, as to time; applied to a writing: so in the Ḳur iii. 139: (Bḍ, Jel, TA:) and to a debt; contr. of HaAl-N, q. v. (Mgh in art. Hl.)
See also OajiylN.
mutaOaj-ilN: see MjilN.

hom.sense: 1. Oajimahu, with kesr, [aor. _a {yaOojamu},] (AZ, Ṣ, O,) inf. n. OajamN; (KL, PṢ;) or Oajamahu, aor. _i {yaOojimu}, (so in the Ḳ,) inf. n. OajomN; (TḲ;) [but Oajima is the form commonly known; and if it were incorrect, the author of the Ḳ would probably, accord. to his usual custom, have charged J with error respecting it;] He loathed it; disliked it; was, or became, disgusted with it; namely, food; (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;), &c.; (Ḳ;) from constantly keeping to it; (AZ, Ṣ, O;) or because of its not agreeing with him: (TA:) he reckoned it bad: (KL:) and tOj-mhu↓ also signifies he disliked, disapproved, or hated, it; or he expressed, or showed, dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, of it; syn. takar-ahahu. (TA.)
Oajama falaAn-aA, aor. _i {yaOojimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OajomN, (TḲ,) He incited, or urged, such a one to do that which he disliked, disapproved, or hated. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

4. yuWojimu Aln-aAsa, or yuWaj-imu↓ Aln-aAsa, [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the former being the reading in the TA,] He makes men's own selves to be objects of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, to them. (Ḳ voce OajuwmN.) [Accord. to the TḲ, you say, Mjamahu minohu, inf. n. UiyjaAmN, meaning He made him to be an object of dislike, disapprobation, or hatred, to him.]

hom.sense: 5. tOj-m He (a lion) entered his Oajamap [or thicket]. (Ḳ.)
tOj-mhu: see 1.

entry.sense: OajomN Any square, roofed, house: (Ḳ:) mentioned by ISd as on the authority of Yaạḳoob: but see OujumN as explained by J [in the Ṣ] on the same authority. (TA.)

hom.sense: OujomN: see OujumN.
It is also a pl. of OajamapN. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OajamN: see OajamapN.

OujumN A fortress; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like OuTumN: (Mgh:) pl. MjaAmN. (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) AlOujumu [is the name of] A fortress (Ṣ, Ḳ) in El-Medeeneh, (Ḳ,) built of stones by the people of that city: and Yaạḳoob says that OujumN signifies any square, roofed, house. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says, [describing a vehement rain,]
watayomaMCa lamo yatoruko bihaA jicoEa naxolapK
walaA Oujum-aA Uil-aA maXiydFA bijanodali
[And Teymà, (a town so called,) it left not therein a trunk of a palm-tree, nor a square, roofed, house, unless raised high with stones: but in the Calc. ed. of the Mo' allakát, (p. 54,) for Oujum-aA, we find OuTum-aA, which has the same meaning]. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.) See also OajomN. (TA.) Accord. to Aṣ, it is also pronounced OujomN↓. (Ṣ.)

OajamapN A thicket, wood, or forest; a collection, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or an abundant collection, (Ḳ,) of tangled, confused, or dense, trees, or shrubs: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it is of reeds, or canes: (Ṣ:) or a [place such as is termed] magiyD of water collected together, in which, in consequence thereof, trees grow: (Ṣ in art. gyD:) [or] it signifies also a bed, or place of growth, of canes or reeds: (Mgh:) the pl. is OajamaAtN and OujumN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OujomN (M, Ḳ) and OajamN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this last is a coll. gen. n., of which OajamapN is the n. un.,] and UijaAmN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [pl. of pauc.] MjaAmN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or the last but one is pl. of OajamN, (M,) and so is the last. (Lḥ, M, Mṣb.) And hence, The haunt of a lion. (TA in art. Hrb.)
MjaAmN [in the CK AajAm] also signifies Frogs. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [App. because frogs are generally found in beds of canes or reeds.]

hom.sense: MjimN Loathing, disliking, or regarding with disgust. (Ṣ, TA.)
maMCN MjimN i. q. maOojuwmN↓ [Water that is loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust]. (TA.)

entry.sense: maOojuwmN: see MjimN.

hom.sense: 1. Oajana, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOojinu} and _u {yaOojunu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Oajina, (Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) aor. _a {yaOojanu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) mentioned by Yz; (Ṣ;) inf. n. of the former OujuwnN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and OajonN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and of the latter OajanN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) It (water) became altered for the worse (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) in taste and colour, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) from some such cause as long standing, (TA,) but was drinkable: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or became altered for the worse in its odour by oldness: or became covered with [the green substance called] TuHolub and with leaves: (Mgh:) Oajuna, also, said of water, signifies it became altered for the worse: (Th:) and in the Iktitáf occurs Oajana, aor. _a {yaOojanu} which is unknown, but may be a mixture of two dial. vars. [namely of Oajana having for its aor. _i {yaOojinu} and _u {yaOojunu} and yaOojanu having for its pret. Oajina]. (MF)
Oajana He (a qaS-aAra, or whitener of cloth) beat a piece of cloth or a garment [in washing it]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OajonN: see MjinN.
OajinN: see MjinN.
OujonapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OajonapN and UijonapN (Ḳ) i. q. wajonapN [The ball, or elevated part, of the cheek]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OajiynN: see MjinN.

Uij-aAnapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UinojiAnapu↓, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) the latter of the dial. of Teiyi, (Lḥ, TA,) or this is a vulgar form, (Mgh,) not allowable, (Ṣ,) and UinojaAnapN↓, (Ḳ,) with I, (TA,) A thing well known; (Ḳ;) a vessel in which clothes are washed; (Mṣb;) a [vessel also called] mirokan, resembling a laqan [which is a kind of basin], in which clothes are washed: (Mgh:) or what is called in Persian PnGAn [i. e. PinoGAno a small cup]: (PṢ:) [it probably received this last meaning, and some others, in post-classical times: Golius explains it as meaning “lagena, phiala, crater:” adding, “hinc vulgo Fingiána (i. e. finojaAnap) calix vocatur: item Urceus: hydria:: (referring to John ii. 6:) Vas dimidiœ seriœ simile, in quo aqua et similia ponuntur:” on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof: and, on the same authority, “Labrum seu vas lapideum instar pelvis, in quo lavantur vestes:”] pl. OajaAjiynu: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) meaning [also] what resemble troughs, surrounding trees. (Mṣb.)

MjinN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajinN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OajonN↓ (ISd, TA) and OajiynN↓ (TA) Water altered for the worse (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) in taste and colour, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) from some such cause as long standing, (TA,) but still drinkable: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or altered for the worse in its odour by oldness: or covered with [the green substance called] TuHolub and with leaves: (Mgh:) pl. OujuwnN; thought by ISd to be pl. of OajonN and MjinN. (TA.)
UinojaAnapN: see Uij-aAnapN.
UiyjaAnapN: see Uij-aAnapN.

miYojanapN [in Golius's Lex. miYojanN] The instrument for beating used by the qaS-aAr [or whitener of cloth, in washing]: but better without C, [written miyjanpN,] because the pl. is mawaAjinu; or, accord. to IB, the pl. is maMjinu. (TA.)

2. OH-dhu, [inf. n. taOoHiydN,] He made it one; or called it one: as also wH-dhu. (TA in art. wHd.) You say, OaH-idi AliAvonayoni Make thou the two to become one. (Ḳ.) It is related in a trad., that Moḥammad said to a man who was making a sign with his two fore fingers in repeating the testimony of the faith, [There is no deity but God, &c.,] OaH-idoOaH-ido [meaning that he should make the sign with one finger only]. (Ṣ.) And OaHad-a Qll-eha means He declared God to be one; he declared, or professed, the unity of God; as also wH-dhu. (T and L in art. wHd.)
OaH-idi AlEaXarapa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoHiydN, (Ḳ,) Make thou the ten to become eleven, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) is a phrase mentioned by Fr on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (Ṣ.)
8. Ait-aHada: see art. wHd: and see what here next follows {10}.

hom.sense:
10. AstOHd He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, alone, by himself, apart from others, or solitary;
syn. Ainofarada; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Qt-aHada↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Ait-aHada, originally AiYotaHada or AiwtaHada], (Ḳ, TA,) or tawaH-ada. (CK.)

maA QsotaOoHada bihi He did not know it; did not know, or had not knowledge, of it; did not understand it; did not know the minute circumstances of it; or did not perceive it by any of the senses; syn. lamo yaXoEuro bihi; (L, Ḳ;) i. e., a thing, or an affair: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (L.)

entry.sense: OaHadN, originally waHadN, the w being changed into O, (Mṣb,) One; the first of the numbers; (Ṣ;) syn. [in many cases] with waAHidN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) with which it is interchangeable in two cases, to be explained below: (Mṣb:) pl. MHaAdN and OuHodaAnN (Ḳ) and OaHaduwna, which last occurs in a phrase hereafter to be mentioned; (TA;) or it has no pl. in this sense; (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) and as to MHaAdN, it may be pl. of waAHidN, [and originally OawoHaAdN,] like OaXohaAdN as pl. of XaAhidN, (Th, Mṣb,) a pl. of pauc. (Mṣb.) The fem. is UiHodaI↓ only; and this is only used in particular cases, to be shown below: (Mṣb:) most agree that the I in this word is the characteristic of the fem. gender: but some say that it is to render it quasi-coordinate to the quadriliteral-radical class: [this, however, is inconsistent with its pronunciation, which is invariably UiHodaI, not UiHod-aI:] (TA:) its pl. is UiHadN, as though the sing. were UiHodapN, like as is said of cikarN as pl. of cikoraI: one of the expositors of the Tes-heel writes it OuHadN, with damm and then fet-ḥ; but a pl. of this measure is not applicable to a sing. of the measure fiEolaI, with kesr. (MF.) The dim. of OaHadN is OuHayodN↓; and that of UiHodaI is OuHayodaI↓. (L in art. wHd.)

It is interchangeable with waAHidN in two cases: first, when it is used as an epithet applied to God: (Mṣb:) for AlOaHadu, as an epithet, is applied to God alone, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and signifies The One; the Sole; He who has ever been one and alone: or the Indivisible: or He who has no second [to share] in his lordship, nor in his essence, nor in his attributes: (TA:) you say, huwa AlwaAHidu and huwa AlOaHadu: and in like manner, OaHadN, without the article, is used as an epithet specially in relation to God, and is interchangeable in this case [but not in other cases] with waAHidN: therefore you do not say rajulN OaHadN nor dirohamN OaHadN and the like [but rajulN waAHdN and dirhamN waAHidN, &c.] (Mṣb.) [See also waAHidN, in art. wHd.] In the phrase in the Ḳur [cxii. 1], qulo huwa Qll-ehu OaHadN [Say, He is God, One God], OaHadN is a substitute for Qll-ehu; for an indeterminate noun is sometimes a substitute for a determinate noun, as in another passage in the Ḳur, xcvi. 15 and 16. (Ṣ.) Secondly, it is interchangeable with waAHidN in certain nouns of number: (Mṣb:) you say OaHada EaXara [masc.] and UiHodaI EaXorapa [fem.] (Ṣ) [meaning Eleven: and in these two cases you may not substitute waAHidN and waAHidapN for OaHadN and UiHodaI: but] in OaHadN waEiXoruwna [One and twenty, and the like,] OaHadN is interchangeable with waAHidN. (Mṣb.) Ks says, When you prefix the article Al to a number, prefix it to every number; therefore you should say, maA faEalati AlOaHada AlEaXara AlOalofa Ald-irohama [What did the eleven thousand dirhems?]: but the Basrees prefix it to the first only, and say, mA fElt AlOaHada EaXara Oalofa dirohamK. (Ṣ.)

In [most] cases differing from these two, there is a difference in usage between OaHadN and waAHidN: the former is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed noun only, governing the noun which follows it in the gen. case; [as in exs. which will be found below;] and is used absolutely in negative phrases; [as will also be seen in exs. below;] whereas waAHidN is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed noun and otherwise: the fem. UiHodaI, also, is only used as a prefixed noun, except in numbers (Mṣb) [and in one other instance, which see below]. Using OaHadN and its fem. in affirmative phrases as prefixed nouns, you say, qaAma OaHadu Alv-alaAvapi [One of the three stood]; and qaAlato UiHodaA humaA [One of them two (females) said]; and xuco UiHodaI Alv-alaAvapi [Take thou one of the three]. (TA.) The phrase UiHodaI banaAti TabaqK means A calamity: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the Ḳ “and,”) a serpent; (Ḳ, TA;) so called because it twists itself round so as to become like a Tabaq. (TA.) And the phrase UiHodaI AlUiHadi, (L, Ḳ, TA,) in which the latter word has kesr to the U and fet-ḥ to the H, and is pl. of the former, also written AlOuHadi, but this form is disapproved by MF, as has been shown above, (TA, [in several copies of the Ḳ incorrectly written AlOaHadi,]) [lit. means One of the ones; and] is applied to a great, or mighty, event; (L, Ḳ, TA;) one that is difficult, distressing, grievous, or terrible. (L, TA.) You say, OataI biUiHodaI AlUiHadi [the last of which words is here again written in several copies of the Ḳ AlOaHadi] He brought to pass a grievous, and great, or mighty, event, (Ḳ, TA,) when you desire to express the greatness and terribleness of an event. (TA.) You also say, fulaAnu OaHadu AlOaHadiyna, and waAHidu AlOaHadiyna, (Ḳ, TA,) the latter in one copy of the Ḳ written waAHidu AlwaAHidiyna, in which the latter word is pl. of the former, (TA,) and waAHidu AlMHaAdi, and UiHodaI AlUiHadi, (Ḳ, TA,) like a phrase before mentioned, only the former is applied to a calamity, and this to an intelligent being, and written in the two manners before mentioned, the difference being only in application, (TA, [in several copies of the Ḳ here again written UiHodaI, AlOaHadi, and in the CK AaHadiI-u AlAaHadi,]) and UiHodaI AlOaHadiyna, (Et-Tes-heel,) and UiHodaI AlMHaAdi, (TA,) which are expressions of the utmost praise, (IAạr, AHeyth, Ḳ,) [lit. Such a man is one of the ones; meaning] such a one is unique among the uniques; (TA;) one who has no equal; unequalled; incomparable. (IAạr, Tes-heel.) It seems that the form of pl. used in the phrase OaHadu AlOaHadiyna is used only as applied to rational beings; but it is said in the Expositions of the Tes-heel that this phrase signifies One of the calamities; the form of the rational pl. being given to nouns significant of things deemed great, mighty, or grievous. (AHeyth.) In the phrase UiHodaI AlUiHadi, the fem. forms are said to be used for the purpose of giving intensiveness to the signification, as though the meaning were daAhiyapu Ald-awaAhiI, the word dAhyp being [an intensive epithet] from dahaMCN as signifying intelligence, or intelligence mixed with craft or cunning and forecast; or by dAhyp being meant a calamity. (Expositions of the Fṣ, TA.) AḤei thought OaHadu AlOaHadiyna to be an epithet applied to a male, and UiHodaI AlUiHadi to be applied to a female: but his opinion has been refuted by Ed-Demámeenee in the Expos. of the Tes-heel: and this latter author there remarks, that in expressions meant to denote praise [of a man], OaHadN and UiHodaI are prefixed to their own proper pls., as OaHaduwna and UiHadN; or to an epithet, as in the case of OaHadu AlEulamaMCi [One of the learned]; but that they have not been heard prefixed to generic nouns. (TA.) You say likewise, huwa Qbonu UiHodaAhaA He is born of noble, or generous, ancestors, both on the father's and the mother's side; speaking of a man and of a camel. (L and Ḳ in art. wHd.) And laA yaquwmu bihecaA AlOamori Uil-aA Qbonu UiHodaAhaA None will manage this thing, or affair, but a noble, or generous, man. (AZ, L in art. wHd.) And laA yasotaTiyEuhaA↓ Qbonu UiHodAtihaA [None will be able to perform it but a noble, or generous, man]. (L in art. wHd.)

One instance is mentioned, of the occurrence, in a trad., of UiHodaI not used as a part of a number [i. e. not as a part of the compound UiHodaI EaXorapa] nor as a prefixed noun; viz., UiHodaI mino saboEK [One of seven]; in which sbE is said to mean the nights of 'Ád [during which that tribe was destroyed], or the years of Joseph [during which Egypt was afflicted with dearth]. (MF, from the Fáïk, &c.)

Used in a negative phrase, OaHadN signifies Any one with whom one may talk or speak: and in this manner it is used without variation as sing. and pl. and fem. (Ṣ) as well as masc. (Mṣb.) You say, laA OaHada fiI Ald-aAri [There is not any one in the house]: but you do not say, fiyhaA OaHadN [as meaning the contrary]. (Ṣ.) We read in the Ḳur [lxix. 47, this ex. of its use as a masc. pl.], famaA minokumo mino OaHadK Eanohu HaAjiziyna [And not any persons of you should have withheld me from punishing him]. (Ṣ.) And in the same [xxxiii. 32, we find this ex. of its use as a fem. pl.], lasotun-a kaOaHadK mina Aln-isaMCi [Ye are not like any others of women]. (Ṣ.)

It is also used in interrogative phrases; as in the saying, halo OaHadN raOaI mivola hecaA [Has any one seen the like of this?]; (AʼObeyd, L;) and in the saying, yaA Hado raMhaA [for yaA OaHadN, O, has any one seen her, or it?]. (L, from a trad.)

It is [said to be] also used in the sense of XaIoCN [meaning Anything], applied to an irrational being; as in the saying, maA biA ld-aAri mino OaHadK Uil-aA HimaArFA There is not in the house anything, rational or irrational, except an ass: so that the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made [accord. to this rendering; but this instance is generally regarded as one in which the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made]. (Mṣb.)
So too in the Ḳur lx. 11, accord. to the reading of Ibn-Mesʼood: (Mṣb:) but others there read XaIoCN, which may mean any one or any thing. (Bḍ, Jel.)

AlOaHadN, (Ḳ,) as also yawoma AlOaHadi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) as a proper name, (Mṣb,) is applied to A certain day; (Ḳ;) [Sunday;] the first day of the week; or, as some say, [i. e. as some term it,] the second of the week; (TA;) for the Arabs are said, by IAạr, to have reckoned the Sabbath, or Saturday, as the first, though they called Sunday the first of the days: (Mṣb in art. jmE:) it is sing., and masc.: (Lḥ:) pl. [as above, i. e.] MHaAdN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OuHodaAnN: (Ḳ:) or it has no pl. (Ḳ: [but in the TA this last observation is very properly restricted, as relating only to OaHadN as syn. with waAHidN, and as applied to any unknown person.]) In this sense, it has no dim. (Sb, in Ṣ, art. Ams.)

AlMHaAdu in lexicology signifies What have been transmitted by some of the lexicologists, but not by such a number of them as cannot be supposed to have agreed to a falsehood: what has been transmitted by this larger number is termed mutawaAtiru. (Mz 3rd nwE.)
UiHodaI: fem. of OaHadN, q. v.
UiHodaApN: fem. of OaHadN, q. v.
OaHadiy-apN The unity of God; (Mṣb;) as also waHodaAniy-apN. (L and Ḳ in art. wHd.)

OuHaAda [accus. of OuHaAdu] is imperfectly decl., because of its deviation from its original, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) both in form and in meaning; (Ṣ;) [being changed in form from waAHidFA, and in meaning from QwaAHidFA: (see vulaAva:)] you say, jaAWuwA OuHaAda OuHaAda, [AHAd being repeated for the purpose of corroboration,] meaning, They came one [and] one, one [and] one; or one [by] one, one [by] one. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The dim. of OuHaAdu is OuHay-idN↓, perfectly decl., like vulay-ivN [q. v.], &c. (Ṣ, in art. vlv.)
OuHay-idN: see OaHaAda.

1. OaHina (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) Ealayohi, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. _a {yaOoHanu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaHanN, (Mṣb,) or OaHonN, and UiHonapN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and OaHana Ealayohi, aor. _a {yaOoHanu}, inf. n. OaHonN; (Kr, TA;) He retained enmity against him in his bosom, watching for an opportunity to indulge it, or exercise it; or hid enmity against him in his bosom; or bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) and he was affected with anger (Ḳ, TA) against him, such as came upon him suddenly from the retention or hiding of enmity in the bosom, or from rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)
3. MHanahu, (TA,) inf. n. muWaAHanapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)

UiHonapN Retention of enmity in the bosom, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it, or exercise it; or concealment of enmity in the bosom; or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and anger (Ḳ, TA) coming upon one suddenly therefrom: (TA:) pl. UiHanN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ṣ that one should not say HinapN; and this is disallowed by Aṣ and Fr and Ibn-El-Faraj: in the T it is said that it is not of the language of the Arabs; and Aṣ is related to have disapproved of Et-Tirimmáh for using its pl. in poetry: but it is said in a trad., maA bayoniI wbayona AlEarabi HinapN [There is not between me and the Arabs retention of enmity in the bosom,, &c.]; and it occurs in another trad., in a similar phrase; and the pl., in a third trad.; therefore we say that it is a dial. var. of rare occurrence. (TA.)
OaxN: see art. Axw.
OuxotN fem. of OaxN, q. v. in art. Axw.

hom.sense: 1. Oaxaca, (Ṣ, A, L, &c.,) in the first pers. of which, Oaxacotu, [and the like,] the c is generally changed into t, and incorporated into the [augmentative] t, [but in pronunciation only, for one writes Oaxact-u and the like,] aor. _u {yaOoxucu}, imperative xuco, originally QWoxuco, (Ṣ, L,) which latter form sometimes occurs, [but with w in the place of Wo when the A is pronounced with damm,] (TA,) inf. n.
