And tOd-I↓ He took his OadaAp, [or prepared himself,, &c.,] liloOamori for the affair: (M:) or tMdI↓ he prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred, himself for the affair; (Ibn-Buzurj, Az, TA;) from AlOadApu: (Az, TA:) or ↓the former of these two verbs, (so in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ,) or ↓the latter of them, (so in other copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, and in the TA,) he took his OadaAp [or equipments,, &c., i. e. he prepared himself,] for [the vicissitudes of] fortune: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and taMdawoA↓, inf. n. taMdK, they took the apparatus, equipments, or the like, that should strengthen, or fortify, them against [the vicissitudes of] fortune, &c.: (T:) [accord. to some,] Alt-aMdiI is [irregularly derived] from AlMdu, meaning “strength.” (TA.)

MdAhu is originally OaEodaAhu; the second A [in M, for OaA,] being hemzeh substituted for E in the original; meaning He aided, or assisted, him: [or he avenged him:] or it may be from AlOadaApu; meaning he made him to have, or gave him, or assigned to him, weapons, or arms. (Ḥam p. 387.) [In either case, it should be mentioned in the present art.; as AEdI belongs to art. Edw, and AlAdAp has for its pl. AlOadawaAtu.] You say, MdAhu EalaI kacaA, aor. yuWodiyhi, inf. n. UiydaMCN, He strengthened him, and aided him, or assisted him, against such a thing, or to do such a thing. (Ṣ.) And MdAhu EalaI fulaAnK, meaning OaEodaAhu and OaEaAnahu [He avenged him of such a one; or he aided, or assisted, him against such a one]. (M and Ḳ in art. EdI.) And mano yuWdiyniI EalaI fulaAnK Who will aid me, or assist me, against such a one? (Ṣ.) The people of El-Ḥijáz say, AsotaOodayotuhu↓ EalaI fulaAnK faMdaAniI Ealayohi, meaning AisotaEodayotuhu faOaEodaAniI (T, Ṣ) and OEaAnaniI (T) [I asked of him (namely the Sultá, T, or the Emeer, Ṣ) vengeance of such a one, or aid against such a one, and he avenged me of him, or aided me against him].

entry.sense: 5: see 4, in two places.
6: see 4, in three places.

10. AstOdAhu Ealayohi i. q. AisotaEodaAhu [He asked of him aid, or assistance, against him; or vengeance of him]: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) or he complained to him of his (another's) deed to him, in order that he might exact his (the complainant's) right, or due, from him. (TA.) See also 4, last sentence.

OadaApN An instrument; a tool; an implement; a utensil: and instruments; tools; implements; utensils; apparatus; equipments; equipage; accoutrements; furniture; gear; tackling: syn. MlapN: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) of any tradesman or craftsman; with which he performs the work of his trade or craft: and of war; OadaApu AlHarobi signifying weapons, or arms: (Lth, T:) and for an affair [of any kind]: (M:) [applied also to the apparatus of a camel, or of a camel's saddle, &c.: (see HidojN:)] and UidaAwapN↓ signifies the same; (M, TA;) and OadaAwapN↓: (TA:) and OadiI-N↓, (Ṣ, TA,) like ganiI-N, (TA,) [in some copies of the Ṣ MdiI-N,]
signifies apparatus, equipments, equipage, accoutrements, furniture, gear, tackling, implements, tools, or the like; syn. OuhobapN: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. of OadaAhN is OadawaAtN. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, Oaxaca OadaAtahu [He took his apparatus,, &c.; or prepared, furnished, equipped, or accoutred, himself]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) liloOamori [for the affair], and lils-afari [for journeying, or the journey], (M,) and lild-ahori [for the vicissitudes of fortune]: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and it is related on the authority of Ks, that they said Oaxaca hadaAtahu; substituting h for O. (Lḥ, M). And Oxacotu licelika AlOamor Oadiy-ahu↓ i. e. Ouhobatahu [I took for that affair its apparatus,, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.) And naHonu EalaI OadiI-K↓ lilS-alaApi We are in a state of preparation for prayer. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence, in grammar, A particle; as being a kind of auxiliary; including the article Al, the preposition, the conjunction, and the interjection; but not the adverbial noun.]

hom.sense: OadiI-N: see OadaApN, in three places.
Also A journey; or a journeying: from MdaI lils-afari. (M.)

entry.sense: OadaAwapN: see OadaApN.

UidaAwapN i. q. miTharapN; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. A small vessel [or bag] of skin, made for water, like the saTiyHap: (TA:) or, as some say, only of two skins put face to face: (M, TA:) pl. OadaAwaI; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) originally, by rule, OadaAYiIu; which is changed, as in the cases of maTaAyaA and xaTaAyaA, from the measure faEaAYilu to the measure faEaAlaI, so that the w in OadaAwaI is a substitute for the augmentative A in the sing., and the final alif [written I] in OadaAwaI is a substitute for the w in the sing. (Ṣ.)
See also OadaApN.

hom.sense: MdaI [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees, irregularly formed from the verb MdaI; like as the noun MdaI in art. AdI is irregularly formed from the verb Oad-aI in that art.]. You say, huwa MdaI XaIoCK, meaning OaqowaAhu and OEodaAhu [It is the strongest kind of thing, and, app., the most effectual to aid or assist, or to avenge]. (TA.)
See also art. AdI.
muWodK part. n. of the intrans. verb MdI [q. v.]. (T, Ṣ, M, &c.)
[And act. part. n. of MdaAhu.]
muwdK, without C, is from OawodaI signifying “he perished” [&c.]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense:
2. Od-Ahu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. tOudiyapN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and OadaMCN, (T,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and so, accord. to the Mṣb, is the former also, but this is a mistake,] He made it, or caused it, to reach, arrive, or come [to the appointed person or place, &c.]; he brought, conveyed, or delivered, it; syn. OawoSalahu; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing; (M;) as, for instance, AlOamaAnapa UilaI OholihaA [the thing committed to his trust and care, to its owner]: (Mṣb:) he delivered it, gave it up, or surrendered it: (T:) he payed it, or discharged it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, his debt, (Ṣ,) a bloodwit, a responsibility, and the like; (Mṣb in art. grm;) [and hence,] Oad-aI maA Ealayohi [he acquitted himself of that which was incumbent on him; or payed, or discharged, what he owed]: (T:) he performed, fulfilled, or accomplished, it; namely, [for instance,] AlHaj-a [the pilgrimage]; (Mṣb in art. qDI;) and in like manner, AlmanaAsika [the religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage]. (Jel in ii. 196, and Mṣb ubi suprà.) It is said in the Ḳur [xliv. 17], Oano Oad-uwA UlaI-a EibaAda Qll-ehi, meaning Deliver ye to me [the servants of God,] the children of Israel: or, as some say, the meaning is, Oad-uwA UilaI-a maA Oamarakumu Qll-ehu bihi yaA EibaAdaQll-ehi [perform ye to me that which God hath commanded you to do, O servants of God]: or it may mean listen ye, or give ye ear, to me; as though the speaker said, Oad-uwA UilaI-a samoEakumo; the verb being used in this sense by the Arabs. (T.) And one says, tOad-ayotu↓ lahu, mino Haq-ihi, (Ḳ, TA,) and Ulayohi, in the place of lahu, meaning Oad-ayotuhu; (TA;) i. e. I payed him his due, or right. (Ḳ, TA.) And a man says, maA OadoriI kayofa OataOad-aI↓ [I know not how to pay]. (TA.) One says also, Od-I Eanohu [meaning He payed, or made satisfaction, for him]: and Od-I Eanohu AlxaraAja [He payed for him, or in his stead, the land-tax]. (Mgh in art. jzO.) [Hence,] El-Akhnas says,
faOad-ayotu Ean-iI maA QsotaEartu mina AlS-ibaA
walilomaAli EinodiIi Alyawoma raAEK wakaAsibu
i. e. But I have put away from me [what I had borrowed, or assumed, of the folishness of youth, and amorous dalliance,] and now I am [or there is at my abode] a keeper and collector to the camels, or cattle, or property. (Ḥam p. 346.)
[Oad-aI UilI kacaA is a phrase often used as meaning It brought, conducted, led, or conduced, to such a thing or state; as, for instance, crime to punishment or to ignominy.]
4. MdI, intrans. and trans.: see art. Adw.

hom.sense: 5. tOd-I Uilayohi Alxabaru The information, or news, reached him. (Ṣ.)
See also 2, in two places.

10. AstOdAhu maAlFA He desired, or sought, to obtain from him property, or sued, or prosecuted, him for it, or demanded it of him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and extracted it, (Ṣ,) or took it, or received it, (Ḳ,) from him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also art. Adw.

entry.sense: OadaMCN a subst. from 2 [signifying The act of making, or causing, to reach, arrive, or come to the appointed person or place, &c.; of bringing, conveying, or delivering; of giving up, or surrendering; payment, or discharge, of a debt, &c.; the act of acquitting oneself of that which is incumbent on him; performance, fulfilment, or accomplishment]. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] huwa Hasanu AlOadaMCi He has a good manner of pronouncing, or uttering, the letters. (TA.)

OadaMCN as a term of the law signifies The performance of an act of religious service [such as prayer, &c.] at the appointed time: opposed to qaDaMCN, performance at a time other than that which is appointed. (Mṣb and TA in art. qDI.)
OadiI-N: see art. Adw.

hom.sense: MdaI [a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees, irregularly formed from the verb Oad-I; like as the noun MdaI mentioned in art. Adw is irregularly formed from the verb MdaI]. You say, huwa MdaI lilOamaAnpi [He is more, or better, disposed to deliver, give up, or surrender, the thing committed to his trust and care] (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) minoka [than thou], (Ṣ,) or mino gayorihi [than another than he]. (M,* Ḳ.) [Az says,] the vulgar say, Oad-aI liloOamaAnapi; but this is incorrect, and not allowable; and I have not known any one of the grammarians allow MdaI, because OafoEal denoting wonder [and the comparative and superlative degrees] is not formed but from the triliteral [verb], and one does not say, OadaI in the sense of Oad-aI: the proper phrase is OaHosanu OadaMCF. (T.)
See also art. Adw.

entry.sense: muWodK: see art. Adw.

Uico a word denoting past time: (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, L, Mughnee, Ḳ:) it is a noun, (Ṣ, L, Mughnee, Ḳ,) indecl., with its last letter quiescent; and properly is prefixed to a proposition; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as in jiYotuka Uico qaAma zaydN [I came to thee when Zeyd stood], and Uico zayodN qaAYimN and Uico zayodN yquwmu [When Zeyd was standing]. (Ṣ, L.) The proposition to which it is prefixed is either nominal, as in [the words of the Ḳur viii. 26,] waQcokuruwA Uico Oanotumo qaliylN [And remember ye when ye were few]; or verbal, having the verb in the pret. as to the letter and as to the meaning, as in [the Ḳur ii. 28, &c.,] waUico qaAla rab-uka lilomalaAYikapi [And when thy Lord said unto the angels]; or verbal with the verb in the pret. as to the meaning but not as to the letter, as in [the Ḳur ii. 121,] waUico yarofaEu Uiborehiymu AlqawaAEida [And when Abraham was rearing the foundations]; all three of which kinds are comprised in the Ḳur where it is said, [ix. 40,] Uil-aA tanoSuruwhu faqado naSarahu Qll-ehu Uico Oaxorajahu Ql-aciyna kafaruwA vaAniIa Qvonayoni Uico humaA fiI AlgaAri Uico yaquwlu liSaAHibihi laA taHzano Uin-a Qll-eha maEanaA [If ye will not aid him, verily God aided him, when those who disbelieved expelled him, being the second of two, when they two were in the cave, when he was saying to his companion, Grieve not thou, for God is with us]. (Mughnee.) But sometimes one half of the proposition is suppressed, as in Uico caAka, [also written Uic-aAka,] meaning Uico caAka kacelika [When that was so], or Uico caAka kaAYinN [When that was, i. e. then, at that time]. (Mughnee.) And sometimes the whole of the proposition is suppressed, (M, Mughnee,) as being known, (Mughnee,) and tenween is substituted for it; the c receiving kesreh because of the occurrence of two quiescent letters together, (M, Mughnee,) namely the c and the tenween, (M,) and thus one says, yawomaYicK; the kesreh of the c not being, as Akh holds it to be, the kesreh of declension, although Ac here occupies the place of a noun governed in the gen. case by another prefixed to it, (M, Mughnee,)
for it still requires a proposition to be understood after it, (Mughnee,) and is held to be indecl. (M, Mughnee) by general consent, like kamo and mano, (M,) as being composed of two letters. (Mughnee.) [J says,] when Uico is not prefixed to a proposition, it has tenween: (Ṣ:) and hence Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, (Ṣ, M,)
nahayotuka Eano TilaAbika Oum-a EamorKw
biEaAfiyapK waOanota UicK SaHiyHu
[I forbade thy suing Umm-ʼAmr in health, thou being then sound]; (Ṣ, M, L, Mughnee, TA; [but in two copies of the Ṣ, for biEaAfiyapK, I find biEaAqibapK; and in the L it is without any point;]) in which [J says] the poet means HiynaYicK, like as one says yawomaYcK and layolataYicK: (Ṣ:) and Fr says that some of the Arabs say, kaAna kacaA w kacaA wahuwa UicK SabiI-N, meaning huwa Uico caAka SabiI-N [Such and such things were, he being then a boy]. (T.) UiciI also occurs for Ac [app. UicK, but whether this or Uico is not clear in the MṢ. from which I take this]. (M.) When UicK is adjoined to nouns signifying times, the Arabs join it therewith in writing, in certain instances: namely HiynaYicK [At that time, or then], and yawomaYicK [In, or on, or at, that day], and layolataYicK [In, or on, or at, that night], and gadaAtaYicK [In, or on, that morning], and EaXiy-ataYicK [In, or on, that evening], and saAEataYicK [In that hour: or at that time; then], and EaAmaYicK [In that year], [and waqotaYicK At that time; then]; but they did not say AlMnaYicK, because AlMna denotes the nearest present time, except in the dial. of Hudheyl, in which it has been found to occur. (T.) When it is followed by a verb, or by a noun not having the article Al prefixed to it, or [rather] by any movent letter, the c of Uico is quieseent; but when it is followed by a noun with Al, [or by any Q,] the c is mejroorah, as in the saying,
Uici Alqawomu kaAnuwA naAziliyna bikaAZimaho
[When the people, or company of men, were alighting, or taking up their abode, at Kádhimeh]. (T.)

In general, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) it is an adverbial noun denoting past time, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) when it is a noun denoting such time, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as in waUico qaAla rab-uka lilomalaAYikapi [explained above], (M,) and in faqado naSarahu Qll-ehu Uico Oaxorajahu Ql-aciyna kafaruwA [also explained above, and in other instances already mentioned]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) in the former of which instances, AO says that it is redundant; (M, Mughnee;) but Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says that this is a bold assertion of his; (M;) [and IHsh says,] this assertion is of no account, and so is that of him who says that it here denotes certainty, like qado: (Mughnee:) [J holds the opinion of AO on this point; for he says,] Uico is sometimes redundant, like UicaA, as in the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 48], waUico waAEadonaA muwsaI, meaning wawaAEadonaA muwsaI [And We appointed a time with Moses; but instances of this kind are most probably elliptical: see the next sentence]. (Ṣ.) As a noun denoting past time, it is [said to be] also an objective complement of a verb, as in [the Ḳur vii. 84,] waQcokuruwA Uico kunotumo qaliylAF [And remember ye when ye were few]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and generally in the commencements of narratives in the Ḳur, it may be an objective complement of Oucokuro understood, as in waUico qaAla rab-uka lilomalaAYikapi [before cited], and the like. (Mughnee: but see the third of the sentences here following.) As such, it is [said to be] also a substitute for the objective complement of a verb, as in [the Ḳur xix. 16,] waQcokuro fiI QlokitaAbi maroyama Uici Qnotabacato [And mention thou, or remember thou, in the Scripture, Mary, the time when she withdrew aside], where Ac is a substitute of implication for mrym. (Mughnee, Ḳ: but see the second of the sentences here following.) As such, it also has prefixed to it a noun of time, of such a kind that it is without need thereof, as in yawomaYicK, or not of such a kind that it is without need thereof, as in [the Ḳur iii. 6,] baEoda Uico hadayotanaA [After the time when Thou hast directed us aright]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) And it is generally asserted, that it never occurs otherwise than as an adverbial noun, or as having a noun prefixed to it; that in the like of waQcokuruwA Uico kunotumo qaliylAF, it is an adverbial noun relating to an objective complement suppressed, i. e. waQcokuruwA niEomapa Qll-ehi Ealayokumo Uico kunotumo qaliylAF [And remember ye the grace of God towards you when ye were few]; and in the like of Uici Qnotabacato, that it is an adverbial noun relating to a suppressed prefixed noun to [that which becomes by the suppression] the objective complement of a verb, i. e. [in this instance] waQcokuro qiS-apa maroyama [And mention thou, or remember thou, the case of Mary]: and this assertion is strengthened by the express mention of the [proper] objective complement in [the Ḳur iii. 98,] waQcokurwA niEomapa Qll-ehi Ealayokumo Uico kunotumo OaEodaMCF [And remember ye the grace of God towards you when ye were enemies]. (Mughnee.)

Also, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to some, (T, Mughnee,) it is used (T, Mughnee, Ḳ) as a noun (Mughnee, Ḳ) to indicate future time, (T, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and UicaA is said to denote past time, (T,) [i. e.] each of these occurs in the place of the other; (TA;) the former being used to indicate future time in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 50], where it is said, walawo taraI Uico faziEuwA [And couldst thou see the time when they shall be terrified], meaning the day of resurrection; this usage being allowable, says Fr, only because the proposition is like one expressing a positive fact, since there is no doubt of the coming of that day; (T;) and in [the Ḳur xcix. 4,] yawomaYicK tuHad-ivu OaxobaArahaA [On that day, she (the earth) shall tell her tidings]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) this being generally regarded as similar to the expression of a future event which must necessarily happen as though it had already happened; but it may be urged in favour of those who hold a different opinion that it is said in the Ḳur [xl. 72 and 73], fasawofa yaEolamuwna Uici AlOaglaAlu fiI OaEonaAqihimo [They shall hereafter know, when the collars shall be on their necks]; for yElmwn is a future as to the letter and the meaning because of its having swf conjoined with it, and it governs Ac, which is therefore in the place of UicaA. (Mughnee.)

It also indicates a cause, as in [the Ḳur xliii. 38,] lano yanofaEakumu Qloyawoma Uico Zalamotumo [It will not profit you this day, since, or because, ye have acted wrongfully], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) i. e. because of your having acted wrongfully in the sublunary state of existence; (Bḍ, Mughnee;) but it is disputed whether it be in this instance a particle in the place of the causative l, or an adverbial noun: (Mughnee:) Aboo-ʼAlee seems to hold that Ac Zlmtm [as meaning when ye have acted wrongfully] is a substitute for, or a kind of repetition of, Alywm; an event happening in the present world being spoken of as though it happened in the world to come because the latter immediately follows the former. (IJ, M, L, Mughnee.) You say also, AlHamodu lil-ehi Uico jiYota [Praise be to God because, or that, thou camest, or hast come]. (Ṣ in art. jyO.)

It is also used to denote one's experiencing the occurrence of a thing when he is in a particular state; (Ṣ, L;) or to denote a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) like UicaA; (Ṣ;) and in this case is only followed by a verb expressing an event as a positive fact, (Ṣ, L,) and occurs after bayonaA and bayonamaA; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as [in exs. voce bayona; and] in bayonamaA OanaA kacaA Uico jaMCa zayodN [While I was thus, or in this state, lo, or behold, or there, or then, at that time, (accord. to different authorities, as will be seen below,) Zeyd came]; (Ṣ, L;) and as in the saying of a poet,
Aisotaqodiri Qll-eha xayorAF waQroDayan-a bihi
fabayonamaAQloEusoru Uic daArato mayaAsiyru
[Beg thou God to appoint for thee good, and do thou be content therewith; for while there has been difficulty, lo, easy circumstances have come about]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) but it is disputed whether it be [in this case] an adverbial noun of place, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as Zj and AḤei hold; (TA;) or of time, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as Mbr holds; (TA;) or a particle denoting the sudden, or unexpected, occurrence of a thing, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as IB and Ibn-Málik hold; (TA;) or a corroborative, i. e. [grammatically] redundant, particle, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) an opinion which Ibn-Ya'eesh holds, and to which Er-Raḍee inclines. (TA.)

It is also a conditional particle, but only used as such coupled with mA, (Ṣ, L, Mughnee,*) and causes two aorists to assume the mejzoom form, (Mughnee,) as when you say, UicomaA taOotiniI Mtika [When, or whenever, thou shalt come to me, I will come to thee], like as you say, Uino tOotiniI waqotFA Mtika [If thou come to me at some, or any, time, I will come to thee]; and you say also UicomaA Oatayota [like as you say, Uino Oatayota, using the pret. in the sense of the future]: (Ṣ, L:) it is a particle accord. to Sb, used in the manner of the conditional Uino; but it is an adverbial noun accord. to Mbr and Ibn-Es-Sarráj and El-Fárisee. (Mughnee.)
[What I have translated from the Ṣ, L, Ḳ, and TA, in this art., is mostly from fSl Alhmzp of bAb AlcAl: the rest, from bAb AlAlf Allyn-p.]

UicaA denotes a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) or one's experiencing the occurrence of a thing when he is in a particular state; (Ṣ;) like UicN: (Ṣ voce UicN:)
it pertains only to nominal phrases; does not require tobe followed by a reply, or the complement of a condition; does not occur at the commencement of a sentence; and signifies the present time, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) not the future; (Mughnee;) as in xarajotu faUicaA AlOasadu bAlbaAbi [I went forth, and lo, or behold, or there, or then, at that present time, (accord. to different authorities, as will be seen below,) the lion was at the door]; and (in the saying in the Ḳur [xx. 21], TA,) faUicaA hiIa Hay-apN tasoEaI [And lo, or behold,, &c., it was a serpent running]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and in the saying, xarajotu faUicaA zayodN qaAYimN, which means I went forth, and Zeyd presented himself to me suddenly, or unexpectedly, at the time, by standing. (Ṣ, TA.) Accord. to Akh, it is a particle, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and his opinion is rendered preferable by their saying, xarajotu faUicaA Uin-a ziyodAF biAlbaAbi [I went forth, and lo, or behold, verily Zeyd was at the door]; for [AcA cannot here be a noun governed in the accus. case, as] what follows Uin-a, which is with kesr, does not govern what precedes it: (Mughnee:) accord. to Mbr, it is an adverbial noun of place: accord. to Zj, an adverbial noun of time. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) Ibn-Málik adopts the first of these opinions; Ibn-ʼOsfoor, the second; (Mughnee;) and so El-Fenjedeehee; (TA;) and Z, the third; and he asserts that its governing word is a verb understood, derived from AlmufaAjaOapu; [agreeably with the explanation cited above from the Ṣ;] but others hold that the word which governs it in the accus. case is the enunciative, which is either expressed, as in xarajotu faUicaA zayodN jaAlisN [I went forth, and there, in that place, or then, at that time, Zeyd was sitting], or meant to be understood, as in faUicaA AlOasadu, i. e. HaADirN [And there, or then, the lion was present]; or if it be supposed to be [itself] the enunciative, its governing word is musotaqir-u or Aisotaqar-a [understood]: and in the last of the phrases here mentioned, it may be an enunciative accord. to the opinion of Mbr, the meaning being fabiQloHaADirapi AlOasadu [And among the things present was the lion]; but not accord. to the opinion of Zj, because a noun signifying time cannot be the enunciative of one signifying a corporeal thing; nor accord to the opinion of Akh, because a particle cannot be used to denote the enunciative of such a thing; or, as signifying time, it may be the enunciative of such a thing if we suppose a prefixed noun to be suppressed, the meaning of faUicaA AlOasadu being faUicAa HuDuwru AlOasadi [And then was the presence of the lion]. (Mughnee.) You may say either xarajotu faUicaA zayodN jaAlisN or jaAlisAF [I went forth, and lo, or behold,, &c., Zeyd was sitting or Zeyd was there sitting], with the nom. as an enunciative and with the accus. as a denotative of state. (Mughnee.) The Arabs said, qado kunotu OaZun-u Oan-a AlEaqoraba OaXad-u lasoEapF mina Alz-unobuwri faUicAa huwa hiI [I used to think that the scorpion was more vehement in stinging than the hornet, and lo, he is (as vehement as) she], and also, faUicAa huwa Uiy-aAhaA, which Sb disallowed, in contending with Ks, who allowed it, and appealed for confirmation thereof to certain Arabs, whose judgment was pronounced in his favour; but it is said that they were bribed to give this judgment, or that they knew the place which Ks held in the estimation of Er-Rasheed; and if the latter expression be of established authority, it is irregular and unchaste. (Mughnee.)

It also denotes the complement of a condition, like fa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) with which it is in this case syn., (Mṣb,) as in the words of the Ḳur [xxx. 35], waUino tuSibohumo say-iYapN bimaA qad-amato Oayodiyhimo UicaA humu yaqonaTuwn [And if an evil befall them for that which their hands have sent before, (i. e. for sins which they have committed,) then they despair]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

It is also an adverbial noun denoting future time, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,*) and implying the meaning of a condition, (Mṣb, Mughnee,) and this is generally the case when it is not used in the manner first explained above. (Mughnee.) In this case it is not used otherwise than as prefixed to a proposition, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) which is always verbal, as in the words of the Ḳur [xxx. 24], vum-a UicaA daEaAkuma daEowapF mina AlOaroDi UcaA Oanotumo taxorujuwna [Then, when He shall call you, or when He calleth you, (for, as in Arabic, so in English, a verb which is properly present is often tropically future,) with a single call from out the earth, lo, or behold, or then, ye shall come forth], in which occur both the usages of AcA here mentioned; (Mughnee;) and in the phrase, UicaA jiYota Oakoramotuka [When thou shalt come, I will treat thee with honour]; (Mṣb;) and in the phrase, OajiyoWuka UicaA QHomar-aAlbusoru [I will come to thee when the fullgrown unripe dates shall become red], and UicaA qadima fulaAnN [when such a one shall arrive], which shows it to be a noun because this is equivalent to yawoma yaqodamu fulaAnN [on the day when such a one shall arrive]: (Ṣ:) or in the phrase qumo UicaA QHomar-a Albusoru [and in many other cases] it denotes time divested of any accessory idea, the meaning being [Arise thou] at the time of the full-grown unripe dates' becoming red: and so in the saying of EshSháfi'ee, If a man were to say, Oanoti TaAliqN UicaA lamo OuTal-iqoki, or mataI lm ATl-qk, [Thou art divorced when I do not divorce thee,] and then be silent for a time sufficient for the divorce to be pronounced therein, she would be divorced; but should he make it dependent upon a thing in the future, the divorce would be delayed to that time, as if he said, AcA AHmr- Albsr [using it in the sense first assigned to this phrase above]. (Mṣb.) The verb after it is in most cases a pret.: in other cases, an aor.: both occur in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
waAln-afosu raAgibapN UicaA rag-abotahaA
waUicaA turad-u UilaI qaliylK taqonaEu
[And the soul is desirous when thou makest it desirous; and when thou reducest it, or restrictest it, to little, it is content]. (Mughnee.) When it is immediately followed by a noun, as in [the phrase in the Ḳur lxxxiv. 1,] UcaA Qls-amaMCu QnoXaq-ato, the noun is an agent with a verb suppressed, explained by what follows it; contr. to the opinion of Akh; (Mughnee;) the complete phrase being UicaA QnoXaq-ati Als-amaMCu QnoXaq-ato [When the heaven shall be cleft, (when) it shall be cleft]; and in like manner, Uino, as in the saying, in the Ḳur [ix. 6], waUino OaHadN mina AlmuXorikiyna QsotajaAraka. (I'Akp. 123.) And in the saying of the poet,
UicaA baAhiliI-N taHotahu HanoZaliy-apN
lahu waladN minohaA facaAka Almudar-aEu kaAna is meant to be understood after AcA [so that the meaning is, When a Báhilee (a man of the tribe of Báhileh) has, or shall have, as his wife a Handhaleeyeh (a woman of the tribe of Handhaleh, who were renowned for generosity), he having offspring from her, that (offspring) is, or will be, the mail-clad]. (Mughnee.)

Sometimes it denotes past time, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) like as Uico sometimes denotes future time, (Mughnee,) as in [the saying in the Ḳur lxii. 11,] waUicaA raOawoA tijaArapF Oawo lahowAF QnofaD-uwA UilayohaA [And when they saw merchandise or sport, they dispersed themselves to it]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) [Thus] it occurs in the place of Uico, like as Uico occurs in the place of UicaA. (TA.)
And sometimes it denotes the present time; and this is after an oath, as in [the phrase in the Ḳur xcii. 1,] waAll-ayoli UicaA yagoXaI [By the night when it covereth with its darkness]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.)

It also occurs in the sense of the conditional Uino, as in the saying, Oukorimuka UicaA OakoramotaniI, meaning Uino OakoramotaniI [I will treat thee with honour if thou treat me with honour]: (T:) [for] what is possible is made dependent upon it as well as what is known to be certain, as in the phrases, UicaA jaMCa zayodN [If Zeyd come] and UicaA jaMCa raOosu AlX-ahori [When the beginning of the month shall come]; or, accord. to Th, there is a difference between UicaA and Uino; (Mṣb;) the latter being held by him to denote what is possible, and the former to denote what is ascertained; so that one says, Uino jaMCa zayodN and UcaA jaMCa raOosu AlX-ahri. (Mṣb in art. An.)

When a verb in the first person sing. of the pret. is explained by another verb after it immediately preceded by UicaA, [taquwlu is understood before the former verb, and therefore] the latter verb must be in the second pers. sing., as in lujotuhu UicaA Oadarotahu fiI fyika [meaning Thou sayest (of a thing) lujotuhu when, or if, thou hast turned it about in thy mouth]. (MF in art. lwj. See also OaIo; last sentence but one.)

It is sometimes redundant, like as Uico is sometimes [accord. to some], as in the saying of ʼAbd-Menáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee,
Hat-aI UicaA Oasolakuwhum fiI qutaAYidapK
Xal-aA kamaA taTorudu Aljam-aAlapu AlX-urudaA
[Until they made them to pass along Kutáïdeh, (here meaning a certain mountain-road so named, Ṣ in art. qtd,) urging on, like as the owners, or attendants, of camels drive those that take fright and run away]; for it is the end of the poem: or he may have abstained from mentioning the enunciative because of its being known to the hearer. (Ṣ.) When UicaA is preceded by Hat-aI, [as in this instance,] it is generally held that AcA is not governed by Ht-I in the gen. case, but is still an adverbial noun, Ht-I being an inceptive particle without government. (Mughnee.)

As to what it is that governs UicaA in the accus. case, there are two opinions; that it is its conditional proposition; or a verb, or the like, in the complement thereof: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) the former is the opinion of the critical judges; so that it is in the predicament of mataI and HayovumaA and Oay-aAna. (Mughnee.)

Sometimes it is used so as not to denote a condition, as in the words of the Ḳur [xlii. 35], waUicaA maA gaDibuwA hum yagfiruwna [And when, or whenever, they are angry, they forgive], in which it is an adverbial noun relating to the enunciative of the inchoative after it; for if it denoted a condition, and the nominal proposition were a complement, it would be connected by fa: and the same is the case when it is used after an oath, as in an ex. given above. (Mughnee.)
See also what follows.

UicFA, (Mṣb, TA, the latter as on the authority of Lth,) with tenween, (TA,) or Uican, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ, the first as on the authority of Lth,) written in the former manner, (TA,) or in the latter, (T,) when connected with a following proposition, (T, TA,) and in a case of pause written UicFA↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ, TA,) and therefore the Basrees hold that in other cases it should be written UicFA, (Mṣb,) though El-Má- zinee and Mbr hold that it should be in this case also with n, while Fr holds that it should be written with A; when it governs, and otherwise with n, in order to distinguish between it and [the adverbial noun] UicaA: (Mughnee:) a particle, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, TA,) accord. to the general opinion; and accord. to this opinion, it is a simple word, not compounded of Uico and Oano; and as being simple, it is that which renders an aor. mansoob, not Oano suppressed and meant to be understood after it: some say that it is a noun: (Mughnee:) [but a knowledge of its meaning is necessary to the understanding of the reason given for asserting it to be a noun.] It denotes a response, or reply, corroborating a condition; (Lth, T, TA;) or compensation, or the complement of a condition; (Mṣb;) or a response, or reply, (Sb, Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) in every instance; (TA;) and compensation, or the complement of a condition, (Sb, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) though not always: (Mughnee, TA:) and its virtual meaning is [Then; i. e., in that case; or] if the case, or affair, be as thou hast mentioned, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or as has happened: (M, TA:) [and hence,] accord. to those who say that it is a noun, the original form of the phrase Uicano Oukorimaka [Then, or in that case, or if the case be so, I will treat thee with honour, said in reply to one who says “I will come to thee,”] is UicaA jiYotaniI Oukrimuka [When thou shalt come to me, I will treat thee with honour]; then the proposition [jYtnI] is thrown out, and tenween [or n] is substituted for it, (Mughnee,) for which reason, and to distinguish between it and [the adverbial] n, the Koofees hold that it should be written with UicaA, (Mṣb,) and Oano [preceded by yajibu EalaI-a or the like] is suppressed and meant to be understood [as that which renders the aor. mansoob; so that when one says Uicano Oukorimaka, it is as though he said UicaA jiYotaniI When thou shalt come to me, it will be incumbent, or obligatory, on me to treat thee with honour]. (Mughnee.) It renders an aor. following it mansoob on certain conditions: (Mughnee, TA:) to have this effect, the aor. must have a future signification, (T, Ṣ, Mughnee, TA,) not present: (TA:) yajibu EalaI-a Oano Oukurimaka must commence the phrase in which the aor. occurs; (Mughnee, TA;) [or, in other words,] the aor. must not be syntactically dependent upon what precedes AcA: (TA:) and there must be nothing intervening between AcA and the aor., (T, Mughnee, TA,) unless it is a particle, (T,) or an oath, (T, Mughnee,) or the negative laA: (Mughnee:) therefore, to a person who says, “To-night I will visit thee,” (Ṣ,) or who says, “I will come to thee,” (Mughnee,) you say, Uicano Oukorimaka [Then, or in that case, &c., I will treat thee with honour]; (T, Ṣ, Mughnee;) and to one who says, “I will treat thee with honour,” you say, UicFA OajiyoYaka [Then, or if the case be so, I will come to thee]. (TA.) When the verb after Acn has the present signification, it does not govern: (Ṣ, Mughnee, TA:) therefore, to a person who says, “I love thee,” you say, Uicano OaZun-uka [Then, or if the case be so, I think thee veracious]; for this is a mere reply: (Mughnee:) and to one talking to thee, UicFA OaZun-uka kaAcbFA [Then I think thee to be lying]. (TA.) When it is put in a middle place, (Ṣ,) not commencing the phrase, (Mughnee,) the verb after it not being syntactically dependent upon what is before it, (Ṣ, TA,) it does not govern: (Ṣ, Mughnee, TA:) therefore, to one who says, “I will come to thee,” (Mughnee, TA,) you say, OanaA Uicano Oukorimuka [I, in that case, will treat thee with honour]: (Ṣ, Mughnee, TA:) for Acn among the words which govern verbs is likened to AlZ-an-u among those which govern nouns: (Ṣ:) and when it is put at the end, it does not govern; as when you say, Oukorimuka [I will treat thee with honour in that case]. (Ṣ.) The saying [of the poet, or rájiz],
laA tatorukan-iI fiyhimu XaTiyraA
Uin-iI UicFA Oaholika Oawo OaTiyraA
is explained by regarding it as an instance of the suppression of the enunciative of Uin-, so that the meaning is, Uin-iI lAa Oaqodiru EalaI celika, and then a new phrase commences [wherefore the verse means Do not thou leave me among them remote, or a stranger: verily I cannot endure that: in that case I should perish, or I should flee]. (Mughnee.) When it is immediately preceded by a conjunction such as wa or fa, the aor. may be either marfooa or mansoob. (Ṣ, Mughnee.) When a noun is introduced between it and the aor., the latter is marfooa, (T, Mughnee,) as in the saying, Uicano Oaxuwka yukorimuka [Then, or in that case, thy brother will treat thee with honour], (T,) or UicFA yaA Eaboda Qll-ehi Oukurimuka [Then, or in that case, O ’Abd-Allah, I will treat thee with honour]; but Ibn-’Osfoor allows the intervention of an adverbial noun [without annulling the government]; and Ibn-Bábshádh, that of the vocative, and of a prayer; and Ks and Hishám, that of a word governed by the verb; but Ks in this case prefers nasb; and Hishám, refa. (Mughnee.) When you put an oath in the place of the noun, you make the aor. mansoob, as in the saying, UicFA waQll-ehi tanaAma [Then, or if the case be so, by God, thou wilt sleep]: but if you prefix l to the verb with the oath, you make the aor. marfooa, saying, Ucano waQll-ehi latanodahum [Then, or if the case be so, by God, assuredly thou wilt regret, or repent]. (T.) When you introduce a particle between it and the aor., you make the latter either marfooa or mansoob, saying, Uicano laA Oukorimuka and laA Oukurimaka [Then, or in that case, I will not treat thee with honour]. (T.)
Sometimes the A is rejected, and they say, cano laA OafuEalu [Then, (a word exactly agreeing with cano in sound as well as in meaning,) or in that case, I will not do such a thing]. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
IJ relates, on the authority of Khálid, that UicFA is used in the dial. of Hudheyl for UicFA. (M.)
[Uicano or UicFA is mentioned and explained in the Ṣ and Ḳ and TA in art. Acn, and in the TA in bAb AlAlf Ally-np also.]
McaAru The sixth of the Greek [or Syrian] months [corresponding to March O. Ṣ.]. (Ḳ.) [This is not to be confounded with Mcaro or Mcuro, which is the ninth month of the Persian calendar.]

hom.sense: 1. Oacina laho (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Uilayohi, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOocanu}, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OacanN, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He [gave ear or] listened to it, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or him: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (M,) he listened to it, or him, pleased, or being pleased. (M, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (T,) maA Oacina Qll-ehi liXaIoCK linabiI-K yatagan-aI bAlqurMni (T, Ṣ) God hath not listened to anything [in a manner] like his listening [to a prophet chanting the Ḳur-án]. (T.) And in the Ḳur [lxxxiv. 2 and 5], waOacinato lirab-ihA And shall listen to its Lord, (M, Bḍ, Jel,) and obey; (Jel;) i. e., shall submit to the influence of his power as one listens to the commander and submits to him. (Bḍ.) And you say, Oacina lil-ahowi He listened and inclined to sport, or play. (M.)
[Hence, perhaps,] Oacina liraAYiHapi AlT-aEaAmi † He desired eagerly, or longed for, the food, [perceiving its odour,] (ISh, Ḳ,) and inclined to it. (ISh, TA.)

[Hence also, app.,] Oacina lahu fiI AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or fiI Oamori kacaA, (T,) or fiI kacaA, (Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaOocanu}, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiconN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and OaciynN, (Ḳ,) [as though originally signifying He gave ear to him in respect of such a thing; and then] he permitted him, allowed him, or gave him permission or leave, to do the thing, or such a thing. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also UiconN, below.] You say, Oacinotu liloEabodi faI Alt-ijaArapi [I gave permission, or leave, to the slave to traffic]. (Mṣb.)

Oacina lahu Ealayohi He took, or got, permission, or leave, for him from him. (M.) You say, Aiycano liI EalaI AlOamiyri (Ṣ, TA) Take thou, or get thou, permission for me from the commander, or governor, or prince. (TA.) El-A'azz Ibn-ʼAbdAllah says,
waUin-iI UicaA Dan-a AlOamiyru bUiconihi
EalaI AlUicni mino nafosiI UicA XiYotN qaAdirN
[And verily I, when the prince is niggardly of his permission, am able to take permission of myself when I will]. (TA.) And a poet says,
qulotu libaw-aAbK ladayohi daAruhaA
tiYocano faUin-iI HayoWuhaA wajaAruhaA
[I said to a door-keeper, near by whom was her house, take thou, or get thou, permission for me to enter, for I am her husband's father, and her neighbour]: meaning, says Aboo-Jaạfar, litaOocano; for the suppression of the l is allowable in poetry, and the pronunciation with kesr to the t is accord. to the dial. of him who says Oanota tiEolamu. (Ṣ.)

Oacina biAlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOocanu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiconN and OacanN and OacaAnN and OacaAnapN, (M, Ḳ,) He knew the thing; knew of it; had knowledge of it; became informed, or apprized, of it. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 279], faOocanuwA biHarobK mina Qll-ehi warasuwlihi (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) Then be ye informed, or apprized, of war [that shall come upon you] from God and his apostle: (M, Ḳ:) or then be ye sure, or assured,, &c. (T.) [See also UiconN, below.]

Oacanahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaconN, (T,) He hit, or hurt, his ear; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) or struck his ear; (so in some copies of the Ṣ;) and Mcanahu↓ signifies the same, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiycaAnN. (TA.) [See also 2.]
Oucina [as though originally signifying He had his ear hit or hurt;] he complained, or had a complaint, of his ear; (Ḳ;) said of a man. (TA.)

2. Oc-nhu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOociynN, (Ḳ,) He wrung, or twisted, (Earaka,) his (a boy's, Ṣ) ear: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he struck, (Daraba, TA,) or struck with his finger, or fillipped, (naqara, M, TA,) his ear. (M, TA.) [See also Oacanahu.] They say, (in a prov., TA in art. jwz,) likul-i jaAbihK jawozapN vum-a yuWoc-anu, (M, TA,) i. e. For every one that comes to water is a single watering for his family and his cattle; then his ear is struck, to apprize him that he has nothing more to receive from them: (TA in the present art., and the like is said in the same in art. jwz:) or, † then he is repelled from the water: (TA in art. jwz:) [for Oc-nhu signifies also]

† He repelled him, (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,) namely, a man, (IAạr, T, M,) from drinking, (Ḳ,) and did not give him to drink. (M, Ḳ.) You say also, Oac-inuwA Ean-iI OuwalahaA, [in which the pronoun appears, from the context, to relate to camels,] † Send ye away from me the first ones of them. (En-Naḍr, T.)
Oc-n Aln-aEola, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ,) He put to the sandal what is termed OucunN, q. v. infrà: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and in like manner one says with respect to other things. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Oc-n, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) also signifies He made known, or notified, a thing (biXaIoCK) much; (M, Ḳ;*) he proclaimed, or made proclamation; syn. naAdaI: (Jel in vii. 42, and Bḍ and Jel in xii. 70 and xxii. 28:) Sb says that some of the Arabs make Oac-ana and Mcana↓ to be syn.: but some say that the former signifies he called out publickly; and the latter, i. q. OaEolama [he made to know,, &c.: see 4]. (M, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxii. 28], waOac-ino fiI Aln-aAsi biAlHaj-i (M) And proclaim thou, among the people, the pilgrimage. (Bḍ, Jel.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Oc-n biAlS-alaApi, (Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (M, Ḳ,) or OacaAnN, (Ṣ,) or both, (TA,) or the latter is [properly speaking] a simple subst. [used as an inf. n.], as in the instances of wad-aEa wadaAE-aA and sal-ama salaAmFA and kal-ama kalaAmFA, &c., (Mṣb,) He called to prayer; (M, Ḳ;) he notified, or made known, or proclaimed, [i. e., chanted, from the miYocanap,] the time of prayer; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA;) and Mcana↓ signifies the same, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiycaAnN. (TA.) IB says, the phrase Oac-ana AlEaSoru, with the verb in the act. form, [a phrase commonly obtaining in the present day,] is wrong; the correct expression being Ouc-ina biAlEaSori [The time of the prayer of afternoon was proclaimed, i. e., chanted], with the verb in the pass. form, and with the preposition to connect it with its subject. (Mṣb.)
You say also, Oac-ana biUirosaAli Uibilihi He spoke of sending away his camels. (En-Naḍr, T.)
4. Mcnhu: see 1, last sentence but one.
[Hence, app.,] inf. n. UiycaAnN, † He prevented him, or forbade him; (Ḳ;) and repelled him. (TA.) [See also 2.]
And † It (a thing, M) pleased, or rejoiced, him, (M, Ḳ,) and he therefore listened to it. (M.)

Mcanotuhu, inf. n. UiycaAnN, (T, Mṣb,) in the place of which the subst. OacaAnN is also used, (T,) signifies OaEolamotuhu [I made him to know, or have knowledge; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice: and I made it known, notified it, or announced it]: (T, Mṣb:) and taOac-anotu↓, also, signifies OaEolamotu [as meaning I made to know,, &c.: and I made known,, &c.]. (Mṣb.) You say, Mcnhu biAlOamori, (T, Ḳ,[in the CK, erroneously, Aacanahu,]) or biAlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,) and Mcnhu AlOamora, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiycaAnN, (T,) meaning OaEolamahu [He made him to know, or have knowledge of, the thing; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him of it; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice, of it; made it known, notified it, or announced it, to him]; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also tOc-nhu↓ AlOamora. (M.) So, accord. to one reading, in the Ḳur [ii. 279], faMcinuwA biHarobK mina Qll-ehi Then make ye known, or notify ye, or announce ye, war from God. (M. [For the more common reading, see 1, latter part.]) And so in the Ḳur [vii. 166], waUico taOac-ana↓ rab-uka And when thy Lord made known, or notified, or announced: (Zj, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) or the meaning here is, swore: (M, Ḳ:*) [for] you say, taOac-ana↓ layafoEadana, meaning he swore that he would assuredly do [such a thing]: (M:) Lth says that taOac-anotu↓ laOafoEalan-a kacaA wakacaA signifies the making the action obligatory. (T.) You say also, taOac-ana↓ AlOamiyru fiI Aln-aAsi The commander, or governor, or prince, proclaimed (naAdaI) among the people, with threatening (Ṣ, Ḳ) and prohibition; i. e. taqad-ama and OaEolama. (Ṣ.) And you say of a building that has cracked in its sides, Mcana biQloUinohidaAmi waAls-uquwTi † [It gave notice of becoming a ruin and of falling down]. (Mṣb in art. dEw.) [See also a similar ex. in a verse cited voce OalaA. And hence,] Mcana AlEuXobu [in the CK (erroneously) Aacana] ‡ The herbage began to dry up; part of it being still succulent, and part already dried up. (M, Ḳ, TA.) And Mcana AlHub-u The grain put forth its Oacanap, or leaves. (TA.) See also 2, latter half, in two places.

Mcana and tOc-n↓ are [also] used in one and the same sense [as meaning He knew; had knowledge; or became informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, of a thing]; like as one says Oayoqana and tayaq-ana. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, taOac-ano↓, meaning AiEolamo [Know thou]; like as you say taEal-amo, meaning AiEolamo. (M.)

entry.sense: 5: see 4, in eight places.

10. AstOcnhu He asked, or demanded, of him permission, or leave, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fiI kacaA to do such a thing. (Mṣb.) [You say, AstOcn meaning He asked, or demanded, permission, or leave, to enter, or to come into the presence of another; and to go. And AstOcn fiI Ald-uxuwli Elyh, and, elliptically, AstOcn Elyh, He asked, or demanded, permission, or leave, to go in to him.]
OuconN: see OucunN.

UiconN [is held by some to be an inf. n., like OacayinN↓: (see 1:) by others, to be] a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) signifying Permission; leave; or concession of liberty, to do a thing: and sometimes command: and likewise will; (Mṣb, TA;) as in the phrase biUiconi Qll-ehi by the will of God: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to El-Harállee, the withdrawal, or removal, of prevention or prohibition, and the giving of power or ability, in respect of being and creation: or, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the rescission of prohibition, and concession of freedom of action, to him who has been prohibited by law: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the notification of the allowance or permission of a thing, and of indulgence in respect of it; as in Uil-aA liyuTaAEa biUiconi Qll-ehi, [in the Ḳur iv. 67,] meaning [but that he may be obeyed] by the will of God, and [also] by his command: (TA:) or, as explained in the Ksh, facilitation; an explanation founded upon the opinion that the actions of men are by their own effective power, but facilitated by God; and in this sense, Esh-Shiháb regards it as a metaphor, or a non-metaphorical trope: (MF:) and accommodation; syn. tawofiyqN; (Hr in explanation of a clause of iii. 139 of the Ḳur [which see below];) but Es-Semeen says that this requires consideration. (TA.)

Also Knowledge; syn. EilomN; (T, M, Ḳ;) and so OaciynN↓; (M, Ḳ;) as in the saying faEalahu biUiconiI (T,* M, Ḳ) and biOaciynI↓ (M, Ḳ) [He did it with my knowledge]:
or UiconN has a more particular signification than EilomN, being scarcely ever, or never, used save of that [knowledge] wherein is will, conjoined with command or not conjoined therewith; for in the saying [in the Ḳur iii. 139, referred to above,] wamaA kaAna linafosK Oano tamuwta Uil-aA biUiconi Qll-ehi [And it is not for a soul to die save with the knowledge of God], it is known that there are will and command; and in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 96], wamaA humo biD-aAriyna bihi mino OaHadK Uil-aA bUiconi Qll-ehi [But they do not injure thereby any one save with the knowledge of God], there is will in one respect, for there is no difference of opinion as to the fact that God hath made to exist in man a faculty wherein is the power of injuring another: (Er-Rághib:) but Es-Semeen says that this plea is adduced by Er-Rághib because of his inclining to the persuasion of the Moatezileh. (TA.) You say also, faEalotu kacaA biUiconihi meaning I did thus by his command. (T.)
OacanN: see OacanapN

OucunN and OuconN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter a contraction of the former, [which is the more common,] (Mṣb,) [The ear;] one of the organs of sense; (M, TA;) well known: (M:) of the fem. gender: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also OaciynN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. McaAnN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) its only pl. form: (M:) dim. OucayonapN↓; but when used as a proper name of a man, Oucayonu, though Oucayonapu has been heard. (Ṣ.) You say, jaMCa naAXir-aA Oucunayohi [He came spreading, or, as we say, pricking up, his ears: meaning] ‡ he came in a state of covetousness, or eagerness. (T, Ḳ, TA. [See also naXara.]) And wajadotu fulaAnFA laA bisFA Oucunayohi ‡ I found such a one feigning himself inattentive, or heedless. (T, TA.) And labisotu OucunaI-a lahu ‡ I turned away from him, avoided him, or shunned him: or I feigned myself inattentive, or heedless, to him. (Ḳ, TA. [See also labisa.])

‡ A man who listens to what is said to him: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or a man who hears the speech of every one: (Ṣ:) or who relies upon what is said to him; as also waAbiSapu Als-amoEi: (M in art. wbS:) applied as an epithet to one and to a pl. number, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) alike, (Ṣ, M,) and to two, and to a woman; not being pluralized nor dualized [nor having the fem. form given to it]: (IB:) you say rajulN OuconN (AZ, Ṣ, M) and OuconN, and rijaAlN OucunN and OuconN [&c.]: (AZ, M:) and sometimes it is applied to a man as a name of evil import. (M.) It is said in the Ḳur [ix. 61], wayaquwluwna huwa OucunN qulo Oucunu xayorK lakumo (T, M) And they say, “He is one who hears and believes everything that is said to him:” as though, by reason of the excess of his listening, he were altogether the organ of hearing; like as a spy is termed EayonN; or Oucun is here from Oacina “he listened,” and is like OunufN and XululN in its derivation: (Bḍ:) for among the hypocrites was he who found fault with the Prophet, saying, “If anything be told him from me, I swear to him, and he receives it from me, because he is an Oucun:” (M:) therefore he is commanded to answer, Say, “A hearer of good for you.” (T, M, Bḍ.)
† A sincere, or faithful, adviser of a people, who counsels to obedience: (Mṣb:) a man's intimate, and special, or particular, friend. (TA.)

† A certain appertenance of the heart; (M;) [i. e. either auricle thereof;] OucunaA Alqalobi signifying two appendages (zanamataAni) in the upper part of the heart: (Ḳ:) and ‡ of a naSol [or arrow-head or the like; i. e. either wing thereof]: and ‡ of an arrow; McaAnu Als-ahomi signifying the feathers of the arrow, as AḤn says, when they are attached thereon; and cuw valaAvi McaAnK [a thing having three such feathers] meaning an arrow: all so called by way of comparison: (M:) and † of a sandal; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. e. the part thereof that surrounds the qibaAl [q. v.]: (M:) or OucunaA Aln-aEoli signifies the two parts, [or loops,] of the sandal, to which are tied the EaDudaAni of the XiraAk, [or two branches of the thong that is attached to another thong between two of the toes, which two branches, however, sometimes pass through the OucunaAni, encompassing the heel,] behind the narrow part (xaSor) of the sole. (AO in an anonymous MṢ in my possession. See also xaSorN.)

‡ A handle, (M,) or [a loopshaped, or an ear-shaped, handle, such as is termed] Eurowap, (T, Ḳ,) of anything; (M, Ḳ) as, for instance, (M,) of a kuwz [or mug]; (T, M;) and of a dalow [or bucket]: so called by way of comparison: and in all cases fem.: (M:) pl. as above. (T.)

† What becomes sharp, or pointed, and then falls off, or out, of the plants called Earofaj and vumaAm when they put forth their xuwS [q. v.], or when their xwS become perfect; because it has the shape of an ear. (AḤn, M.)
Uicano, also written UicFA: see art. AcA.

hom.sense: OacanapN The leaves of trees, (En-Naḍr, T,) or of grain. (Ḳ.)
[The kind of leaf called xuwSap of the vumaAm.]
‡ The young ones of camels and of sheep or goats; (En-Naḍr, T, Ḳ;) as being likened to the xuwSap of the vumaAm. (TA.)
A piece of straw: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] OacanN↓ [in the CK OucunN]. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

Appetite, appetency, longing, yearning, or strong desire. (En-Naḍr, T.) You say, hecihi baqolapN tajidu bihaA AlUibilu Oacanapa XadiydapF This is a herb for which the camels feel a strong appetite, &c. (En-Naḍr, T.) And hecaA TaEaAmN laA Oacanapa lahu This is food for the odour of which there is no appetite. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: OacaAnN A making known; a notification; an announcement. (T, Ṣ, Mgh.) [See 4.] So in the Ḳur [ix. 3], waOacaAnN mina Qll-ehi warasuwlihi UilaI Aln-aAsi [And a notification, or an announcement, from God and his apostle to men, or the people]. (T, Mgh.)

Also, and OaciynN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and taOociynN, [the last an inf. n. of 2, and the second a quasi-inf. n. of the same, which see,] (M, Ḳ,) The notification, or announcement, of prayer, and of the time thereof; (T, Ṣ;) the call to prayer. (M, Ḳ.) [The words of this call (which is usually chanted from the miYocanap, or turret of the mosque,) are Aall-ehu Oakobaro (four times) OaXohadu Ono laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-eho (twice) OaXohadu Oan-a muHam-adFA r-asuwlu Qll-ehu (twice) Hay-a EalaI AlS-alaAhN (twice) HaI-a EalaI AlfalaAHo (twice) Aall-ehu OakobarN (twice) laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehN.]

AlOacaAnu also signifies The [notification, or announcement, called] UiqaAmap; (M, Ḳ;) because it is a notification to be present at the performance of the divinelyordained prayers. (TA.) [This (which is chanted in the mosque) consists of the words of the former OacaAn with the addition of qado qaAmati AlS-alaAho pronounced twice after HaIa EalaI AlfalaAHo.]
AlOacaAnaAni signifies The OacaAni [more commonly so called] and the UiqaAmap. (TA.)
OacuwnN [An animal having an ear; as distinguished from SamuwxN, which means “having merely an ear-hole”]. (Mṣb in art. byD.)

hom.sense: OaciynN: see OucunN.
See also UiconN, in three places.
And see OacaAnN.

I. q. muWocinN↓ [Making to know or have knowledge, biOamorK of a thing; informing, apprizing, advertising, or advising; giving information, intelligence, notice, or advice; making known, notifying, or announcing]: like OaliymN and wajiyEN as meaning muWolimN and muwjiEN. (M.)
See also muWac-inN.
Also A place to which the OacaAn [or call to prayer] comes [or reaches] from [or on] every side. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OucayonapN dim. of OucunN, q. v. (Ṣ.)

OucaAniI-N (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and Mcanu↓ (M, Ḳ) Largeeared; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) long-eared; (M;) applied to a man, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and to a camel, and to a sheep or goat: (M:) [or] the latter epithet is applied to a ram; and its fem. OaconaMCu to a ewe. (T, Ṣ, M.)
OucayoniI-N One who hears everything that is said: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.) [See OucunN.]
Mcanu: see OucaAniI-N.
McinN [act. part. n. of 1. As such, Permitting, or allowing; one who permits, or allows. And hence,] A doorkeeper, or chamberlain. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also OaciynN.
muWocanN: see maOocuwnN.

hom.sense: muWocinN: see OaciynN. You say, siymaAhu biAlxayori muWocinapN His impress notifies [or is indicative of] goodness. (TA.)
muWocinaAtN, signifying The women who notify, or announce, the times of festivity and rejoicing, [particularly on the occasions of weddings,] is a vulgar word. (TA.)
Herbage beginning to dry up; part of it being still succulent, and part already dried up: and a branch, or wood, that has dried, but has in it some succulency. (TA.)

entry.sense: maOocanapN: see what next follows.
muWocanapN: see what next follows.

miYocanapN (which may also be pronounced miycanapN, Mṣb) The place [generally a turret of a mosque] upon which the time of prayer is notified, made known, or proclaimed; (T, M,* Ḳ;*) i. q. manaArapN [which has this meaning and others also]; (AZ, T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also muWocanapN↓: (AZ, T:) or it signifies, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or signifies also, (as in other copies of the same,) i. q. manaArapN: and SawomaEapN: [see these two words:] (Ḳ:) or i. q. manaArapN, meaning SawomaEapN; (Lḥ, M, TA;) by way of comparison [to the turret first mentioned]: but as to maOocanapN↓, it is a vulgar word: (TA:) the pl. is maMcinu, agreeably with the original form of the sing. (Mṣb.)
muWac-inN One who notifies, makes known, or proclaims, [by a chant,] the time of prayer; (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) [i. e., who chants the call to prayer;] as also OaciynN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: maOocuwnN, as meaning A slave permitted, or having leave given him, by his master, to traffic, is used for maOocuwnN lahu, (Mṣb, TA,) by the lawyers. (Mṣb.)
Also Having his ear hit, or hurt; and so muWocanN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. OaciIa, aor. _a {yaOocaIu}, inf. n. OacFI, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ written OacFA, and so by IB, (TA,) and OacaMCN, (CK, [but not found by me in any MṢ. copy of the Ḳ nor in any other lexicon,]) and, accord. to IB, OacaApN and Oaciy-apN, (TA,) or these two are simple substs.; (M, Ḳ;) and tOc-I↓; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [He was, or became, annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt;] he experienced, or suffered, slight evil, [i. e., annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt,] less than what is termed Darar; (El-Khaṭṭábee;) or he experienced, or suffered, what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a small degree; (Ḳ;) bihi [by him, or it]; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) [and minohu from him, or it:] Alt-aOac-iI↓ signifies the being affected by what is termed AlOacaI [i. e. what annoys, molests, harms, or hurts, one]: and also the showing the effect thereof; which is forbidden by the saying of ʼOmar, Uiy-aAka waAlt-aOac-iI↓ biAln-aAsi [Avoid thou, or beware thou of, showing the being annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, by men]; for this is what is within one's power. (Mgh.)
Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, It (a thing) was unclean, dirty, or filthy. (Mṣb.)
4. McI signifies faEala AlOacaI [He did what annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt]. (M, Ḳ.)

And McaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yuWociyhi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. UiycaMCN (T, IB, Mṣb) and [quasi-inf. n.] Oaciy-apN, (T,) or Oac-aI and OacaApN and Oaciy-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but IB refuses his assent to this, saying that these three are inf. ns. of OaciIa, and MF says of UiycaMCN, which is expressly disallowed by the author of the Ḳ, though he himself uses it, that others assert it to have been heard and transmitted, and to be required by rule, but he adds that he had searched for examples of it in the language of the Arabs, and investigated their prose and their poetry, without finding this word; (TA;) [He, or it, annoyed him, molested him, harmed him, or hurt him; or] he did what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, to him. (Bḍ in xxxiii. 53, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 47], wadaEo OacaAhumo, meaning And leave thou the requiting of them until thou receive a command respecting them; (M, Bḍ, Jel;) namely, the hypocrites: (M:) or leave thou unregarded their doing to thee what is [annoying, molesting, harmful, hurtful, or] disagreeable,, &c., to thee. (Bḍ.)
5: see 1, in three places.
Oac-aI inf. n. of 1. (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [As a simple subst., A state of annoyance or molestation.]
And [Annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: quasi-] inf. n. of McaAhu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

It signifies also, [like Oaciy-apN↓ and OacaApN↓,] kul-u maA taOoc-ayota [Anything by which thou art annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt]; (T;) or maA yuWociyka [a thing that annoys, molests, harms, or hurts thee]: (Mgh:) or a slight evil; less than what is termed Darar. (El-Khaṭṭábee.) You say, OamaATa AlOacaI Eani AlT-ariyqi He removed, or put away, or put at a distance, what was hurtful from the road, or way. (Mgh and TA in art. myT.)
Also A thing held to be unclean, dirty, or filthy: so in the Ḳur ii. 222. (Mgh, Mṣb.) [Filth; impurity: often used in this sense in books on practical law.]

OacK Experiencing, or suffering, [annoyance, molestation, harm, hurt, or] what is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, (M,* Ḳ,* Mṣb,) in a great, or vehement, degree; (M, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (M, Mṣb;) as also OaciI-N↓: (M, Ḳ:) and both signify the contr.; i. e. doing what is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, in a great, or vehement, degree. (Ḳ.)

Also, applied to a camel, That will not remain still in one place, by reason of a natural disposition, not from pain, (El-Umawee, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) nor disease; (Ḳ;) as also OacI-N↓: (M:) fem. of the former OaciyapN; (El-Umawee, &c.;) and of the latter Oaciy-apN↓. (TA.)
UicaA and UicFA: see art. AcA.
OacaApN an inf. n. of 1. (IB.)
And [quasi-] inf. n. of McaAhu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also Oac-aI and Oaciy-apN.
Oaciy-N, and Oaciy-apN as its fem.: see OacK, in three places.
Oaciy-apN an inf. n. of 1. (IB.)
And [quasi-] inf. n. of McaAhu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And a subst. from McaAhu; (Mṣb;) or, as also OacaApN↓, a subst. from OaciIa and taOac-aI; (M, Ḳ;) signifying A thing that is disagreeable, or hateful, or evil, in a small degree. (Ḳ.) See also OacFI.

MciI-N, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) with medd and teshdeed, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AaciI-,]) Waves (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of the sea: (Ṣ:) or vehement waves: (TA:) or the OaTobaAq [app. meaning rollers, because they fall over like folds,] which the wind raises from the surface of the water, less than (duwna [but this sometimes signifies above]) what are termed mawoj: (ISh, TA:) pl. OawaAciI-u. (Ṣ.)
1. Oar-ahaA, aor. yaWur-u (Ṣ,) inf. n. Oar-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Inivit eam; he compressed her. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Uir-a Uir-a, (M, TT, L, [and so in the present day,]) or Oaro Oaro, (Ḳ,) A cry by which sheep or goats are called. (M, L, Ḳ.)

miYar-N A man (Ṣ,) much addicted to venery: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so accord. to AʼObeyd, as related by Sh and El-Iyádee, but thought by Az to be maYiyrN, of the same measure as maEiyrN, i. e., mafoEilN, [originally maOoyirN,] from MrahaA. (T.)

hom.sense: 1. Oaruba, aor. _u {yaOorubu}, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaraAbapN (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and UirabN, like SigarN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was, or became, cunning, characterized by intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligent, excellent in judgment, sagacious, (T, [in which it is said that Aṣ is related to have assigned this signification to Oariba, aor. _a {yaOorabu}, inf. n. OarabN,] S, M, Ḳ,) and knowing in affairs. (M.) [The TA assigns the former inf. n. to it when it signifies simply intelligence, and the latter when it has the more comprehensive signification of cunning.]

Oariba biAlX-aIoCi, [aor. _a {yaOorabu},] He became expert, or skilful, in the thing: (M:) or he became accustomed to, or practised or exercised in, the thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and became knowing, or skilful [therein]. (Ṣ.)
Oariba, inf. n. OarabN, is also syn. with Oanisa [app. as meaning He became familiar with a person or thing]. (M.)
And Oariba biAlX-aIoCi also signifies He devoted, or addicted, himself, or clave, or kept, to the thing: (T, Ḳ:) and he was, or became, niggardly, avaricious, or tenacious, of the thing. (T, M, TA.)

And Oariba fiI AlOamori, and tOr-b↓ fiyhi, He exerted, or employed, his power and ability in the affair, and understood it: (ISh, T:) or tOr-b signifies he exerted his strength, force, or energy; or strained himself; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M;) fiI AlX-aIoCi [in the thing]; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and fiI HaAjatihi [in his needful affair, or in the accomplishment of his want]. (Aṣ, Ṣ, M.)
Oariba Ealayohi He had, or obtained, power over him, or it. (M.)

Oariba, aor. _a {yaOorabu}, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. OarabN, (T, Ṣ,) He was, or became, in want, or need. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See Oaribota Eano ciI yadayoka, and two other phrases following it, in a later part of this paragraph.]
Oariba Uilayohi, (M, Mṣb,) or bihi (T,) aor. and inf. n. as above, He wanted it; was, or became, in want, or need, of it; (T, M, Mṣb;) and sought it, or desired it; (T;) namely, a thing. (T, Mṣb.)

Oariba Ald-ahoru Fortune was, or became, hard, or adverse: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) as though it wanted something of us, for which it pressed hard. (M, TA.) And Oariba Ealayohi He was, or became, hard upon him in his demand. (TA, from a trad.)
Oarabahu, [from UirabN,] He struck upon a member, or limb, belonging to him. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Oariba, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) His member, or limb, (generally meaning the arm, or hand, M,) was cut off: (M, Ḳ:) or dropped off: (T:) and his members, or limbs, (generally relating to [the members, or fingers, of] the arm, or hand, TA,) dropped off, one after another, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in consequence of his being affected by the disease termed jucaAm: (TA:) and it (said of a member, or limb,) dropped off. (TA.) The phrase, Oaribota Eano ciI yadayoka, (T, TA,) or mino cI ydyk, (Ṣ, TA, [and said in the latter to be likewise found in the T, but I have consulted two copies of the T and found only En,]) or fiI cI ydyk, (IAạr, as related by Sh,) or mino yadayoka, (Ḳ,) but MF says that mn in this phrase is a mistranscription, (TA,) means, May the members [or fingers] of thy hands, or arms, drop off: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or it means, may what is in thy hands depart from thee, so that thou shalt be in want: occurring in a trad. (IAạr, T, TA.) And Oariba maA lahu, said by Moḥammad on the occasion of a man's coming to him and asking him to acquaint him with some work that should introduce him into Paradise, means, accord. to Ḳṭ, May his members, or limbs, drop off, or be cut off: what aileth him? (TA:) or, accord. to IAạr, may he become in want: what aileth him? (T, TA:) but IAth says that this has been related in three different ways: first, Oariba, signifying an imprecation, [as rendered above,] and used as expressive of wonder: secondly, OarabN↓ m-aA lahu; i. e. HaAjapN lahu; maA being [syntactically] redundant, denoting littleness; the meaning being, he has some little want: or, as some say, a want hath brought him: what aileth him? thirdly, OaribN↓; i. e. huwa OaribN; meaning he is intelligent, or sagacious, or skilful, [as is said in the T,] and perfect: what aileth him? or what is his affair? the inchoative being suppressed. (TA.) maA lahu Oaribato yaduhu, (M, Ḳ,*) another form of imprecation, (M,) means What aileth him? may his arm, or hand, be cut off: or, may he become poor, and want what is in the hands of others. (M, Ḳ.*)
[Hence, perhaps,] Oaribato maEidatuhu His stomach became vitiated, disordered, or in an unsound state. (Ḳ.)
Oariba also signifies He prostrated himself firmly, or fixedly, upon his [seven] members [mentioned in the explanations of the word UirobN]. (T.)

2. Or-b, inf. n. taOriybN, He, or it, [made, or rendered, cunning, or intelligent, excellent in judgment, sagacious, and knowing in affairs; (see Oaruba;)] made to have knowledge, or skill; or made to understand. (M, TA.)
He was, or became, avaricious; [in a state of vehement want of a thing;] eagerly desirous. (AʼObeyd, TA.) [See also 1.]
He cut up, or cut into pieces, (T, A, Mgh,) a sheep, or goat, (A, Mgh,) limb by limb. (T, A, Mgh.)
He cut off a member, or limb, entire. (M, TA.)
He made entire, or complete, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ,) a lot, or portion, (T, TA,) or anything. (M.)

entry.sense: 3. Mrbhu, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. muWaArabapN, (M, A,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, him; syn. daAhaAhu. (Ṣ, M,* A.*) It is said in a trad., (TA,) muWaArabapu AlOariybi jaholN waEanaMCN [The striving to outwit the cunning, or intelligent, or sagacious, is ignorance, and labour without profit]: (A, TA:) i. e., the intelligent is not to be outwitted. (TA.) And Mrb bihi signifies He practised an artifice, a stratagem, or a fraud, upon him. (TA, from a trad.)
4. Mrb Ealayohimo, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of the measure OafoEala, (T,) inf. n. UiyraAbN [originally UiYoraAbN], (Ḳ,) He was successful against them, and overcame them. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

5. tOr-b He affected, or endeavoured to acquire, (takal-afa,) cunning, or intelligence, and excellence of judgment, (Ḳ, TA,) and deceit, guile, or artifice, and wickedness, mischievousness, or malignity. (TA.) [See UirobN.]
tOr-b fiI AlOamori: see 1.
OarobN: see what next follows, in two places.

hom.sense: UirobN Cunning, intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligence, excellence of judgment, sagacity, (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) and knowledge in affairs; (M, L;) as also UirobapN↓ and OurobapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and OarabN↓, (M, A,) or OarobN↓. (L.) You say, huwa cuw UirobK [He is a possessor of cunning, or intelligence,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
Intelligence and religion. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
Deceit, guile, artifice, or fraud; syn. makorN: so in the L and other lexicons: in the Ḳ, nukorN [i. e. “cunning,”, &c., as above]: (TA:) and so UirobapN↓; syn. HiylapN. (Ḳ.)
Wickedness, mischievousness, or malignity; hidden rancour, malevolence, or malice. (Ḳ, TA.) [In a trad. it occurs in this sense written, in the TA, Oarob↓.]
See also OarabN, in four places.

Also A member; a distinct and complete part of an animal body; a limb; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or such as is made complete, or entire, not wanting anything: (M:) pl. MraAbN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb) and OaroMbN; (Ṣ, Mgh;) the latter formed by transposition. (Mgh.) You say, qaT-aEotuhu UirobFA UirobFA I cut him up, member by member, or limb by limb. (TA.) And Als-ujuwdu EalaI saboEapi MraAbK or OaroMbK Prostration [in prayer] is [performed] on seven members; (Ṣ, Mgh;) namely, the. forehead, the hands, the knees, and the feet. (TA.)

Also The membrum genitale; the pudendum; syn. farojN: (M, Ḳ:) but some say that this signification is not known: [see OarabN:] in some copies of the Ḳ, the explanation is written faraHN, with the unpointed H. (TA.)
MraAbN [the pl.] also signifies Pieces of flesh, or of flesh-meat. (M.)
OarabN: see UirobN.

Want, or need; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also UirobN↓ and UrobapN↓ (the same, and A) and OurobapN↓ (Ḳ) and maOorabapN↓ and maOorubapN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maOoribapN↓ (Ḳ) and maOorabN↓: (M, A:) the pl. [of OarabN or UirobN] is MraAbN, and [of UirobapN, and perhaps of the other sings. commencing with A] UirabN; (M;) and the pl. of mOrbp is maMribu. (T, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., respecting Moḥammad, kaAna Oamolakakumo lArbh He had the most power, of you, over his want, and desire: (M,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* TA:) IAth says that the most common reading is liOarabihi, meaning liHaAjatihi: but some read liAorbihi↓, [as in the M and Mgh,] i. e., either the same as above, [and so in the Mgh,] or liEuDowihi, by which is specially meant the membrum genitale: (TA:) but this is not known. (M.) Respecting the phrase Oaraba m-aA lahu, see 1. You say also, maA Uirobuka↓ OilaI hecaA What is [the reason of] thy want of this? (A.) And maA liI fiyhi UirbN↓ I have no want of it. (A.) By gayori OuwliI AlOarobapi↓, in the Ḳur [xxiv. 31], are meant Idiots; or persons deficient in intellect: [from UirobapN as meaning “intelligence:”] (Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr, Ṣ:) or not such as have need of women. (Jel.) maOarabapN↓ laA HafaAwapN, (Ṣ, A,) or maOorabN↓ laA HafaAwapN, (M,) is a proverb, (Ṣ, A,) meaning He only honours thee for the sake of something which he wants of thee; not for love of thee: (A, Meyd:) or only thy want brought thee; not the object of paying extraordinary honour to me. (M.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 690.] You say also, OaloHiqo bimaOorabika↓ mina AlOaroDi, meaning, Go thou whither thou wilt; [so as to attain thy want]. (A.)
OaribN: see OariybN.

Also [Expert; skilful: (see Oariba, of which it is the part. n.:) or] accustomed to, or practised or exercised in, a thing, and knowing, or skilful. (Ṣ, TA.) See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.
OaribN biXaIo CK, [or UilaI XaIoCK, (see Oariba,)] or MribN↓, of the measure faAEilN, (Mṣb,) Wanting, needing, or desiring, a thing. (Mṣb,* TA in art. mhr, &c.)
OurobapN: see UirobN:
and OarabN.
UirobapN: see UirobN, in two places:
and OarabN, in two places.

entry.sense: OurabaI Calamity; misfortune: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) [said to be] the only word of this measure except OuramaI and XuEabaI [names of two places]. (TA.)
OurobaAnN (M, Ḳ): dial. var. of EurobaAnN.
OurobuwnN (TA): dial. var. of EurobuwnN.
OarabuwnN (TA): dial. var. of EarabuwnN.

hom.sense: OariybN Cunning, characterized by intelligence with craft and forecast, or simply intelligent [as in the Ṣ], excellent in judgment, sagacious, (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,) and knowing in affairs; (M;) as also OaribN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former OarabaMCu. (T, M.)
qidorN OariybapN A wide, an ample, or a capacious, cooking-pot. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Mrabu More, or most, cunning, or intelligent, excellent in judgment, or sagacious. (A.) [See OariybN.]
MribN: see OaribN.
maOorabN: see OarabN, in three places.
maOorabapN and maOorubapN and maOoribapN: see OarabN, in four places.

muWar-abN A member, or limb, cut off entire: (T:)
or an entire, unbroken, member, or limb: (Ṣ:) and anything made entire, complete, or perfect. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, katifN muWar-abapN A shoulder cut off entire, (Mgh, TA,) having none of its flesh taken from it, (Mgh,) without any deficiency. (TA.)
1. Oarava: see 2.

2. Or-v, (M, A,) inf. n. taOoriyvN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He kindled, or lighted, a fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also Oarava↓, aor. _u {yaOoruvu}, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. OarovN; (Ḳ; in a copy of the A UirovN;) but this [says SM] no leading lexicographer has mentioned, nor have I found any example of it. (TA.) [See also war-ava.]

[Hence,] tOryv also signifies ‡ The exciting discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between a people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Orav bayona Alqawomi, (M, A,) and Or-v bayonahumu AlX-ar-a waAlHaroba, (T, TA,) ‡ He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people, or company of men; (T, M, A;) kindled the fire of discord, dissension,, &c., [or evil, and war,] between them, or among them. (T,* TA.)
5. taOar-avati Aln-aAru The fire became kindled, or lighted; or it burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
UirovN, originally wirovN, (T, Ṣ,) Inheritance; or a person's obtaining possession of property left to him by one who has died. (MF.)
An inheritance, or a heritage; what is inherited. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

An old condition, case, or state of things, which the last has inherited from the first. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) So in the phrase, huwa EalaI UirovK mino kacaA [He is conforming, in respect of such a thing, with an old state of things, or an old usage, which he has inherited from his ancestors]. (Ṣ.) And in the following ex., from a trad., Uin-akumo EalaI UirovK mino Uirovi Oabiykumo UiboraAhiyma [Verily ye are conforming with an old state of things, or an old usage, which ye have inherited from your father Abraham], the meaning is, that his religion was their heritage. (T,* TA.) [See also wirovN.]
A remainder, or what remains, (M, L, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ḳ,) or of the original of a thing: (M, L:) pl. UiraAvN. (L.)
And [hence, app.,] Ashes. (M, Ḳ.)

Also Origin, race, or stock. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) You say, huwa fiI Uirovi SidoqK He is of an excellent origin, race, or stock. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lafiI Uirovi majodK [Verily he is of a glorious origin, race, or stock]; as also Uirofi majodK, by a change of letters. (Yaạḳoob, M.) Accord. to IAạr, UirovN relates to Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour, on account of one's ancestors' or one's own deeds or qualities, &c.]; and wirovN, to property, or wealth. (M.) [See art. wrv.]
OurovapN: see UiraAtN, in three places.

UiraAvN Fire; (T, M, L, Ḳ;) as also UiraAvapN↓ and OariyvN↓: (TA:) or (so accord. to the M and L, but in the Ḳ “and”) tinder, and the like, prepared for fire; (M, L, Ḳ;) [as also UiraAvapN↓ and OurovapN↓; or these two words signify a means of kindling or inflaming; as will be seen from what follows:] or a lump of the dung of a horse or the like, or a similar thing, with which one kindles a fire; as also OurovapN↓: (A:) or this last signifies dung of camels or horses or the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or wood, or a stick, (T,) that is prepared, or put in readiness, by the ashes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or buried in them, (T,) for the time when it may be wanted (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) for fuel. (T.) It is said in a prov., mentioned in the collection of Meyd, Aln-amiymapu↓ AlEadaAwapi [Calumny, or slander, is a means of kindling, or inflaming, enmity]. (TA: but in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 773, in the place of ArAvp, we find Ourovap↓.)
OariyvN: see the paragraph next preceding.
UiraAvapN: see UiraAvN, in three places.

hom.sense: 1. Oarija, aor. _a {yaOoraju}, inf. n. OarajN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OariyjN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and OariyjapN, (Ḳ, [in which it is only mentioned as syn. with the first and second of these ns., so that it may be a simple subst.,]) It (perfume) diffused, or exhaled, its odour; (Ṣ, A;) as also tMr-j↓: (A:) it had a hot, or strong, odour; syn. tawah-aja riyHuhu. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
It (a place) was, or became, strongly fragrant. (Mṣb.)
Oaraja: see 2, in three places.

entry.sense: 2. Or-j, [and app. Oaraja↓ also,] He perfumed a thing; made it fragrant. (Ḥam p. 135.)
[Both also app. signify He made perfume to diffuse, or exhale, its odour: or made it to have a hot, or strong, odour.]

[And hence,] Or-j, inf. n. taOoriyjN; (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oaraja↓, (TA,) aor. _u {yaOoruju}, (TḲ,) inf. n. OarojN; (Ḳ, TA;) † He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or company of men, like Oar-aXa, (Ṣ, TA,) and fiI AlHarobi in war. (TA.) And Or-j AlHaroba, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, and Ḥam ubi suprà,) and OarajahaA↓, (TA,) † He kindled war, or the war; (Ṣ, TA, and Ḥam ubi suprà;) and in like manner, Aln-aAra the fire. (IAạr, Ḥam.)
5: see 1.
OarajN (L) and OariyjN↓ and OariyjapN↓ (ISd, TA) A sweet odour: (ISd, L, TA:) pl. of the last, OaraAYiju. (ISd, TA.) [See also 1.]
OarijN Perfume diffusing, or exhaling, its odour: having a hot, or strong, odour. (TA.)
Applied also to a place: you say, makaAnN OarijN A strongly fragrant place: (Mṣb:) and bayotN OarijN biAl-iybi [a house, or chamber, fragrant, or strongly fragrant, with perfume]. (A.)
OariyjN: see OarajN.
OariyjapN: see OarajN.
Oar-aAjN (Ḳ) and miYorajN↓ (TA) † A liar: and one who excites discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, among people. (Ḳ,* TA.)
miYorajN: see what next precedes.
AlmuWar-aju † The lion. (Ḳ.)
1. Oaraxa AlkitaAba: see 2.

2. Oar-axa AlkitaAba, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoriyxN; (Ṣ, Mgh;) and Oaraxahu↓, (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaroxN; (TA;) but the former is the more common, (Mṣb,) and the latter is by some rejected, though correct accord. to IḲṭṭ and others; (MF;) and Mrxhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muWaAraxapN; (TA;) as also war-axahu, inf. n. taworiyxN; (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb;) in which the w is a substitute for the C; (Yaạḳoob, Mṣb;) a form seldom used; (Mṣb;) He dated the writing, or letter; inscribed it with a date, or note of the time when it was written.
