MsaAsN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UisaAsN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OususN; (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the first of which is pl. of Ous-N, (Mgh, Mṣb,) like as OaqofaAlN is of qufolN; (Mṣb;) or of OasasN, like as OasobaAbN is of sababN; (Ṣ;) or, as some say, of OususN, [like as OaEonaAqN is of EunuqN,] so that it is a pl. pl.; (TA;) and the second, of Oas-N, like as EisaAsN is of Eus-N; (Mṣb;) and the third, of OasaAsN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) like as EunuqN is of EanaAqN. (Mṣb.) You say, banaI bayotahu EalaI OasaAsihi↓ AlOaw-ali [He built his house upon its first foundation.] (A.) And qalaEahu mino Ous-ihi [He uprooted it from its foundation]. (A.) And fulaAnN OasaAsu↓ Oamorihi Alkacibu ‡ [Such a one, the foundation of his affair, or case, is falsehood]. (A, TA.) And kaAna celaka EalaI Ous-i Ald-ahori, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and Oasihi↓, and Uisihi↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) ‡ That was in old, or ancient, time; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) at the beginning of time; (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ;) and in like manner, EalaI Qsoti Ald-ahori. (A.)

Also A remain, relic, trace, vestige, sign, mark, or track, of anything. (Ḳ.) You say, xuco Ous-a AlT-ariyqi, or Oas-a↓ AlT-ariyqi, [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, meaning, Take thou to the track of the way,] when one guides himself by any mark or track, or by camels' dung: but when the way is manifest, you say, xuco Xaraka AlT-ariyqi. (Ḳ.) Ous-N also signifies The remains of ashes (M, Ḳ) between the OavaAfiI, q.v.: (M:) occurring in a verse of En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee; but accord. to most relates of this verse, it is MsN. (TA.)
Uis-N: see Ous-N, in several places.
OasasN: see Ous-N, in several places.
OasaAsN: see Ous-N, in several places.
OasiysN: see Ous-N, in several places.
4. Msbt AlOaroDu The land produced [herbage such as is termed] EuXob; syn. OaEoXabat. (Ḳ.)

UisobN The hair of the pubes: (M, Ḳ:) or of the pudendum: (Th, M, Ḳ:) or of the podex: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it may be, (Ṣ,) or is said to be, (M,) from wisobN, (Ṣ, M,) which signifies “herbage,” or “plants,” (Ṣ,) or “abundance of herbage:” (M:) the w being changed into C, as in the case of Uirotq and wirovN: (Ṣ:) pl. OusuwbN, and, accord. to IJ, MsaAbN. (M.)
muWas-abN A ram having much wool. (M, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Aisotu Ald-ahori ‡ The first, or beginning, of time; (A;) old, or ancient, time. (IB, A,* Ḳ.*) One says, maA zaAla EalaI Qsoti Ald-ahori majonuwnFA ‡ [He ceased not, or has not ceased, from the beginning of time, or from old time, to be insane, or mad; or] he always was, or always has been, known as being insane, or mad: like as one says, EalaI Uis-i Ald-ahori. (AZ, Ṣ.) And Aboo-Nukheyleh says,
maA zaAla muco kaAna EalaI Q soti Ald-ahori
caA HumuqK yanomiI waEaqolK yaHorXI
‡ [He ceased not, or has not ceased, to be, since he was in the beginning of time, or in old time, i. e., from the first of his existence, a person of increasing foolishness, and of decreasing intellect]. (AZ, Ṣ.) IB says, J has erred in mentioning Ast in this section [of the Ṣ]; its proper place being in art. sth, where he has also mentioned it; for its hemzeh is conjunctive, by common consent; and if conjunctive, it is augmentative: also, his saying that they have changed the [final] s in Uis-N into t, like as they have changed the [final] s of Tas-N into t, making this word TasotN, is a mistake; for, were it so, the hemzeh of Ast would be disjunctive [in every case; whereas it is always conjunctive except after a pause, when it is pronounced with kesr]: moreover, he has attributed this assertion to AZ, who never made it, but only mentioned Ast Aldhr with As- Aldhr because of their agreement in meaning. (TA.)
[Hence also,] Aisotu Alkalobapi † Calamity, or misfortune: (Ḳ:) adversity; difficulty; distress; affliction: (TA:) what is hated, disliked, disapproved, foul, abominable, or evil. (Ḳ.)
And Aisotu Almatoni † The desert: (Ḳ:) or the wide desert. (TA.)
See also art. sth.
OusotiI-N The warp of cloth; (Ḳ;) as also OusodiI-N and OuzodiI-N: (TA:) but it is improperly mentioned in this art.; for it is [originally OusotuwIN,] of the measure OufoEuwlN. (Ḳ.)
AisotiI-N Of, or relating to, the Aisot. (TA in art. sth.)

OusotaAcN a foreign word, pronounced to be such because s and c do not occur in any one Arabic word, (Mṣb,) not found in the poetry of the pagan times, (Ibn-Diḥyeh in TA art. stc,) nor in the language of those times, (Shifá el-Ghaleel, ibid.,) [arabicized from the Persian OusotaAdo,] A master: (MF:) a skilful man, who is held in high estimation: (Mṣb:) a preceptor; a tutor; a teacher: a craftmaster: (Ibn-Diḥyeh; and Golius on the authority of Meyd:) [and so in the present day; as also OusotaA and OusoTaA:] also applied by the vulgar to a eunuch; because he generally tutors children: (Shifá el-Ghaleel, and Ibn-Diḥyeh:) pl. OusotaAcuwna (Ḥar p. 377) [and OasaAtiycu and OasaAticapN; and vulgarly, in the present day, OusotawaAtN and OusoTawaAtN].
UisotaboraqN: see art. brq, in which, and in art. srq, it is mentioned: but this is its proper place, if it be an arabicized word: in the T it is mentioned in art. stbrq.

hom.sense:
1. Oasida, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOosadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OasadN, (TA,) ‡ He (a man, M) was, or became, like a lion, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) in his boldness, (A,) and his other dispositions; (Ṣ, A, TA;)
as also AstOsd↓; (M, A, Ḳ;) [and tOs-d↓; (see OasidN;)] Ealayohi towards him, or against him. (A.) You say OasadN bay-inu AlOasadi [A lion bearing evidence of being like a lion in boldness]: an extr. phrase, like Hiq-apN bayin-apN AlH-iqapi; (TA;) which is [said to be] the only other instance of the kind. (TA in art. Hq.) [Hence the saying,] UicaA daxala fahida waUicaA xaraja Oasida ‡ [When he comes in, he is like a lynx; and when he goes out, he is like a lion: see fahida]. (Ṣ, from a trad.) You say also, Oasida Ealayohi meaning † He became emboldened against him; (TA;) as also AstOsd↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And † He was, or became, angry with him: (M, L, Ḳ:*) or (so accord. to the M and L, but in the Ḳ, “and,”) behaved in a light and hasty manner, or foolishly, or ignorantly, towards him. (M, L, Ḳ.*)
Oasida, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) also signifies † He (a man, Ṣ) became stupified (Ṣ, Ḳ) by fear (Ṣ) at seeing a lion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Thus it has two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)

Oasada, aor. _i {yaOosidu}, i. q. sabaEa [† He bit another with his teeth, like as does the beast of prey: or he reviled, vilified, or vituperated, another; charged him with a vice or fault or the like; or assailed him with foul language, such as displeased him]. (Ḳ.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. Msdhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or Msdhu biAlS-ayodi, (A,) inf. n. UiysaAdN; (TA;) and Awsdhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the O [i. e. the second O, for Msdhu is originally OaOosdhu,] is changed into w; (Ṣ;) and Osd-hu↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He incited him (namely a dog) to the chase. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

Msd bayona AlkilaAbi ‡ He incited the dogs to attack one another. (A.) And Msd bayona Alqawomi, (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. UiysaAdN; (Mṣb;) or Oasada↓, aor. _i {yaOosidu}; (Ḳ;) ‡ He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people, or company of men. (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Msd Als-ayora He journeyed with energy; syn. OasoOadahu; (IJ, M;) from which it is probably formed by transposition. (M.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

hom.sense: 10. AstOsd He called a lion. (M.)
See 1, in two places.
† He became accustomed, or habituated, [to a thing, as a dog to the chase,] and emboldened; syn. DariIa (Mṣb.)

‡ It (a plant, or herbage,) became strong, and tangled, or luxuriant: (Ṣ:) or became tall and large: or grew to its utmost height: (M:) or attained its full growth, and became tangled, or luxuriant, (M,) and strong: (TA:) or became tall, and dry (jaf-a [perhaps a mistake for Ailotaf-a, as in the Ṣ and M,]) and large, (A, TA,) and spread every way: (A:) or became tall, and attained its full growth. (Ḳ.)
Ausotuwsida (Ḳ, TA, [or AusotuWosida,] in the CK Asotawosada) † He (a man, TA) was, or became, excited, roused, provoked, (huy-ija, Ḳ, TA, in the CK hay-aja,) or incited. (TA.)

entry.sense: OasadN [The lion;] a certain beast of prey, (M, TA,) well known: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) IKh and others have mentioned more than five hundred names for it; and it is said to have a thousand names [in the Arabic language; but these, with few exceptions, are epithets used as substs.]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] MsudN (Ṣ, Ḳ [in the TA with two hemzehs, OaOosudN, which is the original form, but deviating from the regular pronunciation,]) and MsaAdN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] OusuwdN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OusudN (Ṣ) and OusodN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last two of which are contractions of the form next preceding them, (Ṣ) and OusodaAnN (Ḳ) and maOosadapN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last called by some a pl., but [rightly] said by others to be a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) the female is called OasadapN; (AZ, Ks, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or OasadN is applied to the male and the female, and sometimes the female is called OasadapN. (Mṣb.)
laqiytu minohu OasadFA is a phrase [meaning I found him to be a man of exceeding boldness; being] expressive of an intensive degree of boldness. (Mughnee in art. b.)
AlOasadu † The constellation Leo. (Ḳzw, &c.) [See Alc-iraAEu.]
And † The star Cor Leonis, or Regulus. (Ḳzw, &c.) [See Aljabohapu.]

OasidN ‡ [Like a lion;] bold; daring; as also OasiydN↓ and mutaOas-idN↓ [and musotaOosidN↓ (see 10)]. (Mṣb.) You say OasadN OasidN [A bold, or fierce, lion], adding the latter word to give intensiveness of signification. (IAạr, M.)
[Its fem.] OasidapN [app. applied to a bitch] signifies † Accustomed, or habituated, [to the chase,] and emboldened; syn. DaAriyapN. (Ḳ, TA, in the CK SAriyap.) [See also 10.]

hom.sense: OasidapN A [kind of enclosure for the protection of camels, sheep, or goats, such as is called] HaZiyrpa. (Ḳ.) [Like OaSiydapN.]
[See also OasidN, of which it is the fem.]

entry.sense: OusodiI-N, with damm, (IB, Ḳ,) thus correctly written, (IB,) in the L [and Ṣ] OasodiI-N, (TA,) A kind of garments or cloths (viyaAbN, Ṣ, for which is put, in the Ḳ, erroneously, nabaAtN, TA): occurring in a poem of El-Hoteiäh, (Ṣ,) who likens thereto an extensive, even, waterless desert. (L.) IB says that he is in error who mentions it in the present art.: Aboo-ʼAlee says that OusodiI-N and OusotiI-N are quasi-pls. of sad-aI and satFI as signifying vawobN masodiI-N, and originally OusoduwIN and OusotuwIN; like as OumoEuwzN is a quasi- pl. of maEozN. (L.) [But see art. sdw and sdI.]
OasiydN: see OasidN.
UisaAdapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OusaAdapN (Ḳ) i. q. wisaAdapN [A pillow,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like UiXaAHN for wiXaAHN. (TA.)
muWosidN ‡ One who trains a dog, or dogs, to the chase. (L, Mṣb.)
maOosadapN A place in which are lions: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or OaroDN maOosadapN a land having lions in it: (Ṣ, A:) or a land abounding with lions: (M, R:) pl. maMsidu. (A.)
See also OasadN.
mutaOas-idN: see OasidN.
musotaOosidN: see OasidN.

1. Oasarahu (Ṣ, M, A,) aor. _i {yaOosiru}, inf. n. OasorN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and UisaArN, (M, TA,) He bound, braced, or tied, him, [namely, his captive,] or it, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) namely, his qatab [or camel's saddle], (Ṣ, A,) or his horse's saddle, (A,) with an UisaAr, i. e. a thong of untanned hide, (Ṣ, A,) by tying the two extremities of the EaroquwotaAni of the camel's saddle, or of the curved pieces of wood of the horse's saddle. (A.)

Also, aor. as above, and so the inf. n., i. e. OasorN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and UisaArN, (Lth, Ṣ,) He made him a captive; captived him; or took him a prisoner; whether he bound him with an UisaAr or did not; (Ṣ;) as also Msrhu↓, of the same form as Oakorama; (Mṣb;) and AstOsrhu↓, accord. to a trad., in which it occurs thus used, transitively: (Mgh:) and he imprisoned him. (TA, from a trad.)

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. OasorN, (Mṣb,) † He (God) created him, or formed him, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) in a goodly manner. (Mṣb.) You say, Oasarahu Qll-ehu OaHosana AlOasori God created him, or formed him, in the best manner. (Fr, TA.)

Ousira, (Ṣ, A,) aor. yuWosaru; (Ṣ;) or Oasira, aor. yaOosaru; (IḲṭṭ;) or Ousira bawoluhu; (M;) inf. n. OasorN, (M, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (M, IḲṭṭ;) He (a man, Ṣ, A) suffered suppression of his urine. (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, A.) [See OusorN, below.]
[2. Os-r He bound, or tied, tight, fast, or firmly. (So accord. to Golius; but for this he names no authority.)]
4: see 1.

5. tOs-r Ealayohi fulaAnN † Such a one excused himself to him, and was slow, or tardy: (AZ, T, Ḳ:*) thus as related by Ibn-Hánee from AZ: as AʼObeyd relates it from him, tOsn; but this is a mistake: it is correctly with r. (T.)
8. yaOotasiru, inf. n. QYotisaArN [written with the disjunctive alif AiytisaArN]; for yat-asiru, inf. N. Qt-isaArN: see art. bsr.

hom.sense: 10. AstOsr liloEaduwi He submitted himself as a captive to the enemy. (Mgh.) You say, AisotaOosiro, meaning Be thou a captive to me. (Ṣ,)
See also 1.

entry.sense: OasorN i. q. UisaArN, q. v. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying, hecaA AlX-aIoCu laka biOasorihi This thing is for thee, or is thine, [lit.] with its thong of untanned hide [wherewith it is bound]; meaning, altogether; like as one says, birum-atihi. (Ṣ.) And xucohu biOasorihi Take thou it all, or altogether. (Mṣb.) And jaMCa Alqawomu biOasorihimo The people came altogether. (Aboo-Bekr.)

Strength of make, or form. (M, Ḳ.) [Accord. to the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, it also signifies Strength of natural disposition; but instead of waAlxuluq, in those copies, we should read waAlxaloqu, agreeably with other lexicons, as is implied in the TA: see 1.]
You say, fulaAnN XadiydN OasorK Alxaloqi ‡ Such a one is of strong, firm, or compact, make, or form. (TA.)

XadadonaA Oasorahumo, in the Ḳur [lxxvi. 28], means ‡ We have strengthened their make, or form: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or, their joints: or, their two sphincters which serve as repressers of the urine and feces (maSar-ataIi Albawoli waAlgaAYiTi), which contract when the excrement has passed forth; or the meaning is, that these two things do not become relaxed before one desires. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

OusorN, (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, A,) a subst., (M, IḲṭṭ,) as also OusurN↓, (M, Lb,) meaning Suppression of the urine: (Ṣ, M, &c.:) suppression of the feces is termed HuSorN: (Ṣ:) or a dribbling of the urine, with a cutting pain in the bladder, and pangs like those of a female in the time of parturition. (IAạr.) You say, Oaxacahu AlOasoru [Suppression of urine,, &c., took him, or affected him]. (A.) And OanaAlahu Qll-ehu OusorAF [May God give him a suppression of urine,, &c.]: a form of imprecation. (A.)

Hence, (M,) Euwdu OusorK (IAạr, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and EuwdN OusorN and Euwdu AlOusori (Expositions of the Fṣ) and Euwdu yusori, (IAạr, Ḳ,) or this is a corruption, (Ḳ,) or a vulgar mistake, (A,) and should not be said, (Fr, Ṣ, A,) unless meant to be used as ominous of good, (A,) A stick, or piece of wood, which is put upon the belly of a man affected by a suppression of his urine, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c.,) and which cures him. (A.)
OusurN: see OusorN.

OusorapN † A man's kinsmen that are more, or most, nearly related to him; his near kinsmen: (Ṣ,* M, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or a man's nearer, or nearest, relations on his father's side: (Aboo-Jaạfar En-Naḥḥás:) so called because he is strengthened by them. (Ṣ, A.)

hom.sense: UisaArN A thing with which one binds; (M, Ḳ;) a thong of untanned hide, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) with which one binds a camel's saddle, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) [as also UiSaArN,] and a captive; and so OasorN, q. v.: (Ṣ:) and a rope, or cord, with which a captive is bound: and a pair of shackles: (TA:) pl. OusurN. (M, Ḳ.) [See also 1.] You say, Hal-a UisaArahu faOaTolaqahu He untied his thong of untanned hide wherewith he was bound, and released him. (A.)
See also OasiyrN.

entry.sense: OasiyrN i. q. maOosuwrN↓; (Ṣ, TA;) Bound with an UisaAr: (M, TA:) shackled: (Ḳ:) imprisoned: (Mujáhid, M, Ḳ:) captived, or a captive; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) absolutely, (TA,) although not bound with an AsAr: (Ṣ:) and UisaArN↓ is sometimes used in the same sense. (Mṣb.) Asyr is also applied as an epithet to a woman, (Mgh, Mṣb,) when the woman is mentioned; but otherwise OasiyrapN is used as the fem.: you say, qatalotu AlOasiyrapa [I slew the female captive], like as you say, raOayotu Alqatiylapa. (Mṣb.) The pl. is OasoraI (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OasaraMCu (M, Ḳ) and (accord. to several authors, pls. of OasoraI, TA) OusaAraI (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OasaAraI: (M, Ḳ:) the first of these forms of pl. is proper to epithets applied to those who are hurt or afflicted in their bodies or their intellects: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ:) it is used in this instance because a captive is like one wounded or stung. (Th, M.)
taMsiyru Als-aroji [in the CK, erroneously, taOosiyr] The thongs of the horse's saddle, whereby it is bound: (Ḳ:) accord. to the more correct opinion, a pl. without a sing. (MF.)
maOosuwrN: see OasiyrN. A camel's saddle bound with an UisaAr: pl. maMsiyru. (TA.)
† A man, and a beast, having strongly-knit joints. (M.)
A man suffering suppression of his urine. (Ṣ.)

OasoTurolaAbN or OusoTurolaAbN, [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,] and with S in the place of s, [from the Greek ἀστρολαβόν, An astrolabe: a word of which F gives the following fanciful derivation:] lAb was a man who traced some lines, and founded upon them calculations; whence OasoTurulaAbK [the lines of Láb], from which was formed the compound word AsTrlAb, and ASTrlAb, the s being changed into S because of the T following. (Ḳ in art. lwb.) It is either an arabicized or a post-classical word: accord. to the Niháyet el-Adab, the names of all the instruments by which time is known, whether by means of calculation or water or sand, are foreign to the Arabic language. (MF.)

1. Oasifa, aor. _a {yaOosafu}, inf. n. OasafN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He grieved, lamented, or regretted: and he was angry: (Mṣb:) or he grieved exceedingly: and he was exceedingly angry: (M:) or he grieved most intensely: (Ḳ:) some say that OasafN signifies the grieving for a thing that has escaped; not in an absolute sense: (MF:) or it properly signifies the rising, or swelling, or mantling, of the blood of the heart, from desire of vengeance; and when this is against an inferior, it is anger; but when against a superior, it is grief. (Er-Rághib.) Moḥammad, being asked respecting sudden death, answered, saying, raAHapN lilomuWomini waOaxocapu OasafK lilokaAfiri, or accord. to one recital, OasifK↓, i. e. [Rest, or ease, to the believer, and an act of punishment] of anger [to the unbeliever], or of one who is angry. (Ḳ.) You say, Oasifa EalaI maA faAtahu, inf. n. as above; (Ṣ;) and tOs-f↓; (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ;*) He grieved, or lamented, for, or at, or regretted, most intensely, what had escaped him: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:) and Oasifa Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) he was angry with him, or at it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or Oasifa fulaAnN EalaI kacaA wakacaA and tOs-f↓, signify, accord. to some, such a one grieved, or lamented, for, or at, such and such things which had escaped him: or, accord. to others, grieved, or lamented, most intensely. (IAmb.) OasafFA in the Ḳur xviii. 5 means, accord. to Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák, jazaEFA [i.e. In grief, or in most violent grief,, &c.]: or, accord. to Ḳatádeh, in anger. (TA.) And yaA OasafaA EalaI yuwsufi, in the Ḳur [xii. 84], means yaA jazaEaAhu [O my grief for Joseph: or O my most violent grief]. (TA.)
4. Msfhu (in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, Oasafahu, TA) He angered him; made him angry: (Ṣ, M,* O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and he grieved him; made him to grieve, or lament. (M,* TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
taOas-afato yadahu ‡ i. q. taXaE-avato [app. meaning His hand became bruised, or mangled; or became cracked, or chapped]. (M, TA.)
OasafN inf. n. of 1, which see throughout. [Used as a subst., i. q. OasaAfpN.]
OasifN (M, Mgh, Mṣb) and AsifN↓ and OasofaAnu↓ and OasiyfN↓ (M, TA) and OasuwfN↓ (M) Angry: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or exceedingly angry. (M.) For an ex. of the first, see 1. See also OasiyfN, in two places.
OasofaAnu: see OasifN: and OasiyfN.

UisaAfN (Ṣ, M, Ṣgh, &c.) and OasaAfN (IAth, Ḳ) A certain idol, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) belonging to Kureysh, (Ṣ, M,) as was also naAYilapu; (Ṣ;) the former of which was placed, by ʼAmr Ibn-Loheí, upon Es-Safà, and the latter upon El-Marweh; and he used to sacrifice to them, in front of the Kaabeh: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) as some assert, (Ṣ,) these two were two persons of Jurhum, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a man and a woman, (M,) AsAf the son of ʼAmr, and nAYlp the daughter of Sahl, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who committed fornication in the Kaabeh, and were therefore changed into two stones, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which Kureysh afterwards worshipped. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Other accounts of them are also given, slightly differing from the latter above.]
OasuwfN: see OasiyfN, in two places: and see OasifN.

OasiyfN Grieving, lamenting, or regretting, (Ḳ,* TA,) most intensely, on account of a thing that has escaped: (M, TA:) and quickly affected with grief, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and tender-hearted; as also OasuwfN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as also OasuwfN↓ (M) and OasofaAnu↓ and MsifN↓ (M, TA) and OasifN↓, (M,) grieving exceedingly: (M:) or grieved: (TA:) and sometimes the first signifies angry, and at the same time grieving, or lamenting: (Ṣ:) pl. OusafaMCu. (M.) See also OasifN.
A slave: (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and a hired man: (ISk, M, Ḳ:) because of their state of abasement and subjection: fem. with p {OasiyfapN}: (M:) and pl. as above. (Ṣ, M.)
A captive. (TA.)
A very old man: (Ḳ:) pl. as above: so in a trad., in which the slaying of such is forbidden. (TA.)
One who scarcely, or never, becomes fat. (Ḳ.)

† A region, or country, that does not give growth to anything, or produce any vegetation; as also OasiyfapN and OusaAfapN↓ and OasaAfapN↓: (M:) and OasaAfapN↓ also signifies † thin, or shallow, earth: (AḤn, M:) and OaroDN OasiyfapN, ‡ thin, or shallow, earth, which scarcely, or never, gives growth to anything, or produces any vegetation: (Ṣ:) or which is not commended for its vegetation: (A, TA:) or, as also OusaAfapN↓
and OasaAfapN↓, † thin, or shallow, earth: or such as does not produce vegetation: and † OaroDN OasifapN↓ land which scarcely, or never, produces vegetation. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OasaAfapN [Grief, lamentation, or regret: and anger: (see 1:) or] excessive grief: and excessive anger: (M:) or most intense grief: (Ḳ:) a subst. from Oasifa. (M, Ḳ.)
The state, or condition, of a slave: (M, Ḳ:) and, of a hired man. (M.)
‡ The state, or condition, of land which scarcely, or never, produces vegetation. (Ḳ, TA.)
See OasiyfN, in three places.

entry.sense: OusaAfapN: see OasiyfN, in two places.
MsifN: see OasiyfN: and OasifN.

UisofiydaAjN [Ceruse; or white lead;] ashes of lead (ramaAdu Alr-aSaASi wAlMnuki, Ḳ, which last word is as though it were added to explain that immediately preceding, TA): when subjected to a fierce heat, it becomes what is termed UisoranojN: [so in the CK: more probably UisorinojN:] it has clearing and mitigating properties, (Ḳ,) and other useful qualities: (TA:) an arabicized word [from the Persian AsfydAj isfédáj]. (Ḳ.)

1. OasakahaA, aor. _i {yaOosiku}, inf. n. OasokN, He hit, hurt, or wounded, her (a woman's) UisokataAni. (TA.) And Ousikato She (a woman) was hurt, or wounded, in a place not that of circumcision, [i.e., in her UisokataAni,] by the circumcising woman's missing the proper place. (Mṣb.) [See baZorq.]
OasokN: see AlUisokataAni.
UisokN see AlUisokataAni.
Also The side of the Aisot [i. e., of the podex, or of the anus]. (Sh, TA.) [Hence,] one says of a man, Uin-amaA huwa Uisoku OamapK, meaning He is but a stinking fellow. (TA.)

AlUisokataAni (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and AlOasokataAni, (M, Ḳ,) The two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e., of a woman, above [or rather within] the XuforaAni; (Mgh; the XuforaAni being the two borders thereof; T, Mṣb;) i. e. the quc-ataAni thereof; (Ṣ and M and L in art. qc;) the two sides, on the right and left, of the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman, between which is the maXaq-: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán”) or [accord. to some, but incorrectly,] the XuforaAni [in the CK the Xafor] of the raHim [here meaning, as in many other instances, the vulva, i. e. faroj], (M, Ḳ,) or of the HayaMC [which also means the vulva, but seldom that of a woman]: (El-Khárzenjee:) or [agreeably with general usage, and with the explanations given before this last,] its two sides, next to its XuforaAni: (M, Ḳ:) or, [what is the same,] its quc-ataAni: (Ḳ:) pl. UisakN (El-Khárzenjee, Ḳ) and [quasi-pl. ns.] UisokN↓ and OasokN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

maOosuwkapN A woman hit, hurt, or wounded, in her UisokataAni: (TA:) a woman (Mṣb) hurt, or wounded, in a place not that of circumcision, by the circumcising woman's missing the proper place; (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e.,] hurt, or wounded, by that cause, in her UisokataAni. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Oasula, aor. _u {yaOosulu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OasaAlapN, (Ṣ, M, IAth,) It was smooth and even: (M:) it (anything) was lank: (Ṣ:) it (a cheek, M, IAth, Ḳ) was smooth and long: (M:) or long, or oblong, and not high in its ball: (IAth:) or long, (Ḳ, TA,) soft in make, (TA,) and lank. (Ḳ, TA.) OasaAlapN in the cheek of a horse is approved, and is an indication of generous quality: you say, tunobiYu OasaAlapu xad-ihi Eano OaSaAlapi jad-ihi [The smoothness and longness,, &c., of his cheek tells of the generous origin of his ancestor]. (AO, Z.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. Os-lhu He made it (an iron thing) thin. (TA.) [He made it (anything) sharp, or pointed. (See the pass. part. n., below.)]

Os-l AlmaTara, inf. n. taOosiylN, The rain moistened to the measure of the Oasalap [or thin part] of the arm. (Ḳ.) When it has moistened to the measure of the EaZamap [or thick part] of the arm, you say of it EaZ-ama, inf. n. taEoZiymN: one says, kayfa kaAnato maToratukumo Oas-alato Oamo EaZ-amato [How was your rain? Did it moisten to the measure of the thin part of the arm, or did it moisten to the measure of the thick part thereof?]. (TA.) And Os-l Alv-araI, (TA,) or Oasala↓, (M, [so in a copy of that work, but probably a mistranscription,]) The moisture reached to the measure of the Oasalap. (M, TA.)
5. tOs-l OabaAhu, (M, Ḳ,) as also tOs-nhu, (M, TA,) He resembled his father, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and assumed his natural dispositions; and so taqay-alahu. (TA.) [See MsaAlu, below.]

OasalN [Rush, or rushes: so called in the present day:] a kind of trees: (Ṣ:) or [rather] a kind of plant, (M, Mgh, TA,) having shoots (M, Mgh) which are slender, (Mgh,) without leaves; (M, Mgh;) or of which the shoot is slender, and of which sieves are made; as is said in the A; and Ṣgh adds, [growing] in El-'Irák: (TA:) AḤn says, (TA,) accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, it is of the kind called OagolaAv, and comes forth in slender shoots, not having branches growing out from them, nor wood, (M, TA,) and sometimes men beat them, and make of them well-ropes and other cords, (TA,) and it seldom or never grows but in a place wherein is water, or near to water: (M, TA:) AḤn says [also], it signifies shoots, or twigs, growing (M, Ḳ) long and slender and straight, (M,) without leaves; of which mats are made: (M, Ḳ:) or OasalapN, (Ḳ,) which is the n. un. of OasalN applied to the plant mentioned above, (M, Ḳ,) signifies any shoot, or twig, in which is no crookedness. (Ḳ.)

Hence, (M,) ‡ Spears; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as being likened to the plant mentioned above, in respect of its evenness and length and straightness and the slenderness of its extremities: n. un. as above: (M:) and † arrows, or Arabian arrows; syn. nabolN; (M, Ḳ:) applied to both of these in a trad. of ʼOmar, which refutes an assertion that it is peculiarly applied to spears, or long spears, and not to nbl: (AʼObeyd, TA:) Sh says that it is applied to spears because of the points of the heads fixed upon them. (TA.)
† Any thin thing of iron, such as a spear-head, and a sword, and a knife. (TA.)
‡ The prickles of palm-trees: (M, Ḳ:) n. un. as above: (M:) by way of comparison [to the plant mentioned above]: (TA:) or any long thorns, or prickles, of a tree. (Ṣ.)
[See also what next follows.]
OasalapN n. un. of OasalN, q. v. (M, Ḳ.)
Hence, by way of comparison, the significations here following from the Ḳ. (TA.)
‡ Anything in which is no crookedness. (M.)

‡ The thin part of a blade of iron, such as that of an arrow, &c.: (M, Ḳ:) and of the fore arm; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. e. the half thereof next the hand; the half next the elbow being called the EaZamap. (Ḳ in art. EZm.)

‡ The thin part,, (Ṣ,) or extremity, or tip, (M, Ḳ,) of the tongue; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the thick part thereof being called the EaZamap. (Ḳ in art. EZm.) One says, OasalaAtu Oalosinatihimo OamoDaI mino Oasin-api Oasalihimo ‡ [The tips of their tongues are sharper than the heads of their spears]. (A, TA.)
‡ The nervus, (Ḳ,) or the extremity thereof, (M,) of a camel. (M, Ḳ.)
‡ The head, [or what we tern the toe, or foremost extremity, also called OanofN and cunaAbapN,] of a sandal; (M, Ḳ;) which is tapering. (M.)
Oasaliy-apN an epithet applied to the letters z and s and S because Pronounced with the tip of the tongue. (TA.)

OasiylN Smooth and even: (M, Ḳ:) anything lank; (Ṣ, A;) syn. saboTN, (A,) [i. e.] musotarosilN: (Ṣ, A:) applied to a cheek, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) [smooth and long: or long, or oblong, and not high in its ball: (see 1:) or] soft, tender, thin, and even: (AZ:) or long, (Ḳ, TA,) soft in make, (TA,) and lank. (Ḳ, TA.) You say rajulN Oasiylu Alxad-i A man having the cheek soft and long: (Ṣ:) and in like manner, farasa a horse. (TA.) And kaf-N Oasiylapu AlOaSaAbiEi A hand small and slender, and lank, or long, in the fingers. (TA.)

MsaAlN a pl. having no sing.: (Ḳ:) mentioned by ISk as a word of which he had not heard any sing. (Ṣ.) You say, huwa EalaI MsaAlK mino Oabiyhi [in the CK, erroneously, AasAlK,] He is of a semblance and of characteristics and natural dispositions which are those of his father; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like MsaAnK. (Ṣ.)
muWas-alN Anything sharpened, or pointed. (M, Ḳ.) You say OucunN muWas-alapN An ear [of a horse or the like] slender, pointed, and erect. (M.)
1. Oasamahu a dial. var. of wasamahu, q. v. (TA.)
AisomN: see art. smw.

OusaAmapu, determinate, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and imperfectly decl., (M, Mṣb,) as a proper name, (Mṣb, Ḳ,)
The lion; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AlOusaAmapu. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

1. Oasana, aor. _u {yaOosunu} (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yaOosinu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OusuwnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and OasonN; (M;) and Oasina, aor. _a {yaOosanu}, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. OasanN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) said of water, i. q. Oajana and Oajina; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] It became altered for the worse (M, Mgh, Mṣb) in odour, (M,) [or in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing, (see Oajana,)] but was drinkable; (M;) or so as not to be drunk, (Mṣb, TA,) thus differing from Oajana and Oajina. (TA.) [See also OaSila.]
OasinN: see what follows.

MsinN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OasinN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) applied to water, (Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) i. q. MjinN [and OajinN]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] Altered for the worse (Mgh, Mṣb) in odour, (Mgh,) [or in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing but drinkable; (see above, and see MjinN;)] or so as not to be drunk, (Mṣb, TA,) thus differing from MjinN and OajinN: (TA:) pl. [of the former] MsaAnN [like as OaTohaArN is pl. of TaAhirN, or perhaps it may have for its sing. OasonN, like OajonN]. (M, TA.) mano maMCK gayori MsinK, in the Ḳur [xlvii. 16], is explained by Fr as meaning Of water not altered for the worse; not Mjin. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. OasaA AljuroHa, (aor. yaOosuw Ṣ,) inf. n. OasowN and OasFA, [but in the Ṣ, the latter seems to be mentioned as a simple subst.,] He dressed the wound; treated it curatively, or surgically. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] heca OamorN laA yuWosaI kalomuhu † [This is an affair of which the evil (lit. the wound) will not be remedied]. (Ṣ.)

[Hence also,] OasaA bayonahumo, (first pers. Oasawotu, Ṣ, Mṣb, inf. n. OasowN, Ṣ, M,) ‡ He made peace, effected a reconciliation, or adjusted a difference, between them; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Os-I↓ bynhm. (El-Muärrij, TA.)

Oasiya aor. yaOosaI, inf. n. OasFA or OasFI, He grieved, or mourned, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Ealayohi [for him, or it], (M, Ḳ,) and EalaI muSiybapK [for an affliction], and lifulaAnK [for such a one]. (Ṣ.) [This belongs to the present art. and to art. AsI; but is distinguished in the M and Ḳ by being mentioned only in the latter art.; though the inf. n. is mentioned in the Ḳ in both arts.] Hence the saying, AlUisaMCu yadofaEu AlOasaA [Medicine dispels grief, or mourning] (TA.)
2. Os-I bayonahumo: see 1.

entry.sense: 3. Msayotuhu bimaAliI, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. muWaAsaApN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) I made him my object of imitation (UisowatiI), [meaning I made myself like him,] in respect of my property: (Ṣ:) or I made him an object of imitation [with, or in respect of, my property], I imitating his example, and he imitating my example: (Mgh:) and waAsayotuhu is a dial. var., but of weak authority: (Ṣ, Mgh:) and MsaAniI [alone] he made me an object of imitation to him by giving me of his property [and thus reducing himself to my condition in some degree while in the same degree raising me to his]; (Ḥam p. 696;) and OuwaAsiyhi [thus without a second C] I make him the object of my own imitation and so share with him my property: (Id p. 198:) or MsAhu bimaAlihi signifies he gave him of his property, and made him an object of imitation in respect of it: or only, of food sufficient for his want; not of what is superabundant: (M, Ḳ:) whence the saying, raHima Qll-ehu rajulFA OaEoTaI mino faDolK wawaAsaI mino kafaAfK [May God have mercy on a man who has given of superabundance, and imparted of food only sufficient for his want so as to make himself equal with him to whom he imparts of such food]: (TA:) [and MsAhu signifies he shared with him: and he was, or became, equal with him: for] AlmuwaAsaApu occurs often in trads., signifying the sharing with another, or making another to share with one, in the means of subsistence [&c.]; and is originally [AlmuWaAsaApu,] with C: also, the being, or becoming, equal with another: (TA:) and you say, Msayotuhu binafosiI, meaning I made him equal with myself; in the dial. of El-Yemen waAsayotuhu. (Mṣb.) Msi bayona Aln-aAsi fiI wajohika, in a letter of ʼOmar, means Make thou the people to share [alike], one with another, in thy consideration and regard: or, as some say, make thou them equal [in respect thereof]. (Mgh.) The saying maA yuWaAsiI fulaAnN fulaAnFA is explained in three different ways: accord. to El-Mufaddal Ibn-Moḥammad, it means Such a one does not make such a one to share with him: accord. to El-Muärraj, does not good to such a one; from the saying of the Arabs, Msi fulaAnFA bixayorK Do thou good to such a one: or, as some say, does not give such a one any compensation for his love, or affection, nor for his relationship; from AlOawosu, meaning AlEawoDu; being originally yuWaAwisuhu, then yuWaAsiwuhu, and then yuWaAsiyhi: or it may be from Oasawotu AljuroHa. (IDrd, TA.) [See also an ex. voce OavarapN].
4: see 2.
5. tOs-I: see 8.

I. q. taEaz-aI [He took patience; or constrained himself to be patient; or he took example by, or became consoled by the example of, another who had suffered in like manner and had been patient]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) You say, tOs-I bihi, i. e. taEaz-aI bihi [He took patience, or constrained himself to be patient, by reflecting upon him, or it; or he took example by him, or became consoled by his example, meaning the example of a person who had suffered in like manner and had been patient]. (Ṣ.) [See 2.]

6. taMsawoA signifies MsaI baEoDuhumo bEoDFA [They imitated one another with their property, one giving of his property to another, so that they thus equalised themselves; they imitated one another and so shared together their property; they shared, one with another, in the means of subsistence, &c.; they were, or became, equal, one with another: see 3]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
waUin-a AlOuwlaI biAlT-af-i mino Ml haAXimK
taMsawoA fasan-uwA lilokiraAmi Alt-aMsiyaA , (Ṣ,) in which tMswA is from AlmuWaAsaApu; not from Alt-aOas-iI, as it is stated to be by Mbr, who says that tMswA means tawaAsawoAA and taEaz-awoA. (IB, TA.) [This verse cited and translated in art. AlI, voce OulaI, q. v.]

8. AYtsI bihi [written with the disjunctive alif AiytasaI] He imitated him; followed his example; did as he did, following his example, or taking him as an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation; he took example by him; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) as also tOs-I↓ bihi: (Mṣb, TA:) he made him an object of imitation (Uisowap) [to himself]. (M, Ḳ.) One says, laA taOotasi bimano layosa laka biUisowapK Do not thou imitate him who is not for thee a [fit] object of imitation. (Ṣ, M.*)

Q. Q. 1. Oasowayotuhu bihi [I made him to imitate him, to follow his example, or to take example by him;] I made him an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation, to him: (M, Ḳ:) from IAạr: and if from AlUisowapu, as he asserts it be, the measure of this verb is faEolayotu, like darobayotu and jaEobayotu. (M.)

hom.sense: OasFA or OasFI Curative, or surgical, treatment. (Ṣ.) [See the verb OasaA.]
Grief, or mourning. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See the verb OasiIa.]

entry.sense: OasK: see OasowaAnu.

hom.sense: OusFI Patience. (Ṣ.)
Also pl. of OusowapN, like as UisFI is pl. of UisowapN. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: OasowapN: see what next follows.
OusowapN: see what next follows.

UisowapN and OusowapN↓ (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OasowapN↓, mentioned by Er-Rághib in one of his works, (MF,) An example; an exemplar; a pattern; an object of imitation; a person by whom one takes example; syn. qudowapN or qidowapN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) each a subst. from AiytasaI bihi; (Mgh;) i. e. maA yuWotasaI bihi: (TA:) explained by Er-Rághib as meaning the condition in which is a man in respect of another's imitating [him], whether good or bad, pleasing or hurtful: (TA:)
also a thing [or person] by which one who is in grief, or mourning, takes example, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) for the being consoled (lilt-aEaz-iI) thereby: (Ṣ:) pl. UisFI and OusFI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the former of the first sing., and the latter of the second. (TA.) The first of these meanings is intended in the saying, liI fiI fulaAnK UisowapN and OusowapN [I have in such a one an example,, &c.]. (Ṣ.) The saying, maA sawiI Alt-uraAbi mina AlOaroDi Uisowapu Alt-uraAbi is tropical, meaning ‡ There is nothing but the dust of the earth, or ground, that follows the dust. (Mgh.)
Also an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n.,] syn. with AiytisaMCN [inf. n. of 8]. (TA.)

OasowaAnu Grieving, mourning, or sorrowful; (M, Ḳ;) as also OasoyaAnu and OasK↓, (M in art. AsI,) or MsK↓ (Ḳ in art. AsI [to which alone the first of these three belongs, but the second and third may be regarded as belonging either to that art. or to the present,]) or OasiI-N↓ (Mṣb.) [See art. AsI] It is [sometimes] followed by OatowaAnu [as an imitative sequent corroborating its meaning]. (M.)
UisaMCN and Oasuw-N↓ A medicine, or remedy; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the latter, (Ṣ,) or each, (TA,) particularly a vulnerary: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. [of each, as is indicated in the TA,] MsiyapN. (M, Ḳ.)
The former is also a pl. of MsK. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Oasuw-N: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: OasiI-N i. q. maOosuw-N↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. e., Dressed; or treated curatively, or surgically; applied to a wound. (Ṣ, M.*)

entry.sense: OusaAwapN Medical, curative, therapeutical, [or surgical,] treatment. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) By rule it should be [UisaAwapN,] with kesr. (Ṣgh, TA.)

hom.sense: MsK A physician; one skilled in medical, curative, therapeutical, [or surgical,] treatment [particularly of wounds]: pl. OusaApN and UisaMCN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) said by IJ to be the only instance of fuEolapN and fiEaAlN interchangeable except ruEaApN and riEaMCN pls. of raAEK: (M:) and Msuwna occurs [as its pl.] in a verse of Hoteiäh. (Ṣ, TA.)
With the people of the desert, (Ṣ,) [its fem.] MsiyapN signifies ‡ A female circumciser [of girls]. (Ṣ, Ḳ: [mentioned in the latter in art. AsI.])
See also OasuwaAnu.

entry.sense: maOosuw-N: see OasiI-N.
1. OasiIa, aor. yaOosaI, inf. n. OasFI or OasFA, He grieved, or mourned, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Ealayohi [for him or it]. (M, Ḳ.) See art. Asw.

OasK, [agreeably with analogy, as part. n. of OasiIa,] (M,) or MsK↓ (Ḳ,) or OasiI-N↓ (Mṣb,) and OasoyaAnu↓, (M, Ḳ,) a dial. var. of OasowaAnu, (TA, [see art. Asw]) Grieving, mourning, or sorrowful: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. [of the first, or second,] OasiyapN (M,) or MsiyapN, (Ḳ,) and [of AsyAn] OasoyaAnapN (M, Ḳ) and OasayoI: (TA:) pl. [of AsyAn] OasoyaAnuwna (M, Ḳ) and OasaAyuwna [which is extr. and somewhat doubtful] (Ḳ) and [of AsyAnp] OasoyaAnaAtN and [of AsyI or of OasiyapN] OasaAyaA (M, Ḳ) and [of AsyI] OasoyayaAtN. (Ḳ.)
OasoyaAnu see above.
OasiI-N see above.
MsK see above.
MsiyapN mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see MsK in art. Ask.

hom.sense: 1. OaXabahu, aor. _i {yaOoXibu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaXobN, (M, TA,) He mixed it. (M, Ḳ.) And OaXabotu Alqawoma; (Ṣ;) or OaX-abotuhumo↓, inf. n. taOoXiybN; (TA;) I mixed the peogle together. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also, aor. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) † He charged him with a vice, fault, or the like; blamed, censured, or reprehended, him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he aspersed, reviled, or reproached, him, and mixed up falsehood in his aspersion of him. (TA.) You say also, OaXabahu biXr-K [i. e. biXar-K or biXur-K] † He cast upon him a stigma, or mark of dishonour, by which he became known: (Lḥ, TA:) or he cast a censure, or reproach, upon him, and involved him in it. (TA.)

OaXiba AlX-ajaru, aor. _a {yaOoXabu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaXabN; (TA;) and tOX-b↓; (Ḳ;) or OaXibati AlgayoDapu; (Ṣ;) The collection of trees, or the thicket, was, or became, dense, tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or very dense, or much tangled or confused, so as to be impassable. (AḤn, A.)
[Hence,] OaXiba AlkalaAmu bayonahumo † Their speech, one with another, became confused, or intricate. (TA.)
And OaXiba AlX-ar-u lil-aYiymi Evil clave to the ignoble. (A.)

entry.sense: 2. OX-bhu, inf. n. taOoXiybN, He rendered it (a collection of trees) dense, tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated. (Ḳ.)
OaXabotu Alqawma: see 1.
OX-b AlkalaAma bayonahumo † He made their speech, one with another, confused, or intricate. (TA.)

OX-b AlX-ar-a bayonahumo † He occasioned confusion, discord, or mischief, between them. (Lth.) And hence, (TA,) taOoXiybN signifies also The exciting discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) bayona qawmK between, or among, a people. (Ṣ, TA.)
5. tOX-b: see 1.
tOX-bwA † They were, or became, mixed, or confounded together; as also AYtXbwA↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaXabuwA]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

‡ They assembled, or congregated, themselves (A, Ḳ) from different parts; (TA;) as also AYtXbwA↓ (Ḳ.) And tOX-bwA Uilayohi † They drew themselves together to him, (Ḳ, TA,) and crowded densely upon him; or collected themselves together to him, and surrounded him. (TA.)
8: see 5, in two places.
OaXabN inf. n. of OaXiba. (TA.)
[Hence,] Confusedness; dubiousness: so in the saying, Darabato fiyhi fulaAnapu biEiroqK ciI OaXabK i. e. ciI QlotibaAsK. (Ṣ.) See art. Drb

Also An abundance of trees. (TA.) In a trad. of Ibn-Umm-Mektoom, Uin-iI rajulN DariyrN bayoniI wabayonaka OaXabN farax-iSo liI fiI AlEiXaMCi waAlfajori means Verily I am a blind man, [and] between me and thee are palm-trees confusedly disposed; therefore grant thou me indulgence with respect to [coming to thee to perform the prayers of] the nightfall and the daybreak. (Ḳ,* MF, TA.)

OaXibN Dense, tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated; applied to a collection of trees: (Ṣ, TA:) or so dense, or so much tangled or confused, as to be impassable; applied to a thicket: (A:) and a place abounding with trees: (TA:) applied also to ‡ a collection of clouds, meaning commingled: (A:) and to † a number, meaning intricate, or confused. (Ṣ, TA.) It is said in a prov., EiySuka manoka waUino kaAna OaXibFA (A,) meaning ‡ [Thy stock is an appertenance of thine] although it be thorny and intricate or confused. (TA. [See art. EyS])

OuXaAbapN ‡ A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or assemblage, of men, or people; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) congregated from every quarter: (L:) pl. OaXaAYibu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) You say, heWulaMCi OuXaAbapN ‡ These are a collection [of people] from different places. (TA.)
Also ‡ Mixtures of unlawful and lawful kinds of property: (A:) or what is mixed with that which has been unlawfully acquired; (Ḳ, TA;) that in which is no good; (TA;) of gains: pl. as above. (Ḳ, TA.)
maOoXuwbN AlHasabi † Not pure in his grounds of pretension to respect. (ISd, TA.) [See also what follows.]
jamoEN muWotaXabN and muWotaXibN ‡ [A mixed collection of people]. (A.)
fulaAnN muWotaXabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) with fet-ḥ [to the X], (Ḳ,) in one copy of the Ḳ, muWaX-abN, (TA,) † Such a one is of mixed, not of pure, race, or lineage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. OaXara, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOoXiru}, (ISk, MṢ,) or _a, (Mṣb,) inf. n. OaXorN, (Mṣb,) He divided [or sawed] a piece of wood (ISk, Mṣb, Ḳ) with the miYoXaAr; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also waXara and naXara. (Mṣb, TA.)

OaXarato OasonaAnahaA, aor. _i {yaOoXiru} [or, accord. to the Mṣb, it seems to be _u,] inf. n. OaXorN; (Ḳ;) and OaX-aratohaA↓ (Ḳ,) inf. n. taOoXiyrN; (Ṣ;) She (a woman, TA) made her teeth serrated, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and sharpened their extremities, (Ṣ,) to render them like those of a young person: but a curse is denounced in a trad. against her who does this. (TA.) [See also art. wXr]

, OaXira aor. _a {yaOoXaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaXarN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) He exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) or he exulted by reason of wealth, and behaved with pride, and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or he behaved with the utmost exultation, &c.: or he rejoiced, and rested his mind upon things agreeable with natural desire. (TA.) [See baTira]

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

[8. QYotaXarato, written with the disjunctive alif AytaXarato She invited another to make her teeth serrated and to sharpen their extremities; as also AstOXrt↓ See the act. part. ns. below: and see also AstwXrt]

OaXirN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaXurN↓ and OaXorN↓ and OaXarN↓ (Ḳ) and OaXoraAnu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) Exulting, or exulting greatly, or excessively; and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) or exulting by reason of wealth, and behaving with pride, and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or behaving with the utmost exultation, &c.: or rejoicing, and resting the mind upon things agreeable with natural desire: (TA:) pl. [of the first] OaXiruwna and [of the second] OaXuruwna (L, Ḳ) and [of the first four] OuXurN (Ḳ [accord. to the TA, but not in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands,]) and (of OaXoraAnu TA) OaXoraI (Ḳ) and OuXaAraI (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaXaAraI (Ḳ.) One says, OaXirN OafirN and OaXoraAnu↓ OaforaAnu, using the latter word in each instance as an imitative sequent. (TA.)
baroqN OaXirN ‡ Lightning flashing repeatedly to and fro. (A.)
nabotN OaXirN ‡ A plant, or herbage, extending beyond its proper bounds. (A.)
OuXarN: see what next follows.

biOasonaAnihi OuXurN and OuXarN↓ and OuXuwrN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which last is a pl., (Ḳ,) In his teeth is a serration, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a sharpness of the extremities [such as is seen in the teeth of young persons]; (Ṣ;) which is sometimes natural and sometimes artificial; (Ḳ;) and [naturally] only in the teeth of young persons. (TA.) Hence the prov., OaEoyayotaniI biOuXuri fakayofa bidurodurK. (Ṣ.) [See art. dr]
OuXuru Alminojali ‡ The teeth of the reaping-hook, or sickle. (Ḳ.)
OuXorapN and its dual (OuXorataAni): see MXirN
Oumoniy-apN OaXoraMCu A very exulting wish: occurring in the Mo'allakah of El-Hárith Ibn-Hillizeh. (EM p. 272.)
OaXoraAnu: see OaXirN, in two places.

hom.sense: MXirN Dividing [or sawing], or one who divides [or saws], wood, with the miYoXaAr (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] The prickles [or serrated parts] of the shanks of the locust; (Ḳ;) as also taMXiyru↓ (TA.)
Also, and OuXorapN↓ and miYoXaArN↓, A joint (EuqodapN) at the extremity of the tail of the locust, like two claws; (Ḳ;) which two things are also called OuXorataAni↓ and miYoXaAraAni↓ (TA.)
MXirapN A woman who sharpens the extremities of her teeth [and makes them serrated: see 1]. (Mṣb.)
yadN MXirapN An arm, or a hand, sawn off; i. q. maOoXuwrapN↓: (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) like EiyXapN raADiyapN in the sense of maroDiyapN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: taOoXiyrN or taOoXiyrapN, as in different Lexicons, (TA,) [the former in the Ḳ,] The thing with which the locust bites: pl. taMXiyru (Ḳ.)
See also the pl. voce MXirN.

muWaX-arN Anything (TA) made thin [and serrated]. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] vagorN muWaX-arN A front tooth serrated and sharpened at the extremity. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) muWaX-aru AlEaDudayoni is applied to the beetle [as meaning Having the fore shanks formed thin, and serrated]. (Ṣ, TA.)
miYoXaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) [A saw;] an instrument with which wood is divided; (Mṣb, Ḳ) as also miyXaArN, from waXara; (Mṣb, TA;) and minoXaArN: (TA:) pl. maMXiyru. (ISk, Mṣb, TA.)
See also this word and its dual voce MXirN.
maOoXuwrN Wood divided [or sawn] with the miYoXaAr (Mṣb.) See also MXirN
maOoXuwrapN A woman who has the extremities of her teeth sharpened [and serrated artificially: see 1]. (Mṣb.)
miYoXiyrN, applied alike to the male and the female, (Ṣ,) to a she-camel and a courser, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a man and a woman, (TA,) Brisk; lively; sprightly. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
muWotaXirapN and musotaOoXirapN↓ A woman who invites [another ] to make her teeth serrated [and to sharpen their extremities: see 1]. (Ḳ.)
musotaOoXirapN: see what next precedes.

UiXofaI, of the measure fiEolaI, [and therefore fem., and imperfectly decl.,] (Ṣ, Mṣb,) accord. to some; but accord. to others, of the measure UifoEalN like UiSobaEN as Kh is related to have said, (Mṣb,) which latter is said by IB to be the correct measure, the [incipient] A being augmentative, and the word [masc.,] with tenween, [i. e. UiXofFI,] perfectly decl.: (TA:) The instrument belonging to the UiskaAf [or sewer of skins or leather]; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA;) i. e., with which he sews; and the instrument with which he bores, or perforates: (TA:) the instrument for boring, or perforating, (Ḳ in art. XfI) belonging to the OasaAkifap; said by ISk to be that which is used for water-skins, or milk-skins, and leather water-bags, and the like; that used for sandals, or shoes, being called mixoSafN: (Ṣ and TA in art. XfI:) and the [instrument called] siraAd with which skin, or leather, is sewed: (Ḳ in art. XfI:) i. q. mixorazN: (Mgh in art. XfI:) pl. OaXaAfK (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ: [in the CK, erroneously, AaXAfiI-u]) In the Ḳ, in the present art., AlUisokaAfu is put, by a mistake of the copyists, for liloUisokaAfi (TA.) See also art. XfI.
1. OaXuka caA xuruwjFA i. q. waXuka, q. v. (TA.)
5. tOX-n He washed his hands with OuXonaAn [q. v. infrà]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

OuXonapN [applied in the present day to Moss: and particularly, tree-moss: in Persian OuXonaho: but] Lth says, (TA,) it is a thing that winds itself upon the trees called bal-uwT and Sanawobar [oak and pine] as though it were pared off from a root (kaOan-ahu maqoXuwrN mino Eiroqi); and it is sweet in odour, and white: (Ḳ, TA:) Az says, I do not think it to be [genuine] Arabic. (TA.)
OuXonaAnapN A vessel for HuroD [or for OuXonaAn as meaning potash]; syn. miHoraDapN. (A in art. HrD)
OuXonaAniI-N A seller of OuXonaAn. (TA.)

2. OS-dhu, inf. n. taOoSiydN, is from OuSodapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [app. meaning He made it an OuSodap: or he wore it as an OuSodap: and hence muWaS-adN or muWaS-adapN as explained below: or] he clad him with an OuSodap. (TḲ.)

4. MSd [in some copies of the Ḳ OaSada, which is a mistake, (see the pass. part. n. muWoSadN, below,)] He closed (Oagolaqa, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and so in the M in art. wSd, or OaTobaqa, as in the M in the present art.) a door, or an entrance; as also AwSd; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) of which it is a dial. var. (Ṣ.) And He covered, or covered over, a cooking-pot. (M.)

OuSodapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, and Ḥam p. 223) and OaSiydapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and muWaS-adN↓ (Ṣ* M,) or muWaS-adapN↓, (Ḳ,) A garment of the kind called SidaAr worn by a young girl: when a girl attains to the age of puberty, she is clad with a diroE: (M:) or a small shirt for a little girl: or worn beneath the vawob; (Ḳ:) or the OuSodap is a garment without sleeves, worn by a bride and by a little girl: (M:) or a small shirt or shift, worn beneath the vwb; and also worn by little girls: (Ṣ:) or a garment of which the sewing is not complete: or i. q. baqiyrapN: or i. q. SudorapN. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) Kutheiyir says,
waqado dar-aEuwhaA wahoIa caAtu muWaS-adK↓
majuwbK walam-aA yalobasi Ald-iroEa riyduhaA
[They clad her with a diroE when she wore a muWaS-ad with an opening cut out at the neck and bosom, when her equal in age had not yet worn the drE]. (Ṣ, M.)

OaSiydN A court; or an open or a wide space in front of a house, or extending from its sides; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of waSiydN, (Ṣ,) which is the more common form: (M:)
or the extreme and exterior part of a house: (Mirḳát el-Loghah, and Meyd, as rendered by Golius:) or an intermediate place between the threshold or door and the house; a place which looks neither upon the public nor upon the interior parts, whether it be an area or a vestibule. (Ibn-Maạroof, as rendered by Golius.)

hom.sense: OaSiydapN: see OuSodapu

A [hind of enclosure for the protection of camels, sheep, or goats, such as is called] HaZiyrapN: (M, Ḳ:) or like a HZyrp, (Ṣ, and Ḥam p.223,) [but made] of rocks, or great masses of stone: (Ḥam:) a dial. var. of waSiydapN [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) pl. UiSaAdN (Ḥam.)

entry.sense: muWoSadN Closed; closed over, or covered: occurring in the Ḳur [xc. 20 and] civ. 8; (L;) in which AA reads muWoSadapN [with hemz; others reading this word without hemz]. (Ṣ, L.) You say baAbN muWoSadN [A closed door]. (A.) And qidorN muWoSadapN A covered cooking-pot. (A.) And baAbu AlEafowi Eanohu muWoSadN † [The door of forgiveness is closed from him; i. e., against him]. (A.)
muWaS-adN, or muWaS-adapN: see OuSodapN, in three places.

hom.sense: 1. OaSarahu, aor. _i {yaOoSiru}, inf. n. OaSorN, He, or it, (a thing, Ks,) confined, restricted, limited, kept close, kept within certain bounds or limits, shut up, imprisoned, held in custody, detained, retained, restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, impeded, or prevented, him or it: (Ks, Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ:) it straitened him. (TA.) You say, OaSarotu Alr-ajula EalaI celika I confined, or restricted, the man to that thing, or affair. (Ks.) And OaSarotuhu Eano HaAjatahu, and Eam-aA OaraAdahu, I withheld, restrained, or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted, and from the thing that he desired. (IAạr.)
OaSara Albayota, aor. and inf. n. as above, He made, or put, to the tent an UiSaAr. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)
Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He broke it. (El-Umawee, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*)
He inclined, or bent, it. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)
It inclined him, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) EalaI fulaAnK to such a one. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) See an ex. voce MSirapN.

entry.sense: 3. [MSrhu, inf. n. muWaASirapN, He was his neighbour, having the USAr of his tent by the side of the UiSaAr of the tent of the other. See the act. part. n. below.]
6. [taMSaruwA They were neighbours; they dwelt, or abode, near together. See the act. part. n. below.]
OaSorN see UiSorN; each in three places.
OuSorN see UiSorN; each in three places.

hom.sense: UiSorN A covenant, compact, or contract; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OuSorN↓ and OaSorN↓: (Ḳ:) [see also wSorN:] any bond arising from relationship, or from a covenant or compact or contract, (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ,) and from an oath: (ISh:) a covenant, compact, or contract, which one does not fulfil, and for the neglecting and breaking of which one is punished: so in the Ḳur ii. 286: (I’Ab:) [see also what follows, in two places:] or a heavy, or burdensome, covenant, compact, or contract: so in the Ḳur iii. 75: (ISh, M:) so, too, in the same vii. 156: (T, M:) pl. MSaArN, a pl. of pauc.: (M:) or a heavy, or burdensome, command; such as was given to the Children of Israel to slay one another: so in the Ḳur ii. 286, accord. to Zj. (TA.)
A weight, or burden; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also OuSorN↓ and OaSorN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because it restrains one from motion: (TA:) pl. as above. (M.)

A sin; a crime; an offence; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also OuSorN↓ and OaSorN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because of its weight, or burdensomeness: (TA:) or the sin of breaking a compact, or covenant: (Fr, Sh:) or a grievous punishment of a sin: so accord. to AM in the Ḳur ii. 286. (TA.)
A thing that inclines one to a thing. (M, Ḳ.) [See also MSirapN. It is said in the Ḥam (p. 321) that OawaASiru is pl. of the former word: but it is evidently pl. of the latter.]

A swearing by an oath which obliges one to divorce or emancipate or to pay a vow. (Ḳ, TA.) So in a trad., in which it is said, mano Halafa EalaI yamiynK UiSorN falaA kaf-aArapa lahaA [Whoso sweareth an oath in which is an obligation to divorce or emancipate or to pay a vow, for it there is no expiation]: for such is the heaviest of oaths, and that from which the way of escape, or evasion, is most strait: the original meaning of ASr being a burden, and a binding. (TA.)
The ear-hole: pl. MSaArN (IAạr, Ḳ) and UiSoraAnN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
UiSaArN and OayoSarN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and UiSaArapN↓ and MSirapN↓ (M, Ḳ) A short rope, (Ṣ,) or small rope, (Ḳ,) by which the lower part of the [kind of tent called] xibaMC is tied, or bound, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) to the peg: (Ṣ:) or a short peg, for the [ropes called] OaTonaAb, with which the lower part of the [kind of tent called] xbM is fastened: (M:) [or] UiSaArN signifies also the peg, (Ḳ,) or short peg, (TA,) of the [kind of tent-rope called] Tunub: (Ḳ:) or a peg of the xbMC: (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA:) pl. of the first OuSurN (Ṣ, M) and MSirapN; (M;) and of the second OayaASiru. (Ṣ.) ISd thinks that MSiraAt↓ is the pl. of MSirapN↓ used in the first of the senses explained above in in the following verse:
laEamoruka laA Oaconuw liwaSoli daniy-apK
walaA OataSabaI MSiraAti xaliyliI
the poet meaning [By thy life, I will not approach to hold loving communion, or intercourse, with an ignoble, or a low, female;] nor will I direct my regard to the short ropes which bind [to the pegs] the lower part of the tent of my friend, coveting his wife, and the like: or he may mean nor will I direct my regard to the female relations of my friend, such as his paternal aunt, and his maternal aunt, and the like. (TA.) [See MSirapN, below.]
Also, the first, A thing by which things are tied firmly, or made firm or fast. (TA.)
A thong of untanned hide which binds together the EaDudaAni of a camel's saddle: and UisaArN is a dial. var. thereof. (M.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) and OayoSarN↓, (AZ, Aṣ, Ḳ,) A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC in which dry herbage, or fodder, is collected: (M, Ḳ:) or a ksMC filled with herbage, and tied: (AZ:) or a ksMC in which is dry herbage, or fodder: otherwise it is not thus called: (Aṣ:) pl. [of the former] OuSurN and MSirapN; (Ḳ;) and of the latter OayaASiru. (AZ.)

And both words, (the former accord. to the Ṣ and M and Ḳ, and the latter accord. to Aṣ and the Ṣ and M and Ḳ,) Dry herbage, or fodder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or dry herbage, or fodder, collected together: (TA:) or dry herbage, or fodder, in a [garment of the kind called] ksMC: otherwise it is not thus called: (Aṣ:) or dry herbage, or fodder, contained in a miHaX-. (M.) [The following saying is cited as an ex. of the first of these significations:] lifulaAnK maHaX-N laA yujaz-u OayoSarahu↓ [To such a one belongs a place, or land, abounding with dry herbage,] the dry herbage whereof will not be cut; (Ṣ;) meaning, because of its abundance. (TA.)

Also, the former, A basket (zabiyl or znobiyl, as in different copies of the Ḳ) in which goods, or commodities, (mataAE,) are carried: so called as being likened to the thing in which dry herbage is put. (TA.)
UiSaArapN: see UiSaArN.
kalaON MSirN Pasturage that detains those that are on it [by reason of its abundance]: (M, TA:) or, to which one goes because of its abundance. (TA.)
MSirapN, and its pl. MSiraAtN: see USaArN, in three places: of which last word, the first is also a pl.
The thing termed Mxiy-ap and MriI- [to which a beast is tied]. (TA.)

A tie of kindred, or relationship, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or affinity, (Ṣ,) or a favour, or benefit, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that inclines one to a man; (Ṣ;) or because it inclines one: (M:) pl. OawaASiru. (Ḳ.) One says, maA taOoSiruniI↓ EalaI fulaAnK MSirapN No tie of relationship, nor any favour, or benefit, inclines me to such a one. (Ṣ.) And EaTafa EalaI-a bigayori MSiraho wanaZara fiI OamoriI bigayori baASiraho [He inclined to me without any tie of relationship, &c., and examined my case without eye]. (A.) [See also UiSorN.]
OayoSarN: see UiSaArN, in three places.
maOoSirN and maOoSarN A place in which a person or thing is confined, shut up, or imprisoned: pl. maMSirN; for which the vulgar say, maEaASiru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also, the former, (M, A,) or maASirN; (TA;) either of the measure mafoEilN from AlOaSoru, or of the measure faAEilN from AlmiSoru; A thing intervening between two other things and preventing the passage from one to the other; a barrier: (A:) a rope across a road or river, preventing the passage of travellers and ships or boats, (M, L,) for the taking of the tithes from them. (L.)

muWaASirN A neighbour: (Ḳ:) [or a close, or near, neighbour: as in the saying,] huwa jaAriI muWaASiriI He is my neighbour, having the UiSaAr of his tent by the side of the UiSaAr of my tent. (El-Aḥmar, Ṣ.)
HaI-N mutaMSiruwna A tribe dwelling, or abiding, near together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

UiSoTabolN A stable (Ḳ) for dawaAb- [i. e. horses or mules or asses]: (Ṣ [in some copies of which it is omitted] and Ḳ:) the A is radical, because an augmentative does not occur at the beginning of a word of four or five letters unless derived from a verb: (Ṣ:) [probably from the barbarous Greek σταβλίον:] AA says that it is not of the [genuine] language of the Arabs: (Ṣ:) IB says that it is a foreign word, used by the Arabs: (TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) it is of the dial. of Syria: (Ḳ, TA:) the pl. is OaSaATibu: and the dim. OuSayoTibN. (TA.)
OaSoTurolaAbN or OuSoTurolaAbN: see AsTrlAb.

hom.sense: 1. OaSula, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OaSaAlapN; (TA;) or OaSila; (M;) It (a thing, M) had, or came to have, root, or a foundation; (M, Ḳ;) as also tOS-l↓: (M:) or it was, or became, firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded; as also tOS-l↓: (Ḳ:) and [in like manner] AstOSl↓ it (a thing) was, or became, firm in its root or foundation, and strong. (Mṣb.) You say, AisotaOoSalati↓ AlXajarapu The tree [took root; or] grew, and became firm in its root. (TA.)

[Hence,] OaSula, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, M,) He (a man, Ṣ,* M) was, or became, firm, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) or sound, (Ṣ,) of judgment; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) intelligent. (M: [and so, probably, in correct copies of the Ḳ; but in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ and in the CK; and TA, instead of EaAqil, the reading in the M, I find EaAqib.])
Also, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, TA,) It (judgment, or opinion,) was, or became, firm, or sound, (Ṣ,* TA,) or good. (Ḳ.)
And, inf. n. as above, It (a thing) was, or became, eminent, noble, or honourable. (Mṣb.)

OaSalahu, [aor. and inf. n. as in what follows next after this sentence,] He hit, or struck, its root, or foundation; that by being which it was what it was, or in being which it consisted; or its ultimate constituent. (A, TA.)

And hence, (A, TA,) OaSalahu EilomFA, (A, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yaOoSulu}, inf. n. OaSolN: (TA;) or MSalahu↓ [with medd, (which I think to be a mistake, unless this be a dial. var.,) and without ElmA]; (so in a copy of the M;) † He knew it completely, or thoroughly, or superlatively well, syn. qatalahu, (Ḳ,) [i. e.] qatalahu EilomFA, so that he was acquainted with its OaSol [or root, or foundation, or its ultimate constituent, as is indicated in the A and TA]: (M:) or this is from OaSalapN, as meaning “a certain very deadly serpent;” (A, TA;) [whence the phrase,]
OaSalatohu AlOaSalapu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OaSolN, (TA,) The [serpent called] ASlp sprang upon him (Ḳ, TA) and slew him. (TA.)

OaSila, aor. _a {yaOoSalu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaSalN, (M,) said of water, i. q. Oasina; (M, Ḳ;) i. e. It became altered for the worse (M, TA) in its taste and odour, (TA,) from fetid black mud (Ḳ, TA) therein: so says Ibn-ʼAbbád: (TA:) and said of flesh-meat, it became altered (Ḳ, TA) in like manner. (TA.)
OaSila fulaAnN yafoEalu kacaA wakacaA Such a one set about, or commenced, doing thus and thus, or such and such things. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. OSl-hu, inf. n. taOoSiylN, He made it to have a firm, or fixed, root, or foundation, whereon to build, (Mṣb, TA,) i. e., whereon another thing might be built. (El-Munáwee, TA.) [Hence,] OS-l maAlahu i. q. Oav-alahu [He made his wealth, or property, to have root, or a foundation; or to become firm, or established, and firmly rooted or founded: see, below, OaSolu maAlK, and maAlN lahu OaSolN]. (M and Ḳ in art. Avl.)

OS-l AlOuSuwla [He disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order, the fundamentals, fundamental articles, principles, elements, or rudiments, of a science, &c.,] is a phrase similar to baw-aba AlOabowaAba and rat-aba Alr-utaba. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. MSl, (inf. n. UiySaAlN, TA,) He entered upon the time called OaSiyl, q. v. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
See also OaSalahu EilomFA.

entry.sense: 5. tOS-l: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: 10. AstOSl: see 1, in two places, first and second sentences.

AstOSlhu He uprooted it; unrooted it; eradicated it; extirpated it; pulled it up, or out, or off, from its root, or foundation, or lowest part, (Ṣ, TA,) or with its roots, or foundations, or lowest parts;; (TA;) he cut it off (M, Mṣb) from its root, or lowest part, (M,) or with its roots, or lowest parts. (Mṣb.) You say, AisotaOoSala Qll-ehu XaOofatahumo, a precative phrase, meaning May God [extirpate or] remove (from them) their XOfp; which is an ulcer, or a purulent pustule, that comes forth in the foot, and is cauterized, and in consequence goes away: (M:) or AstOSl XOfthm [in general usage] means he extirpated them, or may he extirpate them; or he cut off, or may he cut off, the last remaining of them. (TA. [See also art. XOf.]) And AstOSl Alqawoma, i. e. qaTaEa OaSolahumo [He cut off the root, race, or stock, of the people; i. e. he extirpated them]. (M.) And AstOSl Qll-ehu Alkuf-aAra God destroyed altogether or entirely, or may God destroy altogether or entirely, the unbelievers. (Mṣb.) And AstOSl AlxitaAna He performed the circumcision so as to remove the prepuce utterly. (TA in art. sHt.)

entry.sense:
OaSolN The lower, or lowest, part of a thing; [i. e. its root, bottom, or foot;] (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also yaOoSuwlN↓: (M, Ḳ:) so of a mountain: and of a wall; (TA;) i. e. its foundation, or base: (Mṣb:) and of a tree [or plant]; (TA;) i. e. [its stem, or trunk, or stock, or] the part from which the branches are broken off: (TA in art. ksr:) [and also its root, or foot; for] the saAq of a tree is said to be the part between its OaSol and the place where its branches shoot out: (TA in art. swq:) [and a stump of a tree: and hence, a block of wood: (see exs. voce naqiyrN:)] pl. OuSuwlN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [pl. of pauc.] MSulN: (AḤn, Ḳ:) [ISd says that] the former is its only pl.: (M:) [but] the latter pl. occurs in a verse of Lebeed, (which see below,) as cited by AḤn. (TA.) You say, qaEada fiI OaSoli jabali He sat upon, or at, the lowest part [&c.] of the mountain; and fiI OaSoli AlHaAYiTi at the lowest part [&c.] of the wall. (TA.) And qalaEahu mino OaSolihi [He pulled it up, or out, or off, from its root, or foundation, or lowest part]; and bOuSuwlihi [with its roots, or foundations, or lowest parts; both meaning, utterly, entirely, or altogether]. (TA in explanation of AstOSlhu, q. v.) And qalaEa OaSola AlX-ajarapi He pulled up, or out, the lowest part, [or stem or stock or root or foot or stump,] of the tree. (TA.) Lebeed says, [of a wild cow,]
tajotaAfu MSula qaAliSK mutanab-icK
biEujuwbi OanoqaMCK yamiylu hayaAmuhaA
[She enters into the midst of the stems of trees with high branches, apart from others, i. e. from other trees, in the hinder parts of sand-hills, the fine loose sand thereof inclining upon her]: (AḤn, TA:) but as some relate it, OaSolFA qaAliSFA. (TA. [See EM, p. 161.])

A thing upon which another thing is built or founded [either properly or tropically]: (KT, Kull p. 50, TA:) the foundation, or basis, of a thing, [either properly or tropically,] which being imagined to be taken away, or abstracted, by its being taken away, or abstracted, the rest thereof becomes also taken away, or abstracted: (Er-Rághib, TA:) that upon which the existence of anything rests [or depends]; so the father is ASl to the offspring, and the river is ASl to the streamlet that branches off from it: (Mṣb:) or a thing upon which another thing depends as a branch; as the father in relation to the son: (Kull:) [i. e. the origin, source, beginning, or commencement, of a thing: the origin, original, root, race, or stock, from which a man springs. Hence XaIoCN lahu OaSolN A thing having root, or a foundation; and consequently, having rootedness, fixedness, im- mobility, stability, or permanence; rooted, fixed, immoveable, stable, or permanent. Whence,] maAlN lahu OaSolN, (Mgh voce EaqaArN,) and milokN vaAbitN lahu OaSolN, (Mṣb in explanation of that word,) and maA lahu OaSolN, (KT in explanation of the same,) [Real, or immoveable, property;] property such as consists in a house or land yielding a revenue; (Mgh;) or such as a house and palm-trees; (Mṣb;) or such as land and a house. (KT.) [Hence, also, OaSolN maAlK signifying A source of wealth or profit; a stock, fund, capital, or principal. You say,] Ait-axacotuhu linafosiI OaSola maAlKliln-asoli laA lilit-ijaArapi [I took it for myself as a source of wealth or profit, for breeding, not for traffic]. (Mgh in art. qnw.) You say also, baAEa OaSola OaroDihi [meaning He sold the fundamental property, i. e. the property itself, of his land]. (Ṣ voce EikorN.) [See also an ex. in conjugation 4 in art. bqaI: and another in the first paragraph {1} of art. Hbs.] And Oaxacahu biOaSolihi [He took it as it were with its root, or the like; meaning, entirely]. (Ḳ. [See OaSiylapN.]) And qaTaEa OaSolahumo [He cut off their root, race, or stock; i. e. he extirpated them]. (M.) And fulaAnN fiI OaSoli Sidoqi, (Ṣ and L in art. DnO,)
and fiI OaSoli suwoCK, (L ibid.,) Such a one is of an excel-lent origin, or race, or stock, (Ṣ, L,) and of a bad origin, or race, or stock; (L;) ASl being here syn. with DinoC (Ṣ, L) and maEodin. (Ṣ.) And fulaAnN fiI OaSoli Alkarami Such a one is of [a race] the source of generosity, or nobleness; ASl being here syn. with buWobuW. (Ṣ in art. bO.) And laA OaSola lahu walaA faSola He has no Hasab [i. e. grounds of pretension to respect or honour; or rank, or nobility, or the like]; nor tongue [i. e. eloquence]: (Ks, Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or he has no intellect, (IAạr, Mṣb, El-Munáwee,) nor eloquence: (El-Munáwee, TA:) or he has no lineage, nor tongue: (L:) or he has no father, nor child: (Kull p. 53:) [or he has no known stock nor branch; for] faSolN is the contr. of OaSolN, and in relationship signifies a branch. (Mṣb in art. fSl.) You say also, maA faEalotuhu OaSolFA, meaning I have not done it ever; and I will not do it ever; the last word being in the accus. case as an adverbial noun; i. e. I have not done it at any time; and I will not do it at any time. (Mṣb, El-Munáwee, TA.)
[It also signifies The original, or elemental, matter, material, substance, or part, of a thing; syn. with EunoSurN;] that from which a thing is taken [or made]. (KT voce daAxilN.)

[The fundamental, or essential, part of a thing. Hence, sing. of OuSuwlN as signifying The fundamentals, fundamental articles or dogmas, principles, elements, or rudiments, of a science, &c. Whence,] Eilomu AlOuSuwli, (TA,) [meaning] Eilomu OuSuwli Ald-iyni [The science of the fundamentals, fundamental articles or dogmas, or principles, of religion; the science of theology, or divinity; according to the system of the Muslims, as distinguished from that of the philosophers;] the science of the articles, or tenets, of belief; also called Alfiqohu AlOakobaru; (Kull. voce fiqoh;) and [more commonly] Eilomu AlkalaAmi. (Ḥájjee Khaleefeh.) [See also 2.]
A radical (as opposed to an augmentative) letter; as being an essential element of a word. (The Lexicons passim.)
The original form of a word. (The same passim.)
The original, or primary, signification of a word. (The same passim.)
An original copy of a book: and a copy of a book from which one quotes, or transcribes, any portion. (TA, &c., passim.)

[The original, or primary, state, or condition: or] the old state, or condition. (Kull p. 50.) You say, AlOaSolu fiI AlOaXoyaMCi AlUibaAHapu waAlT-ahaArapu The old state, or condition, of things is that of being allowable, or lawful, and that of being pure, or clean. (Kull ubi suprà.) And rajaEato UilaI OaSolihaA She returned, or reverted, [to her original, or old, state, or condition; or to her natural disposition;] to a natural disposition which she had relinquished. (Ṣ voce EitorN.)

[The utmost point, or degree, to which a person, or thing, can go, or be brought or reduced: and, app., the utmost that one can do. Hence the saying,] laOaDoTar-an-aka UilaI OaSolika [I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the utmost point to which thou canst go, or be brought or reduced: or, constrain thee to do thine utmost]. (IAạr in L, art. qH [where it is given in explanation of the phrases laOaDoTar-an-aka and quHaAHika; and so in the T in art. tr in explanation of the former of these two phrases; which is said in the M, in art. tr, to mean I will assuredly make thee to have recourse to thine utmost effort, or endeavour; and in the L in art. qH this is given as another explanation of the latter of the same two phrases. See also the saying, laOulojiYan-aka UilaI qur-i qaraArika, explained voce qaraArN.])

[That by being which a thing is what it is, or in being which it consists; or its ultimate constituent; syn. HaqiyqapN; a meaning well known; and indicated, in the A and TA, by the coupling of Haqiyqap with OaSol, evidently as an explicative adjunct.]

[The prime of a thing; the principal, purest, best, or choicest, part thereof; what is, or constitutes, the most essential part thereof; its very essence. Hence,] OaSolu daArK [The principal part of a country]; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, voce EaqorN;) [which is] the place where the people dwell, or abide. (As and Ṣ ibid. [See EaqorN.]) And OaSolN qawomK [The principal place of abode of a people]. (Ṣ and Ḳ voce bayoDapN. [See this word.]) And huwa fiI OaSoli qawomihi He is of the prime, or of the purest in race, the best, or the choicest, of his people; i. q. Suy-aAbatihimo, and Suy-aAbihimo. (TA in art. Syb.)

What is most fit, or proper: as when one says, AlOaSolu fiI AlUinosaAni AlEilomu [What is most fit, or proper, in man, is knowledge]; i. e., knowledge is more fit, or proper, than ignorance: and AlOaSolu fiI AlmubotadaUi Alt-aqodiymu What is [most] fit, or proper, in the case of the inchoative, is the putting [it] before [the enunciative], whenever there is no obstacle. (Kull p.50.)
What is preponderant in relation to what is preponderated: as, in language, the word used in its proper sense [in relation to that used in a tropical sense]. (Kull ibid.)
What is [essential, or] requisite, or needful: as when one says AlOaSolu fiI AlHayawaAni AlgicaMCu [What is essential, or requisite, or needful, in the case of the animal, is food]. (Kull ibid.)
A [primary, or] universal, or general, rule, or canon. (Kull ibid.)
An indication, an evidence, or a proof, in relation to that which is indicated, or evidenced, or proved. (Kull ibid.)
OaSalN: see its n. un., OaSalapN
OaSilN, (Ḳ,) or OaSiylN↓, (M,) i. q. musotaOoSilN↓. (M, Ḳ.) You say qaloEN OaSilN Eradicating, or extirpating, evulsion: (TA:) or qaToEN OaSiylN↓ extirpating excision. (M.)
OuSulN, said by some to be a pl., and by others to be a dial. var., of OaSiylN: see the latter word, in two places.

hom.sense: OaSalapN: see OaSiylapN.

Also A kind of serpent, the most malignant, or noxious, of serpents: (Ṣ:) or a serpent, (M, Ḳ,) short, (M, [where, in the only copy to which I have access, I find added, kaAlriYapi, app. a mistranscription, for kaAlr-um-api, like the fragment of a rope,]) or small, (Ḳ,) red, but not intensely red, (M,) very deadly, of the most malignant, or noxious, kind, (TA,) having one leg, upon which it stands, (M, TA,) then turns round, then springs, (TA,) that springs upon a man, and blows, killing everything upon which it blows: (M:) or, as some say, a great serpent, (M, Ḳ,) that kills by its blowing: (Ḳ:) or one of the very crafty kinds of serpents, short and broad, said to be like the shaft of an arrow, and it springs upon the horseman: (Mṣb:) pl. OaSalN↓, (Ṣ, M. Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [pl. of pauc.] MSaAlN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence, app.,] † Short and broad: applied to a man and to a woman. (TA.)

entry.sense: OaSoliI-N [Radical; fundamental; primitive; original; underived: an epithet of extensive application; and particularly applied to a letter of a word, as opposed to augmentative; and to a signification]. (The Lexicons, &c. passim.)
OaSoliy-apN [The quality denoted by the epithet OaSoliI-N; radicalness,, &c.:] a term used by IJ [and others] in the place of taOaS-ulN: see 5. (M.)

hom.sense: OaSiylN [Having root, or a foundation; and consequently, having rootedness, fixedness, immobility, stability, or permanence; rooted, fixed, immoveable, stable, or permanent]. You say, Uin-a Aln-axola fiI OaroDinaA laOaSiylN Verily the palm-trees in our land remain permanently, not perishing. (A, TA.)
A man having OaSol, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., lincage, or pedigree: (TA:) or established in his OaSol: (Abu-l-Baḳà, TA:) or noble, or generous. (Mṣb.)

A man firm of judgment, and intelligent. (M, Ḳ.* [Accord. to the copies of the latter, the signification is EaAqibN vaAbitu Alr-aOoIi: but I think that the right reading of the first word is EaAqilN, as in the M, in which this word occupies the last place in the explanation.]) And OaSiylu Alr-aOoIi A man firm, or sound, of judgment. (Ṣ.) And raOoIN OaSiylN Judgment having OaSol [i. e. firmness]. (M.) And majodN OaSiylN Glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, having a firm root or foundation. (Ṣ.) And Xar-N OaSiylN Vehement evil or mischief. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
See also OaSilN, in two places.
[Hence, app.,] AlOaSiylu Destruction: and death: as also, in both senses, AlOaSiylapu↓. (Ḳ.)

[The evening; or] i. q. EaXiI-N; (M, Ḳ, Mṣb, TA;) i. e. (Mṣb, TA) the time from the EaSor, (Ṣ, TA,) from the prayer of the ESr, (Mṣb,) to sunset; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also OaSiylapN↓: (R, TA:) the pl. is OuSulN, (Ṣ, M, R, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or ↓this is a sing., (TA,) or it may be a sing., (M,) for it is used as such, (M, TA,) and OuSolaAnN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and MSaAlN, (Ṣ, M, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) [a pl. of pauc.,] or, accord. to Es-Saláh Es-Safadee, this is a pl. of OuSulN, the sing., not the pl., (TA,) or it is pl. of OuSulN, (Zj, M,) which may be a pl. or a sing., (M,) and OaSaAYilu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) as though pl. of OaSiylapN, (Ṣ,) or it is pl. of this last word. (R, TA.) You say, laqiytuhu OaSiylFA and OuSulFA↓, i. e. [I met him in the evening,] EaXiy-FA. (A, TA.) From the pl. OuSolaAnu is formed the dim. OuSayolaAnN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is extr., (M, Ḳ,) because the dim. of a pl. is [regularly] formed only from a pl. of pauc., which ASlAn is not; or, if ASlAn be a sing., like rum-aAnN and qurobaAnN, this dim. is regular: (M:)
sometimes, (Ḳ,) one says also OuSayolaAlN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) substituting l for the [final] n (Ṣ, M.*) You say, laqiytuhu OuSayolaAnFA↓ and OuSayolaAlFA↓, meaning, as above, EaXiy-FA: (A, TA:) and Lḥ mentions laqiytuhu OuSay-aAlFA↓. (So in two copies of the Ṣ.)
OaSiylapN A man's whole property: (M, Ḳ:) or his palm-trees: (Ḳ, TA: in the CK his palmtree:) thus in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz. (O, TA.)
