Oaxacahu biOaSiylatihi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and biOaSalatihi↓, (IAạr, M, Ḳ,) He took it altogether, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [as it were] with its root, (Ṣ, M,) not leaving aught of it. (TA.) And jaAWuwA biOaSiylatihimo They came altogether; the whole of them. (Ṣ, Z.)
lifulaAnK OaroDN OaSiylapN To such a one belongs land long possessed, or inherited from his parents, by means of which he has his living: a phrase of the people of Et-Táïf. (TA.)
See also OaSiylN, in two places.

entry.sense: OuSuwliI-N One skilled in the science termed EilomN AlOuSuwli: see OaSolN. (TA.)
laqiytuhu OuSay-aAlFA: see OaSiylN, last sentence.
OuSayolaAnN and OuSayolaAlN: see OaSiylN, in four places, last two sentences.
laqiytuhu muWoSilFA I met him entering upon the time called the OaSiyl. (TA.) And OatayonaA muWoSiliyna We came entering upon the time so called. (Ṣ.)
OaSolN muWaS-alN [ A root, or foundation, or the like, made firm, or fixed, or established]. (Ṣ.) [See also OaSiylN.]
XaApN musotaOoSalapN A sheep, or goat, whose horn has been taken from its root. (TA.)
musotaOoSilN: see OaSilN.
yaOoSuwlN: see OaSolN, first sentence.

1. OaT-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOoTiTu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OaTiyTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaT-N, (TA,) It produced, made, gave, emitted, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and particularly, it creaked; and it moaned;] said of a camel's saddle, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, [in the CK, Alr-ajulu is put by mistake for Alr-aHolu]) [and particularly of a new camel's saddle,] and the like, (Ḳ,) such as a [plaited or woven girth called] nisoE and of everything of which the sound resembles that of a new camel's saddle, (TA,) and of a palm-trunk, and of a tree of the kind called sidor, (Ṣ TA,) or of the kind called saroH, (TA,) and of a cane or reed on the occasion of its being straightened, [in which instance it is said to be tropical, but if so it is tropical in several other instances,] and of a bow, (TA,) and of the belly by reason of emptiness, (Ṣ,* TA,) and, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, ‡ of heaven, or the sky, notwithstanding there being [really] no OaTiyT in this instance, for it is meant to denote [the presence of] multitude, and confirmation of the majesty of God. (TA.) [It is also said of other things, as will be shown by phrases here following, and by explanations of OaTiyTN below.] You also say, OaT-ati AlUibilu, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. OaTiyTN, (TA,) The camels moaned by reason of fatigue, or uttering their yearning cry to their young, (Ḳ, TA,) and sometimes by reason of fulness of their udders with milk. (TA.) And laA Mtiyka maA OaT-ati AlUibilu I will not come to thee as long as camels utter cries [or moan] by reason of the heaviness of their loads. (Ṣ.) And laA OafoEalu celika maA OaT-ati AlUibilu, meaning I will not do that ever. (TA.) And maA lanaA baEiyrN yaYiT-u We have not a camel that moans, or cries; meaning we have not any camel; for the camel cannot but do so. (TA, from a trad.) [See also OaTiyTN, below.] And OaT-ato lahu raHimiI ‡ [My feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood,] became affected with tenderness, or compassion, and became moved, [or rather pleaded,] for him [or in his favour]: (Ḳ, TA:) and hence Alt-aOaT-uTu↓ [inf. n. of the verb in the syn. phrase taOaT-aTato lahu raHimiI]. (Ṣgh, TA.) And OaT-ato bika Alr-aHimu [The feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood, pleaded, or hath pleaded, in thee;] i. e., inclined thee to favour. (Ḥam p. 765.) [See another ex. voce HaAs-apN.]
5: see 1, near the end.
OaT-N: see OaTiyTN, below.
nusuwEN OuT-aTN [pl. of MT-N, part. n. of 1,] Creaking [plaited, or woven, thongs]. (Ḳ.)

OaTiyTN [as explained in what here follows seems to be properly an inf. n., though, like all inf. ns., it may be used as a subst.:] The sounding, or the like, or the sound, or the like, [and particularly the creaking, or creaking sound, and the moaning, or moaning sound,] of a camel's saddle (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) when new; (TA;) and so OaT-N↓ of the litters and saddles of camels when the riders are heavy thereon; and the former, also, of a door; said, in a trad., of the gate of paradise, by reason of its being crowded; (TA;) and of a plaited or woven thong when stretching; (Ez-Zejjájee, TA;) and of the back [when strained]; (Ḳ;) and of the bowels, (TA,) and of the belly, or inside, by reason of hunger, (Ḳ,) or by reason of vehement hunger; (TA;) and of camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of their burdens, (Ḳ,) or by reason of the heaviness of their burdens; (Ṣ;) and the prolonging of the cries of camels: (TA:) but ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh says that the cry of camels is termed rugaMCN, and that OaTiyTN signifies the sounding, or sound, of their bellies, or insides, by reason of repletion from drinking. (IB, TA.) OaholN SahiylK WaOaTiyTK, occurring in a trad., means † Possessors of horses and of camels. (TA.)
Also † Hunger, (Ḳ, TA,) itself, as well as the sound of the bowels or belly by reason thereof: from Ez-Zejjájee. (TA.)

OaT-aATN Sounding much; noisy; (Ḳ, TA;) having a sound: applied [to any of the things mentioned above in the explanations of OaT-a and OaTiyTN; and] to a hide; and to a camel repleted with drink; and to a road: fem. with p {OaT-aATapN}: which, applied to a woman, signifies one whose faroj has a sound UicaA juwmiEato. (TA.)

1. OaTarahu, aor. _i {yaOoTiru} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yaOoTuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OaTorN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and OT-rhu↓ inf. n. taOoTiyrN; (Ḳ;) He bent it, or curved it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) namely, a bow, (Ṣ, A,) and a twig, or the like: (A:) he laid hold upon one of its two extremities, and curved it: he bent it, or curved it; namely, anything; EalaI X-aIoCK upon a thing: and the latter verb, [or both,] he bent it into the form of a hoop, bringing its two extremities together. (TA.)
It is said of Adam, kaAna TuwaAlFA faOaT-arahu↓ Qll-ehu He was tall, and God bent him, and diminished his height. (TA.)

And one says, Oaxaca EalaI yadaIi AlZ-aAlimi waOaTarahu EalaI AlHaq-i ‡ [He laid hold upon the two hands, or arms, of the wrongdoer, or prevented, restrained, or withheld, him from doing that which he desired,] and bent him to [conformity with] what was right. (AA, from a trad.) And OaTarota fulaAnFA EalaI mawad-atika ‡ [Thou hast bent such a one to love thee]. (A.)
OaTara Als-ahoma (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOoTiru} and _u {yaOoTuru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He wound an OuTorap upon the arrow. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OaTara Albayota, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He made an UiTaAr, which is a thing resembling a zone or belt, to the tent or house. (Ḳ, TḲ.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
OaT-arato, inf. n. taOoTiyrN She (a girl, IAạr) remained in the house, or tent, of her father, some time, or long, (IAạr, Ḳ,) without marrying. (IAạr.) [See also 5.]
5. tOT-r It (a spear) bent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it (a thing) became crooked, curved, or bent; as also AnOTr↓: (Ḳ, TA:) it became bent into the form of a hoop, its two extremities being brought together. (TA.)
taOaT-arato She affected a bending of her person, body, or limbs, in her gait. (A.)
He confined himself (Ḳ, TA) in a place. (TA.)
taOaT-arato She (a woman) remained, or stayed, in her house, or tent; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) she kept to it. (TA.) [See also 2.]

entry.sense: 7: see 5.

OaTorN The place of curvature (munoHanaI) of a bow, and of a cloud: (Ḳ, TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst., and, being so used, admitting the dual form: or the bent, or curved, part of the extremity of a bow; to which Tarafeh likens the curving of the ribs of a she-camel: (TA:) and what resembles a curvature, seen in the clouds: an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n. (Skr, TA.)
OuTorapN The sinew that is wound immediately above the notch of an arrow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also UiTaArN↓. (Ḳ.)
The edge of the glans of the penis; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also ↓the latter word. (Ḳ, TA.)
The flesh surrounding the nail: (Ḳ:) pl.OuTarN and UiTaArN. (TA.)
A mixture of ashes and blood with which a fracture in a cooking-pot is smeared (Ṣ, Ḳ) and repaired. (TA.)
UiTaArN Anything that surrounds another thing: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as the hoop of a tambourine, (A, Mgh, TA,) and of a sieve. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.)
A ring of hair surrounding the head, the middle of it being bald. (TA.)
The branches of a vine, bent, or wreathed, so as to form a covering over-head. (Ḳ.)
See also OuTorapN, in two places.
UiTaAru AlHaAfiri The part of the hoof of a horse or the like which surrounds, or extends around, the OaXoEar [q.v.]. (Ṣ.)

UiTaAru AlX-afapi (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) ‡ The part, (A,) or flesh, (Mṣb,) surrounding the lip: (A, Mṣb:) or the part that separates between the lip and the hairs of the mustache: (Ḳ:) or the edge of the upper lip, between the lip itself and the parts where the hair grows: (IAth:) or the rising edge, or ridge, between the part where the mustache is clipped and the lip, intermixing with the mouth. (AʼObeyd.) The Muslim should clip his mustache so that this part shall appear. (Mṣb, TA.)
UiTaAru bayotK A thing resembling a zone, or belt, of a tent or house. (Ḳ.)

UiTaAri mina Aln-aAsi ‡ A ring, or circle, of men. (Ḳ.) One says, humo UiTaArN libaniI fulaAnK ‡ They have alighted and taken up their abode [so that they form a ring] around the sons of such a one. (A, Mṣb.)
OaTiyrN A sin; a crime; an offence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, OaxacaniI biOaTiyri gayoriI He punished me for the sin, crime, or offence, of another than myself. (Ṣ.)
maOoTuwrapN A bow. (A.)

A milking-vessel of skin (EulobapN) for the head of which a twig is bent into the form of a hoop, and put round, after which its lip is covered; (Ḳ, TA;) or, sometimes, the edges of the skin of the Elbp are folded upon the hoop-formed twig, and dry upon it. (TA.)

OuTumN and OuTomN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like OujumN and OujomN, (Ṣ, and Mgh in art. Ajm) A fortress: or, as some say, any lofty building: (Mgh:) or a [building such as is termed] qaSor [q. v.]: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and any fortress built of stones: and any square, roofed, house: (Ḳ:) pl. (of pauc., TA) MTaAmN (Ṣ, Mgh. Ḳ) and (of mult., TA) OuTuwmN: (Ḳ:) MTaAmN signifies fortresses of the people of El-Medeeneh: and one of these is termed OaTamapN↓: (Ṣ:) or this signifies [simply] a fortress; and its pl. is MTaAmN (TA.)
OaTamapN: see above.

MTaAmN muWaT-amapN Lofty [fortresses,, &c.]: (A, TA:) [or it may signify fortresses,, &c., disposed in order, or grouped together; for it is said to be] a phrase like OabowaAbN mubaw-abapN, (O, TA,) or like OajonaAdN mujan-adapN. (Ḳ.)

1. Oaf-a, aor. yaWuf-N (IDrd, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and yaYif-u, (IDrd, M, Ḳ,) the latter agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former, though irregular, is the more common,] inf. n. Oaf-N; (M, Mgh;) and Of-f↓, inf. n. tOofiyfN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and tOf-f↓; (M, Ḳ;) He said Ouf-i [q. v.], (IDrd, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) by reason of anxiety, or disquietude of mind, or by reason of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust: (IDrd, M, Ḳ:) held by Sb to be of the same class as sab-aHa and hal-ala meaning “he said suboHaAna Qll-ehi” and “he said laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehu.” (M.) You say also, Oaf-afahu↓, and Oaf-afa↓ bihi, and taOaf-afa↓ bihi, meaning He said to him Ouf-i. (M.) And jaEala fulaAnN yataOaf-afu↓ mino riyHK wajadahaA Such a one began to say Ouf-i Ouf-i by reason of a smell which he perceived. (T.) And Uin-ahu yataOaf-afu↓ Ealayohi Verily he is angry with him, or enraged against him. (TA.)
2: see 1, in three places.
5: see 2, in four places.
Oafo and Oaf-i and Oaf-K, or OafK: see Ouf-N.
Uifo and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see the next paragraph.

Ouf-N Dirt, or filth; as also Ouf-apN↓: (Ṣ:) you say, Ouf-aA lahu, and Ouf-apF↓, Dirt, or filth, to him; in which the tenween is for the purpose of rendering them indeterminate; (Ṣ;) and Ouf-a lahu watuf-N; (T;) and Ouf-apF↓ watuf-apF; and Ouf-aA watuf-aA; (T, Ṣ;) the latter of which is an imitative sequent: (Ṣ:) or Ouf-N signifies the dirt of the ear; and tuf-N, the dirt of the nails; (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ; but in the last, of the nail;) the phrases mentioned above being used on the occasion of deeming a thing dirty or filthy, and afterwards on the occasion of experiencing annoyance or disgust at anything; (Aṣ, T, M,* TA;) and OafafN↓, also, has the former of these two meanings: (TA:) or Ouf-N signifies the dirt around the nail; (M;) or the dirt of the nail; (Ḳ;) and tuf-N, the dirt in the nail: (M:) or the former, a paring of the nail: and a piece of stick, or a reed, which one takes up from the ground: (Ḳ:) in these various senses they are explained as used in the saying, Ouf-aA lahu watuf-aA: (TA:) or the former signifies stink: (Zj, TA:) or paucity; (T, M, Ḳ) as also OafafN↓; (M;) or from OafafN↓ signifying a thing little in quantity; (T; and the same meaning is assigned to this word in the Ḳ;) and tuf-N is an imitative sequent, (T, M, Ḳ,) of the same meaning. (M.)

Ouf-i, also, is a word expressive of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust; (M, Mgh;) or of dislike, displeasure, or hatred; (Ḳ;) and has six forms; (T, Ṣ;) mentioned by Akh; (Ṣ;) or ten; (M;) or forty; (Ḳ;) or more; (TA;) as follow: Ouf-i and Ouf-a and Ouf-u and Ouf-K and Ouf-aA and Ouf-N (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and Ouf-i and Oufa and Oufu and OufK and OufFA and OufN (Ḳ) and Oufo (M, Ḳ) and Ouf-o and Ouf-aI↓, pronounced with imáleh, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. with pure imáleh, and Ouf-aI↓ with intermediate imáleh, and Ouf-aI↓ without imáleh, the alif [written I] in these three denoting the fem. gender, and Ouf-iI↓, with kesr to the f, (Ḳ,) i. e., as a prefixed noun with its complement, [the latter being the pronoun of the first pers.,] (TA,) and Ouf-uwoho↓, (Ḳ,) with damm to the O and f, which latter is with teshdeed, and with the w and h quiescent, (TA,) and Ouf-apo↓ [in a copy of the M Ouf-apF↓] and Oufiho↓ and Ouf-uho↓ (Ḳ) and Uifo↓ and Uif-o↓ and Uifi↓ and UifK↓ and UifFA↓ and UifN↓ and Uif-K↓ and Uif-F↓ and Uif-N↓ and Uif-u↓, with damm to the f, which is with teshdeed, [in a copy of the M Uif-a↓,] and Uif-aA↓, like Uin-aA, and Uif-aI↓, pronounced with imáleh, and Uif-iI↓, with kesr, (Ḳ,) i. e., prefixed to the pronoun of the first person, (IAmb,) and Oafo↓ and Oaf-i↓ (Ḳ) and Oaf-K↓ or OafK↓ and Mfi↓, or Mf-i↓, and MfK↓, or Mf-K↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) [all these forms, making the number (forty) mentioned by the author of the Ḳ, I have drawn from a comparison of three copies of that work, and I believe them to be correct: some other forms are mentioned by SM as perhaps indicated in the Ḳ; but I see no good reason for this: he then adds,] and Oafaho↓ and Oafuwho↓ and Oaf-aho↓, the last mentioned by IB on the authority of IḲṭṭ. (TA.) Ouf-i, [with its variants,] in its primary sense, denotes one's blowing at a thing that falls upon him, such as dust or ashes; or at the place, to remove therefrom what is annoying; therefore people say, at anything that they deem troublesome, or displeasing, or hateful, Ouf-i lahu [as though meaning A puff, or blast of breath, to it]: (Ḳṭ, T:) or [rather] it is a word imitative of a sound; [like ugh in English, both in sound and meaning; and in meaning like our interjections foh and faugh;] (Bḍ on the ex. in the Ḳur which will be found below, and TA;) denoting vexation, or distress of mind, or disgust; (Bḍ ubi suprà) or denoting contempt: (TA:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I am vexed, or distressed in mind, or disgusted: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) or it is an imperative verbal noun [denoting disgust or abhorrence, like out, and away]: (IJ, M:) or he who says Ouf-aA laka uses it in the manner of an imprecation, like as one says wayolFA lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says Ouf-N laka puts it in the nom. case because of the l, like as one says wayolN lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says Ouf-K laka puts it in the gen. case likening it to words imitative of sounds. (IAmb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xvii. 24], walaA taqulo lahumaA Ouf-i, (T, Ṣ, TA,) or Ouf-K, (TA, [in which other readings also are mentioned,]) [And say not thou to them (i. e. to thy father and mother) Ugh,, &c.,] meaning, do not thou deem anything of their affairs burdensome, nor be contracted in bosom thereby, nor be rough, or harsh, or coarse, to them: (Ḳṭ, T:) or do not thou say to them anything expressive of the least disgust, when they have become old, but take upon thyself their service; Ouf-i signifying stink. (Zj, T.)

dictScrap.title: Uif-o / Uif-K / Uif-F / Uif-N / Uif-u / Uif-aA / Uif-aI / Uif-iI

hom.sense: Uif-o and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see Ouf-N.
For Uif-N, see also Uif-aAnN, in three places.

entry.sense: Oaf-apN: see Uif-aAnN, in two places.

hom.sense: Ouf-apN: see Ouf-N, in four places.
Also A dirty, a filthy, an unclean, man: (Ḳ:) from Ouf-N signifying the “dirt of the nail.” (TA.)
One in want; poor; possessing little: (Ḳ:) from OafafN signifying “a thing little in quantity.” (TA.)

A coward: (Ḳ:) as though originally cuw Ouf-apK, i. e. holding back, by reason of disgust, (mutaOaf-ifN,) from fight: (TA:) or experiencing vexation or disgust, and languid or sluggish, in war: (IAạr:) also heavy, or sluggish. (IAth.)

entry.sense: Uif-apN: see Uif-aAnN in three places.

hom.sense: OafafN Vexation, distress of mind, or disgust. (T, IAth, Ḳ.)
See also Ouf-N, in three places.
And see Uif-aAnN, in three places.

entry.sense: Oafaho and Oaf-aho and Ouf-aho and Ouf-iho and Ouf-uho: see Ouf-N.
Ouf-aI, pronounced in three different ways; and Ouf-iI: see Ouf-N.
Uif-aA and Uif-aI and Uif-iI: see Ouf-N.
Oafuwho: see Ouf-N.
OufuwfapN: see what next follows.

Oaf-aAfN A man who says Ouf-i much or often; (M, TA;) as also OuwfuwfapN↓, accord. to the copies of the O and TṢ and Ḳ; but in other lexicons OuwfuwfapN↓: in the O, one who ceases not to say to another Ouf-i laka: in the Jm, the last of these three words is explained as meaning one who ceases no to say this at some of his affairs. (TA.)

Uif-aAnN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and Oaf-aAnN (T, TṢ, L, Ḳ) and Uif-N↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OafafN↓ (T, L, Ḳ) and Uif-apq↓ (L, M) and Oaf-apN↓ (M) and tiYif-apN↓, (T, M, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) of the measure tafoEilapN, [being originally taOofifapN,] accord. to J, who appears to be right in saying so, (IB,) and so accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, who states, on authority of Aboo-Bekr, that it is thus in some of the copies of the Book of Sb, (L,) though in other copies of that book said to be of the measure faEil-apN, (IB, L,) A time; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as in the sayings, kaAna celika EalaI Uif-i↓ celika, and Uif-aAnihi (Ṣ, TA) and Oafafihi↓, and Uif-atihi↓, and taYif-atihi↓, (TA,) That was at the time of that; (Ṣ, TA;) and OataAniI fiI Uif-aAni celika, (IAạr, L,) and EalaI Uif-aAni celika, (IAạr, T, M, L,) and Oaf-aAnihi, (T, L,) and Uif-ihi↓, (M, L,) and Oafafihi↓, (IAạr, T, L,) and Uif-atihi↓, (M, L,) and Oaf-atihi↓, (M,) and taYif-atihi↓, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, L,) preceded by ElI, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, &c.,) and by fI, (L,) He came to me at the time of that. (IAạr, T, &c.)
Ouf-uwoho: see Ouf-N.
Mfi and Mf-i and MfK and Mf-K: see Ouf-N.
OuwfuwfapN: see Oaf-aAfN.
taYif-apN: see Uif-AnN, in three places.
mutaOaf-ifN Eani AlqitaAli [app. Holding back, by reason of disgust, from fight; as though saying Ouf- at the mention thereof: see Ouf-apN]. (TA.)

1. Oafaxahu, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, &c.,) aor. _i {yaOofixu}, inf. n. OafoxN, (L,) He, [or it] struck him, or hit him, [or hurt him,] on the part of his head called the yaOofuwx. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) He who pronounces yAfwx without C says yafaxahu. (Mṣb.)
maOofuwxN A man having his head broken in the part called the yaOofuwx. (L.)

yaOofuwxN, (Lth, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also yaAfuwxN, without C, but the former is the more correct and the better, (Lth, Az, Mṣb,) and is of the measure yafoEuwlN, (Lth, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) whereas the latter is of the measure faAEuwlN, (Lth, Az, Mṣb,) [The top, vertex, or crown, of the head; or the part of the top of the head which is crossed by the coronal suture, and comprises a portion of the sagittal suture;] the part where the anterior and posterior bones of the head meet; (Ḳ;) the place that is in a state of commotion in the head of an infant; (Ṣ;) the place which, in the head of a child, does not close up until after some years; or does not become knit together in its several parts; and this is where the bone of the anterior part of the head and that of its posterior part meet; (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán;”) the place that is soft, in a child's head, before the two bones called the nam-aAgap and ram-aAEap meet, between the haAmap [or middle of the head] and the forehead: (L:) or the middle of the head when it has become hard and strong; before which it is not thus called: (Mṣb:) pl. yaMfiyxu; (Ṣ;) so in the old lexicons [in general]; but in the T and Ḳ yawaAfiyxu [which is pl. of yAfwx without C; or, as pl. of yOfwx, is like tawaAriyxu as pl. of taOoriyxN]; and because of this form of the pl., F says that J is in error in mentioning the word in the present art.: it has been shown, however, that J is not in error in this case. (TA.)
[Hence the saying,] Oanotumo yaMfiyxu AlX-arafi ‡ Ye are the centres and summits of the heads of nobility. (L, from a trad.) And yaOofuwxu All-ayoli † The main [or middle] part of the night. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[See also art. yfx.]

hom.sense: 1. Oafaqa, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOofiqu}, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. OafoqN, (TḲ,) He went his own way, at random, or heedlessly, (rakiba raOosahu,) and went away in the MfaAq [or regions,, &c., of the land]: (Lth, JK, Ḳ:) or he went away in, or into, the land, or country: (Ṣ:) and he took his way into the MfAq [or regions,, &c.,] of the land. (JK.)

[Hence, app.,] Oafaqa, aor. as above; thus, says IB, accord. to Ḳz, and thus it is given on the authority of Kr; (TA;) [see MfiqN;] or Oafiqa, aor. _a {yaOofaqu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. OafaqN; (Ṣ;) He attained the utmost degree, [as though he reached the Oufuq (or horizon, or furthest point of view,)] in generosity; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities. (Ḳ.)
Also, Oafaqa, aor. _i {yaOofiqu}, (Kr, Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. OafoqN, (JK, TA,) He overcame, or surpassed. (Kr, Ibn-ʼAbbád, JK, Ḳ.)

And, inf. n, OufuwqN, He was goodly, or beautiful; he possessed the quality of exciting admiration and approval by his beauty and the pleasingness of his aspect; said of a camel, and of a horse. (JK.)

Oafaqa Ealayohi (JK, TA) He (a man) excelled him; namely, another man: (JK:) or he preceded him in excellence; or outwent him therein; as also Oafaqahu, aor. _i {yaOofiqu}. (TA.) [It is like faAqahu.]

Oafaqa fiI AlEaTaMCi, aor. _i {yaOofiqu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. OafoqN, (TA,) He gave to some more than to others. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying of El-Aạshà,
walaA Almalika Aln-uEomaAnu yawoma laqiytuhu
bigiboTatihi yuEoTiI AlquTuwTa wayaOofiqu
[Nor the King En-Noamán, on the day that I met him, in his goodly, or happy, condition, giving gifts, or stipends, or written obligations conferring gifts, and giving to some more than to others]: (Ṣ:) or the meaning is, writing [writs of] gifts, and sealing them: or, as some say, taking his way into the MfAq [or regions,, &c.,] of the land. (JK.)
Oafaqahu, aor. _i {yaOofiqu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OafoqN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He tanned it (namely a hide) until it became what is termed Oafiyq. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tOf-q binaA He (a man, Aṣ, TA) came to us mino OufuqK [from a region,, &c., of the land]: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) or came to us, and alighted at our abode as a guest: and in the Nawádir el-Aaráb, tOf-q bihi is said to signify he reached him, or overtook him; as also tl-fq bh (TA.)
OufoqN: see OufuqN.

OafaqN The main and middle part (sanan) of a road; (Ḳ;) the face, or surface, thereof: (IAạr, Ḳ:) pl. MfaAqN. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying, qaEada fulaAnN EalaI Oafaqi AlT-ariyqi [Such a one sat upon the main and middle part, or face, or surface, of the road]. (TA.)

The flanks, or ilia: or, as some say, skins; or skin; as in the saying, Xaribotu Hat-aI malaOotu OafaqiI I drank until I filled my skin: (JK:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of OafaqapN↓; (IAạr;) which signifies the flank; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as does also MfiqapN↓. (Th, Ḳ.)
Also pl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or [rather] quasi-pl. n., (M, Ḳ,) of OafiyqN, q. v. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
OafiqN: see OafiyqN, in two places.

hom.sense:
OufuqN (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and OufoqN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; or a remote side; syn. naAHiyapN; (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and a border, or an extremity; (JK;) of a land, or of the earth; and of the sky, or heavens: (JK, Mgh, Mṣb:) [or the horizon, or part next to the horizon, of the sky and of the earth;] or what appears of the sides (Aln-awaAHiI) of the celestial sphere, (Ḳ, TA,) and of the borders, or extremities, of the earth: (TA:) or the place whence blows the south wind, and the north wind, and the west wind, and the east wind: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. MfaAqN: (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the sing. also is used as a pl.;
like fulokN, as is said in the Nh: (MF:) thus in the verse of El-ʼAbbás, in praise of the Prophet:
Oanota lam-a wulidota OaXoraqati AlOaro
DuwaDaMCa to binuwrika AlOufuqu
[When thou wast born, the earth became bright, and the tracts of the horizon, or the regions, shone with thy light]: or, as some say, AlAfq is made fem. by him as meaning Aln-aAHiyapu. (TA.) The phrase Hiyna yagiybu AlOufuqu means When the redness, or whiteness, in the Oufuq [or horizon] disappears. (Mgh.)

Also, in like manner, The side, or lateral part, of a tent: (JK:) or the part between the [two] anterior [pieces of wood called the] zir-aAni, in the [fore part called the] riwaAq, of a tent: (Ḳ:) and the sides, or lateral parts, of a tent of the kind belonging to the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)
OufuqN is also said to be a pl. of OafiyqN; but this is disallowed by Lḥ. (TA.)
See also MfiqN.
OafaqapN: see OafaqN.
Also A burying of a skin, or hide, in the earth, so that its hair may be removed, and it may become ready for tanning. (Lth, Ḳ,* TA.) [See OafiyqN.]

entry.sense: OafaqiI-N, (ISk, JK, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) contr. to rule, (T, Mṣb,) and OufuqiI-N↓, (Aṣ, ISk, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) agreeably with rule, (Ṣ,) being a rel. n. from OufuqN, (Mṣb,) and some (namely the lawyers, in relation to pilgrimage and the like, MF) say MfaAqiI-N↓, (Mgh, MF,) which is incorrect, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or whether it be correct, after the manner of OanoSaAriI-N and the like, requires consideration, (MF,) an epthet applied to a man, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb,) meaning One who is from the MfaAq [or lateral parts, or regions,] of the land; (ISk,* Ṣ, Mṣb;*) mentioned by Aboo-Naṣr: (Ṣ, referring to the first form of the word:) or one who goes about in the MfaAq: (JK:) or one who goes through the MfAq of the land in search of sustenance: (Ḳ,* TA:) as also Oaf-aAqN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) OufuqiI-u mak-apa or OafaqiI-u mk-p means He who is without the places where the pilgrims coming to Mekkeh enter upon the state of UiHoraAm. (Mgh.)
OufuqiI-N: see OafaqiI-N.

hom.sense: OafiyqN: see MfiqN.
Applied also to a bucket (dalow), meaning Excelling other buckets. (AA, Ḳ.)

Also, (Aṣ, Th, JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OafiyqapN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a more particular term than the former, like as jilodapN is more so than jilodN, (Mgh,) and OafiqN↓, (Ḳ, [but see what follows,]) The skin, or hide, that is not completely tanned, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that it is unsubstantial, not firm, or strong, or tough: (Mgh:) when its tanning is complete, and it becomes red, it is termed Oadiym: therefore OafiyqN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mṣb:) or in the second stage of its tanning; for in the first stage it is termed maniyoYap; then, Afyq; and then, Adym: (TA:) or that is tanned, but before it is sewed: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or before it is cut, or slit: (Ḳ:) or when it comes forth from the tan, its tanning being finished, (JK, TA,) its [original] odour being [still] in it: (TA:) or after it is tanned: (Mṣb:) or not tanned: (Th, TA:) or that is tanned without qaraZ or OaroTaI or any of the tans of the people of Nejd: (TA:) ISd says, I think that Th has mentioned OafiqN↓ as syn. with OafiyqN, and explained it as signifying the skin, or hide, that is not tanned; but I am not sure of it: (TA:) the pl. is OafaqN, (Lḥ, JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as OadamN is pl. of OadiymN, (Ṣ,) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (M, Ḳ,) and OufuqN (JK, Ḳ) is allowable, (JK,) or, accord. to Lḥ, it is not allowable, (TA,) and [pl. of pauc.] MfiqapN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as MdmapN and OarogifapN are pls. of OadiymN and ragiyfN. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) OafiyqapN↓ signifies also A siqaMC [or skin for water or milk, &c.] made of a hide of the kind termed Oafiyq. (Mgh.) And OafiyqN also signifies The skin of a man, and of any beast. (TA.)

entry.sense: OafiyqapN: see OafiyqN, in two places.
Oaf-aAqN: see OafaqiI-N.

MfiqN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) of the measure faAEilN, (Ṣ, Ḳz, TA, [in the CK AafiqN, and in like manner in a copy of the JK,]) from Oafiqa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as IB says, accord. to Ḳz, from Oafaqa, aor. _i {yaOofiqu}, and so accord. to Kr, and shown to be of the measure faAEilN by several verses in which it occurs, (TA,) One who has attained the utmost degree in generosity; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities; (Ḳ;) as also OafiyqN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {OafiyqapN}. (IF, Ḳ.) Also applied to a horse, Generous with respect to both parents: fem. with p {MfiqapN}. (Ṣ.) And applied to a camel, That excites admiration and approval by his generousness, excellence, high blood, or the like; (JK;) and so OufuqN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a mare, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a she-camel. (JK.).
MfiqapN: see OafaqN.
MfaAqiI-N: see OafaqiI-N.

1. Oafakahu, aor. _i {yaOofiku}, inf. n. OafokN, (with fet-ḥ, Ṣ, TA, its only form, TA, [in the CK Aifok,]) He changed his, or its, manner of being, or state; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and he turned him, or it, (i. e., anything, Mṣb,) away, or back; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) Eani AlX-aIoCi [from the thing]; (Ṣ;) or Eano wajohihi [from his, or its, mode, or manner, of being,, &c.]: (Mṣb:) so in the Ḳur xlvi. 21, OajiYotanaA litaOofikanaA Eano MlihatinaA Hast thou come to us to turn us away, or back, from our gods? (Bḍ:) or he turned him away, or back, by lying: (TA:) or he changed, or perverted, his judgment, or opinion: (Ḳ:) or he deceived him, or beguiled him, and so turned him away, or back: and simply he deceived him, or beguiled him: and Oufika signifies he was turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [li. 9], yuWofaku Eanohu mano Oufika, i. e., He will be turned away from it (namely, the truth,) who is turned away in the foreknowledge of God: (TA:) or, accord. to Mujáhid, yuWofanu Eanohu mano Oufina [he will be weak in intellect and judgment so as to be thereby turned away from it who is weak in intellect and judgment]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, Oufika Alr-ajulu Eani Alxayori The man was turned away, or back, from good, or prosperity. (Sh.) And Oafakahu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He forbade him what he wished, (Ḳ, TA,) and turned him away, or back, from it. (TA.)

Oafaka, aor. _i {yaOofiku}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Oafika, aor. _a {yaOofaku}; (IAạr, Ḳ;) inf. n. UifokN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and OafokN and OafakN and OufuwkN; (Ḳ;) He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Of-k↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taOofiykN: (TA:) because a lie is a saying that is turned from its proper way, or mode. (Bḍ in xxiv. 11.)
Oafaka Aln-aAsa, aor. _i {yaOofiku}, inf. n. OafokN, He told the people what was false; Oafaka and Oafakotuhu being like kacaba and kacabotuhu. (Az, TA.)
Oafaka fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OafokN; (TA;) or the verb is Mfaka↓; (so in the printed edition of Bḍ, xlvi. 27;) He, or it, made such a one to lie, or say what was untrue. (Ḳ.)
Oufika He was weak [as though perverted] in his intellect and judgment or opinion. (Ḳ,* TA.) But Oafakahu Qll-ehu as meaning God rendered weak his intellect is not used. (L, TA.)
‡ It (a place) was not rained upon, and had no vegetation, or herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1.

8. QYotafakati Albalodapu [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytafakat], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) biOaholihaA, (Ṣ,) The land, or district, or the town, or the like, was, or became, overturned, or subverted, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with its inhabitants: (Ṣ:) as were the towns of the people of Lot. (TA.)
Hence it is said of El-Basrah, qadi QYotafakato biOaholihaA mar-atayoni, meaning ‡ It has been submerged with its inhabitants twice; as though subverted. (Sh.)
You say also, Aiytafakato tiloka AlOaroDu ‡ That land has been burnt up by drought. (IAạr.)

UifokN [an inf. n. used as a subst.;] A lie; a falsehood; (Ṣ, TA;) as also OafiykapN↓: pl. (of the latter, Ḳ) OafaAYiku. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, yaA laloOafiykapi↓, and yaA liloOafiykapi↓; [and laloOafay-ikapi↓, using the dim. form for the purpose of enhancement; i. e. O the lie! and O the great lie!] the l with fet-ḥ denoting calling to aid; and with kesr denoting wonder, as though the meaning were, O man, wonder thou at this great lie. (TA.)

Afkp [so in the TA, without any syll. signs; app. either OafokapN, an inf. n. of un., or MfikapN↓, like daAhiyapN;] A punishment sent by God, whereby the dwellings of a people are overturned: occurring in a trad. relating to the story of the people of Lot. (TA.)

sanapN OafikapN ‡ A year of drought or sterility: (Ḳ, TA:)
pl. OawaAfiku [contr. to rule, as though the sing. were MfikapN↓]. (Z, TA.)
OafuwkN: see Oaf-aAkN.

hom.sense: OafiykN One who is turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile; as also maOofuwkN↓. (Ḳ.)
Lacking strength or power or ability, and having little prudence and artifice. (Lth, Ḳ.)
See also Oaf-aAkN.

entry.sense: OafiykapN: see UifokN, in three places.
Also A severe, or distressing, calamity. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
Oufay-ikapN: see UifokN.

Oaf-aAkN A great, or habitual, liar; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Oafuwku↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OafiykN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. of the first [and last] with p {Oaf-aAkapN}: but the second is both masc. and fem.: (Mṣb:) the pl. of the second is Afk with damm [i. e. OufokN, accord. to the rule of the Ḳ, but the TA seems to indicate that it is OufukN, by likening it to the pl. of SabuwrN]. (Ḳ.)
MfikapN: see Afkp:
and see sanapN OafikpN.
maOofuwkN [Changed in his, or its, manner of being, or state: turned away, or back, from a thing:, &c.]: see maOofuwnN.

Weak [as though perverted] in his intellect (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and judgment or opinion; as also p: (AZ, Ṣ:) accord. to AʼObeyd, (or AA, as in one copy of the Ṣ,) a man who does not attain, or obtain, good, or prosperity. (Ṣ.)
Also, (Ḳ,) fem. with maOofuwnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ A place, (Ḳ,) or land, (OaroDN, Ṣ, Z,) not rained upon, and having no vegetation, or herbage. (Ṣ, Z, Ḳ.)

AlmuWotafikaAtu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AlmuwotafikapN, (TA,) both occurring in the Ḳur, [the former in ix. 71 and lxix. 9, and the latter in liii. 54,] The cities overthrown, or subverted, by God, upon the people of Lot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The former also signifies The winds that turn over [the surface of] the earth, or ground: (Ḳ:) or the winds that blow from different quarters: it is said (by the Arabs, Ṣ) that when these winds blow much, the earth (i. e. its seed-produce, TA) thrives, or yields increase. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

1. Oafala, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a thing, (Mṣb,) or of the moon, (T,) and Oafalato, said of the sun, (T, Ṣ, M,) and of the stars, (M,) aor. _i {yaOofilu} and _u {yaOofulu}, inf. n. OufuwlN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OfolN, (M, Mṣb,) It was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it set; (T, Ṣ, M, &c.;) and so Oafila, aor. _a {yaOofalu}. (Ḳ.)
Hence, Oafala fulaAnN Eani Albaladi Such a one became absent, or went away, from the country, or town. (Mṣb.)

OafiylN A young camel such as is termed Aibonu maxaADK [i. e. that has entered its second year]; (Aṣ, El-Fárábee, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and the like; (Ṣ;) or, and also such as is above this [in age]; (El-Fárábee, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, and also such as is termed Aibonu labuwnK [i. e. that has entered the third year]; beyond which it is not so called: (Aṣ, TA:) or that is seven months old, or eight: (Aṣ, Mṣb:) or a youthful camel: (AZ, Mṣb:) and also (M, Ḳ) a young weaned camel; syn. faSiyl-N: (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. with p {OafiylapN}: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) pl. UifaAlN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OafaAYilu, (Sb, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which latter they liken to canaAYibu as pl. of cnuwbN. (M.) [In my copy of the Mṣb, the pl. is said to be UfAlp: and it is also there said, on the authority of IF, that AfAlp signifies the young ones of sheep.] It is said in a prov., Uin-amaA Alqaromi mina AlOafiyli [The stallion-camel is only that which has increased in growth from the young one in its second year,, &c.]; i. e. what is great has begun small. (TA.)

MfilN part. n. of 1, (T, TA,) applied to the moon, and to any star: (TA:) fem. with p {MfilapN}: (T, TA:) pl. Mfiluwna (Ḳur vi. 76 [the rational form of the pl. being there used because it is applied to stars as being likened to gods]) and Ouf-alN and OufuwlN. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: Oafaho / Oaf-aho / Ouf-aho / Ouf-iho / Ouf-uho / Oafuwho / Ouf-uwho

entry.sense: Oafaho and Oaf-aho and Ouf-aho and Ouf-iho and Ouf-uho and Oafuwho and Ouf-uwho: see Ouf-N.

OafoyuwnN, [like SaEofuwqN, but this is of a very extr. measure; or, as some write it, OufoyuwnN, like EuSofuwrN, &c.;] or UifoyawonN, [like birocawonN;] (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, art. fyn;) [an arabicized word, from the Greek OaPoyuwno, either immediately or through the Persian xaXoxaAX; meaning Opium:] the milk [or juice] of the black Egyptian xXxAX [or poppy, or papaver somniferum]; (Ḳ;) or the milk of the xXxAX, the best of which is the black Egyptian; (TA;) or the expressed juice of the black Egyptian xXxAX, dried in the sun: cold and dry in the fourth degree: (Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna, i. 133:) beneficial for hot tumours, especially in the eye; torporific (to the intellect, TA): in a small quantity, beneficial, and soporific: in a large quantity, a poison: (Ḳ:) [the lexicographers regard the word as Arabic:] some, among whom is the author of the Ḳ, hold that it belongs to art. fyn: others, that it belongs to art. Afn. (TA.)
OuqoHuwaAnN: see art. qHw
1. OaqaTahu, aor _i, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. OaqoTN, (Ṣ,) He made it (namely food) with OaqiT q. v. infrà. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) He fed him with OaqiT: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) like labanahu from labanN and labaOahu from libaON Lḥ mentions the verb in this sense as used without its being made transitive. (TA.)
[OaqiTa in the CK is a mistake for MqaTa q. v.]

4. MqaTa, (Lḥ, Ḳ, [in the CK, incorrectly, OaqiTa,]) of the measure OafoEala, agreeably with a common rule, applying to anything, (Lḥ, TA,) He had much OaqiT; his OaqiT became much, or abundant. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
8. AYtqT [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaqaTa] He made, or prepared, OaqiT: (Ṣ:) strangely omitted in the O and in the Ḳ. (TA.)

OaqiTN (Fr, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UiqiTN (Fr, O, Ḳ) and OaqaTN (Fr, Ḳ) and UiqoTN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last sometimes occurring in poetry, and formed from the first, by transferring the vowel of the q to the preceding letter, (Ṣ,) or a contraction of the second, accord. to a common usage of [the tribe of] Temeem in the cases of words of this measure, (O,) and OaqoTN (Ḳ) and OuqoTN, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) of all which the first is the most chaste, and the last is strange, (TA,) [A preparation of dried curd;] a preparation of, or thing made from, milk (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ) of sheep or goats, (Ḳ,) which has been churned, and of which the butter has been taken, (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) cooked, and then left until it becomes concrete: (Az, Mṣb:) or made from the milk of camels, in particular: (IAạr:) or milk which is dried, and has become hard, like stone; with which one cooks; repeatedly mentioned in trads.: (TA:) or a thing made from milk; being a kind of cheese: (Ḥar p. 587:) pl. OuqoTaAnN. (Ḳ.)
Oaq-aATN A maker of OaqiT. (TA.)
maOoquwTN Food made with OaqiT. (Ṣ.)
1. Oakada He trod wheat. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
2. Ok-d, inf. n. taOokiydN, i. q. wak-ada, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of which it is a dial. var.; (Ṣ;) but it is not so chaste as the latter, and by some is disallowed. (TA.)
4. Mkd i. q. Oawokada. (Ṣ in art. wkd.)
5. tOk-d i. q. tawak-ada. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wkd.)

UkaAdN sing. of OakaAYidN and taMkiydN, (Ḳ,) both of which are irreg. in relation to their sing., (TA,) signifying (i. e. the pls.) Thongs, or straps, by which the qarabuws is bound to the two side-boards of a horse's saddle. (Ḳ.) [See also wikaAdN.]
OakiydN Firm; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a covenant, or compact. (TA.)
1. Oakara, aor. _i {yaOokiru}, inf. n. OakorN, He tilled the ground; ploughed it up for sowing. (Mṣb.)
He dug the ground. (TA.)
He cut, or dug, a river, or canal, or rivulet. (Mṣb.)

And Oakara, aor _u, (TA,) inf. n. as above; (Ḳ;) and tOk-r↓; (Ḳ;) He dug a hollow, or cavity, in the ground, for water to collect therein and to be baled out therefrom clear: (Ḳ, TA:) or tOk-r↓ Oukar-aA signifies he dug hollows, or cavities, in the ground. (Ṣ.)

3. Mkrhu, (TḲ.) inf. n. muWaAkarapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made a contract, or bargain, with him to till and sow and cultivate land for a share of its produce; syn. of the inf. n. muxaAbarapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) The doing of this is forbidden. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: OukorapN A hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in which water collects, and from which it is baled out clear: (Ḳ:) pl. OukarN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Also a dial. var. of kurapN, (Ḳ,) [A ball] with which one plays: (TA:) [and a sphere, or globe:] but it is of weak authority. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: UikaArapN, as used in practical law, Land which is given by its owners to men who sow and cultivate it [app. for a certain share of its produce: see 3]. (Mgh.)
Oak-aArN A tiller, or cultivator, of land: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. OakarapN; as though it were pl. of MkirN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as kafarapN is pl. of kaAfirN. (Mṣb.)
2. Ak-f AlUikaAfa, inf. n. taOokiyfN, He made the AkAf; (Ḳ;) as also wk-fhu, inf. n. tawokiyfN; which latter, accord. to IF, is the original form. (TA.)
See also 4.

4. Mkf AlHimaAra, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiykaAfN, (Ḳ,) He bound, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or put, (Mṣb, TA,) the UikaAf upon the ass; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Ok-fhu↓; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and Awkfhu; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) which is of the dial. of the people of El-Ḥijáz; the first being of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem: and in like manner, Albagola the mule. (Lḥ.)

UikaAfN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OukaAfN, (Ḳ,) as also wikaAfN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wukaAfN, (Ḳ in art. wkf,) The barocaEap, [i. e. pad, or stuffed saddle, generally stuffed with straw,] (Ḳ,) of the ass, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and also used for the mule, and for the camel; (TA in art. wkf;) a saddle like the raHol and qatab: (TA:) and a saddle of a horse made in the form of the ass's AkAf, having at its fore part [or pommel] a thing resembling a pomegranate: (Mgh:) [see also qatabN:] pl. [of pauc.] MkifapN (TA) and [of mult.] OukufN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) Yaạḳoob asserts that the A in UikaAfN is a substitute for the w in wikaAfN. (TA.) A rájiz says,
Uin-a lanaA OaHomirapF EijaAfaA
yaOokulona kul-a layolapK UikaAfaA
meaning [Verily we have some lean asses] which eat every night the price of an AkAf. (TA.)
Oak-aAfN The maker of the kind of saddle called UikaAf. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. Oakalahu, [aor. _u {yaOokulu},] inf. n. OakolN and maOokalN, [He ate it,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) namely, food. (Ṣ.) Er-Rummánee says that OakolN properly signifies The swallowing food after chewing it; so that the swallowing of pebbles is not properly thus termed: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the conveying, or transmitting, to the belly what may be chewed, whether [the thing be] chewed or not; so that it does not apply to milk, nor to sawiyq: and as to the saying of the poet,
mina AlMkiliyna AlmaMCa ZulomFA famaA OaraI
yanaAluwna xayorFA baEoda Oakolihimu AlmaMCa
† [Of the eaters of what they purchase with the price of water, wrongfully, I do not see any attain good after their eating of what they have purchased with the price of the water,] he means a people who used to sell water and purchase with the price thereof what they would eat: (TA:) [for you say, Oakala kacaA as meaning † He ate the price of such a thing: see another ex. voce UikaAfN; and another voce vadoIN.]

The saying, in the Ḳur [v. 70], laOakaluwA mino fawoqihimo wamino taHoti Oarojulihimo [They should eat things above them and things beneath their feet] means, their means of subsistence should be made ample; (Bḍ, TA;) by the pouring of the blessings of the heaven and the earth upon them; or by the abundance of the fruit of the trees, and the produce of the grains sown; or by their being blessed with gardens of ripe fruits, so that they should gather them from the upper part of each tree, and pick up what should have fallen upon the ground. (Bḍ.)
AinoqaTaEa Oakoluhu [lit. His eating became cut off, or stopped,] means ‡ he died; [see also OukulN;] and so AisotawofaI Oakolahu [lit. he completed his eating]. (TA.)
Oakala raWoqahu [lit. He ate his life,] means ‡ he became extremely aged, and his teeth fell out, one after another. (TA.)

huwa yaOokulu Aln-aAsa, and yaOokulu luHuwma Aln-aAsi [He eats men, and eats the flesh of men,] means ‡ he defames men; or does so in their absence: (TA:) and the action thus signified may be [with words, or by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head. (TA in art. hmz.) It is said in the Ḳur [xlix. 12], OayuHib-u OaHadukumo Oano yaOokla laHoma Oaxiyhi mayotFA [lit. Would any one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead?]; defamation, or defamation of the absent, being meant thereby. (Ṣ,* Ibn-ʼArafeh, Bḍ, Jel.)
Oakala ganamiI waXaribahaA ‡ [He ate the flesh of my sheep, and drank the milk of them, means, like Oakala maAliI, he ate, fed upon, devoured, or consumed, my wealth, or property: see 2]. (TA.)
Oakalati Aln-aAru AlHaTaba ‡ The fire devoured, or consumed, the firewood. (Ṣ, Mgh.)
Oakalato OaZofaArahu AlHijaArapu ‡ [The stones wore away his nails]. (TA.)
AlwaAwu fiI maroYI-K OakalatohaA AlyaMCu † [The w in maroYiI-, the I has swallowed it up]; because it is originally maroWuwIN: a phrase occurring in the ʼEyn. (TA.)
Oakala Eumurahu ‡ He consumed his life. (Mgh.)

It is said in a trad., (TA,) Oumirotu biqaroyapK taOokulu AlquraI ‡ [I have been commanded to have given unto me a town which shall devour the other towns]; (Ḳ, TA;) said to be Yethrib [afterwards called El-Medeeneh]; (TA;) i. e., the people of which shall conquer the [other] towns and make spoil of their possessions: or it denotes the superior excellence of that town; and is like the saying, hecaA HadiyvN yaOokulu AlOaHaAdiyva [This is a tradition which does away with, or overrules, the other traditions]. (Ṣgh. Ḳ, TA.)
Oakolu Als-ik-iyni All-aHoma means ‡ The knife's cutting the flesh. (TA.)
OakalaniI raOosiI, inf. n. UikolapN and OukaAlN and OakaAlN, ‡ My head itched. (Ḳ, TA.) An Arab was heard to say, [as is often said in the present day,] jilodiI yaOokuluniI ‡ My skin itches. (TA.)

Oakila, aor. _a {yaOokalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OakalN, (TA,) ‡ It (a limb, or member, [and a sore,] and a piece of stick, or wood,) became corroded or cankered, or decayed, by the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also AYtkl↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala], and tOk-l↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

Oakilati AlOasonaAnu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding sentence, (Mṣb,) ‡ The teeth rubbed together and wasted away; by reason of age; (Ṣ;) or fell out, one after another: (Mṣb:) or broke in pieces, or became much broken: (Ḳ:) and tOk-lt↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and so AYtklt↓. (Ṣ.)

Oakilati Aln-aAqapu, aor. _a {yaOokalu}, inf. n. OakaAlN, † The she-camel experienced an itching and annoyance in her belly, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) from the growth of the hair, (Ṣ, O,) or from the growth of the fur, (Ḳ,) of her fœtus. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. [Ok-lhu, inf. n. taOokiylN, He made him to eat a thing.]

Oak-ala maAliI waXr-abahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) [lit. He made people to eat my property, and made them to drink it,] means ‡ he fed men, or the people, with my property, or cattle. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

Zal-a maAliI yuWak-alu wayuXar-abu, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) or yuWak-ilu wyuXar-ibu, (so in two copies of the Ṣ and in a copy of the Ḳ,) [of which the former is app. the right reading, as the lit. meaning seems to be My cattle passed the day made to eat and made to drink,] i. e., ‡ pasturing as they pleased. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

Ok-lhu AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. as above, ‡ He charged against him, or accused him of doing, the thing; as also Mklhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. UiykaAlN. (TA.) In [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, for Aid-aEaAhu, we here find, erroneously, daEaAhu. (TA.) You say, Oak-alotaniI maA lamo Mkulo [lit. Thou hast made me to eat what I have not eaten,] meaning ‡ thou hast charged against me, or accused me of doing, what I have not done; as also MkalotaniI↓. (Ṣ, TA.) So too, OaXorabotaniI maA lamo OaXorabN. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Xrb.)
3. Mklhu, inf. n. muWaAkalapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and UikaAilN, (Ḳ,) He ate with him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also waAkalahu, though of weak authority; (Ḳ;) or this latter is not allowable. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.)
muWaAkalapN which is forbidden in a trad. is † A debtor's giving a thing to his creditor in order that he may abstain from taking the debt. (TA.)
4. Mkl, [inf. n. UiykaAlN,] said of the palm-tree, and of seed-produce, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of anything, (Ṣ,) It had ripe fruit; it supplied food. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Mklhu AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He gave him to eat the thing; he fed him with the thing. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
See also 2, in two places.
Mkl Aln-aAra † He fed, or supplied, the fire with fuel. (Ṣ.)

Mkl bayona Aln-aAsi, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O,) ‡ He busied himself among the people with propagating calumnies: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or he created, or excited, disagreement, dissension, strife, among them; or made, or did, mischief among them: (A, TA:) or he incited them, one against another. (Ḳ.)

Mkalotuka fulaAnFA, (Ṣ,) or Mkala fulaAnN fulAnFA, (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, fulaAnN fulaAnFA,]) ‡ I made thee, (Ṣ,) or he made such a one, (Ḳ,) to have dominion, or authority, or power, over such a one. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tOk-l: see 1, latter part, in two places:
and see also 8.

Also, said of a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of silver (Ḳ, TA) molten, (TA,) and of lightning, and of collyrium, and of aloes, (Ḳ,) and of anything shiny, (TA,) ‡ It shone, gleamed, or glistened, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) much, or intensely; (Ḳ;) when said of a sword, by reason of its sharpness. (Ṣ, TA.)
8. AYtkl [with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala]: see 1, latter part, in two places.
OamaA tanofak-u taOotakilu Dost thou not cease to eat our flesh, [i. e., to wound our reputations, (see 1,)] and to defame us? (Aboo-Naṣr, TA.) But see below.
AYtklti Aln-aAru ‡ The fire flamed, or blazed, vehemently; as though one part thereof devoured another. (TA.)

AYtkl gaDabFA, (Ḳ,) or mina AlgaDabi, (Ṣ,) ‡ He burned, or burned fiercely, with, or by reason of, anger. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The phrase mentioned above, AmA tnfk- tOtkl, is also cited as an ex. of this meaning. (Ṣ, TA.) You say likewise, AYtkl minohu ‡ He was, or became, angry with him, and excited, or provoked, against him, (Ḳ, TA,) and vehement, or severe; (TA;) as also tOkl↓ mnh. (Ḳ.)
10. AstOklhu AlX-aIoCa ‡ He asked, or begged, of him to assign to him the thing, or to make it be to him, as a means of subsistence, or a thing to be eaten. (Ḳ, TA.)
yasotaOokilu AlD-uEafaMCa ‡ He takes (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and devours (TA) the possessions of the weak ones. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
OukolN: see OukulN.
OakalN inf. n. of Oakila [q. v.].
fiI OasonaAnihi OakalN ‡ In his teeth is a rubbing together and wasting away; by reason of age. (Ṣ, TA.)
OakilN [part. n. of Oakila].
naAqapN OakilapN † A she-camel experiencing an itching and annoyance in her belly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the growth of the hair, (Ṣ,) or from the growth of the fur, (Ḳ,) of her fœtus. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[AlAakilu is erroneously put, in the CK, for AlMkilu, in a sense explained below.]

OukulN and OukolN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) the latter a contraction of the former; (Mṣb;) What is eaten; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also OukolapN↓ and OakolapN↓ (Lḥ, TA) and maOokalapN↓ and maOokulapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maOokuwlN↓; (Lḥ, Mṣb;) any eatable; i. e. anything that is eaten; (Ṣ;) and OakaAlN↓ signifies [the same, an eatable, or] food. (Ṣ, TA.) You say of one who is dead, AinoqaTaEa Oukuluhu [His food has become cut off, or stopped: in the TA, Oakoluhu: see 1]. (Ṣ.) And maA cuqotu OakaAl-aA↓ I have not tasted food. (Ṣ, TA.)

Fruit (Ṣ, Ḳ [in the latter of which, in some copies, Alt-amoru is put for Alv-amaru, erroneously, as is said in the TA]) of palmtrees and other trees [&c.]. (Ṣ.) So in the Ḳur [xiii. 35], OukuluhaA daAYimN [Its fruit shall be perpetual]: (Ṣ, TA:) meaning that the fruits thereof shall be not as those of the present world, which come to one at one time and not at another. (TA.) [Pl. MkaAlN; occurring in the M and Ḳ in art. Atw.]

‡ Means of subsistence: (Ḳ:) worldly good fortune, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and ample means of subsistence. (Ṣ.) You say, fulaAnN cuw OukulK ‡ Such a one is possessed of worldly good fortune, and ample means of subsistence: (Ṣ:) and EaZiymu AlOukuli ‡ possessed of [great] good fortune; or of a [great and] good share of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

‡ Thickness, substantialness, or closeness or compactness of texture, of a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and strength thereof. (Ḳ.) You say vawobN cuw OukulK ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, having thickness,, &c.: and qiroTaAsN cuw OukulK ‡ paper having thickness,, &c. (Ṣ, TA.)
‡ Intelligence; judgment; (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) firmness of intellect. (Ḳ, TA.) You say rajulN cuw OukulK ‡ A man possessing intelligence and judgment. (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, TA.)

OakolapN A single act of eating (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) until one is satisfied. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying, AlmuEotaAdu OakolataAni AlgadaMCu waAlEaXaMCu, meaning That to which people are accustomed is two acts of eating, the eating of the morning-meal and that of the evening-meal. (Mgh.)
See also OukolapN, in two places.
And see OukulN, first sentence.

hom.sense: OukolapN A morsel, or small mouthful, of food. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [For the pl., see below.] You say, Oakalotu OukolapF waAHidapF I ate one morsel. (Ṣ.) And Oakla biOaxiyhi OukolapF † [He ate a morsel by means of defaming his brother] is said, in a trad., of a man who is on terms of brotherhood with another, and then goes to his enemy, and speaks of him in a manner not good, in order that he may give him a present for doing so. (TA.)
A small round cake of bread; syn. quroSapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a single quroS: (Mgh:) pl. OukalN, as below. (TA.)
See also OukulN.

Also † i. q. TuEomapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is also syn. with maOokalapN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, in art. TEm;) i. e. An assigned, or appointed, means of subsistence; such as a grant of a tract of land; and a tax, or portion of a tax or taxes; and the like; (Mgh in explanation of TuEomapN, and TA in explanation of the same and of maOokalapN in art. TEm;) and [it is also said that] maOokalapN↓ signifies a thing that is assigned, or appointed, or granted, to a man, so that he is not to be reckoned with, or called to account, for it: (TA in the present art.:) [thus it applies to any absolute grant, either of land, (as an allodium, an appanage, &c.,) or of revenue:] pl. OukalN (Ḳ) [and app. also MkaAlN, which see below]. You say, hecaA AlX-aIoCu OuklapN laka This thing is a TuEomap to thee, or for thee. (Ṣ.)
See also OakiylapN.

Also, and UikolapN↓ (Ṣ, Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ) and OakolapN↓, (Kr, Ḳ,) ‡ Defamation; or defamation of the absent. (Ṣ, Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) You say, Uin-ahu lacuw OukolapK and UikolapK↓ (Ṣ, TA) and OakolapK↓ (TA) ‡ Verily he is one who defames men; or, who does so in their absence. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: UikolapN A mode, or manner, (Ḳ,) or state, or condition, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which one eats: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) like jilosapN and rikobapN: (Ṣ, TA:) and the posture of the eater, reclining or sitting. (TA.) You say, Uin-ahu laHasanu AlUikolapi [Verily he has a good mode,, &c., of eating]. (Ṣ.)
See also OukolapN, last two sentences.

‡ The itch: or an itching: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also OukaAlN↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) [see OakalaniI raOosiI, of which both are said to be inf. ns.,] and OakilapN↓: (Ḳ:) so the last is written accord. to the correct copies of the Ḳ: accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Shifá el-Ghaleel, it would seem to be OukolapN; but this is at variance with the authority of the leading lexicologists: the same word, OakilapN, is also explained in the Ḳ as signifying a disease in a limb, or member, in consequence of which one part is [as it were] eaten by another; [a meaning which I believe to be correct, (see OukaAlN,) although SM says,] but this is identical with the itch, or an itching: and OakalaAnN↓ is a vulgar term for the same; and so is MkilapN↓, with medd, given as correct by Eth-Tha'álibee, in [his book entitled] the Mudáf and Mensoob, but disallowed by El-Khafájee. (TA.) One says, Uin-iI laOajidu fiI jasadiI UikolapF ‡ [Verily I experience in my body an itching.] (Ṣ.)
OakilapN: see UikolapN.
OukalapN: see OakuwlN.
OakalaAnN: see UikolapN.
OakaAlN: see OukulN, first and second sentences.

OukaAlN ‡ A corrosion, or cankering, or decaying, of a limb, or member, [and of a sore,] from the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also UikaAlN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also OakilapN, voce UikolapN, where a similar meaning is assigned to the former of these two words; and the same seems to be indicated in the Mṣb.]
See also another signification voce UikolapN.
bahaA OukaAlN, said of a she-camel, ‡ She has an itching and annoyance in her belly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the growth of the hair, (Ṣ,) or of the fur, (Ḳ,) of her fœtus. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
UikaAlN: see OukaAlN.
rajulN OakuwlN and OukalapN↓ and OakiylN↓ all signify the same; (Ḳ;) i. e. A man who eats much; [who is a great eater; edacious; voracious;] as also Oak-aAlN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: OakiylN One who eats with another. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also MkilN:
and see OakuwlN.
I. q. maOokuwlN↓ [as signifying Eaten]. (TA.)
See also OakiylapN.

entry.sense:
OakuwlapN A sheep, or goat, which is set apart (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) to be eaten, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) [i. e.] to be slaughtered, (Mṣb,) and which is fattened, (Ṣ, Mgh,) and the taking of which by the collector of the poor-rate is disapproved; (Ṣ;) not left to pasture by itself, being of the best of the beasts: (Mṣb:) and OakiylapN↓ occurs in the same sense, applied to a sheep, or goat, fattened to be eaten. (Mgh.)
Hence the prov., maroEFI walaA OakuwlapF [lit. Pasturage, and no Akwlp]; meaning † wealth collected together, and none expended. (TA.)
Also Barren; applied to a sheep or goat [app. because such is generally eaten]. (Ḳ.)
OukuwlapN: see what next follows.

OakiylapN and OakiylN↓ and OukuwlapN↓, with two dammehs, (Ḳ,) so in the copies of the Ḳ, but perhaps a mistake for OukolapN↓, (TA,) a word of a bad dial., (Ḳ,* TA,) and maOokuwlN↓ and muWaAkilN↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, instead of wahiIa qabiyHapN waAlmaOokuwli waAlmaWaAkili, meaning, as is said in the TA, wahiIa lugapN qabiyHapN, &c., we find wahiIa qabiyHapN AlmaOokuwli waAlmaWaAkili,]) A sheep, or goat, which is set (Ḳ, TA) in the lurking-place of a hunter (TA) for the purpose of catching thereby the wolf and the like. (Ḳ, TA.)

And the first two words, (Ḳ,) or OakiylapN sabuEK, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) A beast which has been eaten, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or partly eaten, (Mgh, Mṣb,) by a beast or bird of prey, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and then rescued from it: (Mgh, TA:) the p in Akylp being added because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (Ṣ.)
See also OakuwlapN.
Oak-aAlN: see OakuwlN.
MkilapN ‡ Pasturing beasts. (Ḳ, TA.)

Mkilapu All-aHomi † The knife; (Ḳ, TA;) because it cuts the flesh: (TA:) and the pointed staff or stick; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened thereto: (TA:) and fire: (Ḳ:) and whips; (Sh, Ḳ;) because they burn the skin. (TA.)
AlMkilu, [in the CK, erroneously, AlAakilu,] ‡ The king. (Ḳ, TA.) [Opposed to AlmaOokuwlu, q. v.]
Mkilu Alr-ibaA ‡ [The receiver of usury]: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, luEina Mkilu Alr-ibaA wamuWokiluhu↓ ‡ [The receiver of usury is cursed, and the giver thereof]. (TA.)
See also UikolapN.
MkaAlN [app. a pl. of pauc. of OukulN, q. v., and of OukolN, agreeably with analogy,] ‡ The [grants termed] maMkil of kings; (Ḳ;) their TuEam [pl. of TuEomapN, explained above, voce OukolapN]. (TA.)
† The stipends of soldiers. (Ḳ.)

cawwAlMkaAli, for which J has erroneously put AlMkAl, [in the Ṣ,] (TṢ, Ḳ,) without cww, (TA,) ‡ The lords, or chiefs, of the tribes, who take the mirobaAE [or fourth part of the spoil, which was the chief's portion in the time of ignorance] (Ṣ, TṢ, Ḳ, TA) &c. (TA.)
maOokalN, (Ṣ,) [in measure] like maqoEadN, (TA,) [an inf. n. of Oakala, q. v.:]
[and also signifying] Gain. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Also A place, and a time, of eating: pl. maMkilu.]
muWokalN † Fortunate; possessed of good fortune; prosperous. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.)
muWokilu Alr-ibaA ‡ [The giver of usury: see MkilN, last sentence]. (TA.)
maOokalapN and maOokulapN↓: see OukulN:
and for the former, see also OukolapN, in two places.
[Also, both words, i. q. miyrapN i. e. Corn, or any provision, which a man brings, or purveys, for himself or his family, or for sale]. (Ḳ.)
Also used in the sense explained above, voce OukulN, [as a subst.,] and likewise as an epithet, so that one says XaApN mOklhN [as meaning A sheep, or goat, that is eaten]. (Ḳ.)
Both words signify [also] A place whence one eats. (Ṣ, O.)
[And hence] one says, Ait-axacotu fulaAnFA maOokalapF and maOokalapN † [I took for myself such a one as a person from whom to obtain what to eat]. (Ṣ, O.)
[The pl. is maMkilu: of which see an ex. voce MkaAlN.]
maOokulapN: see the paragraph next preceding, throughout.

miYokalapN Anything in [i. e. out of] which one eats: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or [bowls of the kind called] SiHaAf, (Ṣ,) or a [bowl of the kind called] SaHofap, (TA,) in which the tribe find it easy to cook, (so in a copy of the Ṣ and in the TA,) or to put, (so in another copy of the Ṣ,) flesh-meat and [the kind of porridge called] EaSiydap: (Ṣ, TA:) or a bowl not so large as a SaHfp, but next to it in size, that satisfies the stomachs of two men, or three: (Ṣ voce SaHofapN:) [or] a small [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEapN, that satisfies the stomachs of three: and a small [cooking-pot such as is called] buromah. (Ḳ.)
maOokuwlN: see OakiylN:
and OukulN:
and OakiylapN.
† The subjects of a king. (Z, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the trad., maOokuwlN Himoyara xayorN mino MkilihaA ‡ The subjects of Himyer are better than their king, or ruler. (Z, TA.)
miYokaAlN A spoon: (Ḳ:) because one eats with it. (TA.)
muWaAkilN: see OakiylapN.
Also, [like musotaOokilN↓,] † One who takes and devours the possessions of men. (TA.)
musotaOokilN: see what next precedes.
2. taOokiymN The being big in the kafal [i. e. the hinder parts, or posteriors, also termed maOokamapN]. (O, Ḳ.) You say, Oak-amati AlmaroOapN The woman was large in the kafal. (TḲ.)

hom.sense: 10. AstOkm It (a place) became what are termed Oakam, q. v. (Ḳ.)
AstOkm majolisahu He (a man, TA) found his sitting-place to be plain, smooth, soft, or easy to sit upon. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OakamN: see what next follows.

OakamapN A hill, or mound, syn. tal-N, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in an absolute sense, or] of what is termed quf- [q. v.], (Ḳ,) or, as in the M, (TA,) of a single collection of stones: or it is inferior to mountains: or a place that is more elevated than what is around it, and is rugged, not to the degree of being stone: (Ḳ:) or an isolated mountain: (Ḳ voce jabalN:) or an eminence like what is termed raAbiyap: a collection of stones in one place, sometimes rugged and sometimes not rugged: (Mṣb:) or i. q. quf-N, except that the Akmp is higher and greater: (ISh, TA:) or what is higher than the quf-, compact and round, rising into the sky, abounding with stones: (TA:) pl. OakamaAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and OakamN↓, [or this is rather a coll. gen. n. of which OakamapN is the n. un.,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and UikaAmN, (Ḳ, TA,) or this is pl. of OakamN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and OukumN, (Ḳ, TA,) or this is pl. of UikaAmN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and MkaAmN [a pl. of pauc.], (Ḳ,) or this is pl. of OukumN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and MkumN [which is also a pl. of pauc.], (IJ, Ḳ,) or this is a pl. of OakamN: (TA:) IHsh says that OakamN is the only word like vamarN in its series of pls.; for its sing. [or n. un.] is OakamapN, and the pl. of this [or the coll. gen. n.] is OakamN, and the pl. of this is UikaAmN, and the pl. of this is OukumN, and the pl. of this is MkaAmN, and the pl. of this is OakaAmiymu [or OawaAkiymu?]. (MF in art. vmr.) It is said in a prov., used in ridiculing any one who has told of his committing some fault, not desiring to reveal it, jusotumuwniI wawaraMCa AlOakamapi maA waraMCahaA [in which I think the first word to be a mistranscription, for jiYotumuwniI, and the literal meaning to be, Ye have come to me; but behind the hill is what is behind it]: related on the authority of Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh. (TA.) And one says, laA tabulo EalaI OakampK, meaning ‡ Publish not what is secret of thine affair. (TA.)
maOokamN and maOokimN: see what next follows.

maOokamapN, (El-Fárábee,) or maOokimapN, (Ṣ,) or both, and maOokamN↓ and maOokimN↓, (IAth, Ḳ,) The hinder part, posteriors, buttocks, or rump, of a woman; syn. EajiyzapN: (Ṣ:) or a portion of flesh on the head of the warik [or haunch]; one of two such portions: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán,“and Ḳ:) or these are two protuberances of flesh on the heads of the upper parts of the warikaAni [or haunches]; on the right and left: (TA:) or they are two portions of flesh conjoining the Eajuz [or buttocks] and the matonaAni [or two portions of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on each side]; (Ḳ, TA;) or, as in the Nh, conjoining the Eajob [or rump-bone] and the mtnAn: or two portions of flesh at the root of the warikaAi: (TA:) pl. maMkimu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Lḥ mentions the saying, Uin-ahu laEaZiymu AlmMkimi [Verily he is big in the hinder parts]; as though they called every portion thereof mOkm. (TA.) And one says in reviling a person, yaA Qbina OaHomari AlmaOokamapi, meaning O son of him who is red in the safilapi. (TA.)
muWak-imapN: see what follows.
muWaAkimapN [in the CK, erroneously, muWAkamap] and muWak-imapN↓ She who is large in the maOokamataAni. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Aalo is a particle of determination: (Mughnee, &c.:) or, accord. to some, it is a conjunct noun, and this is the correct opinion; but some say it is a conjunct particle; and some, a particle of determination: (I'AK p. 40:) [it is equivalent to our article The;] as in Alr-ajulu [The man]: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. lwm, and I’Aḳ p. 48:) accord. to Kh, [what is termed] the determinative is Aalo [altogether, and therefore it is called by some “the determinative alif and lám“]; but accord. to Sb, it is the l alone; [wherefore it is called by some, as in the Ṣ, &c., “the lám of determination;”;] so that accord. to Kh, the hemzeh is a hemzeh of disjunction; but accord. to Sb, it is a hemzeh of conjunction: (I’Aḳ ubi suprà:) [J says,] the l being quiescent, the conjunctive A is prefixed to it in order that it may commence therewith; but when it is conjoined with what precedes it, the A is dropped, as in lilr-ajuli. (Ṣ in art. lwm.) Sometimes the Arabs suppress hemzeh after it; and sometimes they also suppress the A of the article itself: thus, for AlOaHomaru, they say AlaHomaru, and laHomaru. (Zj, cited in TA in art. Ayk.) In the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen, (TA in art. Am, q. v.,) or in the dial. of Himyer, (TA in art. Tyb,) Amo is used in the sense of Al. (TA.)

It is used to distinguish a noun as known [to the hearer or reader in a particular and definite sense]: (Mughnee, I’Aḳ ubi suprà:) first, by its being mentioned [before]; (Mughnee;) as in [the words of the Ḳur lxxiii. 15 and 16,] kama OarosalonaA UilaI firoEawona rasuwlFA faEaSaI firoEawonu Alr-asuwla [Like as we sent unto Pharaoh an apostle, and Pharaoh disobeyed the apostle]; (Mughnee, I’Aḳ;) in which case, the pronoun may supply the place which it and the noun that it accompanies occupies: secondly, by its being conceived in the mind; as in [the Ḳur ix. 40,] Uico humaA fiI AlgaAri [When they two were in the cave]: and thirdly, by its being applied to a thing present; and accord. to Ibn-ʼOsfoor, this does not occur except after nouns of indication, as in jaMCa niI hecaA Alr-ajulu [This man (lit. this, the man,) came to me]; or after OaI- in calling, as in yaA Oay-uhaA Alr-ajulu [O man]; or after UicaA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly, as in xarajotu faUicaA AlOasadu [I went forth, and lo, there was the lion]; or after the noun denoting the present time, as AaloMna [Now]: but this requires consideration; for you say to the reviler of a man in you presence, laA taXotimi Alr-ajula [Revile not thou the man]; and because that which is after UicaA does not render determinate anything present at the time of speaking; and because that in AlMn is really redundant, being inseparable, which the determinative is never known to be: the good example in this case is the saying in the Ḳur [v. 5], Aaloyawoma Oakomalotu lakumo diyonakumo [This day I have completed for you your religion]. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to denote the species: first, to denote the totality of the individuals of the species; and this may have its place supplied by kul- used in its proper sense; (Mughnee, I’Aḳ* ubi suprà;) as in [the Ḳur iv. 32,] waxuliqa AlUinosaAnu DaEiyfFA [For man was created weak]: secondly, to denote the totality of the properties of the individuals, or the combination of all those properties in one thing; and this may have its place supplied by kul- used in a tropical sense; as in zayodN Alr-ajulu EilomFA [Zeyd is the man in respect of knowledge; as though he combined in himself the knowledge of all the individuals of his species]; i. e., he is the complete, or perfect, [or we would rather say, preeminent,] in knowledge; and hence, [in the Ḳur ii. 1,] celika AlkitaAbu [That is the book, or scripture; as though combining in itself the excellences of all other books or scriptures; or meaning that is preeminently the book, or scripture]: and thirdly, to denote the quiddity, or essence; and this may not have its place supplied by kul- used either properly or tropically; as in the saying, [in the Ḳur xxi. 31,] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaMCi kul-a XaIoCK HaI-K [And we have made of water (meaning, accord. to common opinion, sperma genitale,) everything living]; or, accord. to some, it is used in this case to distinguish a thing as known [in a particular sense] by its being conceived in the mind. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to denote predominance of application; as in Almadiynapu [The city], meaning the city of the Apostle; and AlkitaAbu [The book], meaning the book of Seebaweyh: and in this case, it may not be suppressed, except when the noun is used vocatively, or when it is prefixed to another noun which it governs in the gen. case; and in some anomalous instances, as in hecaA Eay-uwqN TaAliEFA [This is the star Capella, rising], originally AlEay-uwqN. (I’Aḳ p. 51.) [In a case of this kind, it is said in the Mughnee to be redundant; but I think it is clearly not so in any of the instances here mentioned, except the last; and this I would rather assign to a category yet to be noticed, in which Al is certainly redundant, and, by rule, inseparable.]

It is also prefixed to a noun transferred from its original application to that of a proper name; it being so prefixed to convey an allusion to the original signification; and such noun being generally an epithet, as HaArivN; but sometimes an inf. n., as faDolN; and sometimes a generic noun, as nuEomaAnN; so that in any of these cases you may prefix Al, saying AlHaArivu and AlfaDolu and Aln-uEomaAnu, with a view to the original signification; and you may suppress it, with a view to the actual state [which is that of a proper name]: for when you mean that a name of this kind is given as one ominous of good, you prefix the Al in order to indicate this; as when you say AlHaArivu with a view to a person's being thus named to prognosticate that he will live and be a tiller, or cultivator; but when you only consider it as a proper name, you do not prefix the Al: thus the prefix Al conveys a meaning not obtained without it; and therefore it is not redundant, as some assert it to be. (I’Aḳ p. 50.) [The author of the Mughnee is one of those who consider Al redundant in this case.]

It is in some cases redundant: and in some of these, it is inseparable; as in [a proper name which cannot be used with a view to an original application from which it has been transferred to that of a proper name though it may have been so transferred, such as] All-aAtu, which is the name of a certain idol that was at Mekkeh [so called because a man used to moisten sawiyq with clarified butter, for the pilgrims, at the place thereof]; and, accord. to some, [as before mentioned,] in AlMni; and in the conjunct nouns Al-aciI and its variations, accord. to those who hold that a noun of this kind is rendered determinate by its complement: in other cases, where it is redundant, it is separable; and this is when it is prefixed to a proper name by poetic licence, as in banaAtu AlOawobari for banaAtu Oawobara, a species of truffle; or, accord. to Mbr, this is not a proper name, and the Al is not redundant; and when it is prefixed to a specificative, as in Tibota Aln-afosa for Tibota nafosFA, accord. to the Basrees, who hold, in opposition to the Koofees, that the specificative may only be indeterminate; (I’Aḳ p. 49;) [and, in like manner, as redundant and separable,] it is irregularly prefixed [by poetic licence] in AlOamosi [q. v.], when it is left in its original form with kesr. (T.)

Accord. to the Koofees, and some of the Basrees, and many of the later authors, it may also supply the place of the affixed pronoun; and such they hold to be the case in the saying in the Ḳur [lxxix. 41], faUin-a Qlojan-apa hiIa QlomaOwiI [Verily Paradise, it shall be his place of abode]; and in mararotu birajulK HasanK Alwajohu [I passed by a man beautiful in his face]; and Duriba zayodN AlZ-ahoru waAlbaTonu [Zeyd was beaten, his back and his belly]; when Alwjh and AlZhr and AlbTn are thus in the nom. case: but those who deny its being used in this manner hold that lahu is to be understood in the verse of the Ḳur, and minohu in the other examples: and Ibn-Málik restricts the licence to cases not including the Silap [or complement of Al used in the manner which is here next to be explained]. (Mughnee.)

It is also a conjunct noun in the sense of Al-aciI and its variations; and as such is prefixed to an act. part. n., and to a pass. part. n., and, as some say, to a simple epithet; (Mughnee, and I’Aḳ p. 43;) as AlD-aAribu [which is equivalent to Al-aciI yaDoribu], and AlmaDoruwbu [which is equivalent to Al-aciI Duriba], and AlHasanu Alwajohi: (I’Aḳ:) but this last not to be regarded, as it cannot be rendered by means of a verb. (Mughnee.) As such, also, it is sometimes prefixed to an adverbial noun, (Mughnee and I’Aḳ,) extraordinarily; (I’Aḳ;) as in the saying,
mano laA yazaAlu XaAkirFA EalaI ylomaEaho
fahowa HarK biEiyXapK caAti saEaho
[Whoso ceases not to be grateful, or thankful, for what is with him, or what he has, he is worthy of a state of life such as is attended with plenty.] (Mughnee and I’Aḳ.) As such it is also sometimes prefixed to a nominal proposition; as in the saying,
mana Alqawomi Alr-asuwlu Qll-ehi minohumo
lahumo daAnato riqaAbu binaI maEad-i
[Of the people of whom is the apostle of God, of those to whom the necks of the sons of Ma' add have become abased]. (Mughnee and I’Aḳ.)
And as such it is also sometimes prefixed to a verbal proposition, of which the verb is an aor.; which shows that it is not [in this case] a particle of determination; (Mughnee;) as in the phrase, Sawotu AlHimaAri Alyujad-aEu [The voice of the ass that has his ear, or ears, cut off]. (T and Mughnee.) But all these three cases are peculiar to poetry; contrary to the opinion of Akh, and, with respect to the last case, to that of Ibn-Málik. (Mughnee.) [Respecting the last instance, see also art. jdE.] Another instance of its usage prefixed in this sense to an aor. is the saying,
maA Oanota biAloHakama AlturoDaI Hukuwmatuhu
[Thou art not the judge whose judgment is approved]; (IAmb, T, I’Aḳ) a saying of El-Farezdaḳ: (IAmb, T:) it is an extraordinary case; (I’Aḳ;) and is [said to be] an instance of a bad poetic license, the like of which in prose would be an error by common consent. (Expos. of the Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.) In like manner, one says, accord. to AZ, hecaA AlyaDoribuka, meaning This is he who beats thee; and raOayotu AlyaDoribuka I saw him who beats thee; and hecaA AlwuDiEa lilX-iEori This is what is appropriated to poetry. (T: [in which this last ex. is perhaps intended to intimate that the prefixing of Al in this manner to a verb is allowable only in poetry.])

The Arabs also say, hawa AlHaSiynu Oano yuraAma wahuwa AlEaziyzu Oano yuDaAma, meaning OaHoSanu mino Oano yuraAm waOaEaz-u mino cano yuDaAm [He is more strongly fortified, or protected against attack, than that he will be sought, or desired, and he is more mighty than that he will be injured; i. e., too strongly fortified, or protected against attack, to be sought, or desired, and too mighty to be injured: see min.] (TA in art. lwm. [But AlHiSonu is there erroneously put for AlHaSiynu.])
Among strange usages, is that of Oalo as an interrogative, mentioned by Ḳṭr; as in Oalo faEalota in the sense of halo faEalota [Didst thou do? or hast thou done?]. (Mughnee.)
Uil-N Anything which has a quality requiring it to be regarded as sacred, or inviolable; which has some right pertaining to it: and thus used in particular senses here following. (R, TA.)

Relationship; or nearness with respect to kindred; (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, R, Ḳ;) as also Uil-apN↓, (Fr, T, Ḳ,) of which the pl. is UilalN. (Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur [ix. 8], laA yaroqubuwA fiykumo Uil-aA (Fr, T) They will not regard, with respect to you, relationship; (Bḍ, Jel;) accord. to some. (Bḍ.) And so in a trad. of ʼAlee, yaxuwnu AlEahoda wayaqoTaEu AlUil-a [He is unfaithful to the covenant, and cuts the tie of relationship]. (TA.) Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
laEamoruka Uin-a Uil-aka mino qurayoXK
kaUil-i Als-aqobi mino raOoli Aln-aEaAmi
[By thy life, thy relationship to Kureysh is like the relationship of the young camel to the young of the ostrich]. (Ṣ.)
Good origin. (Ḳ.) So, accord. to some, in a saying of Aboo-Bekr, which see below. (TA.)

I. q. maEodinN, (Ḳ,) or maEodinN SaHiyHN [as meaning A place, or person, whence a thing, or person, originates, free from imperfection, or from everything that would induce doubt or suspicion or evil opinion]. (El-Muärrij, TA: [in which the verse of Hassán cited above is given as an ex. of this signification.])

A compact, or covenant; or one by which a person becomes responsible for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a person or thing; syn. EahodN: (AO, Aboo-Is- hák, T, Ṣ, M, R, Ḳ:) a confederacy, or league; syn. HilofN; (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, M, Ḳ;) and so, accord. to some, in the Ḳur ubi suprà: (Bḍ:) a covenant between two parties by which either is bound to protect the other; syn. juwaArN: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, R:) a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety; or indemnity; syn. OamaAnN; (Ḳ;) a meaning which it has, accord. to some, in the verse of the Ḳur cited above. (TA.) Hence, wafiI-u AlUili A fulfiller, performer, or keeper, of the compact, or covenant. (TA, from a trad.)

Lordship; syn. rubuwbiy-apN. (M, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur ubi suprà, accord. to some. (Bḍ.) And so in the saying of Aboo-Bekr, above referred to, when he heard the rhyming prose of Museylimeh, hecaA kalaAmN lamo yaxorujo mino Uil-K [This is language which did not proceed from lordship]: so explained by AʼObeyd: (Suh, TA:) or it has here another signification, mentioned before; the meaning being, which did not come from the origin whence came the Ḳur-án: or, accord. to some, it has here the signification next following. (TA.)
Revelation, or inspiration. (Ḳ, TA.)
