AlUil-u also signifies God: [like the word אֵל or rather הָאֵל as used in Hebrew:] (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so say Mujáhid and Esh-Shaabee: (T:) and so it is said to signify in the verse of the Ḳur cited above: (T, TA:) [and so it seems to signify in the saying of Aboo-Bekr, also cited above, accord. to the M:] but Aboo-Is- hák disallows this; and so does Suh, in the R. (TA.) Ibn-El-Kelbee says, (M,) when Uil-u ends any name, it has this meaning, and is the complement of a prefixed noun; and so Uiylu; (M, Ḳ;) as in jaboraYil-u [and jaboraYiylu, &c.]; and so say most of the learned: (TA:) but this is not a valid assertion; for were it so, jaboraYil-u and the like would be perfectly decl.: (M:) some say that these names are constructed inversely, after the manner of the language of the 'Ajam; Al and Ayl meaning servant, and the first part of the name being a name of God. (Suh, TA.)
I. q. XaxoSN [used in a pl. sense]. (Mughnee in art. Uil-aA. [See what is said to be an ex. of this meaning in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in art. AlA in the present work.])

[It is said that] Uil-N is also syn. with jaArN [A neighbour;, &c.]. (Ḳ: [and so, accord. to the TA, in the M; but I have consulted the M without finding this explanation, and think it to be probably a mistranscription for juwaArN, (see above,) as in the T and R.])

entry.sense: Uil-apN: see Uil-N.
OamorN Uil-lI-N A thing, or an affair, relating, or attributable, to AlUil, meaning either God, or revelation or inspiration. (TA.)

OalaA [in its primitive acceptation, being composed of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative lA,] denotes an interrogation respecting a negative, as in the saying [of the poet],
OalaA QSoTibaAra lisalomaI Oamo lahaA jaladN
UicaA OulaAqiI Ql-aciI laAqaAhu OamovaAliI
[Is there not any patience belonging to Selmà, or has she hardiness, when I experience what persons like me have experienced?]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and when used in this manner, it is put before a nominal proposition only, and governs like the negative lA [when used without the interrogative hemzeh]. (Mughnee.)

It also denotes a wish; as in the saying [of the poet],
OalaA Eumora wal-aI musotaTaAEN rujuwEuhu
fayaroOaba maA OavoOato yadu AlgafalaAti
[May there not be a life which has declined whereof the returning is possible, so that it may repair what the hand of negligences hath marred?]; for which reason yrOb is mansoob, because it is the complement of a wish, coupled with fa: and used in this manner, also, it is put before a nominal proposition only, [wl-I in the verse above being a qualificative, like an epithet,] and it governs like the negative lA [without the interrogative hemzeh], and has no enunciative either expressed or understood. (Mughnee.)

It also denotes reproof, or reproach, (T, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and disapproval; as in the saying [of the poet],
OalaA QroEiwaMCa limano walato Xabiyobatuhu
waAcanato bimaXiybK baEodahu haramu
[Is there no self-restraint to him whose youth hath declined, and announced hoariness, after which is to follow decrepitude?]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and used in this manner, also, it is put before a nominal proposition only, and governs as in the cases mentioned above, (Mughnee,) or before a verb [also], which is always marfooa; as in the phrase OalaA tanad-ama EalaI fiEaAlika [Dost not thou repent of thine actions?] and OalaA tasotaHoyiI mino jiyraAnika [Art not thou ashamed for thyself, or of thyself, with respect to thy neighbours?] and OalaA taxaAfu rab-aka [Dost not thou fear thy Lord?]. (T.)

It also denotes EaroDN, (T,) or AlEaroDu, and Alt-aHoDiyDu, both of which signify the asking, or requiring, a thing; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) but the former means the doing so with gentleness; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and the latter, the doing so with urgency: (Mughnee:) and when used in this manner, [also,] it is said to be composed of lA with the interrogative hemzeh; (TA;) and is put before a verbal proposition only; (Mughnee;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur xxiv. 22], OalaA tuHib-uwna Oano yagofira Qll-ehu lakumo [Do not ye, or wherefore do not ye, (see OamaA,) like that God should forgive you?] (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and [in the same, ix. 13,] OalaAtuqaAtiluwna qFwomFA nakavuwA OayomaAnahumo [Will not ye, or wherefore will not ye, fight a people who have broken their oaths?]; (Mughnee;)
or before a mejzoom or marfooa aor., both of these forms being mentioned on the authority of the Arabs, as in OalaA tanozilo taOokulo and OalaA tanozilu taOokulu [Wilt not thou, or wherefore wilt not thou, alight and eat?]. (Ks, T.)

It is also an inceptive particle, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) of which those who parse show the place but neglect the meaning, (Mughnee,) used to give notice of something about to be said, [like as Now, and why, (by the former of which I think it is generally best rendered when thus used,) are often employed in our language, and like as ἀλλὰ (which is remarkable for its near agreement with it in sound) is often used in Greek,] (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and importing averment, because it is composed of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative lA which, when thus composed, have this import, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) like Oalamo, and Oalayosa, because the interrogative particle resembles the particle of negation, and the negation of a negation is an affirmation, (Ḥam p. 589,) and like OamaA before an oath: (Z, Mughnee:) [it may therefore be further rendered by our word surely;; for this word (as Dr. Johnson says in his Dictionary) “is often used rather to intend and strengthen the meaning of the sentence, than with any distinct and explicable meaning:”] or it signifies Haq-FA [verily, or truly]: (M voce OamaA:) it is put before both the [kinds of] propositions, [the nominal and the verbal;] (Mughnee;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 12], OalaA Uin-ahumo humu Qls-ufahaMCu [meaning Now surely it is they who are the lightwitted], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and [in the same, xi. 11,] OalaA yawoma yaOotiyhimo layosa maSoruwfFA Eanohumo [meaning Now surely, on the day of its coming to them, it shall not be averted from them], (Mughnee,) in which yawoma yaOotiyhimo appears to be the object of government of maSoruwfFA, which is the enunciative of layosa whence it has been argued that, as the object of government of the enunciative of lys precedes that verb, the enunciative itself may precede it: (I’Aḳ pp. 74 and 75:) [J says,] you say, OalaA Uin-a zayodFA xaArijN [Now surely Zeyd is going forth], like as you say, UiEolamo Oan-a zayodFA xaArijN [Know thou that Zeyd is going forth]: (Ṣ:) Ks says, OalaA is used to give notice of what is about to be said, and is followed by a command and a prohibition and an enunciation, as in OalaA qumo [Now stand thou], and OalaA laA taqumo [Now stand not thou], and OalaA Uin-a zayodFA qado qaAma [Now surely Zeyd has stood, or has just now stood]. (T.) When it is put before the particle [yaA] used to give notice of what is about to be said, it is merely an inceptive, as in the saying. [of the poet],
OalaA yaA QsolamiI yaA daAra maI-a EalaI AlbilaI
[Now be thou free from evil, O abode of Meiyà, during wear and tear]. (AAF, M.)

Lth says, sometimes OalaA is immediately followed by another lA; and he cites the following ex.:
faqaAma yacuwdu Aln-aAsa Ean-aA bisayofihi
yaquwlu OalaA laA mino sabiylK UilaI hinodi
[Then he began to drive away the people from us, saying, Now is there no way to Hind?]: and one says to a man, “Did such and such things happen?” and he answers, OalaA laA [Why no]: he holds AlA to be used to give notice of what is about to be said, and lA to be a negative. (T.)
OulaA and AlOulaA, and OulaMCi, &c.: see art. AlI.

hom.sense: Oal-aA is a particle denoting taHoDiyD; (Mṣb in art. HD, Mughnee, Ḳ;) i. e., when followed by a future, exciting to an action, and seeking or desiring or demanding the performance of it; and when followed by a preterite, reproof for not doing a thing; (Mṣb ubi suprà;) syn. with hal-aA; (T, TA;) and peculiar to enunciative verbal propositions, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) like the other particles used for the same purpose. (Mughnee.) You say, [Oal-aA tafoEalu kacaA Wherefore wilt not thou do such a thing? and] Oal-aA faEalota kacaA [Wherefore didst not thou such a thing?] (T, TA,) meaning, (TA,) or as though meaning, (T,) lima lamo tafoEalo kacaA. (T, TA.)

It also means Oano laA; the n being incorporated into the l, which is written with teshdeed: (T, TA:) in which case, it is not to be confounded with the foregoing particle. (Mughnee.) You say, Oamarotuhu Oal-aA yafoEala caAka [I commanded him that he should not do that]; and you may say, Oamarotuhu Oano laA yafoEala caAka: it occurs in the old copies of the Ḳur written in the former manner in some places, and in the latter manner in other places. (T, TA.) In the saying in the Ḳur [xxvii. 31], Oal-aA taEoluwA EalaI-a, [which may mean That ye exalt not yourselves against me, or exalt ye not yourselves against me,] it may be a compound of Oano governing a mansoob aor. and the negative laA, or of the explicative Oano and the prohibitive lA. (Mughnee.) [It often has li prefixed to it, forming the compound liYal-aA, which signifies That, or in order that,... not; and may frequently be rendered by lest; as in the Ḳur ii. 145, liYal-aA yakuwna liln-aAsi Ealayokumo Huj-apN That, or in order that, there may not be, or lest there should be, to men, against you, any allegation.]

Uil-aA, [regarded as a simple word,] not to be confounded with the compound of the conditional Uino and the negative laA, (Mughnee at the end of the article on this word,) is used in four manners. (The same in the beginning of the art.) First, (Mughnee,) it is used (as a particle, Ṣ, Mṣb,) to denote exception; [meaning Except, save, or saving; and sometimes but; and sometimes but not; as will be seen below;] (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ; [in which last it is mentioned in art. Al, and again, as in the Ṣ, in the last division of the work;]) and to denote exception, it is used in five manners; after an affirmation, and a negation, and a portion of a sentence devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, and when the thing excepted precedes that from which the exception is made, and when these two are disunited in kind, in which last case it has the meaning of lekin-a [but when the sentence is negative, and but not when the sentence is affirmative]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, qaAma Alqawomu Uil-aA zayodFA [The people, or company of men, stood, except Zeyd]; i. e., Zeyd was not included in the predicament of the people, or company of men: (Mṣb:) and it is said in the Ḳur [ii. 250], (T,) faXaribuwA minohu Uil-aA qaliylFA minohumo [And they drank of it, except a few of them]: (T, Mughnee, Ḳ:) here qlylA is governed in the accus. case by Al-A, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to the most correct opinion: (Mughnee:) accord. to Th, it is so because there is no negation in the beginning of the sentence. (T.) And it is also said in the Ḳur [iv. 69], (T,) maA faEaluwhu Uil-aA qaliylN minohumo [They had not done it, or they would not do it, except a few of them]: (T, Mughnee, Ḳ:) here qlyl is in the nom. case as being a partial substitute, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to the Basrees, (Mughnee,) i. e., as being a [partial] substitute for the [pronoun] w [in fElwh], for it may here be so without perversion of the meaning, whereas it cannot be so without such perversion when the sentence is affirmative: (TA:) accord. to the Koofees, Al-A is a conjunction, like the conjunctive laA: (Mughnee:) accord. to Th, qlyl is here in the nom. case because the sentence commences with a negative: (T:) or in a sentence [like this,] which is not affirmative, in which the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made, accord. to the opinion which is generally preferred and which commonly obtains, the noun signifying the thing excepted is a substitute for the noun signifying that from which the exception is made; but it is allowable to put it in the accus. case according to the general rule respecting exception; so that one says, maA qaAma OaHadN Uil-aA zayodN and Uil-aA zayodFA [There stood not any one, except Zeyd]: and the same is the case in a prohibitive sentence; as in laA yaqumo OaHadN Uil-aA zayodN and Uil-aA zayodFA [Let not any one stand, except Zeyd]; and in an interrogative sentence; as in halo qaAma OaHadN Uil-aA zayodN and Uil-aA zayodFA [Did any one stand, except Zeyd?]; when, in such sentences, the thing excepted is united in kind to that from which the exception is made. (I’Aḳ p. 162.) You say also, maA jaMCaniI Uil-aA zayodN [There came not to me any, save Zeyd], without mentioning that from which the exception is made; (TA;) and maA Darabotu Uil-aA zayodFA [I beat not any, save Zeyd]; and maA mararotu Uil-aA bizayodK [I passed not by any, save by Zeyd]; (I’Aḳ p. 164;) the case of the noun signifying the thing excepted being the same as if Al-A were not mentioned: (I’Aḳ ubi suprà, and TA:*) but you may not say, affirmatively, Darabotu Uil-aA zayodFA, or the like. (I’Aḳ ubi suprà.) When the thing excepted precedes that from which the exception is made, if the sentence is affirmative, the noun signifying the former must be in the accus. case; as in qaAma Uil-aA zayodFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, the people, or company of men, stood]: and so, accord. to the usage generally preferred, when the sentence is not affirmative; as in maAqaAma Uil-aA zayodFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, the people, or company of men, stood not]; but recorded instances allow one's saying also, maA qaAma Uil-aA zayodN Alqawomu. (I’Aḳ p. 163.) When the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made, if the sentence is affirmative, the noun signifying the former must likewise be in the accus. case; as in qaAma Alqawomu Uil-aA HimaArFA [The people, or company of men, stood, but not an ass],
and Darabotu Alqawoma Uil-aA HimaArFA [I beat the people, but not an ass], &c.: (I’Aḳ p. 162:) and so, accord. to the generality of the Arabs, when the sentence is negative; as in maA qaAma Alqawomu Uil-aA HimaArFA [The people stood not, but an ass]; (I’Aḳ p. 163;) and maA raOayotu Alqawoma Uil-aA HimaArFA [I saw not the people, but an ass]; Al-A being here syn. with lekin-a; as also in the Ḳur [xlii. 22], where it is said, laA OasoOalukumo Ealayohi OajorFA Uil-aA Qlomawadapa fiI QlqurobaI [I ask not of you a recompense for it, but affection in respect of relationship]; (Mṣb;) and in the same xx. 1 and 2, maA OanozalonaA Ealayoka QlquroMna litaXoqaI Uil-aA tacokirapF [We have not sent down unto thee the Ḳur-án that thou shouldest suffer fatigue, but as an admonition]; (Bḍ, Jel;) or it is here syn. with balo [which in this case means the same as lkn-]: (Ṣ:) so, too, when the sentence resembles a negative, being prohibitive or interrogative; (I’Aḳ p. 163, explained in p. 162;) [thus, laA taDoribi Alqawoma Uil-aA HimaArFA means Beat not thou the people, but an ass; and] falawlaA kaAnato qaroyapN Mmanato fanafaEahaA UiymaAnuhaA Uil-aA qawoma yuwnusa [in the Ḳur x. 98] means And wherefore did not any inhabitants of a town believe, before the punishment befell them, and their belief profit them, but the people of Jonas? for these were different from the former. (T.) When Uil-aA is repeated for the purpose of corroboration, it has no effect upon what follows it, except that of corroborating the first exception; as in maA mararotu biOaHadK Ual-aA zayodK Uil-aA Oaxiyka [I passed not by any one, except Zeyd, except thy brother], in which Axyk is a substitute for zyd, for it is as though you said, maA mararotu biOaHadK Uil-aA zayodK Oaxiyka; and as in qaAma Alqawomu Uil-aA zayodFA waUil-aA EamorFA [The people stood, except Zeyd, and except ʼAmr], originally Uil-aA zayodFA waEamorFA. When the repetition is not for that purpose, if the sentence is devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, you make the governing word [which is the verb] to affect one, whichever you please, of the nouns signifying the things excepted, and put the others in the accus. case, so that you say, maA qaAma Uil-aA zayodN Uil-aA EamorFA Uil-aA bakorFA [There stood not any, save Zeyd, save ʼAmr, save Bekr]; but if the sentence is not devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made, different rules are observed accord. as the things excepted are mentioned before that from which the exception is made or after it: in the former case, all must be put in the accus., whether the sentence be affirmative or not affirmative; as in qaAma Uil-aA zayodFA Uil-aA EamorFA Uil-aA bakorFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, except ʼAmr, except Bekr, the people stood], and maAqaAma Uil-aA zayodFA Uil-aA EamorFA Uil-aA bakorFA Alqawomu [Except Zeyd, except ʼAmr, except Bekr, the people stood not]: in the latter case, when the sentence is affirmative, all must likewise be put in the accus., so that you say, qaAma Alqawomu Uil-aA zayodFA Uil-aA EamorFA Uil-aA bakorFA [The people stood, except Zeyd, except ʼAmr, except Bekr]; but when the sentence is not affirmative, the same rule is observed with respect to one of them as when the exception is not repeated, accord. to the usage generally preferred, or it may be put in the accus., which is rarely done, and the rest must be put in the accus., so that you say, maA qaAma OaHadN Uil-aA zayodN Uil-aA EamorFA Uil-aA bakorFA [There stood not any one, except Zeyd, except ʼAmr, except Bekr, accord. to the more approved usage], zyd being a substitute for AHd, or you may make the other nouns which remain to be substitutes. (I’Aḳ pp. 164 - 166.)

Secondly, (Mughnee,) it is used as a qualificative, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) in the manner of gayoru, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) [i. e.] in the place of gayoru, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] as syn. with gayoru, (T, Mṣb,) and siwaI; (T;) [both meaning the same, i. e. Other than; or not, as used before a subst. or an adjective;] but its primary application is to denote exception, and its use as a qualificative is adventitious; whereas the primary application of gayoru is as a qualificative, and its use to denote exception is adventitious. (Ṣ.) It [generally] follows an indeterminate, unrestricted pl.; (Mṣb;) or an indeterminate pl., or the like thereof, is qualified by it and by that which follows it; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) the noun which follows it being put in the same case as that which precedes it. (Ṣ.) The following is an ex. of the indeterminate pl.: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) lawo kaAna fiyhimaA MlihapN Uil-aA Qll-ehu lafasadataA [If there had been in them (namely the heavens and the earth) deities other than God, or not God, assuredly they would have become in a state of disorder, or ruin; occurring in the Ḳur xxi. 22]; (Fr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ;) Al-A here meaning sawiI, (Fr, T,) or gayoru, (Mṣb, TA,) and Al-A Qll-eh being a qualificative of Mlhp. (TA.) And the following is an ex. of the like of an indeterminate pl.:
Ouniyxato faOaloqato balodapF fawoqi balodapK
qaliylK bihaA AlOaSowaAtu Uil-aA bugaAmuhaA
[She (the camel) was made to lie down, and threw her breast upon a tract of ground in which were few sounds other than her broken yearning cry for her young one]; for the determination of AlASwAt [by the article Al] is generical: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) this verse is by Dhu-r-Rummeh. (Ṣ in art. bld.) The following is an ex. of the like of a pl..: (Mughnee:) it is by Lebeed: (T:)
lawo kaAna gayoriI sulayomaI Alyawoma gay-arahu
waqoEu AlHawaAdivi Uil-aA AlS-aArimu Alc-akaru
[If it had been other than I, (O) Suleymà, today, the befalling of misfortunes would have altered him; other than the sharp sword diversified with wavy marks or streaks or grain, or of which the edge is of steel and the middle of the broad side of soft iron]. (T, Mughnee. [But in the latter, in the place of Alyawoma, I find Ald-ahora, i. e. ever.]) What Sb says necessarily implies its not being a condition that the word qualified must be a pl. or the like thereof; for he gives as an ex., lawo kaAna maEanaA rajulN Uil-a [If there had been with us a man other than Zeyd, we should have been overcome]. (Mughnee.) Another ex. of the same usage of Uil-aA is the following: jaMCaniI Alqawomu Uil-aA zayodN [The people came to me, others than Zeyd, or not Zeyd]. (Ṣ.) [And ma Oanotumo Uil-aA baXarN mivolunaA Ye are no other than human beings like us. (Ḳur xxxvi. 14.)] And the saying [in the Ḳur xliv. 56], laA yacuquwna fiyhaA Qlomawota Uil-aA Qlmawotapa QloOuwlaI [They shall not taste therein death, other than the first death]; Al-A here meaning siwaI: (T:) or, accord. to some, it here means baEoda [after]. (Jel.) And the saying of ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-kerib,
wakul-u OaxK mufaAriquhu Oaxuwhu
laEamoru Oabiyka UilaA AlfaroqadaAni
[And every brother, his brother forsakes him, or separates himself from him, by the life of thy father, other than the Farhadán; which is the name of the two stars b and r of Ursa Minor]; as though he said gayoru Alfaroqadayoni: (Ṣ:) but Ibn-El-Hájib regards this instance as a deviation from a general rule; for he makes it a condition of the use of Al-A as a qualificative that it must be impossible to use it for the purpose of denoting exception: (Mughnee:) Fr says that this verse has the meaning of a negation, and therefore Al-A here governs the nom. case; as though the poet said, There is not any one but his brother forsakes him, except the Farkadán. (T.) When it is used as a qualificative, it differs from gayoru inasmuch as that the noun qualified by it may not be suppressed; so that one may not say, jaMCaniI Uil-aA zayodN [meaning There came to me not Zeyd]; whereas one says, jaMYaniI gayoru zayodK: and, accord. to some, in this also; that it may not be used as such unless it may be used to denote exception; so that one may say, EinodiI dirohamN Uil-aA daAniqN [I have a dirhem, not a dánik], because one may say Uil-aA daAniqFA [except a dánik]; but not Uil-aA jay-idN [not a good one], because one may not say Uil-aA jay-idFA [except a good one]; but it may be said that this is at variance with what they assert respecting the phrase lawo kaAna fiyhimaA MlihapN, and with the ex. given by Sb, and with the saying of Ibn-El-Hájib mentioned above. (Mughnee.)

Thirdly, (Mughnee,) sometimes, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) it is used as a conjunction, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) in the manner of wa (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) consociating both literally and as to the meaning, as mentioned by Akh and Fr and AO, (Mughnee,) [i. e.] as syn. with wa [And]. (Mṣb.) Thus in the saying, liYalA-a yakuwna liln-aAsi Ealayokumo HujapN Uil-aA Ql-aciyna ZalamuwA [That there may not be to men, against you, any allegation, and (meaning nor) to those who have acted wrongfully]; (Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ;) occurring in the Ḳur [ii. 145]; (Mṣb;) so accord. to Akh and Fr and AO; (Mughnee;) i. e., and those who have acted wrongfully also, to them there shall not be, against you, any allegation: (Mṣb:) Fr explains it as meaning that the wrongdoer has no allegation of which account should be taken; and this is correct, and is the opinion held by Zj. (T.) Thus, too, in the saying [in the Ḳur xxvii. 10 and 11], laA yaxaAfu ladaI-a Qlomurosaluwna Uil-aA mano Zalama vum-a badala HusonFA baEoda suwCK [The apostles shall not fear in my presence, and neither shall he who hath acted wrongfully, then hath done good instead, after evil; as some explain it; but others say that walaA mano Zalama here denotes exception]. (Mughnee, in which it is explained as meaning; and Ḳ.) And thus in the saying of the poet, [namely, El-Mukhabbal Es-Saadee, (Ṣ in art. xld,)]
waOaraI lahaA daArFA biOagodirapi Also
siydaAni lamo yadoruso lahaA rasomu
Uil-aA ramaAdFA haAmidFA dafaEato
Eanohu Alr-iyaAHa xawaAlidN suHomN
[And I see a dwelling formerly belonging to her, at the pools of Es-Seedán, (a hill so called,) the remains of which have not become effaced, and ashes wasted and compacted together, from which three black pieces of stone whereon the cooking-pot was wont to be placed turned back the winds]: he means, OaraI lahaA daArFA waramaAdFA. (Ṣ.)

Fourthly, (Mughnee,) it is redundant, as in the following verse, (Ṣ in art. fk, Mughnee, Ḳ,) of Dhu-rRummeh, (Ṣ ubi suprà, Mughnee,) accord. to Aṣ and IJ: (Mughnee:)
HaraAjiyju maA tanofak-u Uil-aA munaAxapN
EalaI Alxasofi Oawo naromiI bihaA baladFA qaforaA
[She-camels long-bodied, or lean, (but other meanings are assigned to the word which I thus render,) that cease not to be made to lie down in a state of hunger, or with which we direct our course to a desert region]; (Ṣ ubi suprà, Mughnee; [but in one copy of the former, in the place of naromiI, I find yaromiI; and in my copy of the latter, taromiI;]) meaning, mA tnfk- mnAxpF: (Ṣ ubi suprà:) but it is said that this is a mistake of the poet: (Mughnee:) so says Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà; for, he says, Al-A is not to be introduced after tanofak-u and tazaAlu: (TA:) and some say that the right reading is Uil-FA, with tenween, [perhaps a mistranscription, for MlFA,] meaning XaxoSFA [in a pl. sense]: and some, that tnfk- is a complete [or an attributive] verb, and mnAxp is a denotative of state; [consequently, that Uil-aA is a compound of Uino and laA, as in some other instances hereafter to be mentioned;] the meaning being, that are not disengaged, or not free, from fatigue [unless when made to lie down]. (Mughnee.) The following is also given as an ex. of the same kind:
OaraI Ald-ahora Uil-aA manojanuwnFA biOaholihi
[I see fortune, or time, to be like a water-wheel, with its people]: but the reading which is remembered to have been heard is wamaA Ald-ahoru: and if the former be correct, it may be explained on the supposition that ArI is the complement of an oath meant to be understood, and that lA is suppressed, as in [the saying in the Ḳur xii. 85,] taQll-ehi tafotaOu tacokuru yuwsufa; [so that the meaning is, I see not fortune, or time, to be aught save a water-wheel, with its people;] the form of the exceptive sentence which is devoid of the mention of that from which the exception is made indicating such an explanation. (Mughnee.)

[Fifthly,] it occurs as syn. with lDaA [as a particle denoting exception, equivalent to our But; meaning both except and (after an oath or the like) only, or nothing more than]; as in the saying in the Ḳur [xxxviii. 13], Uino kul-N Uil-aA kac-aba Alr-usula [There was not any one but such as accused the apostles of lying], in which ʼAbd-Allah reads, in its place, lam-aA; and for kul-N he reads kul-uhumo; and as in the saying, OasoOaluka biQll-ehi Uil-aA OaEoTayotaniI [I ask, or beg, or beseech, thee by God but that thou give me; i. e., I do not ask of thee anything save thy giving me; the preterite here, as in many instances in which it is preceded by lam-aA (q. v.), not being a preterite in meaning]; for which one says also lam-aA AETytnI. (T.)

It is also a particle [or rather a compound of two words] denoting the complement of a condition; originally Uino laA, which form a compound that does not admit of [the pronunciation termed] imáleh, because Uino and laA are particles. (T.) [It signifies, lit., If not.] It is followed by a fut., which it renders mejzoom; [and in this case it may be rendered as above, or by unless;] as in the saying in the Ḳur [viii. 74], UilaA tafoEaluwhu takuno fitonapN fiI AlOaroDi [If ye do it not, or unless ye do it, there will be a weakness of faith and an appearing of unbelief in the earth]. (T.) [In like manner,] in a saying such as the following, [in the Ḳur ix. 40,] Uil-aA tanoSuruwhu faqado naSarahu Qll-ehu [If ye do not, or will not, aid him, certainly God aided him], it is only a compound of two words, the conditional Uino and the negative laA, and is distinct from Uil-aA of which the usages have been mentioned before, though Ibn-Málik has included it therewith. (Mughnee.) [Often in post-classical works, and perhaps in classical also, but seldom except when it is preceded by a condition with its complement, the verb or verbal proposition which should immediately follow it is suppressed; as in the like of the saying, Uino faEalota kacaA Eafawotu Eanoka waUil-aA qatalotuka If thou do such a thing, I forgive thee, or cancel thine offence; but if thou wilt not do it (i. e., Uil-aA tafoEalohu,) I kill thee: sometimes also it ends a sentence, by an aposiopesis; the whole of what should follow it being suppressed: and sometimes the complement of the condition which precedes, as well as the verb or verbal proposition which should immediately follow it, is suppressed; so that you say, Uino faEalotu kacaA waUil-aA qatalotuka If thou do such a thing, excellent will it be, or the like, (faniEim-aA huwa, or the like, being understood,) but if not, I kill thee. Hence,] it sometimes has the meaning of Uim-aA, [signifying Or, denoting an alternative, corresponding to a preceding Uim-aA, which signifies “either,”] as in the saying, Uim-aA Oano tukal-imaniI waUil-aA faQsokuto [Either do thou speak to me or else (meaning waUil-aA tukal-imaniI or if thou wilt not speak to me) be silent], i. e., waUim-aA Oano tasokuta. (Ṣ.) [It is also followed by Oano, as in Uil-aA Oano yaXaMCa Qll-ehu Unless God should please; in the Ḳur vi. 111, &c. And by w as a denotative of state, as in laA tamuwtun-a Uil-aA waOanotumo musolimuwna Do not ye die unless ye be Muslims; in the Ḳur ii. 126 and iii. 97. And sometimes it is preceded by Aall-hum-a; for the effect of which, in this case, see art. Alh.]
1. Oalaba, (Th, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOolibu} and _u {yaOolubu}, inf. n. OalobN, (M,) It (a thing, Th, M) was, or became, collected; or compact; syn. AijotamaEa; (Th, Ḳ;) or tajam-aEa. (M.)

Oalaba Uilayohi Alqawomu The people came to him from every direction: (M, Ḳ:) or Oalaba Alqawomu [signifies the people multiplied themselves, and hastened; for it] denotes AlUikovaAru and AlUisoraAE: (T in art. Dhb:) and Oalaba, (T, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (T,) signifies he hastened, or went quickly. (T, Ḳ.)
Oalabati AlUibilu The camels obeyed the driver, and collected themselves together. (M, Ḳ.) [See also 5.]
Oalaba Uilayohi He returned to him, or it. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Oalabati Als-amaMCu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOolibu}, (M,) The sky rained with long continuance. (M, Ḳ.)

Oalaba, (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOolibu}, inf. n. OalobN, (Mṣb,) He collected (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ) an army, (Ṣ,) or a people; (Mṣb;) as also Ol-b↓, (M,) inf. n. taOoliybN: (TA:) and camels also: (TA:) or Oalaba AlUibila aor. _i {yaOolibu} (T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and _u {yaOolubu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OalobN, (T, Ṣ,) signifies he collected the camels, and drove them (Ṣ, TA) vehemently: (TA:) or he drove them: (T,* Ḳ:) or he drove them vehemently. (M.)

Oalaba, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) also signifies He drove, pursued, chased, or hunted, with vehemence: (Ḳ, TA:) and he drove away a people. (Mṣb.) You say, Oalaba AlHimaAru Tariydatahu The [wild] ass chased, or pursued, the object of his chase [i. e. his female, as is shown by MF,] with vehemence; (M, Ḳ;) as also Oal-abahaA↓ (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.

taOoliybN also signifies The act of exciting, instigating; or rousing to ardour: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the exciting of discord, or strife, or the making of mischief. (Ḳ.) you say, Ol-b bayonahumo He excited discord or strife, or made mischief, between them. (M.)

5. tOl-bwA They collected themselves together. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) [See also 1.] You say also, tOl-bwA Ealayohi They leagued together, or collected themselves. together, and aided one another, against him. (T.)

OalobN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb) and UilobN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) Persons, or people, collected together; (Ṣ;) an assembly; a collected body: (Mṣb:) or a collection of many people: (T:) and OalobN OaluwbN↓ a great assembly or congregation. (M.)

Also A people, or company of men, combining in hostility against a man. (TA, from a trad.) You say, humo Ealayohi OalobN waAHidN, and UilobN↓, (but the former is the better known, M,) They are [one body of men] assembled against him with injustice and enmity or hostility: (Lth, T, M, Ḳ:) like waEolN waAHidN and SadoEN waAHidN and DilaEN waAHidN. (T, TA.)
UilobN: see OalobN, in two places.
OalabN a dial. var. of yalabN; (M;) Helmets of camels' shins: or, as some say, it signifies steel: (T:) OalabapN is [its n. un., being] a dial. var. of yalabapN. (Ḳ,* TA.) [See also yalabN.]
OaluwbN: see OalobN.

Also One who hastens, or is quick; (T;) and miYolabN↓ likewise signifies [the same; or] quick, or swift: (Ibn-Buzurj, T, Ḳ:) or the former signifies quick in drawing forth the bucket: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:) or brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, or prompt, and quick; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)
riyoHN OaluwbN A cold wind, (M,) that raises and scatters the dust. (M, Ḳ.)
samaMCN OaluwbN A sky raining with long continuance. (M.)
miYolabN: see OaluwbN.
HasuwdN muWal-ibN [An envious man,] who excites discord or strife, or makes mischief. (Ṣ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Oalata, aor. _i {yaOolitu}, inf. n.OalotN, It (a thing) decreased; diminished; lessened; became defective, deficient, incomplete, or imperfect. (Mṣb.)

Oalatahu Haq-ahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOolitu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OalotN (Ṣ, M) and UilaAtahu; (M;) and Oalitahu, aor. _a {yaOolatu}; (Fr;) and Mlthu↓ (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiylaAtN; (Ḳ;) as also OalaAtahu, inf. n. UilaAtN, (so in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or UilaAtapN; (so in the L: [agreeably with analogy, and therefore probably the correct reading: see art. lyt, to which it belongs: in SM's copy of the Ḳ, and in the CK, the verb is written OaloOatahu, and the inf. n. UiloMtN: by MF, the verb is written Mlatahu↓, of the measure faAEala and the inf. n. UilaAtN like qitaAlN:]) [and laAtahu, aor. yaliytN; and walatahu; and Oawolatahu;] He diminished to him his right, or due; abridged him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it: (Fr, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) and in like manner, Oalatahu maAlahu and Mlthu↓, &c., he diminished to him his property; or abridged him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it: (M, TA:) and Oalata AlX-aIoCa he diminished the thing. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] maA OalotanaAhumo mino Eamalihimo mino XaIoCK [in the Ḳur lii. 21, We will not diminish to them aught of the reward of their work]: (T, A:) or, accord. to one reading, (that of Ibn-Ketheer, TA,) mA OalitonaAhumo. (T, TA.) [See also art. lyt.]

Oalatahu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Oalatahu Eano wajohihi, (TA,) aor. _i {yaOolitu}; (T;) as also laAtahu; these being two dial. vars. one of the other, mentioned by Yz, on the authority of AA; (Ṣ;) [and OalaAtahu; (see art. lyt;)] He withheld him, or restrained him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and turned him, or averted him, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) from his course, purpose, or object. (Ṣ, TA.)

Oalatahu, (M, Ḳ,) or Oalatahu yamiynFA, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ,) aor. _i {yaOolitu}, inf. n. OalotN, He made him to swear, or take an oath: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he desired of him that he should swear, or give his testimony, for him. (M, Ḳ.) And Oalatahu biyamiynK, inf. n. as above, He pressed him, or pressed hard upon him, with an oath. (M.) It is related that a man said to ʼOmar, “Fear God, O prince of the faithful:” and another, hearing him, said, OataOolitu EalaI Oamiyri AlmuWominiyna, meaning Dost thou lower the dignity of the prince of the faithful? or dost thou diminish to him [the respect that is due to him]? accord. to IAạr.: or rather, dost thou conjure the prince of the faithful? his saying “Fear God” being as though he conjured him by God: for the Arabs say, Oalat-uka biQll-ehi lam-aA faEalota kacaA, meaning I conjure thee by God but that thou do thus, or such a thing. (T.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.
4: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: OalotN Deficiency: as in the saying, maA fiI mazaAwidihimo OalotN [There is not, in their provision-bags, any deficiency]. (A.)
A swearing; syn. HalifN (M, TA.) [Perhaps an inf. n. in this sense.]
An oath: as in the saying, when one has not given thee thy right, or due, qay-idohu biAloOaloti [Bind thou him by oath]. (T.)
Calumny, slander, or false accusation. (Kr, M, Ḳ.) [Perhaps an inf. n. in this sense also.]
OulotapN A small gift. (AA, T, Ḳ.)
An oath such as is termed gamuws, q. v. (AA, T, Ḳ.)

1. Oalifahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOolafu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UilufN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OalofN (Ḳ) and UilaAfN and wilaAfN, which is anomalous, and OalafaAnN, (M, TA,) He kept, or clave, to it; (AʼObeyd, T, M, Mṣb,* TA;) namely, a thing, (AʼObeyd, T, M, TA,) or a place; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) as also Oalafahu, aor. _i {yaOolifu}; (TA;) and Mlfhu↓, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) aor. yuWolifu (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. UiylaAfN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and Mlfhu↓, aor. yuWaAlifu, inf. n. muWaAlafapN and UilaAfN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) [he frequented it, or resorted to it habitually; namely, a place:] he became familiar with it; or accustomed, or habituated, to it; namely, a thing: (AZ, T:) he became familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable, with him: (AZ, T, Mṣb:) he loved, or affected, him; liked, approved, or took pleasure in, him. (Mṣb.) You say, Oalifati AlT-ayoru AlHarama [The birds kept to the sacred territory], and Albuyuwta [the houses]: and Mlafati↓ AlZ-ibaMCu Alr-amoli The gazelles kept to the sands. (T.)

There are three manners of reading the passage in the Ḳur [evi. 1 and 2], liUiylaAfi↓ qurayoXK UiylaAfihimo riHolapa AlX-itaMCi waAlS-ayofi; the second and third being liUilaAfi and liUilofi; the first and second of which have been adopted; (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, TA;) and the third also; this being the reading of the Prophet [himself]: (TA:) [accord. to all these readings, the passage may be rendered, For the keeping of Kureysh, for their keeping to the journey of the winter and of the summer, or spring; the chapter going on to say, for this reason “let them worship the Lord of this House,”, &c.: or] the second and third readings are from Oalifa, aor. yaOolafu; [and accord. to these readings, the passage may be rendered as above;] but accord. to the first reading, the meaning is, for the preparing and fitting out [&c.; i. e., preparing and fitting out men and beasts in the journey of the winter, &c.]: so says IAmb; and Fr explains in the same manner the third reading: but IAạr says that, accord. to this reading, the meaning is, the protecting [&c.]: he says that the persons who protected were four brothers, Háshim and ʼAbd-Shems and El-Muttalib and Nowfal, the sons of ʼAbd-Menáf: these gave protection to Kureysh in their procuring of corn: (T:) Háshim obtained a grant of security from the king of the Greeks, and Nowfal from Kisrà, and ʼAbd-Shems from the Nejáshee, and El-Muttalib from the kings of Himyer; and the merchants of Kureysh used to go to and from the great towns of these kings with the grants of security of these brothers, and none opposed them: Háshim used to give protection (yuWolifu [in the copies of the Ḳ yuWal-ifu]) [to those journeying] to Syria, and ʼAbd-Shems to Abyssinia, and El-Muttalib to El-Yemen, and Nowfal to Persia: (T, Ḳ:*) or UiylaAf↓ in the Ḳur signifies a covenant, or an obligation; and what resembles permission, (UijaAzap, as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) or protection, (UijaArap, as in the CK,) with an obligation involving responsibility for safety; first obtained by Háshim, from the kings of Syria; (Ḳ,* TA;) and the explanation is, that Kureysh were dwelling in the sacred territory, (Ḳ,) having neither seed-produce nor udders [to yield them milk], (TA,) secure in the procuring of their provisions from other parts, and in their changes of place, in winter and summer, or spring; the people around them having their property seized; whereas, when any cause of mischief occurred to them, they said, “We are people of the sacred territory,” and then no one opposed them: (Ḳ:) so in the O: (TA:) or the l is to denote wonder; and the meaning is, wonder ye at the AylAf of Kureysh [&c.]: (Ḳ:) some say that the meaning is connected with what follows; i. e., let them worship the Lord of this House for the AylAf [&c., agreeably with the first explanation which we have given]: others, that it is connected with what precedes; as J says; (TA;) the meaning being, I have destroyed the masters of the elephant to make Kureysh remain at Mekkeh, and for their uniting the journey of the winter and of the summer, or spring; that when they finished one, they should commence the other; (T, Ṣ;) and this is like the saying, Darabotuhu likacaA Darabotuhu likacaA a likacaA, with suppression of the [conjunctive] w: (Ṣ:) but Ibn-ʼArafeh disapproves of this, for two reasons: first, because the phrase “In the name of God”, &c. occurs between the two chapters: [Bḍ, however, mentions that in Ubeí's copy, the two compose one chapter:] secondly, because AylAf signifies the covenants, or obligations, which they obtained when they went forth on mercantile expeditions, and whereby they became secure. (TA.) UilaAfN↓ [in like manner] signifies A writing of security, written by the king for people, that they may be secure in his territory: and is used by Musáwir Ibn-Hind in the sense of AiytilaAfN [as is also UilofN,] when he says, in satirizing Benoo-Asad,
zaEamotumo Oan-a Uixowatakumo qurayoXN
lahumo UilofN walayosa lakumo UilaAfu
meaning Ye asserted [that your brothers are Kureysh; i. e.,] that ye are like Kureysh: but how should ye be like them? for they have [an alliance whereby they are protected in] the trade of El-Yemen and Syria; and ye have not that [alliance]. (Ḥam p. 636.) [Hence,] UilaAfu Qll-ehi [a phrase used in the manner of an oath,] accord. to some, signifies The safeguard, or protection, of God: or, accord. to others, an honourable station from God. (TA.)
Oalafahu, aor. _i {yaOolifu}, He gave him a thousand; (Ṣ, Ḳ) of articles of property, and of camels. (TA.)

2. Ql-f bayonahumo, inf. n. taOoliyfN, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He united them, or brought them together, (T, Mṣb, TA,) after separation; (T, TA;) and made them to love one another; (Mṣb;) he caused union, or companionship, (Oulofap,) to take place between them. (Ḳ.) And Oal-afotu bayona AlX-ayoYayoni, inf. n. as above, [I united, or put together, the two things.] (Ṣ.) And Ol-f AlX-aIoCa He united, or connected, (T,) or gathered or collected or brought together, (M,) the several parts of the thing. (T, M.)
Hence, taOoliyfu Alkutubi [The composition of books]. (T, TA.)

taOoliyfN is The putting many things into such a state that one name becomes applicable to them, whether there be to some of the parts a relation to others by precedence and sequence, or not: so that it is a more general term than tarotiybN: (KT:) or the collecting together, or putting together, suitable things; from AlAlfp [i. e. AlOulofapu]; and is a more particular term than tarokiybN, which is the putting together things, whether suitable or not, or placed in order or not. (Kull p. 118.)
Oal-afuwA UilaI kacaA: see 5.
Ol-f OalifFA He wrote an alif; (Ḳ;) like as one says jay-ama jiymFA. (TA.)
See also 4, in three places.
3. Mlfhu: see 1, first sentence.

Mlf, (M, TA,) inf. n. muWaAlafapN, (TA,) [app., He made a covenant with another to be protected during a journey for the purpose of trade, or traffic: (see 1:) and hence,] he (a man) traded, or trafficked. (M, TA.)
XaAarapN muWaAlafapF He made a condition with him for a thousand: (IAạr, M:) like as one says, XaAraTotuhu mumaA MpF, meaning, for a hundred. (IAạr, M, Ḳ, in art. mOI.)
4. Mlfhu, inf. n. UiylaAfN: see 1, in three places.
Mlfhu AlX-aIoCa, (T, M,) or AlmawoDiEa, (Ṣ,) or makaAna kacaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He made him to keep, or cleave, to the thing, or to the place, or to such a place. (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.*)
Mlafotu AlX-aIoCa I joined, conjoined or united, the thing. (T.)

Mlafotu Alqawoma, (T,* Ṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) I made the people, or company of men, to be a thousand complete [by adding to them myself]; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) they being before nine hundred and ninety-nine. (T, TA.) And Mlf AlEadada He made the number to be a thousand; as also Oal-afahu↓: (M:) or Ol-f↓ AlOalofa he completed the thousand. (Ḳ.) And in like manner, (Ṣ,) Mlafotu Ald-araAhima I made the dirhems to be a thousand (Ṣ, Ḳ) complete. (Ṣ.) And Oal-afuw↓ lahumu AlOaEomaAra They said to them, May you live a thousand years. (A in art. Emr.)
MlafuwA They became a thousand (T, Ṣ, M) complete. (Ṣ.) And Mlafati Ald-aArahimu The dirhems became a thousand (Ṣ Ḳ) complete. (Ṣ.)

5. tOl-f Alqawomu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and QYotalafuwA↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiyotalafuwA], (T, Ḳ,) The people, or party, became united, or came together, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [after separation, (see 2, of which each is said in the TA to be quasi-pass.,)] and loved one another: (Mṣb:) or the meaning of QYotilaAfN↓ [and taOal-ufN also] is the being in a state of union, alliance, agreement, congruity, or congregation: (Mṣb:) and the being familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable, one with another. (TA.) And taOal-afaA is said of two things; [meaning They became united, or put together; (see 2;)] as also AYtlfA↓. (Ṣ.) And AYtlf↓ AlX-aIoCu signifies The several parts of the thing kept, or clave, together. (M.) And tOl-f It became put together in order. (M.)

tOl-fwA They sought, desired, or asked, [a covenant to ensure them] protection, (IAạr, T, M,) UilaI kacaA [meaning in a journey for the purpose of trade, or traffic, to such a place, as is shown in the T by an explanation of the words of IAạr, kaAna haAXimN yuWolifu UilaI AlX-aAmi, in a passage in which the foregoing signification is assigned to tOl-fwA]; (M;) as also Oal-afuwA↓ AlI kcA. (M.)

tOl-fhu He treated him with gentleness or blandishment, coaxed him, or wheedled him; (Ḳ;) behaved in a sociable, friendly, or familiar, manner with him; (TA;) attracted him, or allured him; and gave him a gift, or gifts; (T, Ḳ;*) in order to incline him to him: (Ḳ:) or he affected sociableness, friendliness, or familiarity, with him. (Mgh.) You say, taOal-afotuhu EalaI AlUisolaAmi [I attracted him, or allured him; and gave him a gift, or gifts, in order to incline him; to embrace El-Islám]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 5, in four places.

OalofN, meaning A certain number, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) well known, (M,) i. e. a certain round number, (Mṣb,) [namely a thousand,] is of the masc. gender: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say valaAvapu MlaAfK [Three thousand], not valaAva MlaAfK; (TA;) and hecaA OalofN waAHidN [This is one thousand], not waAHidapN; (Ṣ;) and OalofN OaqoraEu, [A complete thousand], (T, Ṣ,) not qaroEaMCu: (Ṣ:) it is not allowable to make it fem.: so say IAmb and others: (Mṣb:) or it is allowable to make it fem. as being a pl.: (T:) or, accord. to ISK, it is allowable to say, hecihi OalofN as meaning hecihi Ald-araAhimu OalofN [These dirhems are a thousand]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) and Fr and Zj say the like: (Mṣb:) the pl. is MlufN, applied to three, (M,) and MlaAfN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to a number from three to ten, inclusively, (TA,) and OuluwfN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) used to denote more than ten; (T;) and AlOaAfu [in the TA AlOalafu] is used by poetic licence for AlMlaAfu, by suppression of the [radical] l (M.)

UilofN [originally an inf. n. of Oalifahu, q. v.,] He with whom one is familiar, sociable, companionable, friendly, or amicable; he to whom one keeps or cleaves; [a constant companion or associate; a mate; a fellow; a yoke-fellow; one who is familiar, &c., with another or others; (see muWal-afN;)] (M;) i. q. OaliyfN↓; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) which is an act. part. n. of Oalifahu; (Mṣb;) as is also MlifN↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and OalifN↓ also is syn. with OaliyfN: (Ḳ:) the female is termed UilofapN and UilofN; (M;) both of these signifying a woman with whom thou art familiar, &c., and who is familiar, &c., with thee: (Ḳ:) and the fem. of MlifN↓ is MlifapN: (Ḳ:) the pl. of UilofN is MlaAfN; (T, M;) which is also pl. of OalifN↓: (TA:) and that of OaliyfN↓ is OalaAYifu (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and OulafaMCu: (M, TA:) and that of MlifN↓ is Oul-aAfN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and MlaAfN, like as OanoSaArN is pl. of naASirN, (TA,) and so, (M, TA,) in my opinion, [says ISd,] (M,) is OuluwfN, like as XuhuwdN is pl. of XaAhidN, (M, TA,) though some say that it is pl. of UilofN: (M:) and the pl. of MlifapN↓ is OawaAlifu and MlifaAtN. (Ḳ.) You say, fvlaAnN UilofiI and OaliyfiI↓ [Such a one is my constant companion or associate,, &c.] (T.) And Han-ati AlUilofu UilaI Uilofi [The female mate yearned towards the mate]. (Ṣ.) And nazaEa AlbaEiyru UilaI MlaAfihi [The camel yearned towards his mates]. (T.) Oul-aAfN, (T,) or MlaAfN (TA,) is said by IAạr to mean Persons who keep to the large towns, or cities. (T, TA.) OuluwfN in the Ḳur ii. 244 is said by some to be pl. of UilofN or of MlifN↓: but by others, to signify “thousands.” (Bḍ, L, TA.) OawaAlifu↓ AlT-ayori signifies The birds that keep to Mekkeh and the sacred territory: and OawaAlifu↓ AlHamaAmi Domestic pigeons. (T.)

hom.sense: OalifN: see UilofN, in two places.
As some say, (O,) it also signifies A man having no wife. (O, Ḳ.)

One of the letters of the alphabet; (M;) the first thereof; (Ḳ;) as also OaliyfN↓: (M:) Ks says that, accord. to the usage of the Arabs, it is fem., and so are all the other letters of the alphabet; [and hence its pl. is OalifaAtN;] but it is allowable to make it masc.: Sb says that every one of them is masc. and fem., like as is lisaAnN. (M.) See art. A.
‡ A certain vein lying in the interior of the upper arm, [extending] to the fore arm: (Ḳ, TA:) so called as being likened to an A: (TA:) the two are called AlOalifaAni. (Ḳ.)
† One of any kind of things: (Ḳ, TA:) as being likened to the A; for it denotes the number one. (TA.)

entry.sense: OulofapN A state of keeping or cleaving [to a person or thing]: (M:) a state of union, alliance, agreement, congruity, or congregation; (Mṣb;) a subst. from AlAiYotilaAfu: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and, as such, (TA,) signifying also familiarity, sociableness, socialness, companionableness, friendliness, fellowship, companionship, friendship, and amity. (Mṣb, TA.*)
OalofiI-N Of, or relating to, or belonging to, the number termed OalofN [a thousand]. (TA.)
[qaAmapN Oalifiy-apN A stature resembling the letter alif. Often occurring in late works.]
UilaAfN an inf. n. of Oalifahu: and used as a subst.: see 1.
baroqN UilaAfN Lightning of which the flashes are consecutive or continuous. (TA.)
OaluwfN Having much OulofapN [meaning familiarity, sociableness,, &c.]: pl. OulufN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OaliyfN: see UilofN, in three places:
and see OalifN.

entry.sense: MlifN and MlifapN and OawaAlifu, the pl. of the latter: see UilofN, in seven places.
UiyolaAfN an inf. n.: and used as a subst.: see 1.

maOolafN [An accustomed place;] a place to which a man keeps or cleaves; [which he frequents, or to which he habitually resorts;] with which he is familiar, or to which he is accustomed; (Mṣb;) a place with which men or camels [or birds and the like] are familiar,, &c. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And hence, Leafy trees to which animals of the chase draw near. (AZ, Ḳ.)
mWlfwn, with fet-ḥ, [i. e. muWolafuwna or muWal-afuwna↓,] Possessors of thousands; or men whose camels have become, to each, a thousand. (TA.)

hom.sense: muWal-afN and maOoluwfN↓ Kept to, or clove to; applied to a thing [and to a person; and meaning when applied to the latter, with whom one is familiar, sociable,, &c.]. (T.) It is said in a trad., AlmuWominu UilofN maOoluwfN↓ [The believer is one who is familiar, or sociable,, &c., with others, and with whom others are familiar,, &c.]. (TA.)

AlmuWal-afapu quluwbuhumo Those whose hearts are made to incline, or are conciliated, by beneficence and love or affection: (Ṣ,* Mṣb:) as used in the Ḳur [ix. 60], it is applied to certain chief persons of the Arabs, whom the Prophet was commanded to attract, or allure, and to present with gifts, (T, Ḳ,) from the poor-rates, (TA,) in order that they might make those after them desirous of becoming Muslims, (T, Ḳ,) and lest care for things which they deemed sacred, or inviolable, together with the weakness of their intentions, should induce them to combine in hostility with the unbelievers against the Muslims; for which purpose, he gave them, on the day of Honeyn, eighty [in the TA two hundred] camels: (T:) they were certain men of eminence, of the Arabs, to whom the Prophet used to give gifts from the poor-rates; to some of them, to prevent their acting injuriously; and to some, from a desire of their becoming Muslims, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and their followers also; (Mṣb;) and to some, in order that they might remain stedfast as Muslims, because of their having recently become such; but when Aboo-Bekr became appointed to the government, he forbade this practice. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
OalofN muWal-afapN [These are a thousand] made complete. (Ṣ.)
See also mWlfwn.

entry.sense: [muWal-ifN A composer of a book or books; an author.]
maOoluwfN: see muWal-afN, in two places.

1. Oalaqa, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yaOoliqu}; (Ḳ, TA;) or Oaliqa, aor. _a {yaOolaqu} (CK; [in which it would seem, from what follows in this paragraph and the next, that the pret. is wrong, but that the aor. is right;]) inf. n. OaloqN and UilaAqN; (JK, Ḳ;) It (lightning) lied; (AHeyth, Ḳ;) [i. e.] it was without rain. (JK.)
See also 5.

Also, Oalaqa, aor. _a {yaOolaqu}, inf. n. OaloqN, He lied; spoke falsely: whence the reading of Aboo-Jaạfar and Zeyd Ibn-Aslam, [in the Ḳur xxiv. 14,] Uico taOolaquwnahu tOl-q [When ye spoke it falsely with your tongues]. (TA.)

5. tOl-q It (lightning) shone, gleamed, or glistened; as also AYtlq↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytalaqa]; (JK, Ṣ, IJ, Ḳ;) and so Oalaqa↓, aor. _a {yaOolaqu}. (TA.) Ibn-Aḥmar has made the second trans., using the phrase taOotaliqu↓ AlEuyuwna, either by suppressing a prep., [meaning She shines to the eyes,] or meaning thereby she ravishes the eyes. (TA.)

And taOal-aqatN, said of a woman, She adorned herself: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or she became active and quick to engage in contention or altercation, and prepared herself for evil or mischief, and raised her head: (IF, Ḳ:) or she became like the Uiloqap [fem. of UiloqN, q. v.]. (IAạr.)
8: see 5, in two places.
UiloqN A he-wolf: fem. with p {UiloqapN}: (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the fem. is also applied to a she-ape or monkey; the male of which is not called UiloqN, but qirodN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and rub-aAHN. (Ṣ.)

UilaAqN [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet;] Lying, or fallacious, lightning; (Ḳ;) that has no rain; (JK, Ḳ;) as also Oal-aAqN↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) MliqN↓, likewise, is an epithet applied to lightning [in the same sense; or as signifying shining, gleaming, or glistening: see 1 and 5]: and so is Oul-aqN↓, as syn. with xul-abN [that excites hope of rain, but deceives the expectation]. (TA.)
Also, applied to a man, Lying: (JK:) or lying much, or often, or habitually: (TA:) and very deceitful, and variable in disposition. (TA.)
OaliyqN [app. an inf. n. of Oalaqa; (see 5;)] The shining, gleaming, or glistening, of lightning. (TA.)
Oul-aqN: see UilaAqN.
Uil-aqN, like Uim-aEN, [in a copy of the JK incorrectly written OaliqN,] i. q. mutaOal-iqN [Shining, gleaming, or glistening]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to lightning. (JK.)
Also † An inconstant man; from Alt-aOal-uqu as relating to lightning. (JK: there, in this instance, written Uil-aqN.)
Oal-aAqN: see UilaAqN.
MliqN: see UilaAqN.

1. Oalaka Alil-jaAma, (ISd, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yaOoluku} or _i,] inf. n. OalokN, (ISd, TA,) He (a horse) chewed, or champed, the bit; syn. Ealakahu. (ISd, Ḳ.) One says, of a horse, yOlku All-ujuma He chews, or champs, the bits: but the verb commonly known is yaluwka, or yaEoluku. (Lth.)
[Hence, accord. to some, (see OaluwkN,)] Oalaka bayona Alqawomi, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. _i {yaOoliku}, inf. n. OalokN and OuluwkN, (Mṣb,) He acted as a messenger (taras-ala) between the people. (Mṣb, TA.)
And Oalakahu, aor. _i {yaOoliku}, inf. n. OalokN, He conveyed, or communicated, to him a message. (Kr.)
And Oalaka He sent. (IB in art. lwk.)

4. OalikoniI is from Oalaka signifying “he sent;” and is originally OaOolikoniI; the [second] hemzeh being transposed and placed after the l, it becomes OaloYikoniI; then the hemzeh has its vowel transferred to the l and is thrown out; as is done in the case of malakN, which is originally maOolakN, then maloOakN, and then malakN: (IB in art. lwk:) it means Be thou my messenger; and bear thou my message; and is often used by the poets. (Ṣ in art. lwk.) Accord. to IAmb, one says, OalikoniI UilaI fulaAnK, meaning send thou me to such a one: [but I do not know any instance in which this meaning is applicable:] and the original form is OaloYikoniI; or, if from AlOaluwku, the original form is OaOolikoniI: and he also says that it means be thou my messenger to such a one. (TA.) One says also, OalikoniI UilayohaA birisaAlapK, which should properly mean Send thou me to her with a message: but it is an inverted phrase; since the meaning is, be thou my messenger to her with this message [or rather with a message]: and OalikoniI UilayohaA biAls-alaAmi i. e. convey thou, or communicate thou, to her my salutation; or be thou my messenger to her [with salutation]: and sometimes this [prep.] b is suppressed, so that one says, OalikoniI UilayohaA Als-alaAma: sometimes, also, the person sent is he to whom the message is sent; as in the saying, OalikoniI Uilayoka Als-alaAma [virtually meaning receive thou my salutation; but literally] be thou my messenger to thyself with salutation. (TA.) Lḥ mentions the phrase Oalakotuhu Uilayohi, with respect to a message, aor. Ouliykuhu, inf. n. UilaAkahN; in which case, the hemzeh [in the aor. and inf. n.] is converted into a letter of prolongation. (TA in art. lOk.)
5: see OaluwkN.
10. AstOlk maOolukatahu He bore, or conveyed, his message; (Ḳ;) as also AstlOk. (TA.)

OaluwkN A thing that is eaten [or rather chewed, as will be seen below]: so in the phrases, hcaA Oaluwku SidoqK like Ealuwju SidoqK and Ealuwku SidoqK [This is an excellent thing that is chewed], and maA talaw-akotu biOaluwkK [or maA taOal-akotu↓ biOaluwkK (Ḳ in art. Elj)] like maA taEal-ajotu biEaluwjK [app. meaning I have not occupied myself in chewing with anything that is chewed]. (TA.)

[And hence, accord. to some,] A message, or communication sent from one person or party to another; (Lth, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.; [in the CK, after Alr-isAlapu, by which AlOaluwku is explained in the Ḳ, &c., we find qibala Almaliki muXotaq-N mnhu, in which the first two words should be qiyla Almalaku, as in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA; and AlAuluwku is erroneously put, in the CK, for AlOaluwku;]) said by Lth and ISd to be so called because it is [as it were] chewed in the mouth; (TA;) as also OaluwkahN↓ (ISd, Ṣgh, Ḳ) and maOolukapN↓ (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and maOolakapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maOolukN↓: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb. Ḳ, &c.:) accord. to Kr, (TA,) this last is the only word of the measure mafoEulN: (Ḳ, TA:) but accord. to Sb and Akh, there is no word of this measure: (TA:) [i. e. there is none originally of this measure:]
other instances have been mentioned; namely, makorumN and maEuwnN [originally maEowunN] and maqoburN and maholukN and mayosurN, which last occurs in the Ḳur [ii. 280], accord. to one reading, in the words fanaZirapN UilaI mayosurihi; but it is said that each of these, and maOolukN also, may be regarded as originally with p; or, accord. to AḤei, each is [virtually, though not in the language of the grammarians,] a pl. of the same with p; (MF, TA;) and Akh says the same with respect to makorumN and maEuwnN: (TA:) Seer says that each is curtailed of p by poetic licence; but this assertion will not apply to mayosurN, as it occurs in the Ḳur. (MF, TA.)
OaluwkN also signifies A messenger. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ. [In the CK here follows, wAlmOoluwoku wAlmaOoluqu: but the right reading is waAlmaOoluwku AlmaOoluwqu, as in other copies and in the TA.])
OaluwkahN: see OaluwkN.

maOolakN is said to be the original form of malakN [An angel; so called because he conveys, or communicates, the message from God; (Ḳ,* TA, in art. lOk;)] derived from OaluwkN; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA; [but in the CK is a mistake here, pointed out above, voce OaluwkN;]) so that the measure of malakN is maEalN: (Mṣb:) malakN is both sing. and pl.: Ks says that it is originally maOolakN, from OaluwkN signifying “a message;” then, by transposition, maloOakN, a form also in use; and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, the hemzeh is suppressed, so that it becomes malakN; but in forming the pl., they restore it to maloOakN, saying malaAYikapN, and malaAYiku also: (Ṣ in art. mlk:) or, accord. to some, it is from laOaka “he sent;” so that the measure of malakN is mafalN: and there are other opinions respecting it: (Mṣb:) some say that its m is a radical: see art. mlk. (TA in art. lOk.)
maOolukN: see OaluwkN.
maOolakapN: see OaluwkN.
maOolukapN: see OaluwkN.

1. Oalima, aor. _a {yaOolamu}, inf. n. OalamN, It, (as, for instance, the belly, T, Ṣ, or the head, Mṣb,) or he, (a man, T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) was in pain; had, or suffered, pain; ached. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Oalima baTonahu [He was in pain, or had pain, in his belly] (M) and Oalimota baTonaka [thou wast in pain, or hadst pain, in thy belly] (T, Ṣ) or raOosaka [in thy head] (Mṣb) are like safiha raOoyahu (M) and raXidota Oamoraka (Ṣ, T) and wajiEota raOosaka; (Mṣb;) the noun being in the accus. case accord. to Ks as an explicative, though explicatives are [by rule] indeterminate, as in qarirotu bihi EayonFA and Daqotu bihi caroEFA; (T;) the regular form being [Oalima baTonuhu and] Oalima baTonuka, (T, Ṣ,) as the verb is intrans. (T.)
4. Mlamotuhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiylaAmN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) I caused him pain or aching. (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

5. tOl-m He was, or became, pained: (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or he expressed pain, grief, or sorrow; lamented; complained; made lamentation or complaint; moaned; syn. tawaj-aEa, (T, Ṣ,) and XakaI. (T.) You say, taOal-ama fulaAnN mino fulaAnK [Such a one expressed pain,, &c., on account of the conduct or the like of such a one; complained of such a one]: (T:) and liOazomapi Alz-amaAni [on account of the hardness of the time]. (TA in art. Azm.)
Oalamo: see lamo.

OalamN Pain; ache; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also OayolamapN↓: (T, M, Ḳ:) pl. (of the former, T, M) MlaAmN. (T, M, Ḳ.) You say, maA Oajidu OayolamapF↓ walaA OalamFA I do not find pain nor ache; i. e. wajaEFA: so says AZ: and IAạr says, OayolamapF walaA OalamapF↓ as meaning the same. (T.) And the Arabs say, laOubiytan-aka EalaI OayolamapK↓, meaning I will assuredly bring upon thee [lit. make thee to pass the night in] distress, or difficulty. (Sh.)
OalimN Being in pain; having, or suffering, pain; aching. (M, Ḳ.)
OalamapN: see OalamN.
UilaAma a contraction of UlaI maA: see UilaI, last sentence.

OaliymN Causing pain or aching; painful; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. muWolimN↓; (T, M, Mṣb;) like samiyEN as syn. with musomiEN: (Ṣ:) so when applied to punishment [or torment or torture]: (T, Mṣb:) or, thus applied, painful, or causing pain or aching, in the utmost degree. (M, Ḳ.)
OaluwmapN Lowness, ignobleness, baseness, vileness, or meanness. (O, Ḳ.)
OayolamapN: see OalamN, in three places.
Accord. to IAạr, (T,) A sound, or voice. (T, Ḳ.) You say, maA samiEotu lahu OayolamapN I heard not any sound, or voice, of, or belonging to, him, or it. (IAạr, T.)
Accord. to AA, (T,) Motion. (T, Ḳ.)
muWolimN: see OaliymN.
OalomaAsN, or QlomaAsu: see art. mws.

hom.sense: 1. Oalaha, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) or Oaliha, (Mgh, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) like taEiba, aor. _a {yaOolahu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. UilaAhapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OuluwhapN and Ouluwhiy-aPN, (Ḳ,) He served, worshipped, or adored; syn. Eabada. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence the reading of I’Ab, [in the Ḳur vii. 124,] wayacaraka waUilaAhataka [And leave thee, and the service, or worship, or adoration, of thee; instead of waMlihataka and thy gods, which is the common reading]; for he used to say that Pharaoh was worshipped, and did not worship: (Ṣ:) so, too, says, Th: and IB says that the opinion of I’Ab is strengthened by the sayings of Pharaoh [mentioned in the Ḳur lxxix. 24 and xxviii. 38], “I am your lord the most high,” and “I did not know any god of yours beside me.” (TA.)
Oaliha, aor. _a {yaOolahu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. OalahN, (Ṣ,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) originally waliha. (Ṣ.)
Oaliha EalaI fulaAnK He was, or became, vehemently impatient, or affected with vehement grief, or he manifested vehement grief and agitation, on account of such a one; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like waliha. (Ṣ.)

Oaliha Uilayohi He betook himself to him by reason of fright or fear, seeking protection; or sought, or asked, aid, or succour, of him: he had recourse, or betook himself, to him for refuge, protection, or preservation. (Ḳ.)
Oaliha biAlmakaAni He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (MF.)

Oalahahu, (Ḳ,) like manaEahu, (TA,) [in the CK Aalihahu,] He protected him; granted him refuge; preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; aided, or succoured, him; or delivered him from evil: he rendered him secure, or safe. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. taOoliyhN [inf. n. of Oal-ahahu He made him, or took him as, a slave; he enslaved him;] i. q. taEobiydN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[The primary signification of Oal-ahahu seems to be, He made him to serve, worship, or adore.]

[Accord. to Freytag, besides having the former of the two meanings explained above, it signifies He reckoned him among gods; held him to be a god; made him a god: but he does not mention his authority.]
5. tOl-h He devoted himself to religious services or exercises; applied himself to acts of devotion. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
OulohaAniy-apN: see UilaAhapN.

UilehN, or UilaAhN, [the former of which is the more common mode of writing the word,] is of the measure fEaAlN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like kitaAbN in the sense of makotuwbN, and bisaATN in the sense of mabosuwTF, (Mṣb,) meaning maOoluwhN↓ [An object of worship or adoration; i. e. a god, a deity]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) anything that is taken as an object of worship or adoration, accord. to him who takes it as such: (Ḳ:) with the article Al, properly, i. q. Qll-ehu; [sec this word below;] but applied by the believers in a plurality of gods to what is worshipped by them to the exclusion of Qll-eh: (Mṣb:) pl. MlihapN: (Mṣb, TA:) which signifies idols: (JK, Ṣ, TA:) in the Ḳ, this meaning is erroneously assigned to UilaAhapN: (TA:) [not so in the CK; but there, AlAlihapu is put in a place where we should read AlUilaAhapu, or UilaAhapu without the article:] AlUilaAhapu↓ [is the fem. of AlUilaAhu, and] signifies [the goddess: and particularly] the serpent: [(a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to AlMlihapu; as also other meanings here following:) because it was a special object of the worship of some of the ancient Arabs:] (Ḳ:) or the great serpent: (Th:) and the [new moon; or the moon when it is termed] hilaAl: (Th, Ḳ:) and, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also UilaAhapu↓, without Al, the former perfectly decl., and the latter imperfectly decl., (Ṣ,) and AlOulaAhapu↓, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and OulaAhapu↓, (IAạr, TA,) and AlOalaAhapu↓, (Ḳ,)
[and app. OalaAhapu↓,] and AlOaliyhapu↓, (Ḳ,) the sun; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) app. so called because of the honour and worship which they paid to it: (Ṣ:) or the hot sun. (Th, TA.) [UilhN is the same as the Hebrew אֱלוׄהַ and The Chaldee אֱלֶה; and is of uncertain derivaTion: accord. To some,] it is originally wilaAhN, like as UiXaAHN is originally wiXaAHN; meaning that mankind yearn towards him who is thus called, [seeking protection or aid,] in their wants, and humble themselves to him in their afflictions, like as every infant yearns towards its mother. (TA.) [See also the opinions, cited below, on the derivation of Qll-ehu.]
OalaAhapu and AlOalaAhapu: see UilhN.

hom.sense: OulaAhapu and AlOulaAhapu: see UilhN.
OulaAhapN: see UilaAhapN.
UilaAhapN inf. n. of 1, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Godship; divinity; (Ḳ;) as also OulaAhapN↓ (CK [not found by me in any MṢ. copy of the Ḳ]) and OulohaAniy-apN↓. (Ḳ.)
UilaAhapu and AlUilaAhapu: see UilhN.

entry.sense: AlOaliyhapu: see UilhN.
[UilehiI-N, or UilaAhiI-N, Of, or relating to, God or a god; divine; theological: Hence, AlEilomu AlUilhiI-u or AlUilaAhiI-N: see what next follows.]

[AlUilehiy-apu, or AlUilaAhiy-apu, Theology; the science of the being and attributes of God, and of the articles of religious belief; also termed Eilomu AlUilhiy-aAti or AlUilaAhiy-aAti, and AlEilomu AlUilhiI-u↓ or AlUilaAhiI-u.]

Qll-ehu, [written with the disjunctive alif Aall-ehu, meaning God, i. e. the only true god,] accord. to the most correct of the opinions respecting it, which are twenty in number, (Ḳ,) or more than thirty, (MF,) is a proper name, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) applied to the Being who exists necessarily, by Himself, comprising all the attributes of perfection; (TA;) a proper name denoting the true god, comprising all the excellent divine names; a unity comprising all the essences of existing things; (Ibn-El-ʼArabee, TA;) the Al being inseparable from it: (Mṣb:) not derived: (Lth, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it is originally UilhN, or UilaAhN, (Sb, AHeyth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, meaning maOoluwhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) with [the article] Al prefixed to it, (Sb, AHeyth, Ṣ, Mṣb,) so that it becomes AlUilaAhu, (Sb, AHeyth, Mṣb,) then the vowel of the hemzeh is transferred to the l [before it], (Mṣb,) and the hemzeh is suppressed, (Sb, AHeyth, Ṣ, Mṣb,) so that there remains Qll-ehu, or AlilaAhu, after which the former l is made quiescent, and incorporated into the other: (Sb, AHeyth, Mṣb:) the suppression of the hemzeh is for the purpose of rendering the word easy of utterance, on account of the frequency of its occurrence: and the Al is not a substitute for the hemzeh; for were it so, it would not occur therewith in AlUilaAhu: (Ṣ:) so says J; but IB says that this is not a necessary inference, because AlUilaAhu applies to God (Qll-ehu) and also to the idol that is worshipped; whereas Qll-ehu applies only to God; and therefore, in using the vocative form of address, one may say, yaA Aall-ehu [O God], with the article Al and with the disjunctive hemzeh; but one may not say, yaA AlUilaAhu either with the disjunctive or with the conjunctive hemzeh: (TA:) Sb allows that it may be originally laAhN: see art. lyh: (Ṣ:) some say that it is from Oaliha, either because minds are confounded, or perplexed, by the greatness, or majesty, of God, or because He is the object of recourse for protection, or aid, in every case: or from Oalahahu, meaning “he protected him,”, &c., as explained above: see 1, last sentence. (TA.) The Al is pronounced with the disjunctive hemzeh in using the vocative form of address [yaA Aall-ehu] because it is inseparably prefixed as an honourable distinction of this name; (Ṣ;) or because a pause upon the vocative particle is intended in honour of the name; (Ṣ in art. lyh;) and AAF says that it is also thus pronounced in a form of swearing; as in OafaAall-ehi latafoEalan-a [an elliptical phrase, as will be shown below, meaning Then, by God, wilt thou indeed do such a thing?]; though he denies its being thus pronounced because it is inseparable; regarding it as a substitute for the suppressed hemzeh of AlUilaAhu: (Ṣ in the present art.:) Sb mentions this pronunciation in yaA Aall-ehu; and Th mentions the pronunciation of yaA Qll-ehu also, with the conjunctive hemzeh: Ks, moreover, mentions, as used by the Arabs, the phrase yalaho AagofiroliI [O God, forgive me], for yaA Qll-ehu; but this is disapproved. (ISd, TA.) The word is pronounced in the manner termed tafoxiym, [i. e., with the broad sound of the lengthened fet-ḥ, and with a full sound of the letter l,] for the purpose of showing honour to it; but when it is preceded by a kesreh, [as in biQll-ehi By God, and bisomi Qll-ehi In the name of God,] it is pronounced in the [contr.] manner termed taroqiyq: AḤát says that some of the vulgar say, laAwaQll-eho [No, by God], suppressing the alif, which should necessarily be uttered, as in Alr-aHomnu, which is in like manner written without alif; and he adds that some person has composed a verse in which the alif [in this word] is suppressed, erroneously. (Mṣb.) You say, Aall-eha Qll-eha fiI kacaA, [a verb being understood,] meaning Fear ye God, fear ye God, with respect to such a thing. (Marginal note in a copy of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer. [See another ex. voce kar-apN.]) And Aall-eha laOafoEalan-a and Aall-ehi laOafoEalan-a [By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: in the former is understood a verb significant of swearing; and in the latter, [or in both, for a noun is often put in the accus. case because of a particle understood,] a particle [such as bi or wa] denoting an oath. (Bḍ in ii. 1.) And lilhi maA faEalotu, meaning waQll-ehi maA faEalotu [By God, I did not, or have not done, such a thing]. (JK.) And lil-hi dar-uka ‡ To God be attributed thy deed! (A in art. dr:) or the good that hath proceeded from thee! or thy good deed! or thy gift! and what is received from thee! [and thy flow of eloquence! and the like]: a phrase expressive of admiration of anything: (TA in art. dr:) [when said to an eloquent speaker or poet, it may be rendered divinely art thou gifted!]. And lil-hi dar-uhu ‡ To God be attributed his deed! [&c.]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dr.) And lil-hi AlqaAYilu [meaning To God be attributed (the eloquence of) the sayer! or] how good, or beautiful, is the saying of the sayer, or of him who says [such and such words]! or it is like the phrase lil-hi dar-uhu, meaning † To God be attributed his goodness! and his pure action! (Ḥar p. 11.) And lil-hi fulaAnN [To God be attributed (the excel-lence, or goodness, or deed,, &c., of) such a one!] explained by Az as meaning wonder ye at such a one: how perfect is he! (Ḥar ibid.) [And lil-hi Oabuwka: see art. Abw.] And laAhi Oanota, meaning lil-hi Oanota [lit. To God be thou attributed! i. e. to God be attributed thine excellence! or thy goodness! or thy deed!, &c.]. (JK.) [Similar to lil-hi, thus used, is the Hebrew expression לֵאלׂהִים after an epithet signifying “great” or the like.] Uin-aAlil-hi waUin-aA Uilayohi raAjiEuwna, in the Ḳur [ii. 151], said on the occasion of an affliction, means Verily to God we belong, as property and servants, He doing with us what He willeth, and verily unto Him we return in the ultimate state of existence, and He will recompense us. (Jel.) AZ mentions the phrase AlHamodulaAhi [meaning AlHamodulil-hi Praise be to God]: but this is not allowable in the Ḳur-án: it is only related as heard from the Arabs of the desert, and those not knowing the usage of the Ḳur-án. (Az, TA.)

Aall-hum-a↓ is an expression used in prayer; as also laAhum-a; (JK, Mṣb;) meaning yaA Aall-ehu [O God]; the m being a substitute for [the suppressed vocative particle] yA; (Ṣ in art. lyh, and Bḍ in iii. 25;) but one says also, yaA Aall-hum-a, (JK, and Ṣ ibid,) by poetic licence: (Ṣ ibid:) or the meaning, accord. to some, is yaA Aall-ehu Oum-anaA bixayorK [O God, bring us good]; (JK, and Bḍ ubi suprà;) and hence the origin of the expression. (Bḍ.) You say also Aall-hum-a Uil-aA [which may be rendered, inversely, Unless, indeed; or unless, possibly]: the former word being thus used to denote that the exception is something very rare. (Mṭr in the commencement of his Expos. of the Maḳámát of El-Ḥareeree, and Ḥar pp. 52 and 53.) And Aall-hum-a naEamo [which may be rendered, inversely, Yes, indeed; or yea, verily]: the former word being used in this case as corroborative of the answer to an interrogation, negative and affirmative. (Ḥar p. 563.)
Aall-ehum-a: see what next precedes.
maOoluwhN: see UilehN.

hom.sense:
1. OalaA, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. yaOoluw, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. OalowN (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ) and Ouluw-u (Ḳ, TA [in a copy of the M Oaluw-N]) and OuliI-N; (Ḳ, TA; [in a copy of the M OaliI-N, and in a copy of the Mgh written with fet-ḥ and damm to the O;]) and Oal-aI↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yuWal-I, inf. n. taOoliyapN; (Ṣ;) and AYtlI↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytalaI]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) [and taOal-I↓, as appears from an ex. in a verse cited in art. nXb, q. v.;] He fell short; or he fell short of doing what was requisite, or what he ought to have done; or he flagged, or was remiss;
syn. qaS-ara: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ; and Fr, IAạr, T, Mgh, in explanation of the first of these verbs:) and he was slow, or tardy: (M, Ḳ; and AA, T, Ṣ, in explanation of the second verb:) or he flagged, or was remiss, or languid, and weak. (AHeyth and T in explanation of all of the above-mentioned verbs except the last.) You say, OalaA fiI AlOamori, (Mgh,) and AYtlI↓ fiyhi, (Ṣ,) He fell short,, &c., (qaS-ara,) in the affair. (Ṣ, Mgh.) In the saying, lam yaOolu Oano yaEodila fiI clika, i. e. He did not fall short,, &c., (lamo yuqaS-aro,) in acting equitably and equally in that, fiI is suppressed before An: but in the phrase, lamo yaOoluw mina AlEadoli, as some relate it, [the meaning intended seems to be, They did not hold back, or the like, from acting equitably; for here] the verb is made to imply the meaning of another verb: and such is the case in the saying, laA Mluwka nuSoHFA, meaning I will not refuse to thee, nor partially or wholly deprive thee of, sincere, honest, or faithful, advice: (Mgh:) or this last signifies I will not flag, or be remiss, nor fall short, to thee in giving sincere, honest, or faithful, advice. (T, Ṣ.*) It is said in the Ḳur [iii. 114], laA yaUoluwnakumo xabaAlFA, meaning They will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in corrupting you. (IAạr, T.) And the same meaning is assigned to the verb in the saying walaA yaOotali↓ Ouwluw AlofaDoli minokumo, in the Ḳur [xxiv. 22], by AʼObeyd: but the preferable rendering in this case is that of AHeyth, which will be found below: see 4. (T.) Ks mentions the phrase, Oaqobala biDarobapK laA yaOolu [He came with a blow, not falling short,, &c.], for lA yaOoluw; like laA Oadori [for lA OadoriI]. (Ṣ, M: [but in the copies of the former in my hands, for biDarobapK, I find yaDoribuhu.]) Oal-aI↓ [with teshdeed] is also said of a dog, and of a hawk, meaning He fell short of attaining the game that he pursued. (TA.) And of a cake of bread, meaning It was slow in becoming thoroughly baked. (IAạr, IB.) [See also the phrase laA daryota walaA AYotalyota in a later part of this paragraph.]

You say also, maA Oalawotu AlX-ayoCa, (Ḳ,) or maA Oalawotu Oano OafoEalahu, (M,) inf. n OalwN (M, Ḳ) and Ouluw-N, (Ḳ, TA, [in a copy of the M OulowN,]) meaning I did not leave, quit, cease from, omit, or neglect, (M, Ḳ,) the thing, (Ḳ,) or doing it. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yaOoluw xayorFA Such a one does not leave, quit, or cease from, doing good. (M.) And maA Oalawotu jahodFA I did not leave, omit, or neglect, labour, exertion, effort, or endeavour: and the vulgar say, maA Mluwka jahodFA; but this is wrong: so says Aṣ. (T. [See, however, similar phrases mentioned above.])

OalaA, aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. OalowN, (IAạr, T, TA,) also signifies He strove, or laboured; he exerted himself, or his power or ability; (IAạr, T, TA;) as also taOal-aI↓: (T, TA:) the contr. of a signification before mentioned; i. e. “he flagged;,” or “was remiss, or languid, and weak.” (TA.) You say, OataAniI fiI HaAjapK faOalawotu fiyhaA He came to me respecting a want, and I strove, or laboured,, &c., to accomplish it. (T.)

And OalaAhu, aor. as above, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. OalowN, (IAạr, T, Ṣ,) He was, or became, able to do it: (IAạr, T, Ṣ:) and Ol-I↓, inf. n. taOoliyapN, also signifies he was, or became, able; (TA;) and so AYtlI↓. (ISk, Ṣ, TA.) You say, huwa yaOoluw hcaA AlOamora He is able to perform, or accomplish, this affair. (T.) And maA Oalawotuhu I was not able to do it. (T, M, Ḳ.) And OataAniI fulaAnN fiI HaAjapK famaA Oalawotu rad-ahu Such a one came to me respecting a want, and I was not able to rebuff him. (T.) It is said in a trad., mano SaAma Ald-ahora falaA SaAma walaA Oal-aI↓ [He who fasts ever, or always, may he neither fast] nor be able to fast: as though it were an imprecation: or it may be enunciative: another reading is walaA Mla, explained as meaning walaA rajaEa: [See art. Awl:] but El-Khaṭṭábee says that it is correctly Oal-aI and OalaA. (TA.)
