It also denotes taking option; as in the saying, liI daArN biAlkuwfapi faOnaA xaArijN UlayohaA faUm-aA Oano OasokunahaA wUim-aA Oano OabiyEahaA [I have a house in El-Koofeh, and I am going forth to it, and either I will inhabit it or I will sell it: but this is similar to the usage first mentioned above]. (Ks, T.)

It is a conjunction, (Ṣ in art. Amw, and Mughnee,) accord. to most authorities, i. e., the second Uim-aA in the like of the saying, jaACaniI Um-aA zayodN wUim-aA EamorNw [mentioned above]; (Mughnee;)
used in the manner of Oawo in all its cases except this one, that in the use of Aw you begin with assurance, and then doubt comes upon you; whereas you begin with Uim-aA in doubt, and must repeat it; as in the saying last mentioned: (Ṣ: [and the like is said in the Mughnee, after the explanations of the meanings:]) but some assert that it is like the first Uim-aA, not a conjunction; because it is generally preceded by the conjunction w: and some assert that Uim-aA conjoins the noun with the noun, and the w conjoins Uim-aA with Uim-aA; but the conjoining of a particle with a particle is strange. (Mughnee.)

Sometimes the w is suppressed; as in the following verse, (Mughnee,) of El-Ahwas; (Ṣ;)
yaA layotamaA Oum-uniA XaAlato naEaAmatuhaA
OayomaA UilaI jan-apK OayomaA UilaI naAri
[O, would that our mother took her departure, either to Paradise or Hell-fire!]; (Ṣ,* Mughnee, Ḳ;) cited by Ks, with AymA for Uim-aA: (T:) and sometimes it is with kesr [i. e. UiymaA]: (Ṣ:) IB says that it is correctly Uim-aA, with kesr; asserting the original to be Uim-aA, with kesr, only. (TA.)

And sometimes the former maA is dispensed with; as in the following verse, (Mughnee,) which shows also that maA is sometimes suppressed;
saqatohu Ar-awaAEidu mino Say-ifK
waUino mino xariyfK falano yaEodamaA
[The thundering clouds of summer-rain watered him, or of autumn-rain; so he will not want sufficient drink]: i. e. Uim-aA mino Say-ifK waUim-aA mino xariyfK. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) Mbr and Aṣ say that Uino is here conditional, and that the f is its complement: but this assertion is of no weight; for the object is the description of a mountain-goat as having sufficient drink in every case: AO says that Uino in this verse is redundant. (Mughnee.)

Sometimes, also, one does not require to mention the second Uim-aA, by mentioning what supplies its place; as in the saying, Uim-aA Oano tatakal-ama bixayorK waUil-aA fAsokuto [Either do thou speak what is good or else be silent]. (Mughnee.) [See art. AlA, near its end.]

Distinct from the foregoing is Uim-aA in the saying in the Ḳur [xix. 26], faUim-aOitaryin-a mina AlobaXari OaHadFAi [And if thou see, of mankind, any one]: for this is [a compound of] the conditional Uin and the redundant maA. (Ṣ* in art. Amw, and Mughnee.) [In like manner,] you say, in expressing a condition, Uim-aA taXotiman-a zoydFA faUin-ahu yaHolumu Eanoka [If thou revile Zeyd, he will treat thee with forbearance]. (Ks, T.) And Uim-aA taOotiniI Oukorimoka [If thou come to me, I will treat thee with honour]. (Ṣ.)

In the following saying, Uim-aA Oanota munoTaliqFA AnoTalaqotu [If thou be going away, I go away], the maA is not that which restrains the particle to which it is subjoined from governing, but is a substitute for a verb; (Ḳ and TA in art. maA;) as though the speaker said, UicaA Sirota munoTaliqFA [or rather Uino Sirota]. (TA in that art.) And hence the saying of the poet, [of which a reading different from that here following has been given voce Oam-aA,]
OabaA xuraAXapa Uim-aA Oanota caA nasfarK
faUn-a qawomiIa lamo taUokulohumu AlD-abugu
[O Aboo-Khurásheh, if thou be possessor of a number of men, verily, my people, the year of dearth, or of sterility, hath not consumed them]; as though he said, Uino kunotu caA nafarK. (TA in that art.) [But IHsh states the case differently; saying,] An instance of Oam-aA Oanota munTaliqFA AnoTalaqotu not used to restrain from governing, but as a substitute for a verb, occurs in the saying, Oam-aA Oanota munTaliqFA AinoTalaqotu [Because thou wast going away, I went away]; originally, AinoTalaqotu liOano kunota munTaliqAF: [for an explanation of which, see what is said of Oam-aA Oanota in a reading of the verse commencing with OabaA xuraAXap voce Oam-aA:] but accord. to El-Fárisee and IJ, the government belongs to maA; not to kaAna [or kunota]. (Mughnee in art. maA.)

So too in the saying, AifoEalo hcaA Uim-aAlaA, meaning Uino kunota laAtafoEalu gayorahu [i. e. Do thou this if thou wilt not do another thing; or do thou this at least]; (Mughnee and Ḳ, each in art. maA;) indicating a person's refusal to do [fully] that which he is ordered to do: (TA in that art.:) or Uim-aAlaA faAfoEalo kacaA, meaning if thou wilt not do that, then do thou this; the three particles [Uino and maA and laA] being made as one word: so says Lth: (T:) [J says,] Uim-aAlaA faAfoEalo kacaA is pronounced with imáleh, [i. e. “immá-lè,”] and is originally Uin laA with maA as a connective; and the meaning is, if that thing will not be, then do thou thus: (Ṣ in art. laA:) [but] AḤát [disallows this pronunciation, and] says, sometimes the vulgar, in the place of AifoEalo celika Uim-aAlaA, say, AifoEalo celika baAriI [Do thou that at least]; but this is Persian, and is rejected as wrong: and they say also, Oum-aAlaIo, with damm to the A [and with imáleh in the case of the final vowel, and thus it is vulgarly pronounced in the present day]; but this too is wrong; for it is correctly Uim-aAlaA, [with kesr, and] not pronounced with imáleh, for particles [in general] are not thus pronounced: (T:) and the vulgar also convert the hemzeh into h with damm [saying hum-aAlaIo]. (TA in art. maA.) [Fei says,] laA is a substitute for the verb in the saying, Uim-aAlaA faAfoEalo hecaA, the meaning being If thou do not that, then [at least] do thou this: the origin thereof is this; that certain things are incumbent on a man to do, and he is required to do them, but refuses; and then one is content with his doing some, or a part, of them, and says to him thus: i. e., if thou wilt not do all, then do thou this: then the verb is suppressed, on account of the frequency of the usage of the phrase, and maA is added to give force to the meaning: and some say that it is for this reason that laA is here pronounced with imáleh; because it serves for the verb; like as balaI is, and the vocative yaA: but it is said that it is correctly pronounced without imáleh; because particles [in general] are not pronounced therewith; as Az says. (Mṣb in art. laA.) [El-Ḥareeree says that] Uim-aAlaA is properly [a compound of] three particles, which are Uino and maA and laA, made as one word, and the A at the end thereof is like the A of HubaAraI [in which it is written I, agreeably with rule]; wherefore it is pronounced with imáleh, like as is the A of this latter word. (Durrat el-Ghowwáṣ, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. p. 57 of the Arabic text.) In the Lubáb it is said that laA is used as a negative of the future, as in lA tafoEalo; and the verb [in Uim-aAlaA] is suppressed; so it [lA] serves as a substitute in the saying, AifoEalo hecaA Uim-aAlaA; therefore they pronounce its A with imáleh: and IAth says that the Arabs sometimes pronounced laA with a slight imáleh; and the vulgar make the imáleh thereof full, so that its A becomes I; but this is wrong. (TA.) You say also, xuco hecaA Uim-aAlaA, meaning Take thou this if thou take not that. (T.) It is related that the Prophet saw a runaway camel, and said, “To whom belongeth this camel?” when, lo, some young men of the Ansár said, “We have drawn water upon him during twenty years, and yet he has in him fat; so we desired to slaughter him; but he escaped from us.” He said, “Will ye sell him?” They answered, “No: but he is thine.” And he said, Uim-aAlaA fOaHosinuwA Uilayohi Hat-aI yOotiyahu Oajaluhu, meaning If ye will not sell him, act well to him until his term of life come to him. (T.)

entry.sense: 1. Oamatahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOomitu}, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. N. OamotN, (T, Ṣ, M,) He measured it; determined its measure, quantity, or the like; computed, or conjectured, its measure, quantity,, &c.; (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ;) as also Am-thu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOomiytN. (TA.) You say, Aiymito yaA fulaAnu hecaA liI kamo huwa Compute thou, O such a one, this, for me, how many it is. (T.) And Oamata Alqawoma He computer, or conjectured, the number of the people, or company of men. (T.) And Oamata AlmaMCa He measured, or computed, the distance between him and the water. (T.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) i. q. qaSadahu [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, to it, or towards it; aimed at it; sought after it; or intended, or purposed, it]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.)
2. Om-thu: see 1.
Oum-ita biAlX-ar-i He was suspected of evil. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: OamotN A measure of distance [&c.]; as in the saying, kamo Oamotu bayonaka maA bayona Alkuwfapi What is the measure of the distance between thee and El-Koofeh? (T, TA.)

Doubt: (Th, T, M:) said to be so termed because this word signifies the “computing, or conjecturing, measure, quantity, and the like,” in which there is doubt. (T, TA.) [See 1.] So in the following ex.: Alxamoru Harumato laA Oamota fiyhaA Wine is unlawful: there is no doubt respecting the unlawfulness of it: (Sh, Th, T, Ḳ:) or the meaning is, there is no indulgence, or lenity, with respect to it; from OamotN as signifying “feebleness, or weakness,” in a journey, or pace. (T, TA.)
And in the saying, layosa fI Alxamori OamotN There is no doubt respecting wine, that it is unlawful. (Th, M.) [Or in the like of these two instances it signifies] Disagreement, or diversity of opinion, (AixotilaAfN,) respecting a thing (fiI XaIoCK). (M, Ḳ.)

Curvity, crookedness, distortion, or unevenness: (M, Ḳ:) ruggedness in one place and smoothness in another; (Ḳ;) [inequality of surface;] one part being higher, or more prominent, than another: (TA:) an elevated place: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) small mounds: (Fr, Th, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or what is elevated, of ground: or, as some say, water-courses of valleys, such as are low, or depressed: (Fr, T, TA:) small hills; hillocks: (M, TA:) a hollow, or depressed place, between any two elevated portions of ground, &c.: (IAạr, T, M:) depression and elevation, or lowness and highness, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) in the ground; (A;) used in this sense in the Ḳur xx. 106; (Ṣ;) and the same in a water-skin not completely filled: (Ṣ, A:*) or laxity in a water-skin when it is not well filled so as to overflow: (T,* TA:) or a [consequence of] pouring [water] into a skin until it doubles, or creases, and not filling it; so that one part of it is higher, or more prominent, than another: (M, TA:) pl. UimaAtN (M, Ḳ, TA, but in some copies of the Ḳ MmaAtN, and in the CK AamAtN,) and OumuwtN. (M, Ḳ.) You say, Asotawati AlOaroDu famaA bahaA OamotN The earth, or ground, was even, so that there was not in it any depression and elevation. (A, TA.) And AimotalaOa Als-iqaMCu famaA bihi OamotN The skin became full, so that there was not in it any depression [of one part of its surface] and elevation [of another part]. (Ṣ, A.*) Az says, (TA,) I have heard the Arabs say, qado malaOa Alqirobapa maloOF laA Oamota fiyhi He had filled the water-skin so full that there was no laxity in it. (T, TA.)

A fault, a defect, an imperfection, a blemish, or the like, (T, M, Ḳ,) in the mouth, and in a garment, or piece of cloth, and in a stone. (M, Ḳ.) [Hence the saying,] OamotN fiI AlHajari laA fiyka i. e. [May there be a defect, or the like,] in stones; not in thee: meaning, may God preserve thee when the stones shall have perished: (Sb, M:) Amt is here put in the nom. case, though the phrase is significant of a prayer, because it is not a verbal word: the phrase is like Alt-urAbu laho: and the commencing the sentence with an indeterminate noun is approvable because it is virtually a prayer. (M.) This prov. is mentioned by the expositors of the Tes-heel: not by Meyd. (TA.)
Weakness; feebleness; (T, Ḳ;) langour; remissness. (TA.) You say, sironaA sayorFA laA Oamota fiyhi We performed a journey, or went a pace, in which was no weakness, or feebleness [&c.]. (T, TA.)
A good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (T, Ḳ.)
muWam-atN Suspected of evil and the like. (Ḳ.) [See 2.]
[A water-skin] filled [so as to be equally distended: see OamotN]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: maMCN maOomuwtN A water of which the distance is computed, or conjectured. (TA.)
huwa UilaI OajalK maOomuwtK It is until a determined, defined, or definite, period. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
XaIoCN maOomuwtN A thing that is known. (M, TA.) [And so mawomuwtN.]
1. Oamida Ealayohi, aor. _a {yaOomadu}, inf. n. OamadN, He was angry with him: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) like Oabida (Ṣ) and wamad and wabida and Eabida. (T in art. Abd.)
2. Om-d, inf. n. taOomiydN, He declared the time, considered with regard to its end; or the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach; expl. by bay-ana AlOamada. (Ḳ.)

OamadN Time, considered with regard to its end: zamaAnN being time considered with regard to its end and its beginning: (Er-Rághib:) [but sometimes it is interchangeable with zamaAnN, as will be seen in what follows:] or the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, balaga Oamadahu He, or it, reached, or attained, his, or its, utmost, or extreme, extent, term,, &c. (Mṣb.) And Daraba lahu OamadFA [He assigned, or appointed, for him, or it, a term, or limit]. (A.) And huwa baEiydu AlMmaAdi [He is one whose limits are remote: MmaAdN being the pl.]. (A.)
The period of life which one has reached; as in the saying, maA Oamaduka What is thy period of life which thou hast reached? (Ṣ.)

Each of the two terms of the life of a man; i. e. the time of his birth, and the time of his death. (Sh, T.) El-Ḥasan [El-Basree], being asked by El-Hajjáj, maA Oamaduka, meaning What was the time of thy birth? answered by saying that it was two years before the expiration of ʼOmar's reign as Khaleefeh. (T, L, from a trad.)
The startingplace, and the goal, of horses in a race. (Sh, T, L.)
‡ Any space of time: (Er-Rághib:) a space of time of unknown limit. (Kull pp. 9 and 10.)
Sometimes, † A particular time; as in the phrase Oamadu kacaA The time of such a thing; like zamaAnu OamadN. (Kull p. 10.)

[It is also used for cw OamadN, and (applied to a fem. n.) caAt OamadK, Having a term, or limit; limited in duration; as in the saying,] Ald-unoyaA OamadN wAlMxirpu OabadN [The present state of existence is limited in duration, but the final state of existence is everlasting]. (ʼObeyd Ibn-ʼOmeyr, L in art. Abd.)
OumodapN A remainder, or what remains, (Ḳ,) of anything. (TA)
siqaMCN muWam-adN A skin [exhausted;] in which there remains not a gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once, of water. (Ḳ.)
OamadN maOomuwdN An extreme term, limit, or point, reached, or attained. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Oamarahu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yaOomuru}, (M, &c.,) inf. n. OamorN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UimaArN, (M, L, Ḳ,) which latter, however, is disapproved by MF, (TA,) and UiymaArN is syn. therewith, (Ḳ,) but this also is disapproved by MF, and deemed by him strange, [being by rule the inf. n. of Mmarahu↓, respecting which see what follows,] (TA,) and MmirapN, (M, Ḳ,) which is one of the inf. ns. [or quasi-inf. ns.] of the measure faAEilapN, like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN, (M,) He commanded him; ordered him; bade him; enjoined him; the inf. n. signifying the contr. of nahoIN; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also Mmrhu↓, (Kr, M, Ḳ,) mentioned by AʼObeyd also as a dial. var. of Oamarahu: (Mṣb:) but AʼObeyd says that Mmarotuhu and Oamrotuhu are syn. [in a sense different from that explained above, i. e.] as meaning kav-arotuhu. (TA.) You say, Oamarahu bihi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and Oamarahu Uiy-aAhu, suppressing the prep., (M,) He commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do it. (M, Ḳ.) And Omarotuka Oano tafoEala, and litafoEala, and biOno tafoEala, I commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, thee to do [such a thing]. (M.) [And Oamarahu bikacaA as meaning He commanded him, or ordered him, to make use of such a thing; or the like: whence, in a trad.,] Oumirotu biAls-iwaAki [I have been commanded to make use of the tooth-stick]. (El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer.) [And He enjoined him such a thing; as, for instance, patience.] The imperative of Oamara is muro; originally AWomuro; which also occurs [with wa in the place of W when the A is pronounced with damm]: (M:) but [generally] when it is not preceded by a conjunction, (Mṣb,) i. e., by wa or fa, (T,) you suppress the C, [i. e. the radical C, and with it the conjunctive A preceding it,] contr. to rule, and say, murohu bikacaA [Command, or order, or bid, or enjoin, thou him to do such a thing]; like as you say, kulo and xuco: when, however, it is preceded by a conjunction, the practice commonly obtaining is, to restore the waOomuro bikacaA, agreeably with analogy, and thus to say, Oamuro bikacaA. (Mṣb.)
[You say also, Oamara bihi faqutila He gave an order respecting him, and accordingly he was slain. And Oamara lahu bikacaA He ordered that such a thing should be done, or given, to him.]

In the Ḳur [xvii. 17], OamaronaA mutorafiyhaA fafasaquwA fiyhaA, so accord. to most of the readers, (T, &c.,) means We commanded [its luxurious inhabitants] to obey, but they transgressed therein, or departed from the right way, or disobeyed: (Fr, T, Ṣ, &c.:) so says Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ; adding that, although one says, Oamartu zayodFA faDaraba EamorFA, meaning I commanded Zeyd to beat ʼAmr, and he beat him, yet one also says, Oamarotuka faEaSayotaniI [I commanded thee, but thou disobeyedst me]: or, accord. to some, the meaning is, We multiplied its luxurious inhabitants; (T;) and this is agreeable with another reading, namely, MmaronaA↓; (TA;) and a reading of El-Ḥasan, namely, OamironaA, like EalimonaA, may be a dial. var., of the same signification: (M:) see 4, in two places: or it may be from AlUimaArapu; (Ṣ, TA;) [in which case it seems that we should read Oam-aronaA↓; or, perhaps, OamaronaA: see 2:] Abu-l-ʼÁliyeh reads Oam-aronaA↓, and this is agreeable with the explanation of I’Ab, who says that the meaning is, We made its chiefs to have authority, power, or dominion. (TA.)

Oamarahu, aor. _u {yaOomuru}, also signifies He commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, him to do that which it behooved him to do. (A.) [He counselled, or advised, him.] One says, muroniI, meaning Counsel thou me; advise thou me. (A.)
Oamara biAqotinaASK, said of a wild animal, means He rendered the beholder desirous of capturing him. (M.)

Oamara, (Aṣ, Fr, Th, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaOomuru}; (Mṣb, TA;) and Oamura, aor. _u {yaOomuru}; (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ;) and Oamira, aor. _a {yaOomaru}; (M, Ḳ, and several other authorities; but by some this is disallowed; TA;) inf. n. OamorN (Ḳ) and UimorapN (Ṣ) and UimaArapN; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ;) or the second is a simple subst.; (Ḳ;) or perhaps it is meant in the Ṣ that this and the third are quasi-inf. ns.; (MF;) He had, or held, command; he presided as a commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he became an Oamiyr; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ;) EalaI Alqawomi over the people. (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also 5.] Oamara fulaAnN waOumira Ealayohi, or wOum-ira↓ Elyh, (as in different copies of the Ṣ,) [Such a one has held command and been commanded,] is said of one who has been a commander, or governor, after having been a subject of a commander, or governor; meaning such a one is a person of experience; or one who has been tried, or proved and strengthened, by experience. (Ṣ.)
Oamarahu as syn. with Mmarahu: see 4.

Oamira, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOomaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OamarN and Oamorap; (M, Ḳ, TA; the latter written in the CK Aamorap;) and Omura, aor. _a {yaOomaru}; (IḲṭṭ;) † It (a thing, M, Mṣb, or a man's property, or camels or the like, Abu-l-Ḥasan and Ṣ, and a people, T, Ṣ) multiplied; or became many, or much, or abundant; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and became complete. (M, Ḳ.)

And the former, † His beasts multiplied; or became many; (M, Ḳ;) [as also Mmr↓; for you say,] Mmr↓ banuw fulaAnK, inf. n. UiymaArN, † The property, or camels or the like, of the sons of such a one multiplied; or became many, or abundant. (M.)

Oamira AlOamoru, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaOomaru}, inf. n. OamarN, (Akh, Ṣ,) † The affair, or case, (i. e., a man's affair, or case, Akh, Ṣ,) became severe, distressful, grievous, or afflictive. (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. Om-rhu, inf. n. taOomiyrN, He made him, or appointed him, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb.) [And it seems to be indicated in the Ṣ that Oamarahu↓, without teshdeed, signifies the same.] See 1, in three places. You say also, Oum-iraEalayonaA (A, TA) He was made, or appointed, commander,, &c., over us. (TA.)
Also He appointed him judge, or umpire. (Mgh.)
Om-r AlqanaApa † He affixed a spear-head to the cane or spear. (T, M.) [See also the pass. part. n., below.]
Om-rOamaArapK He made [a thing] a sign, or mark, to show the way. (T.)

3. Mmrhu fiI Oamorihi, (T,* Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. muWaAmarapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He consulted him respecting his affair, or case; (T,* Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;) as also waAmarahu; (TA;) or this is not a chaste form; (IAth, TA;) or it is vulgar; (Ṣ, TA;) and AstOmrhu↓, (M,) inf. n. AsotiYomaArN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AYtmrhu↓, (T,) inf. n. AYtimaArN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., MmiruwA Aln-isaMCa fiI Oanofusihin-a Consult ye women respecting themselves, as to marrying them. (TA.) And in another trad., Mmarato nafosahaA, meaning She consulted herself, or her mind; as also AstOmrt↓ nfshA. (TA.) [See another ex. voce nafosN. And see also 8.]

hom.sense: 4. Mmr, inf. n. UiymaArN: see 1, last sentence but one, in two places.

MmorN; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Oamarahu↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to some, (M,) aor. _u {yaOomuru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OamorN; (Mṣb;) both signifying the same accord. to AO, (Ṣ,) or AʼObeyd, (TA,) but the latter is of weak authority, (Ḳ,) or is not allowable; (M;) and, accord. to El-Hasan's reading of xvii. 17 of the Ḳur, (see 1,) Oamirahu↓ also; (M;) † He (a man) multiplied it; or made it many, or much, or abundant: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) He (God) multiplied, or made many or much or abundant, his progeny, and his beasts: (M, Ḳ:) and Mmr maAlahu † He (God) multiplied,, &c., his property, or camels or the like. (Ṣ.)
See also 1, first sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: 5. tOm-r He became made, or appointed, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (Mṣb;) he received authority, power, or dominion; Ealayohimo over them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also Oamara.]
See also 8.
6: see 8, in three places.

8. AYtmr [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytamara] He obeyed, or conformed to, a command; (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Ḳ;*) he heard and obeyed. (Mṣb.) You say, AYtmr bixayorK, meaning He was as though his mind commanded him to do good and he obeyed the command. (M.) And [you use it transitively, saying,] AYtmr AlOamora He obeyed, or conformed to, the command. (Ṣ.) And laA yaOotamiru ruXodFA He will not do right of his own accord. (A.) Imra el-Keys says, (Ṣ,) or En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, (T,)
wayaEoduw EalaI AlmaroCi maA yaOotamiro
[And that which man obeys wrongs him, or injures him]; meaning, that which his own soul commands him to do, and which he judges to be right, but in which often is found his destruction: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Ḳṭ, that evil which man purposes to do: (T:) or that which man does without consideration, and without looking to its result. (AʼObeyd, T.) [See what follows.]

He undertook a thing without consulting; (Ḳṭ, T;) as though his soul, or mind, ordered him to do it and he obeyed it: (TA:) he followed his own opinion only. (Mgh.) One says, Oamarotuhu fOotamara waOabaI Oano yaOotamira, (A, Mgh,) meaning I commanded him, but he followed his own opinion only, and refused to obey. (Mgh.)
He formed an opinion, and consulted his own mind, and determined upon it. (Sh, T.) And AYtmr raOoyahu He consulted his own mind, or judgment, respecting what was right for him to do. (Sh, T.)

AYtmrwA, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. AYotimaArN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tMmrwA↓, (A,) inf. n. taMmurN, of the measure tafaAEulN; (Ṣ;) and tOm-rwA↓, (TA,) inf. n. taOam-urN; (Ḳ;) They consulted together: (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or AYtmrwA and tMmrwA↓ signify they commanded, ordered, bade, or enjoined, one another; like as one says, AqttlwA and tqAtlwA, and AxtSmwA and txASmwA: (T:) or AYtmrwA EalaI AlOamori and tMmrwA↓ Ealayohi, they determined, or settled, their opinions respecting the affair, or case: (M:) and AYtmrwA bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) signifies they purposed it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) namely, a thing, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and consulted one another respecting it. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [lxv. 6], waOotamiruwA bayonakumo bimaEoruwfK And command ye, or enjoin ye, one another to do good: [such is app. the meaning,] but God best knoweth: (T:) or, accord. to Ḳṭ, purpose ye among yourselves to do good. (TA.) And in the same [xxviii. 19], Uin-a AlomalaOa yaOotamiruwna bika liyaqotulwuka, meaning Verily the chiefs command one another respecting thee, to slay thee: (Zj, T:) or consult together against thee, to slay thee: (AO, T:) or purpose against thee, to slay thee: (Ḳṭ, T:) but the last but one of these explanations is better than the last. (T.)
See also 3.
Accord. to El-Bushtee, AYtmrhu also signifies He gave him permission: but this has not been heard from an Arab. (Az, TA.)
10: see 3, in two places.

OamorN A command; an order; a bidding; an injunction; a decree; an ordinance; a prescript: (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA, &c.:) pl. OawaAmiru: (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.:) so accord. to common usage; and some writers of authority justify and explain it by saying that OamorN is [originally] maOomuwurN bihi; that it is then changed to the measure faAEilN; [i. e., to MmirN;] like OamorN EaArifN, which is originally maEoruwfN; and EiyXapN rADiyapN, originally maroDiy-apN;, &c.; [and then, to OamorN;] and that faAEilN becomes in the pl. fawaAEilu; so that OawaAmaru is the pl. of maUomuwrN: others say that it has this form of pl. to distinguish it from OamorN in the sense of HaAlN [&c.], in which sense it has for its pl. OumuwrN. (Mṣb, TA.) [But I think that OawaAmiru may be properly and originally pl. of MmirapN, for MyapN MmirapN, or the like. MF says that, accord. to the T and M, the pl. of OamorN in the sense explained in the beginning of this paragraph is OumuwrN: but he seems to have founded his assertion upon corrupted copies of those works; for in the M, I find nothing on this point; and in the T, not, as he says, AlOamoruDid-u Aln-ahoIa waAHidu AlOumuwr, but qaAla All-ayovu AlOamoru maEoruwfN naqiyDu Aln-ahoIi waAHidu AlOumuwri, evidently meaning that OamorN signifies the contr. of nahoIN, and is also, in another sense, the sing. of OumuwrN.] [Hence,] Ouwluw AlOamori Those who hold command or rule, and the learned men. (M, Ḳ. [See Ḳur iv. 62.]) And OamoruQll-ehi The threatened punishment of God: so in the Ḳur x. 25, and xi. 42, and xvi.1; in which last place occur the words, OataI Oamoru Qll-ehi falaA tasotaEojiluwhu, meaning The threatened punishment ordained of God hath, as it were, come: so near is it, that it is as though it had already come: therefore desire not ye to hasten it. (Zj, M, TA.) And The purpose of God. (Bḍ and Jel in lxv. 3;, &c.) And AlOamoru qariybN The resurrection, or the time thereof, is near. (Mgh, from a trad.) And maA faEalotuhu Eano OamoriI, in the Ḳur xviii. 81, I did it not of my own judgment: (Bḍ:) or, of my own choice. (Jel.) [Hence also AlOamoru, in grammar, signifies The imperative form of a verb.]

Also A thing; an affair; a business; a matter; a concern: a state, of a person or thing, or of persons or things or affairs or circumstances; a condition; a case: an accident; an event: an action:
syn. XaOonN: (M, F, TA:) and HaAlN, (Mṣb, TA,) and HaAlapN: (Mṣb:) and HaAdivapN: (Ḳ:) and fiEolN: (MF, TA:) and a thing that is said; a saying: (TA voce Ouwluw, at the end of art. Al:) pl. OumuwrN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.;) its only pl. in the senses here explained. (TA.) You say, Oamoru fulaAnK musotaqiymN [The affair, or the like, of such a one is in a right state]: and Amuwruhu musotaqiymapN [His affairs are in a right state]. (Ṣ, A.) And Xat-ata Oamorahu He dissipated, disorganized, disordered, unsettled, or broke up, his state of things, or affairs. (Aṣ, TA in art. XEb.) [Amr seems to be here used, as in many other instances, rather in the sense of the pl. than in that of the sing.]
OamorN kul-iI-N [A universal, or general, prescript, rule, or canon]. (Mṣb voce qaAEidapN, KT voce qaAnuwnN, &c.)

UimorN a subst. from OamiraAliOamoru in the sense of AiXotad-a; (Ṣ;) or a subst. from Oamira as signifying kavura and tam-a; (M;) † [A severe, a distressful, a grievous, or an afflictive, thing: or] a terrible, and foul, or very foul, thing: or a wonderful thing. (TA,) Hence, [used as an epithet, like OamirN, q. v.,] in the Ḳur [xviii. 70], laqado jiYota XayoYFA UimorFA † Verily thou hast done a severe, a distressful, a grievous, or an afflictive, thing: (Ṣ:) or a terrible, and foul, or very foul, thing: (TA:) or a wonderful thing: (Ṣ:) or an abominable, a foul, or an evil, and a wonderful, thing: (Ks, M, Ḳ:*) or a terrible and an abominable thing; signifying more than nakorFA, [which occurs after, in verse 73,] inasmuch as the [presumed] drowning of the persons in the ship was more abominable than the slaying of one person: (Zj, T:) or a crafty, and an abominable, or a foul, or an evil, and a wonderful, thing; and derived from Oamira Alqawomu as meaning kavuruwA. (Ks.)

hom.sense: OamarN a coll. gen. n. of which OamarapN (q. v.) is the n. un.
See also taOomuwrN.
OamirN: see Uim-arN.
† Multiplied; or become many, or much, or abundant. (M, Ḳ.) [See Oamira.] You say zaroEN OamirN † Abundant seed-produce. (Lḥ, M.)

† A man whose beasts have multiplied, or become many or abundant. (M.) † A man blessed, or prospered, (Ibn-Buzurj, M, Ḳ,*) in his property: (M:) fem. with p {OamirapN}. (Ibn-Buzurj.) And with p {OamirapN}, † A woman blessed to her husband [by her being prolific]: from the signification of kavorapN. (M.)
† Severe; distressful; afflictive. (TA.) [See also UimorN.]

OamorapN A single command, order, bidding, or injunction: as in the saying, laka EalaI-a OamorapN muTaAEapN Thou hast authority to give me one command, order, bidding, or injunction, which shall be obeyed by me. (Ṣ, M,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You should not say, [in this sense,] UimorapN, with kesr. (T, Ṣ.)
See also UimorapN.

entry.sense: UimorapN a subst. from Oamara [q. v.]; Possession of command; the office, and authority, of a commander, governor, lord, prince, or king; (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also UimaArapN↓ (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OamaArapN↓; (L, Ḳ;) but this last is by some disallowed, and is said in the Fṣ and its Expositions to be unknown. (MF.) It is said in a trad., laEal-aka sMCa toka Uimorapu Aboni Eam-ika Perhaps thy paternal uncle's son's possession of command hath displeased thee. (TA.)

[And hence, † Increase, or abundance, or the like; as also other forms mentioned in what follows.] You say, fiI wajohi maAlika taEorifu Uimoratahu † In the face of thy property, [meaning such as consists in camels or the like, and also money,] thou knowest its increase and abundance, and its expense: (Ṣ:) or Uim-aratahu↓, and Uim-ratahu↓, which latter is a dial. var. of weak authority, and Oam-aratahu↓, i. e., its increase and abundance: (M:) or Uim-aratahu↓ as meaning its prosperous state; as also OamaAratahu↓, and Oamoratahu↓: (Ibn-Buzurj:) accord. to AHeyth, who reads tuEorafu Uim-aratuhu↓, the meaning is, its decrease; but the correct meaning is, its increase, as Fr explains it. (T, TA.) It is said respecting anything of which one knows what is good in it at first sight: (Lḥ, M:) and means, on a thing's presenting itself, thou knowest its goodness. (T.) One says also, mOaHosana OamaAratahumo↓ † How good is their multiplying, and the multiplying of their offspring and of their number! (M.) And laA jaEala Qll-ehu fiyhi Uim-arapF↓ † May God not make an increase to be therein. (T.)

hom.sense: OamarapN Stones: (Ḳ:) [or a heap of stones:] or it is the n. un. of OamarN, which signifies stones: (M:) or the latter signifies stones set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way: (Ḥam p. 409:) and the former also signifies a hill; (M, Ḳ;) and OamarN is [used as] its pl.: (M:) and a sign, or mark, by which anything is known; (M, Ḳ;) as also OamaArN↓ and OamaArapN↓; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) and OamarN is [used as] its pl. in this sense also: (M:) or a sign, or mark, set up to show the way; (AA, Fr;) as also OamaArN↓ and OamaArahN↓: (Ḳ:) or a small sign, or mark, of stones, to show the way, in a waterless desert; (Ṣ;) as also OamaArN↓ [and OamaArapN↓]; and any sign, or mark, that is prepared: (TA:) or a structure like a manaArap [here app. meaning a tower of a mosque], upon a mountain, wide like a house or tent, and larger, of the height of forty times the stature of a man, made in the time of 'Ád and Irem; in some instances its foundation being like a house, though it consists only of stones piled up, one upon another, cemented together with mud, appearing as though it were of natural formation: (ISh, T:) the pl. (in all the senses above, Ḳ) [or rather the coll. gen. n.,] is OamarN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also UimorapN.

entry.sense:
OamaArN and OamaArapN↓ A sign, mark, or token. (Aṣ, Ṣ Mgh.) See also each voce OamarapN, in three places. You say, hiI OamaArapu maA bayoniI wabayonaka It is a sign, or token, of what is between me and thee. (T,* TA.) And a poet says,
UicaA TalaEato Xamosu Aln-ahaAri faUin-ahaA
OamaArapu tasoliymiI Ealayoki fasal-imiI
[When the sun of day rises, it is a sign of my saluting thee, therefore do thou salute]. (TA.)

Also A time: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so IAạr explains the latter word, not particularizing the time as definite or otherwise: (M:) or a definite time: (TA:) or a time, or place, of promise or appointment; an appointed time or place; syn. mawoEidN: (M, Mgh, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, the former word is pl. [or rather col. gen. n.] of the latter. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
Uico rad-ahaA bikayodihi faArotad-ati
UilaI OamaArK waOamaAri mud-atiI
When He (meaning God) brings it, (namely my soul,) by his skilful ordering, and his power, [and it is thus brought, or it thus comes, to a set time, and] to the time of the end of my appointed period: AmArmd-tI being as above; the former word being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case. (IB. [In the Ṣ we find waOamaArN mud-atiI.])

OamuwrN [an intensive epithet from Oamarahu]. You say, Uin-ahu laOamuwrN biAlomaEorwfi wanahuw-N Eani Alomunokari Verily he is one who strongly commands, or enjoins, good conduct, and who strongly forbids evil conduct. (Ṣ in art. nhI, and A.*)
OamiyrN One having, holding, or possessing, command; (Ṣ;) a commander; a governor; a lord; (M,* Mṣb;) a prince, or king: (M, Ḳ:) fem. with p {OamiyrapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. UumaraMCu. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

A leader of the blind. (M, Ḳ.) So in the saying of El-Aạshà:
UicaAkaAna haAdiI AlfataI fiI AlbilaA
diSadora AlqanaApi OaTaAEa AlOamiyraA
[When the young man's guide in the countries, or lands, or the like, is the top of the cane, he obeys the leader of the blind]. (M.)
A woman's husband. (A.)
A neighbour. (Ḳ.)
A person with whom one consults: (A, Ḳ:) any one of whom one begs counsel, or advice, in a case of fear. (TA.) You say, huwa OamiyriI He is the person with whom I consult. (A.)
OamaArapN: see UimorapN, in three places:
and see also OamarapN, in three places; and OamaArN.
UimaArapN: see UimorapN.
AlUimaArapu is also used for SaAHibu AlUmaArapi, i. e. AlOamiyru. (Mgh.)
Oam-arN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

Uim-arN A man who consults every one respecting his case; as also OamirN↓ and Oam-aArapN↓: (M:) or a man resembling [in stupidity] a kid: [see the latter part of this paragraph:] (Th, M:) or, as also Uim-arapN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and Oam-arN↓ and Oam-arapN↓, (Ḳ,) a man having weak judgment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) stupid, (T, M,) or weak, without judgment, (M, L,) or without intellect, or intelligence, (T,) who obeys the command of every one, (T, Ṣ,) who complies with what every one desires to do in all his affairs; (Ḳ;) a stupid man, of weak judgment, who says to another, Command me to execute thine affair. (IAth.) It is said in a trad., mano yuTiEo Uim-arapF laA yaOokulo vamarapF [He who obeys a stupid man,, &c., shall not eat fruit: or the meaning is] he who obeys a stupid woman shall be debarred from good. (IAth.)
Uim-arapN↓ is applied to a woman and to a man: when it is applied to a man, the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification. (ISh.) The following saying, UicaA TalaEati AlX-iEoraI safarFA falaA turosilo fiyhaA Uim-arapF↓ walaA Uim-arFA, in rhyming prose, means [When Sirius rises in the clear twilight,] send not thou among them (meaning the camels) a man without intelligence [in a great degree, nor one who is so in a less degree; or a woman without intelligence, nor a man without intelligence;] to manage them. (Sh.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) and Uim-arapN↓ and Oam-ara↓ and Oum-arN↓, (Ḳ,) A young lamb: (M, Ḳ:) or the first (UimarN) and the second, a young kid: (M, TA:) or the former of these two, a male lamb: (M, TA:) or a young male lamb: (Ṣ:) and the latter of them, a female lamb: (M, TA:) or a young female lamb. (Ṣ, M.) One says, maA lahu Uim-arN walaA Uim-arapN↓, meaning He has not a male lamb nor a female lamb: (M, TA:) or he has not anything. (T, Ṣ, M.)
Oam-arapN: see Uim-arN, in two places.

hom.sense: Uim-arapN: see Uim-arN, in six places:
and see UimorapN, in four places.

entry.sense: Uim-irapN: see UimorapN.

Oam-aArN [Wont to command]. [Hence,] Aln-afosu AlOam-aArapu [The soul that is wont to command]; (A;) the soul that inclines to the nature of the body, that commands to the indulgence of pleasures and sensual appetites, drawing the heart downwards, so that it is the abode of evils, and the source of culpable dispositions. (KT.) [See nafosN.]
Oam-aArapN fem. of Oam-aArN [q. v.].
See also Uim-arN.
MmirN [act. part. n. of Oamarahu.]

MmirN and muWotamirN↓ Two days, (Ṣ,) the last, (Ḳ,) the former being the sixth, and the latter the seventh, (M,) of the days called Oay-aAmu Alajuwzi: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ: [but see EajuwzN:]) as though the former commanded men to be cautious, and the latter consulted them as to whether they should set forth on a journey or stay at home: (Ṣ:) accord. to Az, the latter is applied as an epithet to the day as meaning yuWotamarufiyhi. (TA.)
taOomuriI-N: see taOomuwrN, in two places.
tuWomuriI-N, and without C (tuwmuriI-N): see taOomuwrN, in six places.

hom.sense: taOomuwrN and taOomuwrapN↓ are properly mentioned in this art.; the measure of the former being tafoEuwlN; (Ḳ;) and that of the latter, tafoEuwlapN: (TA:) not as J has imagined; [who writes them without C, and mentions them in art. tmr;] (Ḳ;) their measures accord. to him being faAEuwlN and faAEuwlapN. (TA.) [But in all the senses here explained, they appear to be with and without C.]

The former signifies The soul: (Ṣ in art. tmr, where it is written without C; and M, A, Ḳ:) because it is that which is wont to command. (A.) One says, qado Ealima taOomuwruka clika Thy soul, or self, hath known that. (AZ, and T in art. tmr.)

The intellect: (M:) as in the saying, Earafotuhu bitaOomuwriI I knew it by my intellect. (M in art. tmr, without C; and TA.) You say also, huwa Abonu taOomuwrihaA, meaning He is the knowing with respect to it. (TA in art. bnI.)

The heart, (T in art. tmr without C, and M, A, Ḳ,) itself. (M, TA.) Hence the saying, HarofN fiI taOomuwriI xayorN mino EaXarapK fI wi EaAYika [One word in my heart is better than ten in thy receptacle]. (T in art. tmr, and TA.)
The pericardium. (M in art. tmr, without C.)

The core, or black or inner part, or clot of blood, (Hab-ap, M, Ḳ, or Ealaqap, TA,) and life, and blood, of the heart: (M, Ḳ:) or blood, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, in art. tmr, and Ḳ,) absolutely: (TA:) and taOomuwru Aln-afosi signifies the life-blood: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or the blood of the body: (Ṣ in art. nfs:) and the life of the soul. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, as being likened to blood, (TA,) ‡ Wine; and so taOomuwrapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) and
‡ A dye: (M, TA:) and
‡ Saffron. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] ‡ Water. (M, Ḳ.) You say, maA fIi Alr-akiy-api taAmuwrN, (T, Ṣ in art. tmr, and M,) or taOomuwrN, (A,) ‡ There is not in the well any water. (T, Ṣ, M, A.)
The wezeer (waziyr) of a king: (M, Ḳ:) because his command is effectual. (TA.)

Any one: as in the saying, maAbihaA taOomuwrN, (T in art. tmr, A, Ḳ,) as also tuWomuwrN↓, (T in art. tmr, and Ḳ,) each with an augmentative t, and without C as well as with it, accord. to Er-Raḍee and others, (TA,) and taOomuriI-u↓, and taOomuwriI-u↓, (M,) and tuWomuriI-u↓, (T in art. tmr, M, TA,) or without C, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, in art. tmr,) and OamarN↓, (M, Ḳ,) There is not in it (i. e. in the house, AldAr, M, A, TA) any one. (M, A, Ḳ, and T and Ṣ in art. tmr.) You say also, bilaAdN xalaMCN layosa fiyhaA tuwmuriI-N↓ Vacant regions wherein is not any one. (Ṣ in art. tmr.) tuWomuriI-N↓ (M, Ḳ) and tuwmuriI-N↓ (Ṣ in art. tmr) and taOomuwriI-N↓ and taOomuriy-N↓ (M, Ḳ) also signify A man, or human being. (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.) You say, speaking of a beautiful woman, maA raOayotu tuwmuriy-aA↓ OaHosana minohaA I have not seen a human being, or creature, more beautiful than she: (Ṣ and M in art. tmr:) and maA raOayotu tuwmuriy-aA↓ OaHosana minohu [I have not seen a man more beautiful than he]. (T and Ṣ in art. tmr.) Accord. to some, they are used only in negative phrases; but accord. to others, they are also used in such as are affirmative. (MF.)
Also Anything: as in the saying Oakala Alc-iYobu AlX-aApa famaA taraka minohaA taAmuwrFA [The wolf ate the sheep, or goat, and left not of it anything]. (T and Ṣ in art. tmr.)
A child, young one, or fœtus syn. waladN. (M, Ḳ.)
The receptacle (wiEaMC) of the child, young one, or fœtus. (M in art. tmr, without C; and Ḳ.)

A wiEaMC [in the ordinary sense; i. e. a bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, Oanota OaEolamu bitaOomuwrika Thou art best acquainted with what thou hast with thee; and with thine own mind. (M.)

Also, (Ḳ,) and taOomuwrapN↓, (M, [in which the former is not given in the following senses,] and Ḳ,) or taAmuwrapN↓, (Ṣ in art. tmr,) A ewer, syn. UiboriyqN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) for wine: (Ṣ:) and, (M, Ḳ,) or, as some say, (TA,) a Huq-ap (M, Ḳ, TA) in which wine is put. (TA.)
Also the first, (M, Ḳ,) or ↓third, (T and Ṣ in art. tmr,) The chamber, or cell, (SawomaEap, T and M in art. tmr, without C, and Ṣ and Ḳ, and nAmuwI, M, Ḳ,) of a monk. (M, Ḳ.)

And hence, (TA,) the first, (Ḳ,) and ↓second, (M, Ḳ,) or ↓third, of these three words, (T and Ṣ, in art. tmr,) ‡ The covert, or retreat, of a lion. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Whence, fulaAnN OasadN fiI taAmuwratihi↓ ‡ Such a one is a lion in his covert: (T and Ṣ in art. tmr:) a saying borrowed from ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib: (T and Ṣ ibid:) or, accord. to some, it means, a lion in the greatness of his courage, and in his heart. (TA.)
Also (i. e. the first only) Play, or sport, of girls or of boys. (Th, M in art. tmr without C, and Ḳ.)
See also yaOomuwrN.
tuWomuwrN A sign, or mark, set up to show the way in a waterless desert; (Ḳ, TA;) consisting of stones piled up, one upon another: (TA:) pl. taMmiyru. (Ḳ.) [See OamarapN.]
See also taOomuwrN.

entry.sense: taOomuwrapN, and without C: see taOomuwrN, in eight places.
Also The pericardium; the integument (gilaAf) of the heart. (Ṣ in art. tmr: there written without C.)
taOomuwriI-N: see taOomuwrN, in two places.
miYomarN Counsel; advice: as in the saying, fulaAnN baEiydN mina AlmiYomari qariybN mina AlmiYobari Such a one is far from counsel, or advice: near to calumny, or slander. (A.)

muWam-arN Made, or appointed, commander, governor, lord, prince, or king: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) made to have authority, power, or dominion: (T, M, Ḳ:) in which latter sense it is explained by Khálid, as applied by Ibn-Mukbil to a spear. (T.)
† A cane, or spear-shaft, having a spearhead affixed to it. (Ḳ.)
† A spear-head (T, TA) sharpened; syn. muHad-adN. (T, M, Ḳ, TA.)
Distinguished, or defined, (muHad-adN,) by signs, or marks: (TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) marked with a hot iron; syn. muwosuwmN. (Ḳ, TA.)
maOomuwrN [pass. part. n. of Oamarahu, q. v.].

It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, &c.,) xayoru AlmaAli muhorapN maOomuwrapN wasik-apN maOobuwrapN ‡ The best of property are a prolific filly [and a row of palm-trees, or perhaps a tall palmtree, fecundated]; (AZ, AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as though the filly were commanded [by God] to be so: (A, in which the epithet mOmwrp thus used is said to be tropical:) [or] mOmwrp is thus for the sake of conformity to mObwrp, and is originally muWomarapN, (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) from MmarahaA Qll-ehu: (TA:) or it is a dial. var. of weak authority; (Ḳ;) though, accord. to AZ, it signifies made to have abundant offspring, from Oamara Qll-ehu Almuhorapa, meaning “God made the filly to have abundant offspring,” a dial. var. of MmarahaA, as AʼObeyd also asserts it to be. (TA.)
maMmiru and maMmiyru: see what next follows.

hom.sense: muWotamirN [Obeying, or conforming to, a command;, &c.: see 8.]
One who acts according to his own opinion; (T;) who follows his own opinion only: or who hastes to speak. (M.)
See also MmirN.

Also, and AlmuWotamiru, [The month which is now commonly called] AlmuHar-amu: (M, Ḳ:) the former appellation (mWtmr) is that by which the tribe of 'Ád called it: (Ibn-El-Kelbee:) pl. maMmiru↓ and maMmiyru [both anomalous]. (M, Ḳ.) [See XahorN.]

entry.sense: yaOomuwrN; (M, Ḳ;) so in all the copies of the Ḳ but in the L and other lexicons, taOomuwrN↓; (TA;) A certain beast of the sea: or, as some say, a small beast: (M:) and a kind of mountain-goat: (M, Ḳ:) or a certain wild beast, (Ḳ, TA,) or a beast resembling the mountain-goat, (M,) having a single branching horn in the middle of his head. (M, TA.) [See yaHomuwrN, the oryx.]

Uamos, meaning Yesterday, or the day before the present day (Mṣb, Ḳ) by one night, (Ḳ,) and tropically applied to ‡ what is before that, (Mṣb,) or a short time before, (Bḍ in x. 25,) [used as a subst. and as an adv.,] is indecl., with any of the three vowels for its termination: (Ḳ:) [written Oamosi and Omosa and Omosu:] or it is an adv. n., indecl., with kesr for its termination, unless made indeterminate, or made determinate [be the article Al]; and sometimes indecl. with fet-ḥ: (Ez-Zejjájee, M, TA:) or, accord. to I Hsh, the termination with fet-ḥ is a rejected form; and that with damm is not mentioned by any of the grammarians: (TA:) but muco Oamosa [Since yesterday] occurs, used by poetic licence: (Sb, Ṣ:) Oamos is a noun of which the last letter is made movent to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters: and the Arabs differ respecting it: (Ṣ:) most of them make it indecl., with kesr for its termination, when it is determinate [without the article Al]: but some of them make it [imperfectly] decl. when it is determinate [in the same manner]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) [accord. to the most approved usage,] you say, [raOayotuhu Oamosi, and biAlOamosi, which is more common, and AlOamosa, I saw him yesterday; and] maA raOayotuhu mucoOamosi [I have not seen him since yesterday]; and if you have not seen him [since the day next] before that, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco Oaw-alu mino Oamosi [I have not seen him since the day before yesterday]; and if you have not seen him [since] two days before that, you say, maA raOayotuhu muco Oaw-alu mino Oaw-ala mino Oamosi [I have not seen him since the day before the day before yesterday]. (ISk, TA.) The phrase raOayotuhu OamosK [I saw him yesterday] has also been heard, but it is extr. (Ḳ.) The people of El-Ḥijáz make Oamos indecl., with kesr for its termination; and the Benoo-Temeem do the same when it is in the accus. or gen. case; but these latter make it [imperfectly] decl. when it is in the nom. case, saying, cahaba Oamosu bimaA fiyhi [Yesterday has gone with what happened during it]; whereas the people of El-Ḥijáz say, cahaba Oamosi bimaA fiyhi, because it is [held by them to be] indecl. on account of its implying that it has the determinative article Al [understood as prefixed to it], the kesreh being added to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; while the Benoo-Temeem hold it to be, in the nom. case, a deviation from AlUamosu, and therefore imperfectly decl., because of its being determinate, [and so resembling a proper name,] and its deviation from the original form, like saHaru in the like case: (IB, TA:) all of the Arabs, however, make it decl. when the article Al is prefixed to it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and when it is made indeterminate, or is prefixed to another noun: (Ṣ:) they say, using it indeterminately, kul-u gadK SaAYirN OamosKA [Every morrow becomes a yesterday]; (Ṣ,* IB;) and making it determinate by the article Al, they say, kaAna AlOamosu Tay-ibFA [The yesterday was good], (IB,) and maDaI AlOamosu AlmubaAraku [The blessed yesterday has past]; (Ṣ;) and prefixing it to another noun, kul-u OamosinaA kaAna Tay-ibFA [All of our yesterday was good], (IB,) and maDaI OamosunaA [Our yesterday has past]: (Ṣ:) [therefore,] in the following verse,
waUin-iI waqafotu Alyawoma waAlOamosi qabolahu
bibaAbika Hat-aI kaAdati AlX-amosu tagorubu
[And verily I stood to-day, and yesterday before it, at thy door until the sun was almost setting], (thus related by IAạr in two different ways, AlOamosi and AlOamosa,) if we read AlOamosi, the Al is redundant, because it is implied in the word Oamosi; but if we read AlOamosa, the Al is not implied in Oamosa, and therefore is prefixed to make it determinate. (IJ, M.) The pl. is MmusN and MmaAsN, (Zj, Ḳ,) both pls. of pauc., (Zj, TA,) and OmuwsN, (Zj, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, incorrectly, AmuwosN,]) which is a pl. of mult. (Zj, TA.) There is no dim. form of Oamos; like as there is none of gadN and AlbaAriHapu and kayofa and Oayona and mataI and OaI-u and maA and Einda and the names of the months and those of the days of the week, except AljumoEapu. (Sb, Ṣ.)

UimosiI-N, contr. to analogy, (M, TA,) and OamosiI-N [which is agreeable with analogy] is allowable, as related by Ṣgh on the authority of Fr, but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) Of, or relating to, or belonging to, yesterday. (M, TA.)

1. Oamalahu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yaOomulu}, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and _i, (so in the M accord. to the TT,) inf. n. OamalN, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) this being the inf. n. accord. to IJ, [as distinguished from OamolN and UimolN,] (M,) He hoped it; or hoped for it; syn. rajaAhu; (Ṣ,* M,* [see OamalN below,] K;) meaning, what was good for him; (Ṣ;) as also Omalhu↓, (T,* M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOmylN: (Ṣ, T:) or he expected it; [or had a distant, or remote, expectation of it; for] it is mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is deemed remote; as in the saying of Zuheyr,
Oarojuw waMmulu Oano tadonuw mawad-atuhaA
[I hope, and have a distant expectation, that her love may approach]: he who has determined upon a journey to a distant town or country says, Oamalotu AlwuSuwla [I have formed an expectation, or a distant expectation, of arriving]; but he does not say, TamiEotu until he has become near thereto; for TamaEN relates only to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is [deemed] near: and Alr-ajaMCu is between AlOamalu and AlT-amaEu; for it is sometimes attended with fear that the thing expected may not come to pass, wherefore it is used in the sense of fear; and when the fear is strong, [lest the thing expected should not come to pass, it denotes distant expectation, and thus] it is used in the sense of AlOamalu; whence the usage in the verse of Zuheyr; but otherwise it is used in the sense of AlT-amaEu: (Mṣb:) or AlrjAC signifies the expectation of benefit, or advantage, from some preceding cause or means: so says El-Harállee: or it is properly syn. with AlOamalu; and in common conventional language, means the clinging of the heart to the coming to pass of a future desired event: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, an opinion requiring the coming to pass of an event in which will be a cause of happiness: (TA:) and Om-lhu↓, inf. n. taOomiylN, signifies he expected it much; and is more commonly used than the form without teshdeed. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
taOomiylN also signifies The inducing [one] to hope or expect. (KL.)

entry.sense: 5. tOm-l AlX-aIoCi [He considered the thing, or studied it, or contemplated it, carefully, or attentively, with investigation;] he looked at the thing endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of it: (Ṣ:) or i. q. tadab-arahu; (Mṣb, TA;) i. e., (Mṣb,) he looked into the thing, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, (Mṣb, TA,) in order to know it, or until he knew it, (Mṣb,) or in order to ascertain its real case: (TA:) or he looked intently, or hardly, at, or towards, the thing: (TA:) or tOm-l signifies he acted, or proceeded, deliberately, not hastily, syn. tavab-ata, (T, M,) or he paused, or waited, syn. talab-iva, (Ḳ,) in an affair, and in consideration; (M, Ḳ, TA;) he paused, and acted with deliberation. (TA.) fiyhi taOam-ulN [meaning It requires careful, or attentive, consideration, or simply it requires consideration,] is a phrase [of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons, &c., used to imply doubt, and also to insinuate politely that the words to which it relates are false, or wrong,] like fiyhi naZarN [q. v.]. (MF in art. SfH.)
OamolN: see OamalN.
UimolN: see OamalN.

OamalN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UimolN↓ (IJ, M, Ḳ) and OamolN↓, (Ḳ,) the first of which is an inf. n., accord. to IJ, (M,) and is the form commonly known, (TA,) Hope; syn. rajaMCN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or expectation; [or distant, or remote, expectation; being] mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is deemed remote: applied also to an affection of the heart from some good to be attained: (Mṣb, TA: [in both of which are further explanations, for which see 1:]) UimolapN↓, also, signifies the same as OamalN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or taUomiylN; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) [or a manner of hoping or expecting; for J adds,] and it is like jilosapN and rikobapN: (Ṣ:)
and muWam-alN↓, likewise, signifies the same as UamalN: (TA:) the pl. of OmalN and UamolN and OamolN is MmalN. (M,* Ḳ, TA.) You say, xaAba saEoyuhu waOamaluhu [His labour, and his hope, or expectation, were disappointed, frustrated, or balked]. (A and TA in art. xyb.) And maA OaTowala Uamolatahu↓ How far-reaching is his hope, or expectation! (T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [or his manner of hoping or expecting!] from AlOamalu. (T.)
Also, the first, An object of hope. (Jel in xviii. 44.)
UimolapN: see OamalN, in two places.
MmilN act. part. n. of 1; [Hoping: or] expecting. (Mṣb.) [See 1.]

hom.sense: muWam-alN One whose beneficence may be hoped for. (Ḥar p. 183.)
AlmuWam-alu The eighth of the horses that are started together in a race; (Ḳ;) these being ten: (TA:) or the ninth thereof: (TA in explanation of Als-ukayotu:) or the seventh thereof. (Ḥam p. 46.)
See also OamalN.

entry.sense: maOomuwlN pass. part. n. of 1; [Hoped: or] expected. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. Oamina, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _a {yaOomanu}, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OamonN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UimonN (Zj, M, Ḳ) and OamanN (M, Ḳ) and OamanapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and UimonapN (T) and OamaAnN (M, Ḳ) [and app. OamaAnapN, for it is said in the Ṣ that this is syn. with OamaAnN,] and MmnN, an instance of an inf. n. of the measure faAEilN, which is strange, (MF,) or this is a subst. like faAlijN, (M,) He was, or became, or felt, secure, safe, or in a state of security or safety; originally, he was, or became, quiet, or tranquil, in heart, or mind; (Mṣb;) he was, or became, secure, or free from fear; OamonN signifying the contr. of xawofN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and so OamanapN (Ṣ) and MminN [&c.]: (M, Ḳ:) he was, or became, or felt, free from expectation of evil, or of an object of dislike or hatred, in the coming time; originally, he was, or became, easy in mind, and free from fear. (El-Munáwee, TA.) [See OamonN, below.] You say also, yaUomanu EalaI nafosihi [He is secure, or safe, or free from fear, for himself]. (M.) And Oamina Albaladu, meaning The inhabitants of the country or district, or town, were in a state of security, or confidence, therein. (Mṣb.) The verb is trans. by itself, and by means of the particle mino; as in Oamana zayodN AlOasada and Oamina mina AlOasadi, meaning Zeyd was, or became, or felt, secure from, safe from, [or free from fear of,] the lion. (Mṣb.) You say also, Oamina kaciba mano Oaxobarahu [He was secure from, or free from fear of, the lying of him who informed him]. (M.) And laA Mnanu Oano yakuwna kaclika [I am not free from fear of its being so; I am not sure but that it may be so]. (Mgh in art. nbc; and other lexicons passim.) And, of a strong-made she camel, Oaminato Oano takuwna DaEayfapF [She was secure from, or free from fear of, being weak]: (M: [in a copy of the Ṣ Ouminato:]) and Oaminati AlEivaAra waAlUaEoyaMCK [She was secure from, or free from fear of, stumbling, and becoming jaded]: (M:) and Oumina EivaAruhaA [Her stumbling was not feared]. (So in a copy of the Ṣ.) And, of a highly-prized camel, Oumina Oano yunoHara [It was not feared that he would be slaughtered; or his being slaughtered was not feared]. (M.) [Oamnahu sometimes means He was, or became, free from fear, though having cause for fear, of him, or it. i. e. he thought himself secure, or safe, from him or it. (See Ḳur vii. 97.)]

Ominahu (inf. n. OamonN TḲ) [and accord. to some copies of the Ḳ Mmanahu↓] and Om-nhu↓ (inf. n. taOomiynN Ḳ) and AYtmnhu↓ ([written with the disjunctive alif Aiytamanahu, and] also written Ait-amanahu, on the authority of Th, which is extr., like Ait-ahala [&c.], M) and AstOmnhu↓ all signify the same (M, Ḳ, TA) [He trusted, or confided, in him; (as also Mmn bihi, q. v.;) he intrusted him with, or confided to him, power, authority, control, or a charge; he gave him charge over a thing or person: these meanings are vaguely indicated in the M and Ḳ and TA.]. You say, yaOomanuhu Aln-aAsu walaA yaxaAfuwna gaAYilatahu [Men, or people, trust, or confide, in him, and do not fear his malevolence, or mischievousness]. (T, M.) And Oaminahu EalaI kacaA (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb *) and AYtmnhu↓ Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [He trusted, or confided, in him with respect to such a thing; he intrusted him with, or confided to him, power, authority, control, or a charge, over it; he gave him charge over it;] he made him, or took him as, Oamiyn over such a thing. (Mgh.) Hence, in a trad., the muWac-in is said to be muWotamanN; i. e. yaOotaminuhu↓ Aln-aAsu Eala AlOawoqaAti Al-atiI yuWac-anu fiyhaA [Men trust, or confide, in him with respect to the times in which he calls to prayer], and know, by his calling to prayer, what they are commanded to do, as to praying and fasting and breaking fast. (Mgh.) It is said in the Ḳur [xii. 11], maA laka laA taOomanunaA EalaI yuwsufa and [taOoman-aA] with idghám [i. e. What aileth thee that thou dost not trust, or confide, in us with respect to Joseph? or, that thou dost not give us charge over Joseph?]; (Ṣ;) meaning, why dost thou fear us for him? (Bḍ;) some pronouncing the verb in a manner between those of the former and the latter modes of writing it; but Akh says that the latter is better: (Ṣ:) some read tiyman-aA. (Bḍ.) You say also, Auwtumina↓ fulaAnN [Such a one was trusted, or confided, in, &c.;] when it begins a sentence, changing the second C into w; in like manner as you change it into I when the first is with kesr, as in Aiytamanahu; and into A when the first is with fet-ḥ, as in Mmana. (Ṣ.) The phrase Auwtumina↓ OamaAnapF, in a saying of Moḥammad, if it be not correctly EalaI OamaAnapK, may be explained as implying the meaning of AusotuHofiZa OamaAnapF [He was asked to take care of a deposite; or he was intrusted with it]. (Mgh.) [You also say, Oaminahu bikacaA, meaning He intrusted him with such a thing; as, for instance, money or other property: see two exs. in the Ḳur iii. 68.]

Oamuna, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or Oamina, (Mṣb,) inf. n. OamaAnapN, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) He was, or became, trusted in, or confided in: (M, Ḳ:) or he was, or became, trusty, trustworthy, trustful, confidential, or faithful: said of a man. (Mgh.)
2. Om-nhu, inf. n. taOomiynN: see 4:
and see also Oaminahu.
Om-n, inf. n. as above, also signifies He said Mmiyna or Oamiyna, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) after finishing the Fátihah, (T,) or EalaI Ald-uEaMCi on the occasion of the prayer, or supplication. (Mṣb.)

4. Mmana is originally OaOomana; the second C being softened. (Ṣ.) You say, Mmnhu, [inf. n. UiymaAnN;] (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) and Om-nhu↓, [inf. n. taOomiynN;] (M, TA;) meaning He rendered him secure, or safe; (Mṣb;) he rendered him secure, or free from fear; (Ṣ, M, TA;) contr. of OaxaAfhu: (TA:) so in Mmanotuhu minohu I rendered him secure, or safe, from him, or it. (Mṣb.) And of God you say, Mmana EibAdahu mino Oano yaZolimahumo [He hath rendered his servants secure from his wronging them]. (Ṣ.) And yuWominu EibaAdahu mino EacaAbihi [He rendereth his servants secure from his punishment]. (M.) You say also, Mmanotu AlOasiyra, meaning I gave, or granted, AlOamaAn [i. e. security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter,] to the captive. (Mṣb.) And Mmana fulaAnN AlaEaduw-a [Such a one granted security,, &c., to the enemy], inf. n. as above. (T.) It is said in the Ḳur ch. ix. [verse 12], accord. to one reading, laA UiymaAna lahumo They have not the attribute of granting protection; meaning that when they grant protection, they do not fulfil their engagement to protect. (T.)

UiymaAnN also signifies The believing [a thing, or in a thing, and particularly in God]; syn. taSodiyqN; (T, Ṣ, &c.;) by common consent of the lexicologists and other men of science: (T:) its primary meaning is the becoming true to the trust with respect to which God has confided in one, by a firm believing with the heart; not by profession of belief with the tongue only, without the assent of the heart; for he who does not firmly believe with his heart is either a hypocrite or an ignorant person. (T, TA.) Its verb is intrans. and trans. (TA, from a Commentary on the Mutowwal.) You say, Mmana, meaning He believed. (T.) And it is said to be trans. by itself, like Sad-aqa; and by means of bi, considered as meaning AiEotiraAfN [or acknowledgment]; and by means of li, considered as meaning UicoEaAnN [or submission]. (TA.) [Thus] you say, [Mmnhu and] Mmn bihi, (inf. n. UiymaAnN, T, Ḳ,) namely, a thing. (T, M.) And Mmn biQll-ehi He believed in God. (T.) It seems to be meant by what is said in the Ksh [in ii. 2], that Mmn bihi [or Mmanahu] properly signifies Mmanahu Alt-akociyba [He rendered him secure from being charged with lying, or falsehood]; and that the meaning he believed him or in him, is tropical; but this is at variance with what its author says in the A; and Es-Saạd says that this latter meaning is proper. (TA.)
The phrase in the Ḳur [ix. 61], wayuWominu lilomWominiyna, accord. to Th, means And he believeth the believers; giveth credit to them. (M.)

Sometimes it is employed to signify The acknowledging with the tongue only; and hence, in the Ḳur [lxiii. 3], clika bOan-ahumo MmanuwA vum-a kafaruwA That is because they acknowledged with the tongue, then disacknowledged with the heart. (TA.)

Also † The trusting, or confiding, or having trust or confidence. (M, Ḳ.) [You say, Mmn bihi, meaning He trusted, or confided, in him, or it: for] the verb of AymAn in this sense is trans. by means of bi without implication; as Bḍ says. (TA.) [And it is also trans. by itself: for] you say, maA Mmana Oano yajida SaHaAbapF, meaning ‡ He trusted not that he would find companions; (M,* Ḳ,* TA;) said of one who has formed the intention of journeying: or the meaning is maA kaAda [i. e. he hardly, or scarcely, found, &c.; or he was not near to finding, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.) See also Oaminahu.

Also The manifesting humility or submission, and the accepting the Law, (Zj, T,* Ḳ,) and that which the Prophet has said or done, and the firm believing thereof with the heart; (Zj, T, M;) without which firm belief, the manifesting of humility or submission, and the accepting that which the Prophet has said or done, is termed UisolaAmN, for which one's blood is to be spared. (T.) [In this sense, it is trans. by means of li, accord. to some, as shown above; or by means of bi, for, accord. to Fei,] you say, Mmanotu biQll-ehi, inf. n. as above, meaning I submitted, or resigned, myself to God. (Mṣb.) [There are numerous other explanations which it is needless to give, differing according to different persuasions.]
[See also UiymaAn below.]

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in five places.
10. AstOmnhu He asked, or demanded, of him AlOamaAn [i. e. security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter]. (T,* Mṣb, TA.)
See also Oaminahu.
AstOmn Uilayohi He entered within the pale of his OmaAn [or protection, or safeguard]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

OamonN [an inf. n. of Oamini: as a simple subst. it signifies Security, or safety: (see Oamina:) or] security as meaning freedom from fear; contr. of xawofN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also UimonN↓ (Zj, M, Ḳ) and OaminN↓ (M, Ḳ) and Oamanahu↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [and UimonapN↓ (see Oamina)] and OamaAnN↓ and MminN↓, (M, Ḳ,) which last is an inf. n. of Oamina [like the rest], (MF,) or a subst. like faAlijN; (M;) and OamaAnapN↓ is syn. with OamaAnN, (Ṣ,) both of these signifying security, or safety, and freedom from fear: (PṢ:) or OamonN signifies freedom from expectation of evil, or of an object of dislike or hatred, in the coming time; originally, ease of mind, and freedom from fear. (El-Munáwee, TA.) You say, Oanota fiI OamonK [Thou art in a state of security], (T, M,) mino caAka [from that]; and fI OamaAnK↓ signifies the same; (T;) and so fI MminK↓. (M.) And OamanapF↓ nuEaAsFA, in the Ḳur [iii. 148], means Security (OamonFA) [and slumber]. (Ṣ.) OamaAnN↓ also signifies Protection, or safeguard: and [very frequently] a promise, or an assurance, of security or safety; indemnity; or quarter: in Pers. PanaAho and zinohaArN: (KL:) syn. Uil-u. (Ḳ in art. Al.) You say, daxala fiI OamaAnihi↓ [He entered within the pale of his protection, or safeguard]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [And kunN fiI OamaAni↓ Qll-ehi Be thou in the protection, or safeguard, of God.] And OaEoTayotuhu AlOamaAna↓ [I gave, or granted, to him security or safety, or protection or safeguard, or the promise or assurance of security or safety, or indemnity, or quarter]; namely, a captive. (Mṣb.) And Talaba minohu AlOamaAna↓ [He asked, or demanded, of him security or safety, or protection or safeguard,, &c., as in the next preceding ex.]. (Mṣb, TA.)
OamonFA in the Ḳur ii. 119 means caA Oamon [Possessed of security or safety]: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M:) or mawoDiEa OamonK [a place of security or safety; like maOomanFA]. (Bḍ.)
See also MminN.
You say also, maA OaHosana Oamonaka, and Oamanaka↓, meaning How good is thy religion! and thy natural disposition! (M, Ḳ.)
UimonN: see OamonN.
OamanN: see OamonN, first and last sentences.
OaminN: see MminN.

Also, (Ḳ, [there said to be like katifN,]) or MminN↓, (M, [so written in a copy of that work,]) Asking, or demanding, or seeking, protection, in order to be secure, or safe, or free from fear, for himself: (M, Ḳ:) so says IAạr. (M.)
UimonapN: see OamonN.

hom.sense: OmanapN: see OamonN, in two places:
and see also OamaAnapN.

Also A man who trusts, or confides, in every one; (T, Ṣ, M;) and so OumanapN↓: (Ṣ:) and who believes in everything that he hears; who disbelieves in nothing: (Lḥ, T:) or in whom men, or people, trust, or confide, and whose malevolence, or mischievousness, they do not fear: (T, M:) and OumanapN↓ signifies trusted in, or confided in; [like OamiynN;] and by rule should be OumonapN, because it has the meaning of a pass. part. n. [like luEonapN and DuHokapN and luqoTalpN, &c. (see laqaTN)]: (M:) or both signify one in whom every one trusts, or confides, in, or with respect to, everything. (Ḳ.)
See also OamiynN.

entry.sense: OumanapN: see OamanapN, in two places.
OamaAnN: see OamonN, in seven places.

OamuwnN, applied to a she camel, of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, like EaSuwbN and HaluwbN, ‡ Trusted, or confided, in; (T;) firmly, compactly, or strongly, made; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) secure from, or free from fear of, being weak: (Ṣ, M:) also, that is secure from, or free from fear of, stumbling, and becoming jaded: (M:) or strong, so that her becoming languid is not feared: (A, TA:) pl. OumunN. (M, Ḳ.) [See also what next follows.]

hom.sense:
OamiynN Trusted; trusted in; confided in; (T,* Ṣ,* M, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also Oum-aAnN↓; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. q. maOomuwnN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and muWotamanN↓: (ISk, T, Ḳ:) [a person in whom one trusts or confides; a confidant; a person intrusted with, or to whom is confided, power, authority, control, or a charge, EalaI XaIoCK over a thing; a person intrusted with an affair, or with affairs, i. e., with the management, or disposal, thereof; a confidential agent, or superintendent; a commissioner; a commissary; a trustee; a depositary;] a guardian: (TA:) trusty; trustworthy; trustful; confidential; faithful: (Mgh, Mṣb:*) pl. OumanaMCu, and, accord. to some, OamanapN↓, as in a trad. in which it is said, OaSoHaAbiI OamanapN liOum-atiI, meaning My companions are guardians to my people: or, accord. to others, this is pl. of MminN↓ [app. in a sense mentioned below in this paragraph, so that the meaning in this trad. is my companions are persons who accord trust, or confidence, to my people]. (TA.) Hence,
Oalamo taEolamiI yaA Oasoma wayoHaki Oan-aniI
Halafotu yamiynFA laA Oaxuwnu OamiyniI
[Knowest thou not, O Asmà (OasomaMC, curtailed for the sake of the metre), mercy on thee! or woe to thee! that I have sworn an oath that I will not act treacherously to him in whom I trust?] i. e. maOomuwniI↓: (Ṣ:) or the meaning here is, him who trusts, or confides, in me; (ISk, T;) [i. e.] it is here syn. with MminiI↓. (M.) [Hence also,] AlOamiynu fiI AlqimaAri, (Ḳ voce mujumidN, &c.,) or Oamiynu, AlqimaAri, [The person who is intrusted, as deputy, with the disposal of the arrows in the game called Almayosir; or] he who shuffles the arrows; Al-aciI yaDoribu biAlqidaAHi. (EM p. 105.) [Hence also,] Alr-uwHu AlOamiynu [The Trusted, or Trusty, Spirit]; (Ḳur xxvi. 193;) applied to Gabriel, because he is intrusted with the revelation of God. (Bḍ.) Oum-aAnN↓, mentioned above, and occurring in a verse of El-Aạshà, applied to a merchant, is said by some to mean Possessed of religion and excellence. (M.) muWotamanN↓ is applied, in a trad., to the muWac-in, as meaning that men trust, or confide, in him with respect to the times in which he calls to prayer, and know by his call what they are commanded to do as to praying and fasting and breaking fast. (Mgh.) huwa maOomuwnu↓ AlmuEaAmalapi means He is [trusty, or trustworthy, in dealing with others; or] free from exorbitance and deceit or artifice or craft to be feared. (Mṣb.)
An aid, or assistant; syn. EawonN [here app. meaning, as it often does, an armed attendant, or a guard]; because one trusts in his strength, and is without fear of his being weak. (M.)

† The strong; syn. qawiI-N. (Ḳ, TA: [in the latter of which is given the same reason for this signification as is given in the M f or that of Ewn; for which qwI may be a mistranscription; but see OamuwnN.])

One who trusts, or confides, in another; (ISk, T, Ḳ;) [as also MminN↓, of which see an ex. voce HacirN;] so accord. to ISk in the verse cited above in this paragraph: (T:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
See also MminN, in five places.
And see Mmiyna.
OamaAnapN: see OamonN, first sentence.

Trustiness; trustworthiness; trustfulness; faithfulness; fidelity; (M, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also OamanapN↓. (M, Ḳ.) OamaAnapu Qll-ehi [for OamaAnapu Qll-ehi qasamiI or maA Ouqosimu The faithfulness of God is my oath or that by which I swear] is composed of an inf. n. prefixed to the agent, and the former is in the nom. case as an inchoative; the phrase being like laEamoru Qll-ehi, as meaning an oath; and the enunciative being suppressed, and meant to be understood: accord. to some, you say, OamaAnapa Qll-ehi [app. for naXadotuka OamaAnapa Qll-ehi I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by the faithfulness of God, or the like], making it to be governed in the accus. case by the verb which is to be understood: and some correctly say, waOamaAnapi Qll-ehi [By the faithfulness of God], with the w which denotes an oath: (Mgh:) or this last is an oath accord. to Aboo-Ḥaneefeh; but Esh-Sháfiʼee does not reckon it as such: and it is forbidden in a trad. to swear by AlOamaAnap; app. because it is not one of the names of God. (TA.) [Or these phrases may have been used, in the manner of an oath, agreeably with explanations here following.]

A thing committed to the trust and care of a person; a trust; a deposite; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and the like: (Mṣb:) property committed to trust and care: (TA:) pl. OamaAnaAtN. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [viii. 27], wataxuwnuwA OamaAnaAtikumo [Nor be ye unfaithful to the trusts committed to you]. (Mgh.) And in the same [xxxiii. 72], Uin-aA EaraDonaAAlOamaAnapa EalaI Als-mwaAti waAloOaroDiwaAlojibaAli faOabayona Oano yaHomilonahaA waOaXofaqona minohaA waHamalahaA AloUinosaAnu [Verily we proposed, or offered, the trust which we have committed to man to the heavens and the earth and the mountains, and (accord. to explanations of Bḍ and others) they refused to take it upon themselves, or to accept it, and they feared it, but man took it upon himself, or accepted it: or, (accord. to another explanation of Bḍ, also given in the T, and in the Ḳ in art. Hml, &c.,) they refused to be unfaithful to it, and they feared it, but man was unfaithful to it: but in explaining what this trust was, authors greatly differ: accord. to some,] AlAmAnp here means obedience; so called because the rendering thereof is incumbent: or the obedience which includes that which is natural and that which depends upon the will: [for] it is said that when God created these [celestial and terrestrial] bodies, He created in them understanding: or it may here [and in some other instances] mean reason, or intellect: [and the faculty of volition: and app. conscience: these being trusts committed to us by God, to be faithfully employed: (see an ex. voce jacorN:)] and the imposition of a task or duty or of tasks or duties [app. combined with reason or intellect, which is necessary for the performance thereof]: (Bḍ:) or it here means prayers and other duties for the performance of which there is recompense and for the neglect of which there is punishment: (Jel:) or, accord. to I’Ab and Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr, (T,) the obligatory statutes which God has imposed upon his servants: (T, Ḳ:*) or, (T, Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-ʼOmar, [the choice between] obedience and disobedience was offered to Adam, and he was informed of the recompense of obedience and the punishment of disobedience: but, in my opinion, he says, (T,) it here means the intention which one holds in the heart, (T, Ḳ,) with respect to the belief which he professes with the tongue, and with respect to all the obligatory statutes which he externally fulfils; (Ḳ;) because God has confided to him power over it, and not manifested it to any [other] of his creatures, so that he who conceives in his mind, with respect to the acknowledgment of the unity of God, (T, Ḳ,) and with respect to belief [in general], (T,) the like of that which he professes, he fulfils the AmAnp [or trust], (T, Ḳ,) and he who conceives in his mind disbelief while he professes belief with the tongue is unfaithful thereto, and every one who is unfaithful to that which is confided to him is [termed] HaAmilN, (T,) or HaAmilu AlOamaAnapi, and muHotamiluhaA: (Bḍ:) and by AlUinosaAnu is here meant the doubting disbeliever. (T.)
Also, [as being a trust committed to him by God, A man's] family, or household; syn. OaholN. (TA.)
Oum-aAnN: see OamynN, in two places.
Also One who does not write; as though he were (kaOan-ahu [in the CK lAan-ahu because he is]) an Oum-iI. (Ḳ, TA.) [But this belongs to art. Am; being of the measure fuEolaAnN, like EuroyaAnN.]
And A sower, or cultivator of land; [perhaps meaning a clown, or boor;] syn. zar-aAEN: (CK:) or sowers, or cultivators of land; syn. zur-aAEN: (Ḳ, TA:) in one copy of the Ḳ ziraAE. (TA.)

MminN Secure, safe, or free from fear; as also OamiynN↓ (Lḥ, T,* Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaminN↓. (M, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xcv. 3], wahcaA Alobaladi AloOamiyni↓ [And this secure town]; (Akh, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M;) meaning Mekkeh. (M.) baladN MminN and OamiynN↓ means A town, or country, or district, of which the inhabitants are in a state of security, or confidence, therein. (Mṣb.) It is also said in the Ḳur [xliv. 51], Uin-a Alomut-aqiyna fiI maqaAmK OamiynK↓, meaning [Verily the pious shall be in an abode] wherein they shall be secure from the accidents, or casualties, of fortune. (M.) [And hence,] AlOamiynu↓ is one of the epithets applied to God, (Mgh, Ḳ,) on the authority of El-Ḥasan; (Mgh;) an assertion requiring consideration: it may mean He who is secure with respect to the accidents, or casualties, of fortune: but see AlmuWominu, which is [well known as] an epithet applied to God. (TA.) Mminu AlmaAli means What is secure from being slaughtered, of the camels, because of its being highly prized; by AlmAl being meant AlUibil: or, as some say, ‡ what is highly esteemed, of property of any kind; as though, if it had intellect, it would feel secure from being exchanged. (M.) You say, OaEoTayotuhu mino Mmini maAliI, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK Mmani,]) meaning ‡ I gave him of the choice, or best, of my property; of what was highly esteemed thereof; (Ḳ, TA;) and mino Oamoni↓ maAliI which Az explains as meaning of the choice, or best, of my property. (TA: [in which is given a verse cited by ISk showing that Oamon, thus used, is not a mistranscription for Mmin.]) And Mminu AlHilomi means Steadfast in forbearance or clemency; of whose becoming disordered in temper, and free from self-restraint, there is no fear. (M.)
See also OamiynN, in three places:
and see AaminN.
See also OamiynN, in two places.

entry.sense: Mmiyna [in the CK, erroneously, Mmiynu] and Oamiyna↓; (Th, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) both chaste and well known, (TA,) the latter of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Mṣb, TA,) as some say, (TA,) [and this, though the less common, is the original form, for] the medd in the former is only to give fulness of sound to the fet-ḥah of the O, (Th, M, Mṣb, TA,) as is shown by the fact that there is no word in the Arabic language of the measure faAEiylN; (Mṣb, TA;) and some pronounce the former Mm-iyna, (Ḳ,) which is said by some of the learned to be a dial. var., (Mṣb,) but this is a mistake, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) accord. to authorities of good repute, and is one of old date, originating from an assertion of Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, [i. e.
