Th,] that Mmiyna is like EaASiyna, by which he was falsely supposed to mean its having the form of a pl., [and being consequently Mm-iyna,] (Mṣb, [and part of this is said in the M,]) whereas he thereby only meant that the m is without teshdeed, like the S in EaASiyna; (M;) beside that the sense of qaASidiyna [which is that of Mm-iyna, from Oam-a,] would be inconsistent after the last phrase of the first chapter of the Ḳur [where Mmyna is usually added]; (Mṣb;) and sometimes it is pronounced with imáleh, [i. e. “émeena,”] as is said by El-Wáhidee in the Beseet; (Ḳ;) but this is unknown in works on lexicology, and is said to be a mispronunciation of some of the Arabs of the desert of El-Yemen: (MF:) each form is indecl., (Ṣ,) with fet-ḥ for its termination, like Oayona and kayofa, to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together: (T, Ṣ, TA:) it is a word used immediately after a prayer, or supplication: (Ṣ,* M:) [it is best expressed, when occurring in a translation, by the familiar Hebrew equivalent Amen:] El-Fárisee says that it is a compound of a verb and a noun; (M;) meaning answer Thou me; [i. e. answer Thou my prayer;] (M, Mgh;*) or O God, answer Thou: (Zj, T, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or so be it: (AḤát, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or so do Thou, (Ḳ, TA,) O Lord: (TA:) it is strangely asserted by some of the learned, that, after the Fátihah, [or Opening Chapter of the Ḳur-án,] it is a prayer which implies all that is prayed for in detail in the Fátihah: so in the Towsheeh: (MF:) or it is one of the names of God: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so says El-Ḥasan (M, Mṣb) El-Basree: (Mṣb:) but the assertion that it is for yaA Aall-ehu [O God], and that AsotajibN [answer Thou] is meant to be understood, is not correct accord. to the lexicologists; for, were it so, it would be with refa, not nasb. (T.)
UiymaAnN [inf. n. of 4, q. v.]
[Used as a simple subst., Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles, &c.: faith: trust, or confidence:, &c.]

Sometimes it means Prayer; syn. SalaApN: as in the Ḳur [ii. 138], where it is said, wamaA kaAna Qll-ehu liyuDiyEa UiyamAnakumo, (Bḍ, Jel, TA,) i. e. [God will not make to be lost] your prayer towards Jerusalem, (Bḍ,* Jel,) as some explain it. (Bḍ.)
Sometimes, also, it is used as meaning The law brought by the Prophet. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
maOomanN A place of security or safety or freedom from fear; or where one feels secure. (M, TA.)

muWomanN pass. part. n. of Mmanahu. (T.) It is said in the Ḳur [iv. 96], accord. to one reading, (T, M,) that of Aboo-Jaạfar El-Medenee, (T,) lasota muWomanFA [Thou art not granted security, or safety,, &c.; or] we will not grant thee security,, &c. (T, M.)

muWominN [act. part. n. of 4; Rendering secure,, &c.]. AlmuWominu is an epithet applied to God; meaning He who rendereth mankind secure from his wronging them: (T, Ṣ:) or He who rendereth his servants secure from his punishment: (M, IAth:) i. q. Almuhayominu, (M,) which is originally AlmuWaOominu; [for the form mufoEilN is originally muWafoEilN;] the second C being softened, and changed into I, and the first being changed into h: (Ṣ:) or the Believer of his servants (Th, M, TA) the Muslims, on the day of resurrection, when the nations shall be interrogated respecting the messages of their apostles: (TA:) or He who will faithfully perform to his servants what He hath promised them: (T, TA:) or He who hath declared in his word the truth of his unity. (T.)
[Also Believing, or a believer; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles, &c.: faithful: trusting, or confiding:, &c.: see 4.]
maOomuwnN: see OamiynN, in three places.
maOomuwnapN A woman whose like is sought after and eagerly retained because of her valuable qualities. (M.)
maOomuwniy-apN A certain kind of food; so called in relation to El-Ma-moon. (TA.)
muWotamanN: see OamiynN, in two places.

1. Oamiha, aor. _a {yaOomahu}, inf. n. OamahN, He forgot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the reading of I’Ab, [in the Ḳur xii. 45,] waAd-akara baEoda OamahK [And he remembered, or became reminded, after forgetting]. (Ṣ.) AHeyth is said to have read baEoda OamohK; and accord. to AO, OamohN signifies nisoyaAnN [like OamahN]; but this is not correct. (Az, TA.)

He confessed, or acknowledged: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) occurring in this sense in a trad. of Ez-Zuhree; but not well known. (Ṣ.) The reading of I’Ab, mentioned above, baEoda OamahK, is explained by AʼObeyd as meaning after confessing, or acknowledging. (TA.)
5. tOm-h Oum-FA He adopted a mother; (M, Ḳ;) as also taOam-amahaA. (M in art. Am.)

Oum-ahapN i. q. Oum-N [A mother of a human being and of any animal]: (M, Ḳ:) the former is [said by some to be] the original of the latter: (Ṣ:) Aboo-Bekr says that the h in the former is a radical letter: (TA:) or the former applies to a rational creature; and the latter, to [a rational and] an irrational: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Az, the pl. of the former applies to the rational; and that of the latter, to the irrational: (TA:) the former sing. sometimes applies to an irrational creature: (IJ, TA:) [for some further remarks on both of these words and their pls., see the latter of them:] the pl. [of the former] is Oum-ahaAtN and [that of the latter is] Oum-aAtN: (T, Ṣ:) Az says that the Amw is added in the former for the purpose of distinguishing between the daughters of Adam [to whom it is generally applied] and other animate beings. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Mmato, (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, Mmato,]) second pers. Oamawoti; (Ṣ;) and Oamiyato, (M, Ḳ,) like samiEato; (Ḳ;) and Oamuwato, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) like karumatN; (Ḳ;) inf. n. Oumuw-apN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) She (a woman) became a slave; (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ;) as also taOam-ato↓. (Mṣb.)
Oamati Als-in-aworu, aor. taOomuw, inf. n. OumaMCN, The cat [mewed, or] uttered a cry; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like maMCa to, aor. tamuwoCu, inf. n. muwaMCN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2. Oam-aAhaA, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOomiyapN, (Ḳ,) He made her a slave. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 5. taOam-ato: see 1.
tOm-I OamapF He took for himself a female slave; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AisotaOomaAhaA↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. huwa yaOotamiI bihi He follows his (another person's) example; imitates him; i. q. yaOotam-u bihi (TA in the present art.) And AYtmI biAlX-aIoCi [written with the disjunctive alif AiytamaI] is used for AYtam-a bihi [He made the thing to be a rule of life or conduct], by substitution [of I for m], (M and Ḳ in art. Am,) the doubling [of the m] being disapproved. (M in that art.)

OamapN, originally Amwp, (Mṣb,) [but whether OamawapN or OamowapN is disputed, as will be seen in what follows,] A female slave; (M, Ḳ;) a woman whose condition is that of slavery; (T;) contr. of Hur-apN: (Ṣ:) [in relation to God, best rendered a handmaid:] dual OamataAni: (Mṣb:) pl. MmK, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) like qiADK, (Mṣb,) a pl. of pauc. [respecting which see what follows after the other pls.], (Lth, T,) and UimaMCN [the most common form] (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UimowaAnN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OumowaAnN (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the M) and OamowaAnN (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the M) [the last, or last but one, accord. to different copies of the M, on the authority of Lḥ,] and OamawaAtN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for which one may say OamaAtN. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) Accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr (TA) it is originally OamawapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) because it has for a pl. MmK, (Ṣ, M,) which is [originally OaOomuwN,] of the measure OafoEulN, (Lth, T, Ṣ,) like MkumN, pl. of OakamapN, (Sb, M,) and like OayonuqN, [pl. of naAqpN, which is originally nawaqpN,] for a sing. of the measure faEolapN has not a pl. of this form; (Ṣ;) and Mbr says that there is no noun of two letters but a letter has been dropped from it, which it indicates by its pl. or dual, or by a verb if it is derived therefrom: (TA:) or it is originally faEolapN: (AHeyth, T, Ḳ:) AHeyth says that they suppressed its final radical letter, and, forming a pl. from it after the manner of naxolapN and naxolN, instead of saying OamN, which they disliked as being of only two letters, they transposed the suppressed w, changing it into A, and placing it between the A and m. (T: [in which this opinion, though it does not account for the termination of the pl. MmK, is said to be preferable.]) One says, jaMCa toniIF Oamapu Qll-ehi [The handmaid of God came to me]: and in the dual, jaMCa toniI OmataA Qll-ehi: and in the pl., jaMCa niI UimaMCu Qll-ehi and UimowaAnu Qll-ehi and OamawaAtu Qll-ehi; and one may also say, OamaAtu Qll-eh. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [ISd says,] wamaAhu Qll-ehu mino kul-i OamapK bHajarK is mentioned by IAạr as said in imprecating evil on a man; but I think it is mn kl- Oamoti [May God cast a stone at him from every elevated place, or the like]. (M.)
OamawiI-u Of, or relating or belonging to, a female slave. (Ṣ.)
Oumay-apN dim. of OamapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) originally OumayowapN. (Mṣb.)
1. Oan-a, aor. yaYin-u, inf. n. OaniynN and OunaAnN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and taOonaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oan-N, (M, Ḳ,) He moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or said, Ah! syn.

hom.sense: taOaw-aha; (M, Ḳ;) by reason of pain: (Ṣ, TA:) he complained by reason of disease or pain: (TA:) he uttered a cry or cries: (Mṣb:) said of a man. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Oan-iti Alqawosu, aor. taYin-u, inf. n. OaniynN, The bow made a gentle and prolonged sound. (AḤn, M.)

laA OafoEaluhu maA Oan-a fiI Als-amaMCi najomN means I will not do it as long as there is a star in the heaven: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) Oan-a being here a dial. var. of Ean-a. (Ṣ.) You say also, maA Oan-a fiI AlfuraAti qaTorapN As long as there is a drop in the Euphrates. (T, Ṣ.) And laA OafoEaluhu maA Oan-a fiI Als-amaMCN [I will not do it as long as there is rain in the heaven]. (Ṣ.) [It is said in the M that Lḥ mentions the last two sayings; but it is there indicated that he read qaTorapF and samaMCF: and] ISk mentions the saying, laA OafoEaluhu maA Oan-a fiI Als-amaMCi najomFA, (T, M,) and maA Ean-a fiI Als-amaMCi najomN; (T;) [in the former of which, Oan- must be a particle (which see below); but it seems that it should rather be Uin-a, in this case, as ISd thinks; for he says,] I know not for what reason An- is here with fet-ḥ, unless a verb be understood before it, as vabata or wujida: [and he adds,] Lh mentions maA Oan-a clika Aljabala makaAnahu [as long as that mountain is in its place]: and maA Oan-a HiraMCF makaAnahu [as long as Mount Hirà is in its place]: but he does not explain these sayings. (M.)

OanN is a pronoun, denoting the speaker, [I, masc. and fem.,] in the language of some of the Arabs: they say, Oano faEalotu [I did], with the n quiescent: but most of them pronounce it [Oana↓] with fet-ḥ when conjoined with a following word; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) saying, Oana faEalotu: (TA:) and [OanaA↓] with A in a case of pause: (Mughnee, Ḳ:)
and some pronounce it with A also when it is conjoined with a following word; saying, OanaA faEalotu; [as we generally find it written in books;] but this is of a bad dialect: (TA:) [this last assertion, however, requires consideration; for the dial. here said to be bad is that of Temeem, accord. to what here follows:] the Basrees hold that the pronoun consists of the C and the n, and that the [final] A is redundant, because it is suppressed in a case of conjunction with a following word; but the Koofees hold that the pronoun is composed of all the three letters, because the A is preserved in a case of conjunction with a following word in the dial. of Temeem. (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) [Accord. to Az,] it is best to say OanaA↓ in a case of pause; and Oana↓ in a case of conjunction with a following word, as in Oana faEalotu caAka [I did that]; but some of the Arabs say, OanaA↓ faEalotu caAka; and some make the n quiescent in a case of this kind, though this is rare, saying, Oano qulotu caAka [I said that]; and Ḳuḍáʼah prolong the former A, saying, Mna↓ qulotuhu. (T.) [Accord. to J,] OanaA↓ is a pronoun denoting the speaker alone, and is made to end invariably with fet-ḥ to distinguish it from the particle Oano which renders the aor. mansoob; the final A being for the purpose of showing what is the vowel in a case of pause; but when it occurs in the middle [or beginning] of a sentence, it is dropped, except in a bad dialect. (Ṣ.) [Accord. to ISd,] Oana↓ is a noun denoting the speaker; and in a case of pause, you add A at the end, [saying OanaA↓,] to denote quiescence; (M;) [or] it is better to do this, though it is not always done: (TA:) but it is said, on the authority of Ḳṭr, that there are five dial. vars. of this word; namely, Oana↓ faEalotu, and OanaA↓, and Mna↓, and OanN, and OanahN↓, all mentioned by IJ; but there is some weakness in this: IJ says that the h in OanahN↓ may be a substitute for the A in OanaA, because the latter is the more usual, and the former is rare; or it may be added to show what is the vowel, like the h, and be like the h in kitaAbiyaho and HisaAbiyahN. (M.) For the dual, as well as the pl., only naHonu is used. (Az, TA.)

It is also a pronoun denoting the person addressed, or spoken to, by assuming the form Oanota↓ [Thou, masc.]; t being added to it as the sign of the person addressed, (Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) and Oano being the pronoun, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to the general opinion; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) the two becoming as one; not that one is prefixed to the other as governing it in the gen. case: (Ṣ:) and so Oanoti↓, (Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) addressed to the female: (Ṣ, M:) and OanotumaA↓, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) addressed to two; not a regular dual, for were it so it would be OanotaAn; but like kumaA in DarabotukumaA: (M:) and OanotumN↓ and Oanotun-a↓, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) which are [respectively] the masc. and fem. pls. (TA.)

To each of these the k of comparison is sometimes prefixed; so that you say, Oanota kaOanaA↓ [Thou art like me, or as I], and OanaA kaOanota↓ [or Oana kaOanota I am like thee, or as thou]; as is related on the authority of the Arabs; for though the k of comparison is not prefixed to the [affixed] pronoun, and you say, Oanota kazayodK but not Oanota kiI, yet the separate pronoun is regarded by them as being in the same predicament as the noun; and therefore the prefixing it to the latter kind of pronoun is approved. (Ṣ.) It is said in the Book of layosa, by IKh, that there is no such phrase, in the language of the Arabs, as Oanota kiI, nor as OanaA kaka, except in two forged verses; wherefore Sb says that the Arabs, by saying Oanota mivoliI and OanaA mvoluka, have no need of saying Oanota kiI and OanaA kaka: and the two verses are these:
walawolaA AlbalaMCu lakaAnuwA kanaA
falawolaA AlHayaMUu lakun-aA kahumN
[And but for the sense of shame, we had been like them, or as they: and but for trial, or affliction, they had been like us, or as we]: and
Uino takuno kiI fiUin-aniI kaka fiyhaA
Uin-anaA fiI AlmalaAmi muSoTaHibaAni
[If thou art like me, or as I, verily I am like thee, or as thou, in respect of her, or it, or them: verily we, in respect of blame, are companions]. (TA.) Az mentions his having heard some of the Benoo-Suleym say, kamaA OanotaniI, [the latter word being a compound of the pronoun Oanota, regularly written separately, and the affixed pronoun niI,] meaning Wait thou for me in thy place. (TA.)

It is also a particle: and as such, it is - First, a particle of the kind called maSodariI-N, rendering the aor. mansoob: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) i. e., (TA,) it combines with a verb [in this case] in the future [or aor.] tense, following it, to form an equivalent to an inf. n., and renders it mansoob: (Ṣ, TA:) you say, Ouriydu Oano taquwma [I desire that thou stand, or that thou wouldst stand, or that thou mayest stand]; meaning Ouriydu qiyaAmaka [I desire thy standing]. (Ṣ.) It occurs in two places: first, in that of the inchoative, or in the beginning of a phrase, so that it is in the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 180], waOano taSuwmuwA xayorN lakumo [And that ye fast is better for you]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) i. e. SiyaAmukumo [your fasting]. (TA.) And, secondly, after a word denoting a meaning which is not that of certainty: and thus it is the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Ḳur lvii. 15], Oalamo yaOani lil-aciyna MmanuwA OanN taxoXaEa quluwbuhumo [Hath not the time that their hearts should become submissive, i. e. the time of their hearts' becoming submissive, yet come unto those who have believed?]: and in the place of an accus. case; as in the saying [in the Ḳur x. 38], wamaA kaAna hcaA AlquroMnu Oano yufotaraC [And this Ḳur-án is not such that it might be forged; i. e., AfutiriMCN; so in Bḍ and Jel; and so in a marginal note to a copy of the Mughnee, where is added, meaning mufotarFI forged]: and in the place of a gen. case; as in the saying [in the Ḳur lxiii. 10], mino qaboli Oano yaOotiIa OaHadakumu Alomawotu [Before that death come unto any one of you; i. e. before death's coming unto any one of you]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) Sometimes it makes the aor. to be of the mejzoom form, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) as some of the Koofees and AO have mentioned, and as Lḥ has stated on the authority of certain of the Benoo-Sabbáh of Dabbeh; (Mughnee;) as in this verse:
UicaA maA gadawonaA qaAla wilodaAnu OaholinaA
taEaAlwogA UilaI Oano yaOotinaA AlS-ayodu naHoTibi
[When we went away in the morning, the youths of our family, or people, said, Come ye, until that the chase come to us, (i. e. until the coming of the chase to us,) let us collect firewood]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) And sometimes it is followed by an aor. of the marfooa form; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 233], accord. to the reading of Ibn-Moheysin, limano OaraAda Oano yutim-u Alr-aDaAEapa [For him who desireth that he may complete the time of sucking; i. e. the completing thereof]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) but this is anomalous, (I’Aḳ p. 101, and TA,) or Oano is here a contraction of Oan-a [for Oan-ahu]: (I’Aḳ:) and in the saying of the poet,
Oano taqoraMni EalaI OasomaMCi wayoHakumaA
min-iI Als-alaAma waOano laA tuxobiraA OaHadaA
[That ye two convey, or communicate, to Asmà, (mercy on you! or woe to you!) from me, salutation, and that ye inform not any one]; but the Koofees assert that OanN is here [in the beginning of the verse] a contraction of Oan-a, and anomalously conjoined with the verb; whereas the Basrees correctly say that it is OanN which renders the aor. mansoob, but is deprived of government by its being made to accord with its co-ordinate maA, termed maSodariy-ap; (Mughnee;) or, as IJ says, on the authority of Aboo-ʼAlee, OanN is here used by poetic licence for Oan-akumaA; and the opinion of the Baghdádees [and Basrees], that it is likened to maA, and therefore without government, is improbable, because Oano is not conjoined with a verb in the present tense, but only with the preterite and the future. (M.) When it is suppressed, the aor. may be either mansoob or marfooa; but the latter is the better; as in the saying in the Ḳur [xxxix. 64], Oafagayora Qll-ehi taOomuruwn-iI OaEobudu [Other than God do ye bid me worship?]. (Ṣ.) If it occurs immediately before a preterite, it combines with it to form an equivalent to an inf. n. relating to past time; being in this case without government: you say, OaEojayaniyOano qumota [It pleased me that thou stoodest]; meaning thy standing that is past pleased me: (Ṣ:) and thus it is used in the saying [in the Ḳur xxviii. 82], lawolaA OanN man-a Qll-ehu EalayonaA [Were it not for that God conferred favour upon us; i. e., for God's having conferred favour upon us]. (Mughnee.) It is also conjoined with an imperative; as in the phrase mentioned by Sb, katabotu Uilayhi biOanp qumN [I wrote to him, Stand; i. e. I wrote to him the command to stand]; which shows that AḤei is wrong in asserting that whenever it is conjoined with an imperative it is an explicative [in the sense of OayN], and that in this particular instance the b may be redundant, which it cannot here be, because, whether redundant or not, it is not put immediately before anything but a noun or what may be rendered by a noun. (Mughnee.)

Secondly, it is a contraction of Oan-a; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and occurs after a verb denoting certainty, or one used in a manner similar to that of such a verb: (Mughnee:) so in the saying [in the Ḳur lxxiii. 20], Ealima OanN sayakuwnu minokumN maroDaI [He knoweth that (the case will be this:) there will be among you some diseased; the affixed pronoun hu, meaning AX-aOona, being understood after Oano, which therefore stands for Oan-ahu, i. e. Oan-a AlX-aOona]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) and in the phrase balaganiI Oano qado kaAna kacaA wakacaA [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge,, &c., that (the case is this:) such and such things have been]; a phase of this kind, in which Oano occurs with a verb, not being approved without qado, unless you say, balaganiI Oan-ahu kaAna kacaA wakacaA: (Lth, T:) [for] when the contracted Oano has for its predicate a verbal proposition, of which the verb is neither imperfectly inflected, like layosa and EasaI, nor expressive of a prayer or an imprecation, it is separated from the verb, according to the more approved usage, by qado, or the prefix sa, or sawofa, or a negative, as laA, &c., or lawo: (I’Aḳ pp. 100 and 101:) but when its predicate is a nominal proposition, it requires not a separation; so that you say, Ealimotu Oano zayodN qaAYimN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was standing]; (I’Aḳ p. 100;) and balaganiI Oano zaydN xaArijN [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me,, &c., that (the case is this:) Zeyd is going, or coming, out, or forth]; (TA;) except in the case of a negation, as in the saying in the Ḳur [xi. 17], wOano laA Uilha Uil-aA huwa [And that (the case is this:) there is no deity but He]. (I’Aḳ p. 100.) Thus used, it is originally triliteral, and is also what is termed maSodariy-ap; [Ealima Oano, in the first of the exs. above, for instance, meaning Ealima Oan-ahu, i. e. Ealima Oan-a AlX-aOona, which is equivalent to Ealima kawona AlX-aOoni;] and governs the subject in the accus. case, and the predicate in the nom. case: and its subject must be a pronoun, suppressed, [as in the exs. given above, where it means AlX-aOoni, and in a verse cited before, commencing Oano taqoraMni, accord. to A'boo-ʼAlee,] or expressed; the latter, accord. to the more correct opinion, being allowable only by poetic license: and its predicate must be a proposition, unless the subject is expressed, in which case it may be either a single word or a proposition; both of which kinds occur in the following saying [of a poet]:
biOanoka rabiyEN wgayovN mariyEN
waOanoka hunaAka takuwna Alv-imaAlaA
[he is speaking of persons coming as guests to him whom he addresses, when their provisions are exhausted, and the horizon is dust-coloured, and the north wind is blowing, (as is shown by the citation of the verse immediately preceding, in the T,) and he says, They know that thou art like rain that produces spring-herbage, and like plenteous rain, and that thou, there, art the aider and the manager of the affairs of people]. (Mughnee. [In the T, for rabiyEN, I find Al-arbiyEu; and for waOanoka, I there find waqidomFA: but the reading in the Mughnee is that which is the more known.]) [J says,] Oano is sometimes a contraction of Oan-a and does not govern [anything]: you say, balaganiI OanN zayodN xaArijN [explained above]; and it is said in the Ḳur [vii. 41], wanuwduwA Oano tilokumu Aljan-apu [And it shall be proclaimed to them that (the case is this:) that is Paradise]: (Ṣ:) [here, however, Oanp is regarded by some as an explicative, as will be seen below:] but in saying this, J means that it does not govern as to the letter; for virtually it does govern; its subject being meant to be understood; the virtual meaning being Oan-ahu tilokumu Aljan-apu. (IB.) [In another place, J says,] You may make the contracted Oano to govern or not, as you please. (Ṣ.) Aboo-Tálib the Grammarian mentions an assertion that the Arabs make it to govern; as in the saying [of a poet, describing a beautiful bosom],
kaOano vacoyayohi Huq-aAni
[As though its two breasts were two small round boxes]: but [the reading commonly known is
kaOano vadoyaAhu Huq-aAni ; (this latter reading is given in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 104 of the Ar. text; and both are given in the Ṣ;) kaOano here meaning kaOan-ahu; and] Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern except with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent. (T.) The author of the Ḳ says in the B that you say, Ealimotu Oano zyodFA lamunoTaliqN [I knew that Zeyd was indeed going away], with l when it is made to govern; and Ealimotu Oano zayodN munoTaliqN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was going away], without l when it is made to have no government. (TA. [But in the latter ex. it governs the subject, which is understood, as in other exs. before given.]) [See an ex. in a verse ending with the phrase wakaOano qadi cited voce qad, where kaOano is for kaOan-ahu, meaning kaOan-a AlX-Ona, and a verb is understood after qd. And see also Oan-a, below.]

Thirdly, it is an explicative, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) meaning Oayo (Ṣ, M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or [rather] used in the manner of Oayo; (Mughnee, and so in some copies of the Ḳ;) [meaning qaAYilFA, or qaAYiliyna; or yaquwlu, or yaquwluwna; or some other form of the verb qaAla; i. e. Saying;, &c.;] as in the saying [in the Ḳur xxiii. 27], faOawoHayonaA Uilayohi Oani ASonaEi Aloquloka [And we revealed, or spake by revelation, unto him, saying, Make thou the ark]; (Mughnee, Ḳ) and [in the Ḳur vii. 41,]wanuwduwA Oano tilokumu Alojan-apu [And it shall be proclaimed to them, being said, That is Paradise]; or in these two instances it may be regarded as what is termed maSodariy-ap, by supposing the preposition [bi] understood before it, so that in the former instance it is the biliteral, because it is put before the imperative, and in the second it is the contraction of Oan-a because it is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee;) and [in the Ḳur xxxviii. 5,] waAnoTalaqa AlomalaOu minohumo Oani AmoXuwA(Ṣ, M, Mughnee) i. e. [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, or in speech, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action, &c. (Mughnee.) For this usage of Oano certain conditions are requisite: first, that it be preceded by a proposition: secondly, that it be followed by a proposition; so that you may not say, cakarotu EasojadFA Oano cahabFA, but you must say OaIN in this case, or must omit the explicative: thirdly, that the preceding proposition convey the meaning of Alqawolu, as in the exs. above; in the last of which, AnTlq has the meaning assigned to it above; not that of walking or going away: fourthly, that there be not in the preceding proposition the letters of Alqawolu; so that one may not say, qulotu lahu Oani AfoEalo; or, if there be in it those letters, that the word which they compose shall be interpreted by another word; as in the saying, in the Ḳur [v, 117], maA qulotu lahumo Uil-aA maA OamarotaniI bihi Oani AEobuduwA Qll-eha which may mean, as Z says, I have not commanded them [aught save that which Thou commandedst me, saying, Worship ye God]; (Mughnee;) in which instance Fr says that it is an explicative: (T:) fifthly, that there be not a preposition immediately before it; for if you say, katabotu Uilayohi biOani AfoEalo kacaA, it is what is termed maSodariy-ap [as we have before shown]. (Mughnee.) When it may be regarded as an explicative and is followed by an aor. with lA as in OaXarotu Uilayohi Oano laA tafoEal kacaA, it may be marfooa, [namely, the aor.,] on the supposition that lA is a negative; or mejzoom, on the supposition that it is a prohibitive; and in both cases An is an explicative; [so that the meaning is, I made a sign to him, as though saying, Thou wilt not do such a thing, in the former case; or, in the latter, Do not thou such a thing;] or mansoob, on the supposition that lA is a negative and that An is what is termed maSodariy-ap: but if lA is wanting, it may not be mejzoom, but may be marfooa [if we use An as an explicative] or mansoob [if An be what is termed maSodariy-ap]. (Mughnee.)

Fourthly, it is redundant, as a corroborative, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) like whatever else is redundant: and thus it is in four cases: one of these, which is the most common, being when it occurs after lam-aA denoting time; [and this is mentioned in the M;] as in the saying [in the Ḳur xxix. 32], walm-aA Oano jaMCa to rusulunaA luwTFA [And when our apostles came to Lot]: (Mughnee:) [or,] accord. to J, (TA,) it is sometimes a connective to lam-aA; as in the saying in the Ḳur [xii. 96], falam-aA Oano jaMCa AlobaXiyru [And when that (like as we say, “now that,”) the announcer of good tidings came]: and sometimes it is redundant; as in the saying in the Ḳur [viii. 34], wamaA lahumo Oano laA yuEacibahumu Qll-ehu [as though it might be rendered But what reason have they, God should not punish them?]: (Ṣ, TA:) but IB says that the connective is redundant; and [that An is not redundant in the latter instance, for] if it were redundant in this verse of the Ḳur it would not render the [aor.] verb mansoob. (TA. [The author of the Mughnee, like IB, disallows that An is redundant in a case of this kind, which Kh asserts it to be; and says that fiI is understood before it.])
The second case is when it occurs between lawN and a verb signifying swearing, the latter being expressed; as in this verse:
faOuqosimu Oano lawi QlotaqayonaA waOanotumu
lakaAna lanaA yawomN mina AlX-ar-i muZolimu
[And I swear, had we and you met, there had been to us a dark day of evil]: and when that verb is omitted; as in the following ex.:
OamaA waQll-ehi Oano lawo kunota Hur-iA
wamaA biQloHur-i Oanota walaA AlEatiyqi
[Verily, or now surely, by God, if thou wert freeborn; but thou art not the freeborn nor the emancipated]: so say Sb and others: Ibn-'Os- foor holds it to be a particle employed to connect the complement of the oath with the oath; but this is rendered improbable by the fact that it is in most cases omitted, and such particles are not. (Mughnee.) The third case, which is extr., is when it occurs between the k [of comparison] and the noun governed by it in the genitive case; as in the saying,
wayawomFA tuwaAfiynaA biwajohK muqas-amK
kaOanN ZaboyapK taEoTuw UilaI waAriqi Als-alamo
[And on a day thou comest to us with a beautiful face, like a doe-gazelle raising her head towards the goodly green-leaved tree of the selem kind], accord. to the reading of him who makes Tbypo to be governed in the genitive case [instead of the accus. or the nom.; for if we read it in the accus. or the nom., Oano is a contraction of Oan-a; in the former case, Zbyp being its subject, and its predicate being suppressed; and in the latter case, the meaning being kaOan-ahaA ZaboyapN, so that the subject of An is suppressed]. (Mughnee.) The fourth case is when it occurs after UicaA; as in the following ex.:
faOumohluhu Hat-aI UcaA Oano kaOan-ahu
muEaATiI yadK fiI luj-api AlmaMCi gaAmiru
[And I leave him alone until when he is as though he were a giver of a hand to be laid hold upon, in the fathomless deep of the water immerged]. (Mughnee.)

[Fifthly,] among other meanings which have been assigned to it, (Mughnee,) it has a conditional meaning, like UinN: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) so the Koofees hold; and it seems to be most probably correct, for several reasons: first, because both these forms occur, accord. to different readings, in several instances, in one passage of the Ḳur; as in [ii. 282,] Oano taDil-N UiHodaAhumaA [If one of them twain (namely, women,) err];, &c.: secondly, because [the prefix] fa often occurs after it; as in a verse commencing with OabaA xuraAXapa [as cited voce Oam-aA, accord. to some who hold that Om-aA in that verse is a compound of the conditional Oano and the redundant maA; and as in the Ḳur ii. 282, where the words quoted above are immediately followed by fatucak-ira UiHodaAhumaA QloOuxoraI]: thirdly, because it is conjoined with UinN [which forms a part of the compound Uik-aA] in this ex.:
Uim-aA Oaqamota waOam-aA Oanota murotaHilFA
faQll-ehu yakolaOu maA taOotiI wamaA tacaru
[If thou remain, and if thou be going away (Oam-aA meaning Oano kunota, as syn. with Uino kunota), may God guard thee (yakolaOu being marfooa because of the f) as long as thou doest and as long as thou leavest undone]: thus related, with kesr to the former An [in Uin-aA] and with fet-ḥ to the latter [in Oam-aA]. (Mughnee.)

[Sixthly,] it is a negative, like Uino: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) so, as some say, in [the Ḳur iii. 66,] OanE yuWotaI OaHadN mivola maA Ouwtiytumo [meaning accord. to them Not any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given]: but it is said [by others] that the meaning is, [taken with what precedes it,] And believe not ye that (biOano) any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given, except it be given to him who followeth your religion; and that the phrase “say thou, Verily the direction is the direction of God,” is parenthetic. (Mughnee.)

[Seventhly,] it is syn. with Uico, (AZ, T, Mughnee, Ḳ, [in Freytag's Lex., from the Ḳ, Uico qiyla, but qyl in the Ḳ relates to what there follows,]) as some say, in [the Ḳur l. 2,] balo EajibuwA OanN jaMCahumo munocirNminohumo [Verily they wonder because a warner from among themselves hath come unto them]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and in other instances; but correctly, in all these instances, An is what is termed maSodariy-ap, and li denoting cause is understood before it. (Mughnee.) [See also Oam-aA and Uim-aA.]

[Eighthly,] it is syn. with liYal-A, accord. to some, in [the Ḳur iv. last verse,] yubay-inu Qll-ehuOano taDil-uwA [God explaineth to you (the ordinances of your religion, Jel), lest ye should err, or in order that ye may not err]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and in the saying,
nazalotumo manozila AlOaDoyaAfi min-aA
faEaj-alonaA AlqiraI Oano taXotimuwnaA
[Ye became, or have become, in the condition of our guests; so we hastened, or have hastened, the entertainment, lest ye should revile us, or in order that ye should not revile us]: (Mughnee:) but correctly, in such a case [likewise], An is what is termed maSodariy-ap, and the original wording is karaAhapa Oano taDil-uwA [from a motive of dislike that ye should err], (Mughnee, Ḳ,) and maxaAfapa Oano taXotimuwnaA [from a motive of fear that ye should revile us]: so say the Basrees: some say, extravagantly, that l is meant to be understood before it, and Al-aciI after it. (Mughnee.)

[Ninthly,] it occurs in the sense of Al-aciI; as in the saying, zayodN OaEoqalu minN Oano yakocib [Zeyd is more reasonable than he who lies; which is equivalent to saying, Zeyd is too reasonable to lie: but respecting its usage in a phrase of this kind, and respecting the form of the aor. after it in such a case, see mino]. (Kull p. 78.)
By a peculiarity of pronunciation termed EanoEatapN, the tribe of Temeem say Eano instead of OanN. (M.)

entry.sense:
UinN is used in various ways: first, as a conditional particle, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ,) denoting the happening of the second of two events in consequence of the happening of the first, (Ṣ, Mṣb,*) whether the second be immediate or deferred, and whether the condition be affirmative or negative; (Mṣb;) [and as such it is followed by a mejzoom aor., or by a pret. having the signification of an aor.;] as in the saying, [Uino tafoEalN OfoEalN If thou do such a thing, I will do it; and] Uino taOotiniI Mtika [If thou come to me, I will come to thee]; and UinN jiYotaniI Oakoramotuka [If thou come to me, I will treat thee with honour]; (Ṣ;) and Uino faEalota faEalotu [If thou do, I will do] for which the tribe of Teiyi say, as IJ relates on the authority of Ḳṭr, hino faEalota faEalotu; (M;) and Uino daxalot Ald-aAra OawN [If thou stand, I will stand]; and Uino daxaloti Ald-aAra Oawo lamo tadoxuliI Ald-aArD faOanoti TaAlqN [If thou enter the house, or if thou enter not the house, thou shalt be divorced]; (Mṣb;) and [in the Ḳur viii. 39,] Uino yanotahuwA yugofarN lahumo maA qad salafa [If they desist, what hath already past shall be forgiven them]; and [in verse 19 of the same ch.,] waUino taEuwduwA naEudo [But if ye return to attacking the Apostle, we will return to assisting him]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) [On the difference between it and UicA, see the latter.] When either it or UicaA is immediately followed by a noun in the nom. case, the said noun is governed in that case by a verb necessarily suppressed, of which it is the agent; as in the saying, in the Ḳur [ix. 6], waUino OaHadN mina QlomuXorikiyna QstajaAraka; the complete phrase being waUini AsotajaAraka OaHadN mina QlomuXorikiyna QsotajaAraka [And if any one of the believers in a plurality of gods demand protection of thee, (if) he demand protection of thee]: so accord. to the generality of the grammarians. (I’Aḳ p. 123.) Sometimes it is conjoined with the negative laA, and the ignorant may imagine it to be the exceptive Uil-aA; as in [the saying in the Ḳur ix. 40,] Uil-aA tanoSuruwhu faqad naSarahu Qll-ehu [If ye will not aid him, certainly God did aid him]; and [in the next preceding verse,] Uil-aA tanofiruwA yuEac-ibokumo [If ye will not go forth to war, He will punish you]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*) It is sometimes used to denote one's feigning himself ignorant; as when you say to one who asks, “Is thy child in the house?” and thou hast knowledge thereof, Uino kaAna fiI Ald-aAri OaEolamotuka bihi [If he be in the house, I will inform thee thereof]. (Mṣb.) And to denote one's putting the knowing in the predicament of the ignorant, in order to incite to the doing or continuing an action; as when you say, UinN kunota QbuniI faOaTiEoniI [If thou be my son, obey me]; as though you said, “Thou knowest that thou art my son, and it is incumbent on the son to obey the father, and thou art not obedient; therefore do what thou art commanded to do.” (Mṣb.) And sometimes it is divested of the conditional meaning, and becomes syn. with law; as in the saying, Sal-i waUinN Eajazota Eani AlqiyaAm [Pray thou though thou be unable to stand;]
i. e. pray thou whether thou be able to stand or unable to do so; and in the saying, OakorimN ziyodFA waUino qaEada i. e. [Treat thou Zeyd with honour] though he be sitting; or, whether he sit or not. (Mṣb.) [Uim-aA as a compound of the conditional UinN and the redundant maA, see in an art. of which AmA is the heading.]

[Secondly,] it is a negative, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) syn. with maA; (Ṣ;) and is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in the saying [in the Ḳur lxvii. 20], Uini QlokaAfiruwna Uil-aA fiI guruwrK [The unbelievers are not in aught save in a deception]; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) and before a verbal proposition; as in [the Ḳur ix. 108,] Uino OaradonaA Uil-aA QloHusonaI [We desired not, or meant not, aught save that which is best]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) The assertion of some, that the negative UinN does not occur except where it is followed by Uil-aA, as in the instances cited above, or by lam-aA, with teshdeed, which is syn. therewith, as, accord. to a reading of some of the Seven [Readers], in the saying [in the Ḳur lxxxvi. 4], Uino kul-u nafosK lam-aA EalayohaA HaAfiZN, i. e., maA kul-u nafosK Uil-aA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [There is not any soul but over it is a guardian], is refuted by the sayings in the Ḳur [x. 69 and lxxii. 26], Uino Eindakumo mino suloTaAnK bihecaA [meaning, accord. to the Jel., Ye have no proof of this that ye say], and Uino OadoriyOaqariybN maA tuwEaduwna [I know not whether that with which ye are threatened be nigh]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.*) The conditional and the negative both occur in the saying in the Ḳur [xxxv. 39], walaYino zaAlataA Uino OamosakahumaA mino OaHadK mino baEodihi [And I swear that, if they should quit their place, not any one should withhold them after Him]: the former is conditional; and the latter is negative, and is [part of] the complement of the oath which is denoted by the l prefixed to the former; the complement of the condition being necessarily suppressed. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a nominal proposition, it has no government, accord. to Sb and Fr; but Ks and Mbr allow its governing in the manner of layosa; and Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr reads, [in the Ḳur vii. 193,] Uini Ql-aciyna tadoEuwna mino duwni Qll-ehi EibaAdFA OamovaAlakumN [Those whom ye invoke beside God, or others than God, are not men like you]: also, the people of El-ʼÁliyeh have been heard to say, UinN OaHadN xayorFAmino OaHdK Uil-aA biAlEaAfiyapi [Any one is not better than any other one, except by means of health, or soundness]; and Uino celika naAfiEaka walaA DaAr-aka [That is not profitable to thee nor injurious to thee]: as an ex. of its occurrence without government, which is mostly the case, the saying of some, Uin-a↓ qaAYmN may be explained as originally UinN OanaA qaAYimN [I am not standing]; the O of OanaA being elided for no reason in itself, and the n of UinN being incorporated into the n of OanaA, and the A of this latter being elided in its conjunction with the following word; but Uin-a qaAYimFA has also been heard. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it occurs [as a negative] in the complement of an oath: you say, waQll-ehi UinN faEalotu, meaning maA faEalotu [By God, I did not]. (Ṣ.)

[Thirdly,] it is a contraction of Uin-a, and is put before a nominal and before a verbal proposition. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) In the former case, it is made to govern and is made to have no government: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) [i. e.] in this case, it is allowable to make it govern; contr. to the opinion of the Koofees: (Mughnee:) Lth says that he who uses the contracted form of Uin-a uses the nom. case with it, except that some of the people of El-Ḥijáz use the accus. case with it: (T:) thus it is said, accord. to one reading, [in the Ḳur xi. 113,] Uino kul-aA lamaA layuwaf-iyan-ahumN rab-uka OaEomaAlahumN [Verily all of them, thy Lord will indeed fully render them the recompense of their works]: (T, Mughnee:) Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern, unless with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent; and he adds that in the instance cited above, they make kul-A to be governed in the accus. case by lywf-yn-hm; as though the phrase were layuwaf-iyan-ahumo kul-aA; and that kul-u would be proper; for you say, Uino zayodN laqaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]: (T:) the ex. given by Sb is, Uino EamorFA lamunTaliqN [Verily ʼAmr is going away]. (Mughnee.) But it is [most] frequently made to have no government; as in the saying [in the Ḳur xliii. 34 accord. to one reading], waUino kul-u celika lamaA mataAEu QloHayaApi Qld-unoyaA [And verily all that is the furniture of the present life]; and, accord. to the reading of Hafs, [and of 'Ásim and Kh, in the Ḳur xx. 66, respecting which see Uin-a,] Uino hecaAni lasaAHiraAni [Verily these two are enchanters];, &c. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a verbal proposition, it is necessarily made to have no government: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and in most cases the verb is a preterite and of the kind called naAsix [which effects a change of the grammatical form or of the meaning in a nominal proposition before which it is placed]; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 138], waUino kaAnatN lakabiyrapF [And verily it was a great matter]; and [in the Ḳur xvii. 75,] waUino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka [And verily they were near to seducing thee]; (Mughnee;) in which last ex. AZ says, it means laqado, i. e. without doubt; and so in the same ch. vv. 78 and 108: (T:) less frequently it is an aor. of a verb of this kind; as in the saying [in the Ḳur xxvi. 186], waUino naZun-uka lamina QlokaAcibyna [And verily we think thee to be of the number of the liars]: and both these kinds of expression may be taken as exs. to be imitated: less frequently than this it is a preterite of a verb not of the kind termed nasx; as in the saying [of a poet],
Xal-atN yamiynuka UinN qatalota lamusolimFA
[May thy right arm, or hand, dry up, or become unsound! verily thou hast slain a Muslim]; but this may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated; contr. to the opinion of Akh; for he allows the phrase, Uino qiAma laOanaA [Verily I stood], and UinN qaEada lOanota [Verily thou sattest]: and less frequently than this it is an aor. of a verb not of the kind termed nAsx; as in the saying, Uino yaziynuka lanafosuka waUinN yaXiynuka lahiyahN [Verily thy soul is that which beautifies thee, and it is that which deforms thee]; and this, by common consent, may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated. (Mughnee.) Wherever you find UinN with la after it, decide that it is originally Uin-a; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in the exs. above: but respecting this l there is a difference of opinion: see this letter. (Mughnee.) J says, (TA,) UinN is sometimes a contraction of Uin-a, and this must have l put before its predicate, to compensate for what is elided, of the doubled letter; as in the saying in the Ḳur [lxxxvi. 4, accord. to him who reads lamaA instead of lam-aA], Uino kul-u nafosK lamaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [Verily every soul hath over it a guardian]; and in the saying, UinN zaydN laOaxuwka [Verily Zeyd is thy brother]; in order that it may not be confounded with UinN which is syn. with the negative maA: (Ṣ, TA:) but IB says, l is here introduced to distinguish between negation and affirmation, and this Uino has neither subject nor predicate; so J's saying that the l is put before its predicate is without meaning: and this l is sometimes introduced with the objective complement of a verb; as in Uino Darabotu lazayodFA [Verily I struck, or beat, Zeyd]; and with the agent; as in Uino qaAma lazayodN [Verily Zeyd stood]. (TA.) When the contracted Uino governs, this l is not necessary; so you may say, Uino zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]; because in this case it cannot be confounded with the negative; for the negative does not render the subject mansoob and the predicate marfooa: and when it does not govern, if the meaning is apparent, the l is not needed; as in
wanaHonu OubaApu AlD-ayomi mino Mli maAlikK
waUino maAlikN kaAnato kiraAma AlmaEaAdini
[And we are persons who refuse to submit to injury, of the family of Málik: and verily the family of Málik are generous in respect of their origins]; kaAnato being here for lakaAnatN. (I’Aḳ p. 99.)

[Fourthly,] it is redundant, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) occurring with maA; as in the saying, maA Uino yaquwmu zayodN [Zeyd does not stand]; (Ṣ;) and in the saying [of a poet],
kaA Uino Oatayota biXaIoCK Oanota takorahuhu
[Thou didst not a thing which thou dislikest]. (Mughnee, Ḳ: in the CK Aatotu.) It is mostly thus used after the negative mA, when put before a verbal proposition; as above; or before a nominal proposition; as in the saying,
wamaA Uino Tib-unaA jbunN wlekinN
manaAyaAnaA wadawolapu MxariynaA
[And our habit is not cowardice; but our destinies and the good fortune of others caused our being defeated]: and in this case it prevents the government of mA, as in this verse: but in the saying,
baniI gudaAnapa maA Uino Oanotumu cahabFA
walaA SariyfFA walekinN Oanotumu Alxazafu
[Sons of Ghudáneh, ye are not indeed gold, nor silver, or pure silver, but ye are pottery], accord. to him who relates it thus, saying chbFA and SryfFA, in the accus. case, it is explained as a negative, corroborative of mA: (Mughnee:)
and accord. to J, (TA,) the negatives maA and UinN are sometimes thus combined for corroboration; as in the saying of the rájiz, (El-Aghlab El-ʼIjlee, TA,)
maA UinN raOayonaA malik-aA OagaAraA
Oakovara minohu qirapF waqaAraA
[We have not indeed seen a king who has made a hostile incursion possessing more numerous sheep, or goats, and camels, than he]; (Ṣ, TA;) but IB says that An is here redundant, not a negative. (TA.) Sometimes it is redundant after the conjunct noun maA; as in the saying,
yurajiI- AlmaroUu maA UinN laA yaraAhu
wataEoriDu duwna OadonaAhu AlxuTuwbu
[Man hopes for that which he will not see; for calamities intervene as obstacles in the way to what is nearest thereof]. (Mughnee.) And after the maA termed maSodariy-ap, (Mughnee,) [i. e.,] after the adverbial maA [which is of the kind termed mSdry-p]; (TA;) as in the saying (of Maaloot El-Kurey'ee, cited by Sb, TA),
waraj-i AlfataI liloxayori maA Uino raOayotahu
EalaI Als-in-i xayorFA laAyazaAlu yaziydu
[And hope thou that the youth is destined for good as long as thou hast seen him not ceasing to increase in good with age]. (Mughnee.) And after the inceptive OalaA; as in the saying,
OalaA Uino saraI layoliI fbit-u kaYiybaA
OuHaAciru Oano tanoOaI Aln-awaI bigaDuwbaA
[Now he journeyed on, or during, that my night, and I passed the night in an evil state, broken in spirit by grief, being fearful that the distance to which he was going with Ghadoob (a woman so named) would become far]. (Mughnee.) And before the meddeh denoting disapproval: [for] Sb heard a man, on its being said to him, “Wilt thou go forth if the desert become plentiful in herbage?” reply, OaOanaA UiniyhN [What, I, indeed?] disapproving that he should think otherwise than that. (Mughnee. [See also art. AnI.])

[Fifthly,] it is syn. with qado: so it is said to be in the saying [in the Ḳur lxxxvii. 9], Uino nafaEati Qlc-ikoraI [Admonition hath profited], (T, Mughnee, Ḳ,) by IAạr (T) and by Ḳṭr: (Mughnee:) and Abu-l-ʼAbbás relates that the Arabs say, UinN nafaEati Qlc-ikoraI meaning qadoqaAma zayodN [Zeyd has stood]; and he adds, that Ks states his having heard them say so, and having thought that it expressed a condition, but that he asked them, and they answered that they meant qadoqaAma zayodN, and not maA qaAma zayodN. (T.) [So too, accord. to the Ḳ, in all the exs. cited in the next sentence as from the Mughnee; but this is evidently a mistake, occasioned by an accidental omission.]

[Sixthly,] it is asserted also by the Koofees, that it is syn. with Uico, in the following exs.: in the Ḳur [v. 62], waQt-aquwA Qll-eha UinN kunotumo muWominiyna [And fear ye God, because ye are believers: and so, accord. to AZ, as is said in the T, in a similar instance in the Ḳur ii. 278: and in the same, iv. 62]: and [in the Ḳur xlviii. 27,] latado xulun-a Qlmasojida QloHaraAma Uino XaMCa Mminiyna [Ye shall assuredly enter the sacred mosque, because God hath willed, in security]: and in like instances, when the verb therein expresses what is held sure to happen or to have happened: and in the saying,
OatagoDabu UinN OudonaA qutayobapa Huz-ataA
jihaArFA walamo tagoDabo liqatoli Qboni HaAzimi
[Art thou angry because the ears of Ḳuteybeh have been cut, openly, or publicly, and wast not angry for the slaughter of Ibn-Házim?]: (Mughnee:) but in all these instances [it is sufficiently obvious that] An may be otherwise explained. (Mughnee, Ḳ.)

[Seventhly,] it is sometimes syn. with UicaA; as in the Ḳur [ix. 23], laA tat-axicuwA MbaMCakumo waUixowaAnakumo OawoliyaMCa Uini QsotaHab-uwA QlokuforaEalaI QloUiymaAni [Take not ye your fathers and your brethren as friends when they love unbelief above belief]; and in the same [xxxiii. 49], waQmoraOapF muWominapF Uino wahabato nafosahaA liln-abiI- [And a believing woman when she giveth herself to the Prophet]: so says AZ. (T.)

[Eighthly,] it is used for Uim-aA, (Mughnee and Ḳ, voce Uim-aA,) distinct from Uim-aA which is a compound of the conditional UinN and the redundant maA. (Mughnee ibid.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce Uim-aA in the present work, commencing with the words saqatohu Alr-awaAEidu.]
Oana: see Oano, in four places.

Oan-a is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative; and is originally Uin-a; therefore Sb has not mentioned it among those particles [as distinct from Uin-a, from which, however, it is distinguished in meaning]: (I’Aḳ p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle; (I’Aḳ, Mughnee;) a particle governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case, (Ṣ, I’Aḳ, Mughnee, Ḳ,) combining with what follows it to form an equivalent to an inf. n., (Ṣ,) [for,] accord. to the most correct opinion, it is a conjunct particle, which, together with its two objects of government, is explained by means of an inf. n. (Mughnee.) If the predicate is derived, the inf. n. by means of which it is explained is of the same radical letters; so that the implied meaning of balaganiI Oan-aka tanoTaliqu [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge,, &c., that thou goest away], or Oan-aka munoTaliqN [that thou art going away], is balaganiI AlAinoTilaAqu [or rather QnoTilaAquka thy going away has come to my knowledge,, &c.]; and hence, the implied meaning of balaganiI Oan-aka fiI Ald-aAri [It has come to my knowledge,, &c., that thou art in the house] is balaganiI QsotiqoraAruka fiI Ald-aAri [thy remaining in the house has come to my knowledge,, &c.], because thea predicate is properly a word suppressed from Aistaqar-a or musotaqir-N: and if the predicate is underived, the implied meaning is explained by the word kawoni; so that the implied meaning of balaganiI Oan-a hecA zayodN [It has come to my knowledge,, &c., that this is Zeyd] is balaganiI kawonuhu zayodFA [his being Zeyd has come to my knowledge,, &c.]; for the relation of every predicate expressed by an underived word to its subject may be denoted by a word signifying “being;” so that you say, hecaA zayodN and, if you will, hecaA kaAYinN zayodFA; both signifying the same. (Mughnee.) There are cases in which either Oan-a or Uin-a may be used: [see the latter, in twelve places:] other cases in which only the former may be used: and others in which only the latter. (I’Aḳ p. 91.) The former only may be used when the implied meaning is to be explained by an inf. n. (I’Aḳ, Ḳ.) Such is the case when it occurs in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the nom. case; as in yuEojibuniI Oan-aka qaAYimN [It pleases me that thou art standing], i. e. qiyaAmuka [thy standing pleases me]: or in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the accus. case; as in Earafotu Oat-aka qaAYimN [I knew that thou wast standing], i. e. qiyaAmaka [thy standing]: or in the place of a noun governed in the gen. case by a particle; as in Eajibotu mino Oan-aka qaAYimN [I wondered that thou wast standing], i. e. mino qiyaAmka [at, or by reason of, thy standing]: (I’Aḳ p. 91:) [and sometimes a preposition is understood; as in laA Xak-a Oan-ahu kacaA, for laA Xak-a fiI Oan-ahu kacaA There is no doubt that it is thus, i. e. laA X-k-a fiI kawonihi kacaA There is no doubt of its being thus:] and Oan-a must be used after lawo; as in lawo Oan-aka qaAYimN laqumotu [If that thou wert standing, I had stood, or would have stood, i. e. lawo vabata qiyaAmuka, or lawo qiyaAmuka vaAbitN, accord. to different opinions, both meaning if thy standing were a fact: see I’Aḳ pp. 305 and 306]. (Ḳ.) Sometimes its O is changed into E; so that you say, Ealimotu Ean-aka munoTaliqN [meaning I knew that thou wast going away]. (M.)

With k prefixed to it, it is a particle of comparison, (Ṣ,* M, TA,) [still] governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, kaOan-a zayodFA EamorNw [It is as though Zeyd were ʼAmr], meaning that Zeyd is like ʼAmr; as though you said, Uin-a zayodFA kaAYinN kaEamorKw [verily, Zeyd is like ʼAmr]: [it is to be accounted for by an ellipsis: or] the k is taken away from the middle of this proposition, and put at its commencement, and then the kesreh of Uin-a necessarily becomes changed to a fet-ḥah, because Uin-a cannot be preceded by a preposition, for it never occurs but at the commencement [of a proposition]. (IJ, M.) Sometimes, kaOan-a denotes denial; as in the saying, kaOan-aka OamiyrunaA fataOomuranaA [As though thou wert our commander so that thou shouldst command us], meaning thou art not our commander [that thou shouldst command us]. (TA.) It also denotes wishing; as in the saying, kaOon-aka biI qado qulotu AlX-iEora faOujiydahu, meaning Would that I had poetized, or versified, so that I might do it well: (TA:) [an elliptical form of speech, of which the implied meaning seems to be, would that I were as though thou sawest me that I had poetized,, &c.; or the like: for] you say [also], kaOan-iI bika meaning kaOan-iI OaboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be tomorrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition: (Ḥar p. 126: [see also bi; near the end of the paragraph:])
[thus,] kaOan-a also denotes knowing; and also thinking; [the former as in the saying immediately preceding, and] as when you say, kaOan-a Qll-eha yafoEalu maA yaXaMCu [I know, or rather it appears, as though seen, that God does what He wills]; and [the latter as when you say,] kaOan-aka xaArijN [I think, or rather it seems, that Thou art going forth]. (TA.)

[When it has The affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. Or Pl., you say, Oan-iI and Oan-aniI, and Oan-aA and Oan-anaA: and When it has also the k of comparison prefixed to It,] you say, kaOan-iI and kaOan-aniI, [and kaOan-aA and kaOan-anaA,] like as you say, lekin-iI and lekin-aniI [&c.]. (Ṣ.)

As Oan-a is a derivative from Uin-a, it is correctly asserted by Z that Oan-amaA imports restriction, like Uin-amaA↓; both of which occur in the saying in the Ḳur [xxi. 108], qulo Uin-amaA↓ yuwHaI UilaI-a Oan-amaA Uilehukumo UilehF waAHidN [Say thou, It is only revealed to me that your God is only one God]: the former is for the restricting of the quality to the qualified; and the latter, for the reverse: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) i. e. the former is for the restricting of the revelation to the declaration of the unity; and the latter, for the restricting of “your God” to unity: (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee:) but these words of the Ḳur do not imply that nothing save the unity was revealed to the Prophet; for the restriction is limited to the case of the discourse with the believers in a plurality of gods; so that the meaning is, there has not been revealed to me [aught], respecting the godhead, except the unity; not the attribution of any associate to God. (Mughnee.) [Oan-amaA, however, does not always import restriction; nor does always even Uin-amaA↓: in each of these, mA is what is termed kaAf-apN; i. e., it restricts the particle to which it is affixed from exercising any government; and sometimes has no effect upon the signification of that particle: (see art. maA; and see Uin-amaA, below, voce Uin-a:) thus, for instance, in the Ḳur viii. 28, waQEolamuwA Oan-amaA OamowaAlukumo fitonapF means And know ye that your possessions and your children are a trial; not that they are only a trial. When it has the k of comparison prefixed to it, it is sometimes contracted; as in the following ex.:] a poet says,
kaOam-aA yaxotaTiyna EaXlaI qataAdK
wayasotaDoHikona Eano Hab-i AlgamaAmi
[As though, by reason of their mincing gait, they were walking upon tragacanthas; and they were laughing so as to discover teeth like hailstones]: kaOam-aA being for kaOan-amaA. (IAạr.)
Oan-a is someTimes contracted into Oano; (Ṣ, Mughnee;) and in This case, it governs in the manner already exPlained, voce Oano. (Mughnee.)

It is also syn. with laEal-a; (Sb, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ;) as in the saying, Aiyti Als-uwqa Oan-aka taXotariI lanaA XayoYFA [Come thou to the market; may-be thou wilt buy for us something; Aiyti being originally AiYoti]; i. e. laEal-aka: (Sb, M, Mughnee, Ḳ:*) and, accord. to some, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) so in the Ḳur [vi. 109], where it is said, wamaA yuXoEirukumo Oan-ahaA UicaA jaMCato laA yuWominuwna [And what maketh you to know? (meaning, maketh you to know that they will believe when it cometh? i. e. ye do not know that: Jel:) Maybe, when it cometh, they will not believe]: (Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ:) thus accord. to this reading: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and Ubeí here reads laEal-ahaA. (Ṣ.) Oan-a and laOan-a and lawo Oan-a are all syn. with Eal-a and laEal-a; and Oan-iI and Oan-aniI, and laOan-iI and lOan-aniI, and luwo Oan-iI and lawo Oan-iniI, with Eal-iI and laEal-iI. (Ḳ voce laEal-a.)
It is also syn. with Oajalo [Yes, or yea; or it is as thou sayest]. (M, TA.) [See also Uin-a as exemplified by a verse commencing with wayaqulona and by a saying of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr.]

hom.sense:
Uin-a is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative, like Oan-a, of which it is the original: (I’Aḳ p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle, (I’Aḳ, Mughnee,) corroborating the predicate; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case; (Ṣ, I’Aḳ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) [and may generally be rendered by Verily, or certainly, or the like; exactly agreeing with the Greek ὄτι, as used in Luke vii. 16 and in many other passages in the New Testament; though it often seems to be nothing more than a sign of inception, which can hardly be rendered at all in English; unless in pronunciation, by laying a stress upon the predicate, or upon the copula;] as in the saying, Uin-a zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily, or certainly, Zeyd is standing; or simply, Zeyd is standing, if we lay a stress upon standing, or upon is]. (I’Aḳ p. 90.) But sometimes it governs both the subject and the predicate in the accus. case; as in the saying,
UicaA QXotad-a junoHu All-ayoli falotaOoti walotakunN
xuTaAka xifaAfFA Uin-a Hur-aAsanaA OusodaA
[When the darkness of night becomes, or shall become, intense, then do thou come, and let thy steps be light: verily our guardians are lions]; (Mughnee, Ḳ; [but in the latter, for QXotad-a, we find Qsowad-a, so that the meaning is, when the first portion of the night becomes, or shall become, black,, &c.;]) and as in a trad. in which it is said, An-a qaEora jahan-ama saboEiyna xariyfFA [Verily the bottom of Hell is a distance of seventy years of journeying]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) the verse, however, is explained by the supposition that it presents a denotative of state [in the last word, which is equivalent to XijoEaAnFA or the like], and that the predicate is suppressed, the meaning being, taloqaAhumo OusodFA [thou wilt find them lions]; and the trad. by the supposition that qaEora is an inf. n., and saboEiyna is an adverbial noun, so that the meaning is, the reaching the bottom of hell is [to be accomplished in no less time than] in seventy years. (Mughnee.) And sometimes the inchoative [of a proposition] after it is in the nom. case, and its subject is what is termed Damiyru XaOonK, suppressed; as in the saying of Moḥammad, Uin-a mino OaXad-i Aln-aAsi EacaAbFA yawoma Alqiyemapi AlmuSaw-iruwna [Verily, (the case is this:) of the men most severely to be punished, on the day of resurrection, are the makers of images], originally Uin-ahu, i. e. Uin-a AlX-aOona; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) and as in the saying in the Ḳur [xx. 66], Uin-a hecaAni lasaAHiraAni, [accord. to some,] as will be seen in what follows. (TA.)

Of the two particles Uin-a and Oan-a↓, in certain cases only the former may be used; and in certain other cases either of them may be used. (I’Aḳ p. 91.) The former must be used when it occurs inceptively, (Kh, T, I’Aḳ p. 92, Mughnee, Ḳ,) having nothing before it upon which it is syntactically dependent, (Kh, T,) with respect to the wording or the meaning; (Ḳ;) as in Uin-a zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]. (I’Aḳ, Ḳ.) It is used after OalaA, (I’Aḳ, Ḳ,) the inceptive particle, (I’Aḳ,) or the particle which is employed to give notice [of something about to be said]; (Ḳ;) as in OalaA Uin-a zayodFA qaAYimN [Now surely Zeyd is standing]. (I’Aḳ Ḳ.) And when it occurs at the commencement of the complement of a conjunct noun; (I’Aḳ, Ḳ;*) as in jaMCa Al-aciI Uin-ahu qaAYimN [He who is standing came]; (I’Aḳ;) and in the Ḳur [xxviii. 76], waMtayonaAhu mina Qlokunuwri maA Uin-a mafaAtiHahu latanuwoCu biQloEuSobapi OuwliI Alquw-api [And we gave him, of treasures, that whereof the keys would weigh down the company of men possessed of strength]. (I’Aḳ,* Ḳ,* TA.) And in the complement of an oath, (I’Aḳ, Ḳ,) when its predicate has la, (I’Aḳ,) or whether its subject or its predicate has la or has it not; (Ḳ;) as in waQll-ehi Uin-a zayodFA laqaAYimN [By Allah, verily Zeyd is standing], (I’Aḳ,) and Uin-ahu qaAYimN: or, as some say, when you do not employ the l, the particle is with fet-ḥ; as in waQll-ehi Oan-aka↓ qaAYimN [I swear by Allah that thou art standing]; mentioned by Ks as thus heard by him from the Arabs: (TA:) but respecting this case we shall have to speak hereafter. (I’Aḳ.) And when it occurs after the word qawolN or a derivative thereof, in repeating the saying to which that word relates; (Fr, T, I’Aḳ,* Ḳ;*) as in the saying [in the Ḳur iv. 156], waqawolihimo Uin-aA qatalonaA QlomasiyHa [And their saying, Verily we have slain the Messiah]; (Fr, T;) and qulotu Uin-a zayodFA qaAYimN [I said, Verily Zeyd is standing]; (I’Aḳ;) and [in the Ḳur v. 115,] qaAla Qll-ehu Uin-I mun-z-iluhaA Ealayokumo [God said, Verily I will cause it to descend unto you]; accord. to the dial. of him who does not pronounce it with fet-ḥ: (Ḳ:) but when it occurs in explaining what is said, you use Oan-a↓; as in the saying, qado qulotu laka kalaAmFA HasanFA Oan-a OabaAka XariyfN waOan-aka EaAqilN [I have said to thee a good saying; that thy father is noble and that thou art intelligent]; (Fr, T;) or when the word signifying “saying” is used as meaning “thinking;” as in Oataquwlu Oan-a zayodFA qaAYimN [Dost thou say that Zeyd is standing?], meaning OataZun-u [Dost thou think?]. (I’Aḳ.) Also, when it occurs in a phrase denotative of state; (I’Aḳ;) [i. e.,] after the w denotative of state; (Ḳ;) as in zurotuhu waUin-iI cuwOamalK [I visited him, I verily having hope, or expectation]; (I’Aḳ;) and in jaMCa zayodN waUin-a yadahu EalaI raOosihi [Zeyd came, he verily having his hand upon his head]. (Ḳ.)
And when it occurs in a phrase which is the predicate of a proper (as opposed to an ideal) substantive; (I’Aḳ, Ḳ;*) as in zayodN Uin-ahu qaAYimN [Zeyd, verily he is standing], (I’Aḳ,) or caAhibN [going away]; contr. to the assertion of Fr. (Ḳ.) And when it occurs before the l which suspends the grammatical government of a verb of the mind, preceding it, with respect to its objective complements; (I’Aḳ, Ḳ;*) as in Ealimotu Uin-a zayodFA laqaAYimN [I knew Zeyd verily was standing]; (I’Aḳ;) and in [the Ḳur lxiii. 1,] waQll-ehu yaEolamu Uin-aka larasuwluhu [And God knoweth thou verily art his apostle]: (Ḳ:) but if the l is not in its predicate, you say, Oan-a↓; as in Ealimotu Oan-a zayodFA qaAYimN [I knew that Zeyd was standing]. (I’Aḳ.) And in the like of the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 171], waUin-a Ql-aciyna QxotalafuwA fiI QlokitaAbi lafiI XaqaAqK baEiydK [And verily they who differ among themselves respecting the book are in an opposition remote from the truth]; because of the l [of inception] which occurs after it, in lafiI: (Ks, AʼObeyd:) the l of inception which occurs before the predicate of Uin-a should properly commence the sentence; so that Uin-a zayodFA laqaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing] should properly be laUin-a zayodFA qaAYimN; but as the l is a corroborative and Uin-a is a corroborative, they dislike putting two particles of the same meaning together, and therefore they put the l later, transferring it to the predicate: Mbr allows its being put before the predicate of Oan-a↓; and thus it occurs in an unusual reading of the saying [in the Ḳur xxv. 22], Uil-aA Oan-ahumo layaOokuluwna QlT-aEaAma [But they ate food]; but this is explained by the supposition that the l is here redundant: (I’Aḳ p. 95:) this is the reading of Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr: others read, Uil-aA Uin-ahumo layaOokuluna AlT-aEaAma [but verily they ate food]: and Uin-a [as well as Oan-a↓] is used after the exceptive Uil-aA when it is not followed by the l [of inception]. (TA.) Also, When it occurs after Hayovu; as in Aijoliso Hayovu Uin-a zayodFA jaAlisN [Sit thou where Zeyd is sitting]. (I’Aḳ p. 92, and k) And after Hat-aI; as in mariDa zayodN Hat-aI Uin-ahumo laA yarojuwnahu [Zeyd has fallen sick, so that verily they have no hope for him]: whereas after a particle governing the gen. case, [i. e. a preposition,] you say, Oan-a↓. (IHsh in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. P. 76.)

Either of these two forms may be used after UicaA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; as in xarajotu faUicaA Uin-a zayodFAqaAYimN [I went forth, and lo, verily Zeyd was standing], and faUicaA Oan-a↓ zayodFA qaAYimN [and lo, or at that present time, Zeyd's standing]; in which latter case, Oan-a with its complement is [properly] an inchoative, and its enunciative is UicaA; the implied meaning being, and at that present time was the standing of Zeyd: or it may be that the enunciative is suppressed, and that the implied meaning is, [and lo, or at that present time,] the standing of Zeyd was an event come to pass. (I’Aḳ p. 93.) Also, when occurring in the complement of an oath, if its enunciative is without l: (I’Aḳ:) [see exs. given above:] or, as some say, only Oan-a↓ is used in this case. (TA.) Also, when occurring after fa denoting the complement of a condition; as in mano yaOotiniI faUin-ahu mukoramN [He who cometh to me, verily he shall be treated with honour], and Oan-ahu↓ mukoramN; in which latter case, Oan-a with its complement is an inchoative, and the enunciative is suppressed; the implied meaning being, honourable treatment of him shall be an event come to pass: or it may be an enunciative to an inchoative suppressed; the implied meaning being, his recompense shall be honourable treatment. (I’Aḳ p. 94.) Also, when occurring after an inchoative having the meaning of a saying, its enunciative being a saying, and the sayer being one; as in xayoru Alqawoli Uin-I OaHomadu [The best saying is, Verily I praise God], and Oan-iI↓ OaHomadu; in which latter case, Oan-a with its complement is an enunciative of xayoru; the implied meaning being, the best saying is the praising of God [or my praising of God]. (I’Aḳ ubi suprà.) You also say, lab-ayoka Uin-a AlHamodalaka [At thy service! Verily praise belongeth to Thee! O God]; commencing [with Uin-a] a new proposition: and sometimes one says, Oan-a↓; meaning biOan-a AlHamoda laka [because praise belongeth to Thee]. (Mṣb.)
The cases in which Uin may not be used in the place of Oan-a have been mentioned above, voce Oan-a.

[When it has the affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. or pl.,] you say, Uin-iI and Uin-aniI, (Ṣ,) and Uin-aA and Uin-anaA, (TA,) like as you say lekin-iI and lekin-iniI [&c.]. (Ṣ.) Uin-a as a contraction of Uin-a OanaA has been mentioned above, as occurring in the phrase Uin-a qaAYimN, voce Uino, q. v.

Accord. to the grammarians, (T,) Uin-amaA is a compound of Uin-a and maA, (T, Ṣ,) which latter prevents the former's having any government: (T:) it imports restriction; like Oan-amaA, which see above, voce Oan-a, in three places: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) [i. e.] it imports the restriction of that which it precedes to that which follows it; as in Uin-amaA zayodN munoTaliqN [Zeyd is only going away], and Uin-amaA yanoTaliqu zayodN [Only Zeyd goes away]: (Bḍ in ii. 10:) [in other words,] it is used to particularize, or specify, or distinguish a thing from other things: (Ṣ:) it affirms a thing in relation to that which is mentioned after it, and denies it in relation to other things; (T, Ṣ;) as in the saying in the Ḳur [ix. 60], Uin-amaA QlS-adaqaAtu lilofuqaraMCi [The contributions levied for pious uses are only, or but, for the poor]: (Ṣ:) but El-Ámidee and AḤei say that it does not import restriction, but only corroboration of an affirmation, because it is a compound of the corroborative Uin-a and the redundant maA which restrains the former from exercising government, and that it has no application to denote negation implied in restriction, as is shown by the trad., Uin-amaA Al-iribaA fiI Aln-asiyoYapi [which must mean, Verily usury is in the delay of payment], for usury is in other things beside that here mentioned, as ribaA AlfDoli [or profit obtained by the superior value of a thing received over that of a thing given], by common consent: (Kull p. 76:) some say that it necessarily imports restriction: J says what has been cited above from the Ṣ: some say that it has an overt signification in denoting restriction, and is susceptible of the meaning of corroboration: some say the reverse of this: El-Ámidee says that if it were [properly] restrictive, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import; but to this it may be replied, that if it were [properly] corroborative, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import: it [therefore] seems that it is susceptible of both these meanings, bearing one or the other according as this or that suits the place. (Mṣb.) Uin-amaA is to be distinguished from Uin-a with the conjunct [noun] maA, which does not restrain it from governing [though its government with this is not apparent, and which is written separately]; as in Uin-a maA Einoka HasanN meaning Verily what is with thee is good, and in Uin-a maA faEalota HasanN meaning Verily thy deed is good. (I’Aḳ pp. 97 and 98.)

Uin-a is sometimes contracted into UinN; (Ṣ, Mughnee, Ḳ;) and in this case, it is made to govern and is made to have no government: (Ṣ:) it is seldom made to govern in this case; often made to have no government: the Koofees say that it is not contracted; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) and that when one says, Uino zayodN lamunoTaliqN [the meaning is virtually Verily Zeyd is going away, but] UinN is a negative and the l is syn. with Uil-A; but this assertion is refuted by the fact that some make it to govern when contracted, as in exs. cited above, voce Uino, q. v. (Mughnee.)

It is also syn. with naEamN [Even so; yes; yea]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) contr. to the opinion of AO. (Mughnee.) [See also Oan-a, last sentence.] Those who affirm it to have this meaning cite as an ex. the following verse (Mughnee, Ḳ *) of ʼObeyd-Allah Ibn-Keys-er-Rukeiyát: (Ṣ,* TA:)
wayaqulona XayobN qado EalaA
ka waqado kabirota faqulotu Uin-aho
[And they say, (namely, the women,) Hoariness hath come upon thee, and thou hast become old: and I say, Even so, or yes, or yea]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) but this has been rebutted by the saying, We do not concede that the h is here added to denote the pause, but assert that it is a pronoun, governed by Uin-a in the accus. case, and the predicate is suppressed; the meaning being, Uin-ahu kacelika [Verily it, i. e. the case, is thus]. (Mughnee.) [J says,] The meaning is, Un-ahu qado kaAna kamaA taqulona [Verily it, i. e. the case, hath been as ye say]: A ʼObeyd says, This is a curtailment of the speech of the Arabs; the pronoun being deemed sufficient because the meaning is known: and as to the saying of Akh, that it signifies naEamo, he only means thereby that it may be so rendered, not that it is originally applied to that signification: he says that the h is here added to denote the pause. (Ṣ.) There is, however, a good ex. of Uin-a in the sense of naEamo in the saying of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, to him who said to him, “May God curse a she camel which carried me to thee,” Uin-a waraAkibahaA, i. e. Even so, or yes, or yea; and may God curse her rider: for the suppression of both the subject and the predicate is not allowable. (Mughnee.) And hence, accord. to Mbr, the saying in the Ḳur [xx. 66], as thus read, Uin-a hecAni lasaAHiraAni [meaning, if so, Yes, these two are enchanters]. (Mughnee.)
[But this phrase has given rise to much discussion, related in the Mughnee and other works. The following is a brief abstract of what has been said respecting it by several of the leading authorities.] A booIs-hák says that the people of El-Medeeneh and El-Koofeh read as above, except 'Ásim, who is reported to have read, UinN hecaAni, without teshdeed, and so is Kh; [so too is Hafs, as is said above, voce Uino;] and that AA read Uin-a hecyoni, the former word with teshdeed, and the latter in the accus. case: that the argument for Uin-a hecaAni, with teshdeed and the nom. case, [or rather what is identical in form with the nom. case,] is, that it is of the dial. of Kináneh, in which the dual is formed by the termination An in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases alike, as also in the dial. of Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab: but that the old grammarians say that h is here suppressed; the meaning being, Uin-ahu hecaAni: (T:) this last assertion, however, is weak; for what is applied to the purpose of corroboration should not be suppressed, and the instances of its suppression which have been heard are deviations from general usage, except in the case of Oan-a, with fet-ḥ, contracted into Oano: (Mughnee:) Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ then adds, that some say, Uin-a is here syn. with naEamo: this last opinion he holds to be the best; the meaning being, naEamo hecaAni lahumaA saAHiraAni [Yes, these two, verily they are two enchanters: for this is not a case in which the l (which is the l of inception) can be regarded as transferred from its proper place, at the commencement of the sentence or proposition, as it is in some instances mentioned in the former half of this paragraph: but it is said in the Mughnee that this explanation is invalidated by the fact that the combining of the corroborative l and the suppression of the inchoative is like the combining of two things inconsistent, or incompatible; as is also the opinion that the l is redundant, because the redundant l prefixed to the enunciative is peculiar to poetry]: next in point of goodness, in the opinion of A booIs-hák, is, that it is of the dial. of Kináneh and Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab: the reading of AA he does not allow, because it is at variance with the written text: but he approves the reading of 'Ásim and Kh. (T.)

Uin-a also occurs as a verb: it is the third person pl. fem. of the pret. from AlOayonu, syn. with Alt-aEabu; or from Mna syn. with qaruba: or the third person sing. masc. of the pret. passive from AlOanyinu, in the dial. of those who, for rud-a and Hub-a, say rid-a and Hib-a, likening these verbs to qiyla and biyEa: or the sing. masc. of the imperative from the same: or the pl. fem. of the imperative from AlOayonu; or from Mna syn. with qaruba: or the sing. fem. of the corroborated form of the imperative from waOaI, syn. with waEada. (Mughnee.)

entry.sense: OanaA, signifying I: see Oano, in seven places.
Oanaho, signifying I: see Oano, in two places.
Oan-apN i. q. OaniynN [inf. n. of Oan-a, but app. a simple subst., signifying A moan, moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or a saying Ah: or a complaint: or a cry]. (TA.)
Oanota, signifying Thou: fem. Oanoti; dual OanotumaA; pl. masc. Oanotumo, and pl. fem. Oanotun-a: see Oano, in six places.

Oan-aAnN One who moans; who utters a moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or who says Ah; much, or frequently; as also OunaAnN↓ and OunanapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or this last signifies one who publishes complaint, or makes it public, much, or frequently: (M:) or one who talks and grieves and complains much, or frequently; and it has no verb derived from it: (T:) and you say, rajulN OunanapN qunanapN, [in which the latter epithet is app. an imitative sequent to the former,] meaning an eloquent man. (TA.) The fem. of Oan-aAnN is with p {Oan-aAnapN}: (M, Ḳ:) and is said to be applied to a woman who moans, or says Ah, and is affected with compassion, for a dead husband, on seeing another whom she has married after the former. (MF.) [See also Han-aAnapN, voce Han-aAnN.]
Mna, signifying I: see Oano, in two places.

Mn-N part. n. of Oan-a, [Moaning; or uttering a moan or moaning or a prolonged voice of complaint; or saying Ah; by reason of pain: complaining by reason of disease or pain: or] uttering a cry or cries: fem. with p {Mn-apN}. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] you say, maA lahu HaAn-apN walaA Mn-apN He has not a she camel nor a sheep, or goat: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or he has not a she camel nor a female slave (M, Ḳ) that moans by reason of fatigue. (M.)
