maYin-apN, occurring in a trad., (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, &c., in the first and last in art. mOn, and in the second in the present art.,) where it is said, Uin-a Tuwla AlS-alaApi waqiSara AlxuTobapi maYin-apN mino fiqohi Alr-ajuli, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA, &c.,) is of the measure mafEilapN waqiSara AlxuTobapi maYin-apN mino fiqohi Alr-ajuli, [originally maOoninapN,] from Uin-a, (Ṣ, Z in the Fáïk, IAth, Mgh, Ḳ,) the corroborative particle; (Z, IAth, Mgh;) like maEosaApN from EasaI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but not regularly derived from Uin-a, because a word may not be so derived from a particle; or it may be said that this is so derived after the particle has been made a noun; (Z, IAth;) or neither of these modes of derivation is regular: (MF:) the meaning is, [Verily the longness of the prayer and the shortness of the oration from the pulpit are (together)] a proper ground for one's saying, Verily the man is a person of knowledge or intelligence: (Z,* Mgh, Ḳ in art. mOn:) this is the proper signification: accord. to AO, the meaning is, a thing whereby one learns the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man: (Mgh:) or it means a thing suitable to, (Ṣ, Mgh,) and whereby one knows, (Ṣ,) the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or a sign (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) of the knowledge, or intelligence, of the man; and suitable thereto: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or an evidence thereof: (M:) or an indication, or a symptom, thereof; everything that indicates a thing being said to be maYin-apN lahu: [so that maYin-apN likacaA may be well rendered a thing that occasions one's knowing, or inferring, or suspecting, such a thing; and in like manner, a person that occasions one's doing so: or, more properly, a thing, &c., in which such a thing is usually known to take place, or have place, or be, or exist, like maZin-apN:] one of the strangest of the things said of it is, that the C is a substitute for the Z of maZin-apN: (IAth:) this seems to have been the opinion of Lḥ: (Az, L:) accord. to AA, it is syn. with MyapN [a sign,, &c.]. (TA.) Aṣ says (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA, all in art. mOn) that the word is thus, with teshdeed to the n, in the trad. and in a verse of poetry, as these are related; (Ṣ, TA;) but correctly, in his opinion, it should be maYiynapN of the measure faEiylapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) unless it be from Uin-a, as first stated above: (Ṣ, TA:) AZ used to say that it is maYit-apN, with t, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) meaning a thing (lit. a place) meet, fit, or proper, or worthy or deserving, and the like; of the measure mafoEilapN, [originally maOotitapN,] from Oat-ahu meaning “he overcame him with an argument or the like:” (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) but some say that it is of the measure faEil-apN, from maOana meaning AiHotamala: see art. mOn. (Ḳ in that art.) You say also, huwa maYin-apN liloxayori, from Uin-a, He is a person fit, or proper, for one's saying of him, Verily he is good; and in like manner, maEosaApN, from EasaI, as meaning “a person fit, or proper, for one's saying of him, May-be he will do good.” (A, TA.) And Uin-ahu lamaYin-apN Oano yakuwna kacaA Verily it is meet, fit, or proper, for one's saying of it, Verily it is thus; or is worthy, or deserving, of one's saying, &c.: or verily it is a thing meet, fit, or proper, for one's saying, &c.; or is a thing worthy, or deserving, of one's saying, &c.: of the measure mafoEilapN, from Uin-a. (Ḳ in the present art.) And Uin-ahu lamaYin-apN Oano yafoEala caAka Verily he is meet, fit, or proper, for doing that; or is worthy, or deserving, of doing that: or verily he is a person meet, fit, or proper, for doing that; or is a person worthy, or deserving, of doing that: and in like manner you say of two, and of more, and of a female: but maYin-apN may be of the measure faEil-apN [from mOn], i. e. a triliteral-radical word. (M.)
You also say, OataAhu EalaI maYn-ap caAka, meaning He came to him at the time, or season, [or fit or proper time,] of that; and at the first thereof. (M.)
OanaA (pronoun of the first person sing.): see art. An.

2. On-bhu, inf. n. taOoniybN, He blamed, reproved, reprehended, chid, or reproached, him: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or he did so severely, or angrily: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or, with the utmost severity or harshness: (T, M, TA:) or he repulsed him, meaning a person who asked something of him, in the most abominable manner. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.)

OunobuwbN An internodal portion, or the portion between any two joints, or knots, of a cane, or reed, and of a spear-shaft: (T:) [and] a spear, or lance:
pl. OanaAbiybu: mentioned in this art. [in the T, and] by Ibn-El-Mukarram [in the L]. (TA.) [See also art. nb.]
Oanota, Oanoti, OanotumaA, Oanotumo, and Oanotun-a: see Oano, in art. An.
1. [Oanuva, aor. _u {yaOonuvu}, inf. n. OanaAvapN and OunuwvapN, (see the former of these two ns. below,) It was, or became, female, feminine, or of the feminine gender.]
[And hence, Oanuvato, said of land (OaroD), ‡ It was, or became, such as is termed Oaniyvap.]

[Hence also,] Oanuva, said of iron, ‡ It was, or became, soft. (Golius, from the larger of two editions of the lexicon entitled mrqAp Allgp.) Accord. to IAạr, softness is the primary signification. (M.) [But accord. to the A, the second and third of the meanings given above are tropical: (see OaniyvN:) and the verb in the first of the senses here assigned to it, if not proper, is certainly what is termed Haqiyqap Eurofiy-ap, i. e., conventionally regarded as proper.]

hom.sense: 2. On-vhu, inf. n. taOoniyvN, He made it (namely, a noun [&c.], S and Mṣb) feminine; (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb;) he attached to it, or to that which was syntactically dependent upon it, the sign of the feminine gender. (Mṣb.)
† He, or it, rendered him effeminate. (KL.) [See the pass. part. n., below.]

On-v lahu, inf. n. as above, ‡ He acted gently, [or effeminately] towards him; as also tOn-v↓ lh. (Ḳ, TA.) And On-v fiI Oamorihi, inf. n. as above, (T, A,) ‡ He acted gently in his affair: (A:) or he applied himself gently to his affair: (T:) and some say, tOn-v↓ fI Amrh, meaning he acted effeminately in his affair. (T, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Mnavato, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiynaAvN, (Ḳ,) She (a woman) brought forth a female, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or females. (M.)
[And hence,] † It (land, OaroD,) was, or became, such as is termed miYonaAv. (A.)
5. tOnv It (a noun [&c.]) was, or became, or was made, feminine. (Ṣ, L.)
See also 2, in two places.

OunovaI Female; feminine; of the female, or feminine, sex, or gender; contr. of cakarN: (T, Ṣ, M:) an epithet applied to anything of that sex or gender: (T:) IAạr asserts, that a woman is termed AnvI from the phrase baladN OaniyvN, q. v, because of her softness; she being more soft than a man: (M, L:) [but see the observation at the end of the first paragraph of this art.:] the pl. is UinaAvN; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and sometimes one says OunuvN, as though it were pl. of UinaAvN; (Ṣ;) or it is [truly] pl. of UinaAvN, like as numurN is of nimaArN; (T;) and OanaAvaI, (T, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last occurs in poetry. (T.) You say, hecaA TaAYirN waOunovaAhu [This is a (male) bird and his female]: not OunovaAtuhu. (ISk, T.) In the Ḳur iv. 117, I’Ab reads OuvunFA [in the place of OunuvFA or UinaAvFA]; and Fr says that it is pl. of wavanN, the w in wuvunN being changed into O as in Ouq-itatN [for wuq-itatN]. (T, L.)
AimoraOapN OanovaI ‡ [A feminine woman,] means a perfect woman; (T, A, Ḳ;) a woman being thus termed in praise; like as a man is termed rajulN cakarN. (T, A.)

[The pl.] UinaAvN also signifies † Inanimate things; (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ;) as trees and stones (T, Ḳ) and wood. (T.) In the passage of the Ḳur mentioned above, UinaAvFA is said to have this meaning: (T, M:) [or it there means females; for] Fr says that El-Lát and El-'Ozzà and the like were said by the Arabs to be feminine divinities. (T, TA.)
Also † Small stars. (Ḳ.)

And [the dual] AlOunovayaAni ‡ The two testicles; syn. AlxuSoyataAni; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or AlxuSoyaAni [which is said by some to mean the scrotum; but the former is generally, though app. not always, meant by AlAnvyAn]. (M, Mgh, Mṣb.)
And The two ears: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) because they are of the fem. gender. (TA.)
And † The two tribes of Bejeeleh and Ḳuḍáʼah. (Ḳ)
And OunovayaA Alfarasi † The inner parts (Alr-abalataAni) of the thighs of the horse. (M, L.)
And AlOunovaI is also used to signify † The [engine of war called] manojaniyq; because the latter word is [generally] of the feminine gender. (M.)
OaniyvN: see muWan-avN.

OaroDN OaniyvapN, (AA,* IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and miYonaAvN↓, (ISh, T, M, Ḳ,) ‡ Plain, even, or soft, land, or ground, (ISh, IAạr, T, M, Ḳ,) that produces many plants, or much herbage; (AA, T, M, Ḳ;) or that produces herbs, or leguminous plants, and is plain, even, or soft; (El-Kilábee, Ṣ;) or fitted for producing plants, or herbage; not rugged. (ISh, T, L.) And makaAnN OaniyvN A place in which the herbage grows quickly, and becomes abundant. (T, L.) And baladN OaniyvN † A country, or district, of which the soil is soft, and plain, or even. (IAạr, M, L.)

HadiydN OaniyvN ‡ Female iron; that which is not what is termed cakarN: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) soft iron. (T and Ḳ in art. Anf.) And sayofN OaniyvN ‡ A sword of female iron: (M, L:) or a sword that is not sharp, or cutting; a blunt sword: (T, M,* L:) and sayofN miYonaAvN↓, and miYonaAvapN↓, (T, M, L, Ḳ,) mentioned by Lḥ, (T, L,) a blunt sword; (Ḳ;) as also muWan-avN↓: (TA:) or a sword of soft iron. (T, L.)
OanaAvapN [inf. n. of Oanuva, q. v.:] The female, or feminine, nature, or quality, or gender; (M;) as also OunuwvapN↓. (A.)
‡ The quality of land which is termed OaniyvapN. (A.)
[‡ Softness of iron: see OanyvN.]
OunuwvapN: see the paragraph next preceding.
muWonivN A woman bringing forth, or who brings forth, a female, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or females. (M.)

miYonaAvN A woman who usually brings forth females: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and a man who usually begets female children; for the measure mifoEaAlN applies equally to both sexes: (Ṣ:) the contr. epithet is micokaArN. (TA.)
See also muWan-avN, in two places.
OaroDN miYonaAvN: see OaniyvN.
sayofN miYonaAvN, and miYonaAvapN: see OaniyvN.
muWan-avN [A feminine word; a word made feminine.]

[Also,] (T, A, Ḳ,) and OaniyvN↓, (AA, T,) and miYonaAvN↓, (Ḳ,) and miYonaAvapN↓, (TA,) ‡ i. q. muxan-avN, (AA, T, A, Ḳ,) i. e. An effeminate man; one who resembles a woman (AA, T, TA) in gentleness, and in softness of speech, and in an affectation of languor of the limbs: (TA:) or a man in the form, or make, of a female. (T.)
sayofN muWan-avN: see OaniyvN.

TiybN muWan-avN ‡ Perfume that is used by women; such as xaluwq and zaEofarAn, (Sh, T, L,) and what colours the clothes: (L:) cukuwrapu AlT-iybi being such perfumes as have no colour; such as gaAliyap and kaAfuwr and misok and Euwd and Eanobar and the like, which leave no mark. (T, L.)

1. OanaHa, aor. _i {yaOoniHu}, inf. n. OanoHN and OaniyHN and OanuwHN, He (a man, Ṣ) breathed hard, or violently, in consequence of heaviness, or oppression, experienced by him as an effect of disease, or of being out of breath, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) as though he made a reiterated hemming in his throat, (kaOan-ahu yatanaHonaHu,) and did not speak clearly, or plainly: (Ṣ, TA:) or he made a reiterated hemming in his throat (tanaHonaHa), when asked for a thing, by reason of niggardliness: (L:) or he uttered a long, or vehement, sigh, or a kind of groaning sound, (zafara,) when asked for a thing. (A.) You say, yaOoniHu EalaI maAlihi He utters a long, or vehement, sigh, or a kind of groaning sound, over his property [from unwillingness to part with it]. (A.)

It is said in a trad. of Ibn-ʼOmar, raOaI rajulFA yaOoniHu bibaTonihi, meaning, [it is asserted, though this seems doubtful, He saw a man] raising, or lifting, his belly with an effort, oppressed by its weight: from OunuwHN in the last of the senses assigned to it below. (TA.)
Oun-aHN: see MniHN, with which it is syn., and of which it is also pl.
OanuwHN: see MniHN, in two places.
OaniyHN: see OunuwHN. [See also 1.]
Oan-aAHN: see MniHN.

MniHN act. part. n. of 1; A man breathing hard, or violently,, &c.: and a man who, when he is asked for a thing, makes a reiterated hemming in his throat (yatanaHonHu), by reason of niggardliness;
as also OanuwHN↓, and Oun-aHN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Oan-aAHN↓: (Lḥ:) or OanuwHN↓ signifies a man who hangs back from, or falls short of, doing generous deeds; as also OazuwHN: (El-Ghanawee and Ṣ in art. AzH, and TA in the present art.:) and is also applied to a horse, meaning that runs, and makes a kind of groaning noise; UicaA jaraI fazafara: this is the right reading in the Ḳ: in some copies AcA jrI qaroqara [that makes a rumbling sound in his belly when he runs]: (TA:) the pl. of MniHN is Oun-aHN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
MniHapN, applied to a female, signifies Short. (Ḳ.)

1. Oanisa bihi, (AZ, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Uilayohi, (A,) aor. _a {yaOonasu}; (Mṣb, TA;) and Oanasa, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOonisu} (M, Mṣb, TA) and _u {yaOonusu}; (M;) and Oanusa, aor. _u {yaOonusu}; (M, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) inf. n. OanasN and OanasapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) both of Oanisa, (Ṣ,) or UinasN, (AZ, AḤát, T, M, Mṣb,) also of Oanisa, (AZ, AḤát, Mṣb, TA,) but this is rare, (T, TA,) and OunosN, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) which is the more common, (T, TA,) and is of Oanasa, (Ṣ,) or OunosN has a different signification from UinosN the inf. n. of Oanisa, [see OunosN below,] (AZ, AḤát,) or it is a subst. from Oanisa bihi, (Mṣb,) and OunosapN; (M;) [but this also is probably a subst.;] one says OunosN and OunosapN, like as one says buEodN and buEodap; (Ḥam p. 768;) He was, or became, sociable, companionable, conversable, inclined to company or converse, friendly, amicable, or familiar, with him, or by means of him, and to him: and [Ans bh] he was, or became, cheered, or gladdened, by his company or converse, or by his, or its, presence; or cheerful, gay, or gladsome: the inf. n. signifying the contr. of waHoXapN: (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he was, or became, at ease, or tranquil, with him: (M:) or his heart was, or became, at ease, or tranquil, with him; without shrinking, or aversion: (Mṣb:) and AstOns↓ bihi, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) and Uilayohi, (A,) and tOn-s↓ bihi, signify the same, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) i. e., the same as Oanisa (M, A, Mṣb, TA) and Oanasa (M, Mṣb) and Ounusa: (M:) Oanisa bifulaAnK is likewise explained as signifying he delighted, or rejoiced, in such a one; he was happy, or pleased, with him: (IAạr, TA:) [and Mnshu↓, a form of frequent occurrence, inf. n. muWaAnasapN, which occurs in this art. in the TA, also signifies he was, or became, sociable,, &c., with him; like Oanisa bihi, &c.: it is also said in the TA that Oanisa bihi and Mnasa↓ bihi are syn., meaning, app., like AstOns and tOn-s bh, and that Mns in this case is therefore of the measure faAEala; but this admits of some doubt, as it is said immediately after Mnshu as meaning the contr. of OawoHaXahu:] and AstOns↓, (Ḳ, TA,) said of a wild animal, (TA,) signifies [he became familiar, or tame, or domesticated; or] his wildness (tawaH-uXuhu) departed: (Ḳ, TA:) you say UicaA jaMCa All-ayolu QsotaOonasa kul-u waHoXiI-K waQsotawoHaXa kul-u UinosiIN [When the night comes, every wild animal becomes familiar with his kind, and every human being becomes shy of his kind, i. e., of such thereof as he does not know, when meeting them in the dark]. (A, TA, Mṣb in art. wHX.)

hom.sense: 2. Aan-ashu inf. n. taOoniysN, He rendered him familiar; or tame. (KL.)
See also 4, in three places.

entry.sense: 3: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: He perceived it; syn. of the inf. n. UidoraAkN. (TA.)

He saw him, or it, (Ṣ, M, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and looked at him, or it; (M, TA;) as also On-shu↓, inf. n. taOoniysN; (Ḳ;) and AstOnshu↓: (M:) or he saw it so that there was no doubt or uncertainty in it: or he saw it, meaning a thing by the sight or presence of which he was cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled; UiynaAsN signifying UiboSaAru maA yuWonasu bihi: (Bḍ in xx. 9:) or he saw it, not having before known it, or been acquainted with it. (TA.)
He heard it; namely, a sound or voice. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He felt it; was sensible of it; (M, Ḳ, TA;) experienced it in himself; (TA;) namely, [for instance,] fright, or fear. (A, TA.)

He knew it: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he was acquainted with it: (TA:) he had certain knowledge of it; was certain of it. (M, TA.) You say, Mnasotu minohu ruXodFA (Ṣ, A, TA) I knew him to be characterized by ruXod, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e., maturity of intel-lect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs. (TA.) [See Ḳur iv. 5.] And it is said in a prov., baEoda QT-ilaAEK UiynaAsN, i. e. After appearance [is knowledge, or certain knowledge]. (Fr, TA.)
5. tOn-s bihi: see 1.
tOn-s AlbaAzI The falcon looked, raising his head (M, A, Ḳ) and his eyes. (A.)
tOn-s lahu: see 10.
10. AstOns, and AstOns bihi and Uilayohi: see 1.
AstOns signifies also He (a wild animal) became sensible of the presence or nearness of a human being. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

He looked; as in the phrase Aicohabo faQsotaOoniso halo taraI OaHadFA [Go thou and look if thou see any one]: (Fr, TA:) he considered, or examined, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of a thing; (Ḳ, TA;) and looked aside, or about, to ascertain if he could see any one: (TA:) he sought, or asked for, knowledge, or information; he inquired: (M, TA:) and hence, (Bḍ in xxiv. 27,) he asked permission. (Fr, Zj, Ḳ, TA, and Bḍ ubi suprà.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxiv. 27], laA tadoxuluwA buyuwtFA gayora buyuwtikumo Hat-aI tasotaOonisuwA watusal-imuwA [Enter ye not houses other than your own houses] until ye inquire whether its inhabitants desire that ye should enter or not; [and salute:] (M:) or (which is essentially the same, M) until ye ask permission: (Fr, Zj, M, TA:) but Fr says that the sentence presents an inversion, and that the meaning is, until ye salute, and ask if ye shall enter or not: (TA:) I’Ab says that tastOnswA is a mistranscription; and he and Ubeí and Ibn-Mesʼood read tasotaOocinuwA, which signifies the same: (Az, TA:) [it is said that] AstOns also signifies he made a reiterated hemming, like a slight coughing; [as a man does to notify his nearness;] syn. tanaHonaHa: and so some explain it in the text of the Ḳur quoted above. (TA.)
AstOnshu: see 4.

entry.sense: OunosN Sociableness; companionableness; conversableness; inclination to company or converse; friendliness; amicableness; socialness; familiarity: cheerfulness; gayness; gladsomeness: contr. of waHoXapN: (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) joy; gladness; happiness: (Ḥar p. 652:) or ease, or tranquillity: (M:) or ease, or tranquillity, of heart, and freedom from shrinking, or from aversion: (Mṣb:) an inf. n. of 1, (Ṣ, M,) as are also OanasN↓ and OanasapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and UinosN↓, (M,) but this is rare as signifying the contr. of waHoXapN: (T, TA:) or UinosN↓ is the inf. n. of Oanisa bihi; but OunusN is not: (AZ, AḤát, Mṣb, TA:) this latter is a subst. from that verb [signifying as explained above]: (Mṣb:) or only signifying converse, and companionship, or familiarity, with women; (AZ, AḤát, TA;) or amatory conversation and conduct; or the talk of young men and young women: (Fr, TA:) [but of all the forms above, OunosN is that which is most commonly used, at least in post-classical works, as signifying the contr. of waHoXapN.]

[Also † Delight, as meaning a cause of delight, or thing that gives delight.] A poet says,
yaA saAkiniI mak-apa laA zilotumu
OunosFA lanaA Uin-iIa lamo Oanosakumo
maA fiykumu EayobN siwaI qawolikumo
Einoda All-iqaA OawoHaXanaA Ounosukumo
[O inhabitants of Mekkeh, may ye not cease to be a delight to us: verily I have not forgotten you: there is in you no fault beside your saying, at meeting, Your sociableness, or companiableness,, &c., has made us feel lonely and sad; meaning, in your absence]. (TA in art. wHX.) [See OawoHaXa. But this signification, though allowable as tropical, is perhaps post-classical.]
Aibonu Ounos: and fulaAnN Qbonu Ounosi fulaAnK and kayofa Qbonu Ounosika and kayofa taraI Qbona Ounosika: see UinosN.

hom.sense: UinosN: see OunosN, in two places.

‡ A chosen, select, particular, or special, friend or companion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Aibonu UinosK (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Aibonu OunosK↓. (So in a copy of the A.) You say, hecaA UinosiI; (Ṣ;) and Uinosuka, and Qbonu Uinosika; (Ḳ;) ‡ This is my chosen, or particular, friend; (Ṣ;) and thy chosen, or particular, friend. (Ḳ.) And fulaAnN Qbonu Uinosi fulaAnK (Ṣ,) or Abn Ounosi↓ flAn (A,)
‡ Such a one is the chosen, or particular, friend of such a one. (Ṣ, A.) One also says, kayofa Qbonu Uinosika and Ounosika↓, (Ṣ, M,) or kayofa taraI Qbona Uinosika (AZ, Fr, A) and Ounosika↓, (A,) meaning himself, (AZ, Fr, Ṣ, Ṣ TA,) i. e., † How dost thou regard me in my companionship with thee? (Ṣ:) or the meaning is, ‡ how dost thou find thyself? (A:) or how is thyself? (M, TA.)

Mankind; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) the opposite of jin-N; (Mṣb;) as also OanasN↓, (Akh, Ṣ, TA,) and UinosaAnN↓; (A, Ḳ;) the last being a gen. n., (Mṣb,) but applied to the male (Ṣ,* Mṣb) and female, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sing. and pl.: (Mṣb:) one is [also] termed UinosiI-N↓ and OanasiI-N↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the former of which is a rel. n. from UinosN; (M;) [and the latter, from OanasN: the fem. of each is with p:] the vulgar apply to a woman, instead of UinosaAnN↓, [which is the more approved,] UinosaAnapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) this latter [accord. to some] should not be used: (Ṣ:) but it is correct, though rare: it is said in the Ḳ to occur in poetry, but supposed to be post-classical: it occurs, however, in classical poetry, and has been transmitted by several authors: (MF:) the pl. (of UinosN, M, TA) is MnaAsN; (M, Ḳ, TA;) and (of the same, Ḳ in art. nws, or of UinosaAnN↓, M) OunaAsN, (M, Ḳ ubi suprà,) with which naAsN is syn., (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) being a contraction thereof; (Sb, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) and (of UinosiI-N↓, Ṣ, M, or OanasiI-N↓, Ṣ, or of UinosaAnN↓, Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) OanaAsiI-N, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as karaAsiI-u is pl. of kurosiI-N, or like as saraAHynu is pl. of sirHaAnN, but I being substituted for n, (M, TA,) after the same manner as they say OaraAnK for OaraAnibu; (Fr, TA;) and OanaAsK, (Lḥ, M,) in the accus. case OanaAsiIa, as the word is read in the Ḳur xxv. 51, by Ks, (TA,) and by Yaḥyà Ibn-El-Hárith, (Ḳ, TA,) dropping the I between the second and last radical letters, [for, with some others, it seems, they held the word to be derived from the root nsI,] (TA,) and OanaAsiyapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which the p is a substitute for one of the two yás in OanaAsiI-u, a pl. of UinosaAnN; or, accord. to Mbr, OanaAsiyapN is pl. of UinosiI-N, [in the TA, of Uinosiy-apN, which I regard as a mistranscription,] and is like zanaAdaqapN for zanaAdiyqu, and faraAzitapN for faraAziynu; (M, TA;) and you say also Uinosay-uwna. (TA.) naAsN is masc., as in the Ḳur ii. 19, &c.; and sometimes fem., as meaning A tribe, or a body of men, qabiylapN, or TaAYifapN; as in the phrase, mentioned by Th, jaMCatoka Aln-aAsu, meaning, The tribe, or portion of people (qiToEap), came to thee. (M, TA.) banuwAlUinosaAni↓ means The sons of Adam. (M.) And Aln-aAsu Aln-aAsu, an expression mentioned by Sb, means, Men in every place and in every state are men: a poet says,
bilaAdN bahaA kun-aA wakun-aA nuHib-uhaA
Uici Aln-aAsu naAsN waAlbilaAdu bilaAdu
meaning [A country in which we were, and which we used to love,] since the men were ingenuous men, and the country was a fruitful country. (M.) The following trad., lawo OaTaAEa Qll-ehu Aln-aAsa fiI Aln-aAsi lamo yakuno naAsN If God complied with the prayer of men with respect to men there would be no men, is said to mean, that men love to have male children born to them, and not females, and if there were no females, or if the females were not, men would cease to be. (TA.) It is related that a party of the jinn, or genii, came to a company of men, and asked permission to go in to them, whereupon the latter said to them, Who are ye? and they answered, naAsN mina Aljn-i [A people of the jinn], making their answer to accord. with common usage; for it is customary for men, when it is said to them, Who are ye? to answer, naAsN mino baniI fulaAnK [Men of the sons of such a one]. (IJ, M, L: but in the L, for nAs, in both instances, we find OunaAsN.) [See also naAsN in art. nws.] Respecting the derivation of UinosaAnN↓, authors differ, though they agree that the final n is augmentative: the Basrees say that it is from AlUinosu; (Mṣb;) and its measure is fiEolaAnN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) but an addition, of I, is made in its dim., [which is OunayosiyaAnN,] like as an addition is made in ruwayojilN, the dim. of rajulN: (Ṣ:) [but it should be observed that ruwayojilN is more probably the dim. of raAjilN:] some say that it is from UiynaAsN, signifying “perception,” or “sight,” and “knowledge,” and “sensation;” because man uses these faculties: (TA:) and Moḥammad Ibn-ʼArafeh El-Wásitee says that men are called Uinsiy-uwni because they are seen (yuWonasuwna, i. e. yurawona), and that the jinn are called jin- because they are [ordinarily] concealed (mujotan-uwna, i. e. mutawaAruwna,) from the sight of men: (TA:) [it is said in the B, as cited in the TA, that the form OanisaAn is also used for UinosaAnN; as though it were a dual, meaning “a double associate,” i. e., an associate with the jinn and with his own kind; for it is added, Oanisa biQloMojin-i waOanisa biQloMoxaloqi:] some derive the word from Aln-awosu, signifying “motion:” (TA:) some (namely, the Koofees, Mṣb) say that it is originally UinsiyaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) of the measure UifoEilaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) from Aln-isoyaAnu [“forgetfulness”], (Mṣb,) and contracted to make it more easy of pronunciation, because of its being so often used; (Ṣ;) but it is restored to its original in forming the dim., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which is OunayosiyaAnN: (Mṣb, TA:) this form of the dim., they say, shows the original form of the word which is its source; (TA;) and they adduce as an indication of its derivation the saying of I’Ab, Uin-amaA sum-iya UinosaAnFA liOan-ahu Euhida Uilayohi fanasiIa [He (meaning the first man) was only named AnsAn because he was commanded and he forgot]: (Ṣ, TA:) [in like manner,] it is said that Aln-aAsu is originally Aln-aAsiI; the former of these, accord. to one reading, and the latter accord. to another, occurs in the Ḳur ii. 195; the latter referring to Adam, and to the words of the Ḳur in xx. 114: (TA:) but Az holds that UinosiyaAnN is of the measure fiEoliyaAnN, from AlUinosu, and similar to xiroSiyaAnN. (L, TA.*)
OanasN i. q. OunosN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also i. q. UinosN, q. v. (Akh, Ṣ, TA.)
Also A numerous company of men; (Ḳ,* TA;) many men. (TA.)

A tribe (HaI-u) staying, residing, dwelling, or abiding: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the people of a place of alighting or abode: (M, TA: [but in the latter, in one place, said to be UinosN, with kesr; though a verse cited in both, as an ex., shows it to be OanasN:]) the inhabitants of a house: (AA, TA:) pl. (of the word in the first sense, of these three, TA, and in the second, M, TA) MnaAsN. (M, TA.)

One with whom a person is sociable. (Ḥam p. 136.) You say also, humo Oanasu fulaAnK They are they with whom such a one is sociable (Aal-aciyna yasotaOonisu Uilayohimo). (Lḥ, M.) And huwa Oanasu fulaAnK He is much accustomed to the serving of him. (Ḥar p. 472.)

entry.sense: OanasapN i. q. OunosN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A human being; a man; as also OanasiI-N↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and UinosaAnN↓. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See UinosN, in two places.

[Domestic, as opposed to wild. Ex.] HumurN Uinosiy-apN Domestic asses; asses that are accustomed to the houses: commonly known as written with kesr to the Ounosiy-apN: but in the book of Aboo-Moosà is an indication of its being with damm to the C [Oanasiy-apN]: and as some relate a trad. in which it occurs, Oanasiy-apN, which is said to be of no account. (TA.)

The left side (AZ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) of an animal, (Mṣb,) or of a beast and of a man, (M,) or of anything: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the right side: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) [but the latter seems to be a mistake:] Az says that Lth has well explained this term and its contrary waHoXiI-N, saying that the latter is the right side of every beast; and the former, the left side; agreeably with those of the first authority in sound learning; and [that] it is related of El-Mufaddal and Aṣ and AO, that all of them asserted the latter to be, of every animal except man, [the “far” side, or “off” side,] the side on which it is not milked nor mounted; and the former, [the near side,] the side on which the rider mounts and the milker milks: (TA in art. wHX:) [and the like is said, as a citation from Az, in the Mṣb in art. wHX: but after this, in my copy of the Mṣb, there seems to be an omission; for it is immediately added, “But Az says, This is not correct in my opinion:”] it is said that everything that is frightened declines to its right side; for the beast is approached to be mounted and milked on the left side, and, fearing thereat, runs away from the place of fear, which is the left side, to the place of safety, which is the right side: (Ṣ,* IAmb in Mṣb; both in art. wHX:) [accordingly,] Er-Rá'ee describes a beast as declining to the side termed AlwHXI because frightened on the left side: (Ṣ and Mṣb in art. wHX:) and 'Antarah alludes to one's shrinking with the side so termed from the whip, [which he likens to a cat,] because the whip of the rider is in his right hand: (Ṣ in art. wHX:) but Abu-l-ʼAbbás says that people differ respecting these two terms when relating to a man: that, accord. to some, they mean the same in this case as in the cases of horses and other beasts of carriage, and of camels:
but some say, that in the case of a man, the latter term means the part next the shoulder-blade; and the former, the part next the arm-pit. (TA in art.wHX.) Of every double member of a man, as the upper half of each arm, and the two fore arms, and the two feet, it means That [side] which is towards the man; and wHXI-, that which turns away from him: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or, of the foot, the former means that [side] which is towards the other foot; [i. e., the inner side;] and the latter, the contrary of the former. (TA in art. wHX.) Of a bow, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or of a Persian bow, (TA in art. wHX,) That [side] which is towards thee; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and wHXI-, the back: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wHX:) or the former, that [side] which is next to the archer; and the latter, that which is next to the animal shot at: (M, TA:) or of a bow, whether Persian or not is not said, [the former means the side against which the arrow lies; and] the latter, the side against which the arrow does not lie. (TA in art. wHX.)
OanasiI-N: see UinosN and UinosiI-N, each in two places.

UinosaAnu AlEayoni ‡ The image that is seen [reflected] in the black of the eye; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) what is seen in the eye, like as is seen in a mirror, when a thing faces it: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or the pupil, or apple, (naAZir,) of the eye: (M:) or the black (Hadaqap) of the eye: (Mṣb:) pl. OanaAsiI-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but not OunaAsN. (Ṣ.)
UinosaAniI-N: see UinosiI-N, first signification.
[UinosaAniy-apN Human nature; humanity; as also naAsuwtN, which is probably post-classical, opposed to laAhuwtN, q. v., in art. lyh.]
OanuwsN A tame, or gentle, dog; contr. of EaquwrN: pl. OunusN. (M, A, Ḳ.)
See also MnisapN.

OaniysN i. q. muWaAnisN↓ [generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, meaning, A sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, or familiar, person; a cheerful companion]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one with whom one is sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, familiar, or cheerful: (Ḳ:) a person, (A,) or anything, (Ṣ,) by whose company, or converse, or presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled. (Ṣ, A.) You say, maA biAld-aAri Oniyso (or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, mino OaniysK,) There is not in the house any one by whose company, or converse, or presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled: (A:) or there is not in the house any one. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) [See also MnisapN.]
AlOaniysu † The domestic cock; (AA, Ḳ;) also called AlX-uqaru. (TA.)

AlOaniysapu ‡ The fire; (IAạr, A, Ḳ;) as also maOonuwsapu↓, [imperfectly decl., being a proper name and of the fem. gender,] (M,) and AlmaOonuwsapu↓, (M, Ḳ,) of which [says ISd] I know no verb: (M:) because, when a man sees it in the night, he becomes cheerful and tranquil thereat, even if it be in a desert land. (TA.) You say, baAtati AlOaniysapu Oaniysatahu ‡ [The fire was during night his cheerful companion, or his cheerer by its presence]. (A, TA.)

Mnasu [More, and most, sociable,, &c.]. Hence, Mnasu mina AlHum-aI † [A closer companion than fever]: a saying of the Arabs, meaning, that fever scarcely ever quits the patient; as though it were sociable with him. (M, TA.)

jaAriyapN MnisapN A girl of cheerful mind, (Lth, A, Ḳ, TA,) whose nearness, and conversation, or discourse, thou lovest, (Lth, TA,) or whose conversation, or discourse, and nearness, are loved: (A:) or a girl of pleasant conversation or discourse; as also OanuwsN↓: (M:) and Mnisapu AlHadiyvi who becomes sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, familiar, or cheerful, by means of thy conversation or discourse: it does not mean who cheers thee [by conversation or discourse]: (Ṣ:) pl. OawaAnisu (Lth, A, TA) and MnisaAtN: (Lth, TA:) and the pl. of OanuwsN is OunusN. (M, TA.) [See also OaniysN.]
maOonasN [app. i. q. makaAnN maOonuwsN, q. v.] (A.)

muWonisN † A name which the Arabs, (Ṣ, M,) and the ancients, (M,) used to give to Thursday; (Ṣ, M;) because on that day they used to incline to places of pleasure; and ʼAlee is related to have said that God created Paradise on Thursday, and named it thus. (M, TA.)

AlmuWonisaAtu ‡ Weapons: (M, A:) or all weapons: (Ḳ:) or the spear and the migofar and the tijogaAf and the tasobigap and the turos (Fr, Ḳ) and the sword and the helmet: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) so called because they render their possessor at ease with his adversaries, and secure, or cause him to have a good opinion [of his safety, and thus, cheer him, or solace him, by their presence: see 4]. (M, A.*)
See also baAbuwnajN.

makaAnN maOonuwsN, (M,) and maHal-N maOonuwsN, (A,) [A place, and] a place of alighting or abode, in which is Ounos [i. e. sociableness,, &c.]: (A:) mOnws is a kind of possessive noun, because they did not say Oanasotu AlmakaAna, nor Oanisotuhu. (M, L.)
maOonuwsapu and AlmaOonuwsapu: see OaniysN.
muWaAnisN: see OaniysN.
AlmutaOan-isu † The lion; (TṢ, Ḳ;) as also AlmusotaOonisu↓: (TṢ, TA:) or he that is sensible of the prey from afar, (Ḳ, TA,) and examines and looks about for it. (TA.)
AlmusotaOonisu: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. Oanafahu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaOonifu} (M, Ḳ) and _u {yaOonufu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OanofN, (M,) He struck, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or hit, or hurt, (M,) his nose; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) namely, a man's. (Ṣ.)
It (the water) reached his nose, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) on the occasion of his descending into a river; (Ṣ;) as also Mnfhu↓, (Ḳ, [but in some copies written again Oanafahu,]) inf. n. UiynaAfN. (TḲ.)

Oanafati AlUibilu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) The camels trod herbage, or pasture, such as is termed Ounuf, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., which had not been pastured upon. (Ṣ.) [But in the TT, as from the M, I find MAnafa↓, (which should rather be written OaAnafa, or, accord. to the more usual mode, Mnafa,) He trod such herbage, or pasture.]
Oanifa, aor. _a {yaOonafu}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OanafN, (M,) He (a camel) had a complaint of, or suffered pain in, his nose, from the burap [or nose-ring]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) from ISk. (Ṣ.)
Oanifati AlUibilu, accord. to certain of the Kilábees, means The flies alighted upon the noses of the camels, and they sought places which they did not seek before. (T.)

Oanifa minohu, aor. _a {yaOonafu}, inf. n. OanafN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OanafapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) [He turned up his nose at it;] he disdained it; scorned it; abstained from it, or refused to do it, by reason of disdain and pride; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he disliked it, or hated it, and his soul was above it; (L;) namely, a thing: (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb:) and he shunned it, avoided it, or kept himself far from it: (Mṣb:) and he disliked it, or hated it; namely, a saying. (AZ, T, Mṣb.) You say, maAraOayotu OaHomaI OanafFA mino fulaAnK [I have not seen any one more vehemently disdainful, or scornful, than such a one]. (Ṣ.) And Hamala mino celika OanafFA He conceived, in consequence of that, disdain, or scorn, arising from indignation and anger. (TA, from a trad.) [The verb is also trans. without mn: you say,] yaOonafu Oano yuDAma [He disdains, or scorns, or refuses to bear, or to submit to, being injured]. (Ḳ.) [When immediately trans.,] Oanifa also signifies He loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust. (IAạr, T.) You say, Oanifa AlbaEiyru AlkalaOa The camel loathed, disliked, or regarded with disgust, the herbage, or pasture. (T.) And Oanfa AlT-aEaAma wagayorahu He disliked the food, &c. (M.) And Oanifato farasiI hecihi hecaA Albalada This my mare disliked this region. (T, as heard from an Arab of the desert.) And taOonafu faHolahaA She (a woman, and a mare, and a camel, being pregnant,) dislikes her male, or stallion. (T.) And Oanifato, said of a woman, signifies She, being pregnant, had no appetite for anything. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
2: see 4.

taOoniyfN also signifies † The sharpening, or making pointed, the extremity of a thing. (Ṣ.) You say of a spear-head, or an arrow-head, or a blade, Oun-if-, inf. n. taOoniyfN, (Ḳ,) † It was sharpened or pointed [at its extremity]. (TA.)
[Used as a subst.,] † Sharpness of the extremity of the hock; which, in a horse, is approved. (TA.)
Oun-ifa taOoniyfa Als-ayori, said by an Arab of the desert in describing a horse, means † He was made even, like as is made even the cut thong or strap. (M.)
† The seeking after herbage, or pasture, (Ḳ, TA,) such as is termed Ounuf. (TA.)

On-f maAlahu, (T,) or AlUibila, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above; and MnafahaA↓, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiynaAfN; (T;) † He pastured his beasts upon the first of the herbage: (T:) or he pursued, with the camels, repeatedly, or gradually, or step by step, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) after the first of the herbage, (Ṣ,) or after the herbage which had not been pastured upon: (Ḳ,* TA:) or he went with them thereto. (L.)
4. Mnfhu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiynaAfN, (Ṣ,) He, (Ṣ,) or it, (M,) made him to have a complaint of, or to suffer pain in, his nose. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
See also Oanafahu.
He, or it, induced him to feel disdain, scorn, indignation, and anger; (IF, M, Ḳ, TA;) as also An-fhu↓, inf. n. taOoniyfN: (Ḳ:) or caused him to dislike, or hate, or to loath, or feel disgust. (T.)
† He hastened it; namely, his affair. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
See also 2.
Mnf as an intrans. verb: see 1.

entry.sense: 5. tataOan-afu AlX-ahawaAti † She desires of her husband, with eagerness, one thing after another, by reason of intense longing in pregnancy. (T, the Moḥeeṭ, L, Ḳ.*)
yataOan-afu AlUixowaAna † He seeks the brethren, they disdaining, or scorning, or disliking; not holding social intercourse with any one. (TA.)

10. AstOnfhu and AYtnfhu↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytanafahu] † He took [its Oanof, i. e.,] the first of it: (M:) he began it, or commenced it: (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or i. q. Aisotaqobalahu [which has also the latter of the two significations mentioned above, (Mgh in art. qbl,) and moreover signifies he anticipated it; and from what follows here, it seems to be probable that this last signification, as well as the other, may be meant by it in this instance]: (T, M:) namely, a thing, (M, Mṣb,) or an affair. (T.) You say, AstOnfhu biwaEodK † He made him a promise in anticipation; without his asking it of him. (M.) And, of a woman, AusotuWonifato biAln-ikaAHi Oaw-alFA † [She was just married, or bedded, for the first time]. (M.) See also OunufN, last sentence.
[Hence, Harofu QsotiYonaAfK, in grammar, An inceptive particle, placed at the commencement of a new proposition grammatically independent of that which precedes it.]

OanofN a word of well-known meaning; (Lth, T, Ḳ;) The nose; syn. maEoTisN; (Mṣb;) the aggregate composed of the two nostrils and the septum and the [bone called] qaSabap, which is the hard part of the Anf; (MF;) i. q. manoxirN [which is evidently an explanation by a synecdoche, as this word properly signifies nostril]: (M:) it pertains to man and to others: (Ṣ:) OunofN↓ is a dial. var. of the same; (MF, TA;) and so is UinofN↓, which is a form used by the vulgar peculiarly: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is MnufN and MnaAfN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] OunuwfN. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The dual is applied to The two nostrils; as in the saying of Muzáhim El-'Okeylee, yasuwfu biOanofiyohi Aln-iqaAEa [He scents with his two nostrils the dust]. (TA.) You say also, huwa yatatab-aEu Oanofahu ‡ He scents, or sniffs, the odour, and follows it. (T, [in which, however, I find yatobaEu in the place of yttb-E] O, L, Ḳ, TA.) And, of a she-camel, taroOamu biOanofihiA † [She makes a show of affection with her nose, by smelling her young one; not having true love]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, voce mucaAYirN;, &c.: see also muEaAriDN.) And maAta Hatofa Oanofihi (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c., in art. Htf,) and Htf Oanofiyohi, (Ḳ ibid.,) † He died [a natural death,] on his bed, (Ḳ,) without being slain or beaten (Ṣ, Ḳ) or drowned or burned. (Ḳ. [See art. Htf]) And HamiIa Oanofuhu ‡ He became vehemently angry, or enraged; as also warima Oanofuhu. (IAth. [See also art. HmI]) And rajulN HamiI-u AlOanofi ‡ A disdainful, or scornful, man; who disdains, or scorns, being injured. (T, Ḳ, TA. [See, again, art. HmI.]) And samiI-u AlOanofi † [lit. Highnosed, signifies the same;] i. q. OanofaAnu. (T, Ḳ.) And OanofN fiI Als-amaMCi waQsotN fiI AlmaMCi † [A nose in the sky and a rump in the water]; a prov., applied to him who magnifies himself in words and is little in actions. (Ḥar p. 641.) And HaEala Oanofahu fiI qafaAhu ‡ [lit. He put his nose in the back of his neck]; meaning he turned away from the truth, or what was right, and betook himself to what was false, or vain: (Ḳ, TA:) expressing the utmost degree of turning away, or turning the head, from a thing. (TA.) And OaDaAEa maTolaba Oanofihi, (M, Ḳ,) and muwoDiEa Oanofihi, (M,) † [He neglected, or left unprotected,] the womb from which he had come forth: (Th, M:) or the faroj of his mother. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And huwa AlfaHolu laA yuqoraEu Oanofuhu, and laA yuqodaEu, He is the speaker, or orator, who is not to be rebutted. (TA.) AlOasdi Oanofu † [The nose of the lion] is the asterism called Aln-avorapu, q. v. (Ḳzw in his Description of the Mansions of the Moon.)

† [A prominent part of anything, as being likened to a nose;] the extremity of anything. (M.) [Thus,] Oanofu jabalK ‡ A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA.) Oanofu Aln-aAbi, (Ṣ, M. Ḳ, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ erroneously, AlbaAbi, (TA,) ‡ The extremity, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) or edge, (M, TA,) of the canine tooth, or tush, when it comes forth. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA.) Oanofu xuf-i AlbaEiyri † The extremity of the manosim [i. e. toe, or each of the two nails of the foot,] of the camel. (T, Ḳ.) Oanofu All-iHoyapi ‡ The fore part, (M, TA,) or side, (Ḳ,) of the beard. (M, Ḳ, TA.) Oanofu Aln-aEoli † The toe, or foremost extremity, of the sandal [also called its Oasalap and its cunaAbap]. (M.) OanofaA Alqawosi † The two extremities which are in the inner sides of the two curved ends of the bow. (M.)

† The first, or first part, of anything; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) relating also to times; (M;) as also musotaOonafN↓ (M, TA.) Thus, Oanofu AlmaroEaI † The first of the herbage, or pasture. (Ṣ,* M.) Oanofu AlmaTari † The first vegetation produced by the rain. (T, Ḳ.) jaMCa fiI Oanofi Alxayoli ‡ [He came among the first of the horses, or horsemen]. (TA.) saAra fiI Oanofi Aln-ahaAri ‡ [He journeyed in the first part of the day]. (TA.) hecaA Oanofu Eamali fulaAnK ‡ This is the first of the things which such a one has begun to do. (T, TA.) Oanofu AlX-ad-i, (T, Ṣ, M,) and AlEadowi, (M,) † The first of the run, or running: (T:) the most vehement thereof. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*) Oanofu Albarodi † The first of the cold: (T:) the most vehement thereof; (T, Ṣ, M;) so says Yaákoob. (Ṣ.)
‡ A lord, or chief. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) You say, huwa Oanofu qawomihi ‡ He is the lord, or chief, of his people. (TA.)
‡ A piece broken off of a cake of bread. (Ḳ, TA.)
† A part of ground, or land, that is hard, and lying open, exposed to the sun. (IF, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OunofN: see OanofN, first sentence:
and see OunufN.

entry.sense: UinofN: see OanofN, first sentence.

hom.sense: OanifN A camel having a complaint of, or suffering pain in, his nose, from the burap [or nose-ring]: (ISk, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or wounded by the nose-rein, whether it be with a xiXaAX or burap (AʼObeyd, T, M) or xizaAmap [all of which are different kinds of nose-rings]. (AʼObeyd, T.) And consequently, Submissive, and tractable: (Ṣ, TA:) or submissive and obedient, that dislikes chiding and beating, and goes as he is able to do spontaneously and easily: (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA:) and MnifN↓ signifies the same; (AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ;) but the former is the more correct and the more chaste: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) by rule, it should be maOonuwfN, like maSoduwrN, (T, Ṣ, M,) and maboTuwnN. (T, Ṣ.) To such a camel, the believer is likened in a trad.; (T, Ṣ, M;) because he ceases not to complain, or suffer pain; (M;) or because he does not require to be chidden nor to be punished, but endures and performs what is incumbent on him. (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA.)
Disdaining, or disdainful; scorning, or scornful; i. q. HamiI-u AlOanofi: and OanofaAnu↓ [signifies the same;] i. q. samiI-u AlOanofi. (T, Ḳ.)
See also MnifN.

entry.sense: rawoDapN OunufN ‡ A meadow of new herbage, (Mṣb,) not pastured upon (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) by any one; (Ṣ;) as also muWonifN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) or untrodden: contracted, by poetic licence, into OunofN↓, in a verse of Abu-n-Nejm. (M.) And kalaON OunufN † Herbage not pastured upon (Ṣ, M) by any one. (M.)

kaOosN QnufN † A cup of wine not drunk: (Ḳ:) or from which one has not drunk before; as though the drinking thereof were [but just] begun; like rawoDapN OunufN: (Ṣ) or † full: and in like manner, manohalN OunufN † [a full watering-place]; (M;) or ‡ not before drunk from. (TA.) And xamorN OunufN ‡ Wine of which none has before been taken from its jar. (M, TA.*)
OaroDN OunufN i. q. OaniygapN, q. v. (M, TA.)
naqiycapN OunofN † A long [as though new and undiminished] coat of mail. (L in art. nqc, from El-Mufaddal.)
OamorN OunufN † An event brought to pass at the first, not being before decreed: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to those who assert that there is no decreeing [by God]. (TA.)
miXoyapN OunufN † A goodly [as though novel] gait, or manner of walking. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

Mtiyka mino ciI OunufK is like the phrase mino ciI qabalK; i. e., fiymaA yusotaqobalN [I will come to thee in what is (now) to be begun (of time); meaning, immediately; nearly the same as MnifFA, but relating to the nearest future time, whereas this latter relates to the nearest past time]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And OafoEalu caAka mino ciI OunufK: i. e., fiymaA yusotaOonafu↓ [I will do that in what is (now) to begun, &c.]; like mino ciI EawoDK. (Ḳ in art. EwD.)

Oanofapu AlS-alaApi † The beginning, or commencement, of prayer; (Ḳ;) i. e. the first saying of Aall-ehu Oakobaru: (TA:) accord. to a relation of a trad., in which it occurs, with damm, [Ounofap,] (IAth, Ḳ,) but correctly with fet-ḥ. (Hr, IAth, Ḳ.) The p seems to be here added to Oanof as it is in canabapN for canabN. (Ṣgh.)
OanafapN Disdain; scorn; disdainful and proud incompliance or refusal; (Mṣb;) indignation; and anger: (TA:) a subst. [or, accord. to the Ṣ and M and Ḳ, an inf. n.] from Oanifa minohu. (Mṣb.)
OanofaAnu: see OanifN.
Oanofiy-apN Snuff, for the nose: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

OanuwfN A man very disdainful, scornful, or indignant; very disdainfully and proudly incompliant or refusing; (M;) who disdains, or scorns, exceedingly, to do ignoble deeds: (Ḥar p. 312:) pl. OunufN. (M.)
A woman whose nose has a pleasant odour: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or whom one likes to smell: (IAạr, M:) or who disdains, scorns, abstains from, shuns, or dislikes, that in which is no good. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OaniyfN † A mountain which produces vegetation before other regions. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And OaroDN OaniyfapN, (T, M,) or Oaniyfapu Aln-aboti, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † Land that produces its vegetation early: (T:) or that produces vegetation quickly: (Eṭ-Ṭáee, ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that produces vegetation; as also OunufN↓. (M.)
Applied to iron, i. q. Oaniyvu; i. e. Soft. (Aboo-Turáb, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: OunaAfiI-N (with damm, Ḳ) Having a large nose; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (M, Ḳ:) similar to EuDaAd-iIN and OucaAniI-N. (TA.)

hom.sense: Mnafu [More, and most, disdainful,, &c.]. You say, maA raOayotu Mnafa mino fulaAn I have not seen any one more disdainful, or scornful, or indignant, than such a one. (Ṣ, TA.)
hecihi Mnafu bilaAdi Qll-ehi This is the speediest, in producing vegetation, of the countries of God. (T, Ṣ,* M,* Ḳ.*)
MnifN: see OanifN.

MnifFA means † In the beginning, or first part, of this present time in which we are; from OanofN as meaning the “first,” or “first part,” of a thing: and hence what here immediately follows. (Ḥam p. 348.) maA caA qaAla MnifFA, (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,*, &c.,) and OanifFA↓, (IAạr, Bḍ, Ḳ, Jel,) in the Ḳur [xlvii. 18], (M, &c.,) means ‡ What was this that he said just now? (Zj, T, M, Bḍ, Jel:) or, a little while ago? (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) i. e., in the first time near to us? (Zj, T, M:) from AisotaOonafotu AlX-aIoCa “I began the thing.” (Zj, T, M.) You say also, Oatayotu fulaAnFA MnifFA ‡ [I came to such a one a little while ago]; like as you say, mino ciI qibalK. (Lth, T.) And jaMCa MnifFA ‡ He came a little while ago; syn. qubayola. (M.) And faEalahu biMnifapK↓, mentioned by IAạr, but not explained by him; in my opinion, [says ISd,] like faEalahu MnifFA ‡ [He did it a little while ago: or just now]. (M.) And it is said in a trad., Ounozilato Ealay-a suwrapN MnifFA A chapter of the Ḳur-án has been sent down to me now. (TA.)

entry.sense: MnifapN ‡ The first part of life (mayoEap and Oaw-aliy-ap) of a boy. (Ks, Ḳ, TA.)
See also MnifN.
muWonifN: see OunufN.

hom.sense: muWan-afN † Sharpened at its extremity; or pointed; (M, Ḳ;) applied to a spear-head, or an arrowhead, or a blade, (Ḳ,) or anything. (M.)
† Made even: a thong, or strap, made of a certain measure, and evenly. (M.)
The former of these two epithets, applied to a woman, signifies † Just married or bedded, (Al-atiI QsotuWonifato biAln-ikaAHi,) for the first time. (M.)

entry.sense: maOonuwfN A camel that is urged on by [means of the rein attached to] his nose. (M.)

miYonaAfN † A man who begins to make use of the places of pasturing and alighting; (M;) who pastures his beasts upon the first of the herbage. (Aṣ, T, Ḳ.* [In the CK, Aunufu AlkalaOi is put for Oanofa AlkalaOi.])

† A man (TA) journeying in the beginning, or first part, of the night: (Ḳ:) so in all the copies of the Ḳ; but correctly, as in the Moḥeeṭ and the O, in the beginning, or first part, of the day. (TA.)
jaAriyapN muWotanafapu AlX-abaAbi † A girl [in the prime of youth;] in whom no trace of agedness appears. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mutaOan-ifN: see muWotanafN.
musotaOonafN: see OanofN, in the latter part of the paragraph.
1. Oaniqa, aor. _a {yaOonaqu}, inf. n. OanaqN, It excited admiration and approval by its beauty or goodliness; it pleased, or rejoiced. (Mṣb.)

Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He rejoiced; was joyful, happy, or pleased. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Oaniqotu bihi, (Lth, JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Lth, JK,) I was pleased with it, or by it; or was rejoiced by it. (Lth, JK, Mṣb, Ḳ. [In the CK AaEojaba is erroneously put for OuEojiba.]) It is said in a trad., maA mino EaAXiyapK OaXad-u OanaqFA walaA OaboEadu XibaEFA mino TaAlibi EilomK There is not any eater by night [i. e. any man] who hath more pleasure and approval and desire and love [in his pursuit, nor any who is further from satiation therein, than the student, or pursuer, of science]; meaning that the man of learning is excessively greedy and insatiable, persevering in vehement desire. (L.)
And Oanaqa AlX-aIoCa, (AZ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (AZ,) He loved the thing. (AZ, Ḳ.)
2. On-q, inf. n. taOoniyqN, He made, or caused, to wonder. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. MnaqaniI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyonaAqN and niyqN, (Ḳ,) [but the latter is properly a quasi-inf. n.,] It excited my admiration and approval; pleased me; or rejoiced me. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
maA Mnaqahu fiI kacaA How vehemently does he seek, or pursue, or desire, such a thing! or how vehement is he in seeking, pursuit, or desire, with respect to such a thing! (JK, Ḳ.)

5. tOn-q He sought, pursued, or desired, the most pleasing of things; (TA;) [he affected nicety, or refinement; he was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or chose what was excellent, or best; and he exceeded the usual bounds; as also tanaw-aqa and tanay-aqa, in all these senses;] fiI AlmaToEami, in respect of food, never eating anything but what was clean [and choice]; and fiI Almalobasi, in respect of apparel, never dressing otherwise than well; and fiI AlkalaAmi, in respect of speech, never speaking otherwise than chastely; and fiI jamiyEi AlOumuwri, in respect of all affairs. (TA in art. nTs.) tOn-q fiyhi is like tanaw-aqa; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. He did it, or performed it (namely, a thing, or an affair,) with niyqap [i. e. daintiness, nicety, exquisiteness, refinement, neatness, or scrupulous nicety and exactness; or in a manner exceeding what is usual]: (Ṣ:) or he chose what was excellent, or best, to be done in it, and did it admirably: (TA:) or he did it (namely, his work, Mṣb) firmly, solidly, soundly, or thoroughly, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and skilfully. (Ḳ: [but in this last sense, ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh allows only the latter of these two verbs. TA in art. nwq.]) You say also, tOn-q fulaAnN fiI Al-ar-awoDapi Such a one found himself in the meadow, or garden, (waqaEa fiyhaA,) pleased, or rejoiced, therewith: (Ṣ:) or he found it pleasant or delightful, delighted in it, or took pleasure or delight in it, and enjoyed its beauties: and he sought after its beauties, step by step, and was pleased, or rejoiced, therewith, and enjoyed it. (TA.) And tOn-q AlmakaAna He was pleased, or rejoiced, with the place, and attached to it, not quitting it: (L:) he loved the place. (Fr, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-Mesʼood, UicaA waqaEotu fiI Mli HLmL waqaEotu fiI rawoDaAtK OataOan-aquhun-a, or, as in the T, OataOan-aqu fiyhin-a, meaning [When I find myself in the chapters of the Ḳur-án commencing with Há Meem,] I find myself in meadows, or gardens, the beauties of which I seek after step by step, and with which I am pleased, or rejoiced, and which I enjoy: i. e., I find pleasure, or delight, in reading them, or reciting them, and enjoy their beauties. (TA.)
OanaqN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.] (Lth, JK, &c.)

[Hence, A pleasing, or rejoicing, state, or condition.] You say, huwa fiI OanaqK mino EayoXihi waxiSobK [He is in a pleasing, or rejoicing, state, or condition, in respect of his life, and in a state of plenty]. (JK.)

Goodliness, or beauty, and pleasingness, of aspect, or outward appearance: or, as some say, a uniform and uninterrupted state of verdure before the eye; because it pleases, or rejoices, its beholder. (TA.)
Herbage, or pasturage, (Ḳ, TA,) that is goodly, or beautiful, and pleasing, or rejoicing: an inf. n. used as a subst. (TA.)
OaniqN: see OaniyqN.
maA lahu fiI AlX-aIoCi OaniqapN He has no pleasure, or pride, in the thing. (JK.)

OanuwqN A certain bird; (Ṣ;) i. e. the raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus]; (IAạr, Ṣ;) called by Kumeyt caAtu Qsomayoni [possessor of two names] because having these two appellations: (Ṣ:) or the eagle: and also the former bird: (Ḳ:) ISk cites 'Omárah as saying that it is in his opinion the eagle; but that people say it is the rxmp; and he adds, [alluding to a prov., which see below,] that the eggs of the rxmp are found in ruins, and in plain country: (TA:) or the male of the raxam: (JK, TA:) or a certain black bird, having what resembles the Eurof [or comb of the cock], (AA, Ḳ,) that deposits its eggs in remote places: (AA:) or a certain black bird, (AA, Ḳ,) like a great hen, (AA,) bald in the fore part of the head, (AA, Ḳ,) having a yellow bill, (Ḳ,) or having a long bill: (AA:) she guards her eggs, and defends her young one, and keeps with her offspring, and submits not herself to any but her mate, and migrates among the first of the migrating birds, and returns among the first of the returning birds, and will not fly while moulting, and will not be deceived by her small feathers but waits until they become quills and then flies, and will not remain constantly in the nests, and will not alight upon the quiver (Ḳ) knowing it to contain arrows: (TA:) the word is sing. and pl.: (TA:) or its pl. is OunuqN. (JK.) Hence the prov., (JK, Ṣ,) OaEaz-u mino bayoDi AlOanuwqi [More rare than the eggs of the anook]: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) because this bird guards its eggs, so that they are hardly ever, or never, found; for its nests are on the tops of mountains, and in difficult and distant places; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) notwithstanding which, it is said to be stupid: (Ṣ:) ISd says that the female bird called rxmp may be meant thereby; or the male, because the eggs of the male exist not; or the eggs of the latter may be meant because he often guards them, like as does the male ostrich. (TA.)

OaniyqN Goodly, or beautiful; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) pleasing, or rejoicing; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also OanaqN↓: (JK, TA:) and loved. (TA.) You say, rawoDapN OaniyqN A meadow, or garden, that is loved: and rawoDapN OaniyqapN a meadow, or garden, that is pleasing, or rejoicing. (TA.)

lahu UinaAqapN and OanaAqapN (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) He has goodliness, or beauty, and pleasingness: but in the L, [and in some copies of the Ṣ,] lahu UinaAqapN walabaAqpN; and what precedes it indicates that the meaning is he has a faculty of doing well or excellently [and of nice or refined skilfulness]. (TA.)
Mnaqu [originally OOonaqu] More, or most, pleasing or rejoicing. (TA.)

mutaOan-iqN [part. n. of 5; Seeking, pursuing, or desiring, the most pleasing of things; affecting nicety, or refinement; dainty, nice, exquisite, refined,, &c.; in respect of food, apparel, speech, &c.:] one who is in a pleasing condition (fiI OanaqK) in respect of his life, and in a state of plenty. (JK.) It is said in a prov., layosa AlmutaEal-iqu kaAlmutaOan-iqi, (JK, TA,) i. e. He who is content with what is little, (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. Elq,) or what is barely sufficient, of sustenance, (TA in the present art.,) is not like him who seeks, pursues, or desires, the most pleasing of things, or who is dainty,, &c., (mano yataOan-aqu,) and eats what he pleases, (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. Elq,) or him who is not content save with the most pleasing of things. (TA in the present art.)

MnukN pure raSaAS [or lead]: or black riSiAS: (Mṣb:) i. q. Ousorub-u; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. raSaASN qaloEiI-N; so says Ḳṭ; and Az says, I think it is an arabicized word: (TA:) or white Asrb-: or black Asrb-: or pure Asrb-: (Ḳ:) or i. q. qazodiyrN [which is applied in the present day to tin, and pewter]: (Kr:) El-Kásim Ibn-Maan says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, hecaA raSaASN MnukN, i. e. [this is] pure [lead]: (TA:) it is of the measure OafoEulN, [originally OaOonukN,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is one of the forms of pls., (Ṣ,) like OafolusN; (Mṣb;) and there is no other word of this measure, (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ,) among sing. nouns, (Az, Ṣ,) except OaXud-N [originally OaXodudN], (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and MjurN in the dial. of those who pronounce it without teshdeed: (Ṣgh:) it is disputed, however, whether OaXud-N be a sing. or a pl.: (Az, TA:) [and as to MjurN, see what follows:] or, accord. to some, (Mṣb,) MnukN is of the measure faAEulN, (Kr, Mṣb,) and is the only word of that measure in Arabic: (Kr:) or it is a foreign word; and so are MjurN and [the proper names] Mmulu and kaAbulu. (Mṣb.) It is said, in a trad., that he who listens to a singing female slave, Mnuk shall be poured into his ears (Ṣ, TA) on the day of resurrection. (TA.)

AlOanaAmu (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and AlMnaAmu↓ (Ḳ) and AlOaniymu↓, (M, Ḳ,) the last allowable in poetry, (M,) i. q. Alxaloqu; (M, Ḳ, and Bḍ and Jel in lv. 9;) i. e. [Mankind; for such is the general meaning of Alxaloqu, or] mankind and the jinn (or genii) and others: (Jel ubi suprà:) or the jinn and mankind: (T, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or what are on the face of the earth of all that are termed Alxaloq [or created beings]: (Lth, T, Mṣb:) or all that is on the face of the earth: (Ḳ:) or everything having a ruwH [i. e. soul, or spirit]: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) or every one who is subject to sleep. (TA [as though it were derived from Aln-awomu.]) AlAnAm is not mentioned by J, though occurring in the Ḳur-án. (TA.)
AlOaniymu: see above.
AlMnaAmu: see above.
Uin-amaA: see Uin-a, in art. An.
UinowN: see UinoIN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. OanaI, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yaOoniI, (Ṣ,) inf. n. UinNI (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OanoIN and OanaMCN, (M, Ḳ,) or, accord. to [some of the copies of] the M, OanFI, (TA, [in which this is said to be the right form,]) or OanFA, (as written in the CK,) said of a thing, Its time came; or it was, or became, or drew, near; syn. OataI waqotuhu, and jaMCa OanaAhu; (Bḍ lvii. 15 [in explanation of a passage cited voce Oano];) or HaAna: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or OanaI, aor. yaOoniI, inf. n. OanoIN, signifies it was, or became, or drew, near; and it was, or became, present. (Mṣb.) You say, OanaI laka Oano tafoEala, aor. yaOoniI; and Mna, aor. yaYiynu; and naAla lk, aor. yaniylu; and OanaAla; all meaning HaAna laka [The time has come, or has drawn near, for thee that thou shouldst do such a thing: or the time of thy doing such a thing has come to thee: or thy doing such a thing has drawn near]: so says Zj; and Fr says the like: but the best of these is OanaI laka. (T.) And OanaI Alr-aHiylu The time of departure came, or drew near; syn. HaAna waqotuhu. (TA, from a trad.)

It came, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time or state; to maturity, or ripeness; it became mature, or ripe; (T, Ṣ, M, IAmb,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) or, accord. to some, only when said of a plant; (M, Ḳ;) [or it signifies also] it became thoroughly cooked. (T, Mṣb.*) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 53], gayoranaAZiriyna UinaAhu Not waiting, or watching, for its becoming thoroughly cooked; or for its cooking becoming finished. (T, Ṣ,* M.) [See also UinFI, below.] You say also, OanaI AlHamiymu, (inf. n. OanoIN, TA,) The hot water became heated to the utmost degree. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And OanaI AlmaMCu The water became hot to the utmost degree. (M.)

OanaI, aor. OuniI-N, inf. n. OanoIN, It (a thing) was, or became, behind, or after, its time: (Lth, T:) or OanaI, inf. n. OuniI-N, it, or he, (a man, TA,) was, or became, behind, backward, or late; it, or he, delayed, or held back; (M, Ḳ;) as also OaniIa, aor. yaOonaI, inf. n. UinFI; and Oan-aI↓, inf. n. taOoniyapN. (Ḳ.)
See also 5, in two places.
2: see 4, in two places:
and see 1.

You say also, Oan-ayotu fiI AlX-aIoCi I fell short, or fell short of what was requisite or what I ought to have done, or flagged, or was remiss, in, or in respect of, the thing. (TA. [The verb is there written without any syll. signs; but the context seems to indicate that it is as above.])

4. MnI and On-I↓ signify the same. (IAạr, T, M.) You say, MnaAhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with medd, (Mṣb,) aor. yuWoniyhi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. UiynaMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [in the CK, Aanayotuhu AinoyFA is erroneously put for Mnayotuhu UiynaMCN,] He postponed it, put it off, deferred it, delayed it, retarded it; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) retrained it, withheld it, impeded it; (Ṣ, TA;) whatever the thing be. (T.)
And Oan-ayotu↓ AlT-aEaAma fiI Aln-aAri I kept the food long upon the fire. (TA.) And laA tuWoni furoSataka Postpone not thou, or defer not, thine opportunity, or the time when thou art able to do a thing. (T.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the prayer of Friday, raOayotuka Mnayota waMcayota (M,* Mgh,* TA) I see thee to have delayed coming, and to have done what is annoying to others by stepping over the necks [of those already in their places in the mosque]: (Aṣ, Mgh,* TA:) a saying of ʼOmar. (Mgh.)

MnaAhu also signifies He made him, or it, to be distant, remote, or far off; removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it; like OanoMhu [from which it is formed by transposition]. (TA.) [Hence,] yuWoniyka occurs in a verse of Es-Sulameeyeh; (M, TA;) meaning yunoYiyka; the C being put before the n (M.)

entry.sense: 5. tOn-I He acted deliberately, or leisurely, not hastily; as also AstOnI↓; and OaniIa↓, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yaOonaI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. OnoIN: (TA:) he acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; and with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness; fiI AlOamori in the affair; as also AstOnI↓: (Mgh:) or he acted gently; (IAạr, T, TA;) as also OaniIa↓, aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) or he acted gently, and waited; fiI AlOamori in the affair: (Ṣ:) or he waited, or was patient, or waited with patience, (T, Mṣb,) and did not hasten, in an affair. (Mṣb.) Alt-aOat-iI and Alt-aOan-iI are nearly syn.: you say, tOn-I lahu He acted gently with him, [or to him,] and did not hasten in his affair. (Mgh.) You say also, AstOnI↓ bihi He waited patiently with him; or waited, and had patience, with him; (Ṣ, TA;) he did not hasten him; (Lth, T;) as also AstOnAhu↓. (ʼEyn, Ḥar p. 67.) And AusotuWoniIa↓ bihi HawolFA [He was waited patiently with for a year]. (Ṣ.) And AisotaOoni↓ fiI Oamorika Hasten not in thine affair. (Lth, T.) And AisotaOonayotu↓ fiI AlT-aEaAmi I waited for the food to become perfectly prepared or cooked. (Ḥar p. 67.) And taOan-ayotu Alr-ajula (and Ealayohi, M and Ḳ in art. nZr, [see AinotaZarahu,]) I waited for the man; as also AisotaOonayotu↓ bihi: whence, yusotaOnaI↓ biAlojiraAHaAti One should wait for the issues, or consequences, or results, of wounds. (Mgh.) And taOn-ayotuka Hat-aI laA OanaApa biI [I have waited patiently for thee until there is no disposition to wait patiently in me]. (Ṣ.)
10: see 5, passim.
OanoIN: see what next follows.

UinoIN (AO, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UinFI↓, (Akh, T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) the latter in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written OanaMCN, (TA,) [and in other copies of the same omitted,] and UinowN↓, (Akh, Th, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with w substituted for I, (AAF, M,) and OanoIN↓ (Ḳ) and OanFI↓, (M, IAmb,) An hour, or a short portion, or a time, or an indefinite time, (saAEapN,) of the night: (Zj, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a time or season (waqotN) of the night: (M in art. Anw:) or i. q. wahonN [the period about midnight; or the time after an hour, or a short period, of the night; or when the night is departing]: (M, Ḳ:) or any saAEap [i. e. hour, or short portion, or time,] (M, Ḳ) of the night: (M:) [and any period of time; as will be seen below:] or, accord. to some, (M,) UinFI↓ signifies the whole day; (M, Ḳ;) as also OanFI↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. is MnaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OunI-N and UiniI-N. (M, Ḳ.) You say, maDaI UinoIN mina Al-ayoli and UinowN↓ [&c.] A time, or season, [&c.,] (waqotN, [&c.,]) of the night passed: (M in art. Anw:) dual UinoyaAni and UinowaAni. (Ṣ.) And a poet says,
Oatam-ato HamolahaA fiI baEoDi XahorK
waHamolu AlHaAmalaAti UnFI Tawiylu
[She completed her gestation in a portion of a month; but the gestation of the pregnant in general is a long period of time]. (IAạr, T.) Another uses the phrase DaH-aAku AlOuniIo, occurring at the end of a verse, [for DH-Ak AlOuniI-i,] meaning Found to be laughing whenever one comes to him. (M.)

hom.sense: OanFI: see UinoIN, in two places.

The utmost point, reach, or degree, (M, Ḳ,) of a thing; (M;) as also UinFI↓: so in the phrase, balaga OanaAhu and UinaAhu It (a thing, M) attained its utmost point, reach, or degree: (M, Ḳ:) or this means, [or, accord. to the CK, “and” it means,] its state of being thoroughly cooked; its state of maturity; or its full, or final, time or state. (Ḳ.) [See 1, where an ex. from the Ḳur xxxiii. 53 is cited. Both words are said to be inf. ns.]
See also OanaApN.

entry.sense: UinFI: see UiniIN, in two places:
and see OanFI.

OanaMCN [Postponement; a putting off; a deferring; a delaying; a retarding: restraint; a withholding; an impeding:] a subst. from MnaAhu, aor. yuWoniyhi, inf. n. UiynaMCN, meaning “he postponed it,”, &c.: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA:) the context of the Ḳ erroneously requires it to be understood as a subst. from OanaI, aor. yaOonI. (TA.)

UinaMCN A certain thing of which one makes use, (M,) well known; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a vessel, or receptacle, (Mgh, Mṣb,) for water [&c.]: (Mgh:) pl. MniyapN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally OaOoniyapN; (M;) and OawaAnK; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) the former a pl. of pauc.; and the latter a pl. of mult., (Mgh,) pl. of MniyapN. (T, Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: OanaApN Moderation; gentleness; deliberateness; a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment,, &c.; patience, as meaning contr. of hastiness: and gravity; staidness; sedateness; calmness: a subst. from taOan-aI; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) syn. tuWadapN; (T;) and rifoqN; (Ḥam p. 317;) and HilomN and waqaArN; (M, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also OnFI↓. (M, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, kAlAanoIi is erroneously put for kaAlOanaI.])

Also Hope: [in this sense, accord. to the TA, written with kesr; but this is doubtless a mistake, probably occasioned by a mistranscription:] so in the charge of 'Orweh to his sons; yaA baniI-a UicaA raOayotumo xal-apF raAYiEapF mino rajulK falaA taqoTaEuwA OanaAtakumo mitohu waUino kaAna Einoda Aln-aAsi rajula saWoCK [O my sons, when ye see a quality exciting admiration and approval, in a man, cut not ye off your hope of him, though he be in the estimation of the people a bad man]. (M.)

A woman in whom is a languor on the occasion of rising, or standing up; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and a gentle, or grave, deportment: (Ṣ:) or in whom is a languor impeding from rising, or standing up: (Aṣ:) and wahonaAnapN signifies the like: (T:) Sb says that it is originally wanaApN, like as OaHadN is originally waHadN; from AlwanaI: (Ṣ:) the people of El-Koofeh say that it is only wanaApN: so says Lth: and he says that OanaApN signifies, as applied to a woman, blessed, prospered, or abounding in good, as it is explained also by ADk, and forbearing, gentle, grave, staid, sedate, or calm, and compliant, or agreeing with another in mind or opinion: and the pl. is OanawAtN: or, as some say, it signifies a grave, staid, sedate, or calm, woman, who does not clamour, nor utter foul language. (T.)

OaniI-N, as part. n. of 1, A thing of which the time has come, or drawn near: and which has come, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time or state; to maturity, or ripeness: but accord. to some, only applied to a plant. (M, Ḳ.) [Compare MnK.]

entry.sense: Uiniyho a word expressive of disapproval, and of deeming a thing remote or improbable: Sb relates that it was said to an Arab of the desert, who had taken up his abode in a town, or place, “Wilt thou go forth when the desert shall have become plentiful in herbage?” and he said, OaOanaA Uiniyho [What, I, indeed?], meaning “Do ye say this to me when I am know to do thus?” as though he disapproved of their questioning him: but there is much diversity of opinion respecting this word: (TA:) [accord. to some,] it is composed of the redundant Uino and the meddeh denoting disapproval [followed by the h of silence]. (Mughnee voce UinN.) [See what is said of the redundant Ano in the present work.]

Oan-aI signifies Whence? syn. mino Oayona; (T, Ṣ, M;) being an interrogative respecting the direction, or quarter, from which a thing is: (Mṣb:) and whence [used to denote a condition]: (TA:) and where? and where [used to denote a condition]; syn. Oayona: (T, Ḳ: [in which latter the first signification is not mentioned:]) and as one of the adverbial nouns used to denote a condition, whencesoever; from whatever direction or quarter: (Ṣ:) and wherever; wheresoever: (Lth, T:) and when? and when [used to den a condition]; syn. mataI: (T, Ḳ: [but in the latter of these, in art. An, in the place of mataI we find Hayovu, which I regard as a mistake:]) and how? syn. kayofa: (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and however. (Lth, TA.)
[I mention all these significations together because one of them is assigned by some authorities and another by others to An-I in one and the same instance.] You say, Oan-aI yakuwnu hecaA Whence, from what direction or quarter, from what way, will, or should, be this? (Mṣb.) And Oan-aI laka hecaA Whence [came, or cometh,] to thee this? (Ṣ.) It is said in the Ḳur [iii. 32], yaA maroyamu Oan-aI laki hecaA O Mary, whence [came] to thee this? (T.) And in the same [xxxiv. 51], waOan-aI lahumu Qlt-anaAwuXu mino makaAnK baEiydK, meaning [But] whence [shall the attaining of belief be possible to them from a distant place, i. e., (as explained in the Ṣ in art. nwX,) in the world to come, when they have disbelieved in the present world? or but how, &c.?]. (T.) And in the same [1xxx. 25], accord. to one reading, Oan-aI SababonaA AlmaMCa Sab-aA, meaning Where have we poured forth the water, pouring? but in this is an allusion to the direction [whence the rain comes]; and it may be rendered whence?, &c.; and accord. to this reading, the pause upon TaEaAmihN [immediately preceding] is complete. (IAmb, T.) And you say, Oan-aI taOotiniI Mtika, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning Whencesoever, or from whatever direction or quarter, thou shalt come to me, I will come to thee. (Ṣ.) In the saying of 'Alkameh,
wamuToEamu Algunomi yuwoma Algunomi muToEamuhu
Oan-aI tawaj-aha waAlmaHoruwmu maHoruwmu
the meaning is, [And he who is given spoil to enjoy, (lit., who is fed therewith,) on the day of spoil, is given it to enjoy] wherever he repairs, or however he repairs, [and the prohibited is prohibited.] (Lth, T, TA.) The saying in the Ḳur [iii. 159], qulotumN Oan-aI hecaA means Ye say, When is this? or How is this? (T,) or Whence is this? (T, Bḍ, Jel.) And Oan-aI XYotumo, in the same, [ii. 223,] may mean Whence, or when, or how, ye will. (TA.) You say also, Oan-aI laka Oano tafotaHa AlHiSona, meaning How [is it, or will it be, possible for thee to open, or conquer, the fortress]? (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: MnK Hot, or heated, to the utmost degree: applied to hot water, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur lv. 44: (Ṣ, M:) fem. MniyapN; occurring in the Ḳur lxxxviii. 5. (M.)
See also OaniI-N.

Also A man much characterized by moderation, gentleness, or deliberateness; by a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment, &c.; by patience, as meaning contr. of hastiness; by gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: Oatayotuhu MniyapF baEoda MniyapK is a phrase mentioned by AAF, meaning I came to him time after time: in which, [says ISd,] I am of opinion that Mnyp is of the measure faAEilapN from AlUnaI: but the word commonly known is Mwinap [pl. of OawaAnN; or Myinap, which is syn. with Mwinap: see OawaAnN]. (M.)
Uiniyho: see art. AnI.

1. Oah-a, (Ṣ in art. Awh, and Ḳ,) inf. n. Oap-N (Ḳ) and Oah-apN (Ṣ,* Ḳ) and the same without teshdeed; (Ḳ,* TA; [app. meaning MhapN, which, however, belongs to art. Awh, q. v.;]) or Uih-apN; (so in the CK; [but in some copies of the Ḳ, and Oah-aha↓, as in the TḲ, where it is said that the inf. n. of this form of the verb is taOohiyhN;]) and tOh-h↓; (Ḳ;) [i. q. Mha and Oaw-aha and taOahiyhN; or] He expressed pain or grief or sorrow, or he lamented or complained or moaned, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as one in an evil state, and broken in spirit by grief or mourning, and said Mhi, or haAho. (Ḳ.) [See a verse cited in art. Awh, voce MhapN.]
2: see 1.
5: see 1.
Uiho, i. e. Ui with the h of pausation; imperative of waOaI, q. v. (Mughnee in art. Alf)
Mhi and MhK and MhFA, &c.: see art. Awh.

2. Oh-bhu liloOamori, [inf. n. taOohiybN,] He furnished, prepared, equipped, or accoutred, him, for the thing, or affair; he furnished him, or provided him, with the apparatus, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like, proper, or necessary, for it. (MF.)
Oh-b AlOamora He prepared the thing, or affair. (MF.)
See also 5.

5. tOh-b He furnished, prepared, equipped, or accoutred, himself; furnished, or provided, himself with proper, or necessary, apparatus, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) lils-afari for journeying; (Mṣb;) or liloOamori for the thing, or affair; as also Oh-b↓. (Ḳ.)
OahabN: see UihaAbN.

OuhobapN Apparatus, equipments, equipage, accoutrements, furniture, gear, tackling, implements, instruments, tools, or the like; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as in Ouhobapu AlHarobi [the apparatus, arms, weapons, equipage, or accoutrements, of war]; (Ṣ;) as also hubapN: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former, OuhabN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, Oaxaca licelika AlOamori Ouhobathu [He took his apparatus, &c., for that thing, or affair; also meaning, he made his preparation, or he prepared himself, for it]. (TA.)

UihaAbN A skin, or hide, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in an absolute sense, (A,) of a bull or cow, sheep or goat, or wild animal: (TA:) or a skin, or hide, not yet tanned: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and sometimes applied to the skin of a man: (Mṣb:) pl. (of pauc., TA) MhibapN (IAạr, Ḳ) and (of mult., TA) OuhubN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with two dammehs, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and OhabN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) contr. to rule, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or, accord. to Sb, (L,) this last is a quasi-pl. n.: (Mgh, L:) in one copy of the Ḳ, it is written Mhub. (TA.) You say, jaAEuwA Hat-aI OakaluwA AlOuhuba [They hungered so that they ate the skins, or hides]. (A.) And kaAda yaxoruju mino UihaAbihi fiI Eadowihi † [He almost issued from his skin in his running]. (A.) And Haqana Ald-imaMCa fiI OuhubihaA † [He spared the people's blood in their bodies]. (TA, from a trad.)
1. Oahala, aor. _u {yaOohulu}, inf. n. OuhuwlN; (Mṣb;) or Ouhila, like EuniIa; (Ḳ, TA;) It (a place, Mṣb, TA) was, or became, peopled, or inhabited. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)

Oahala, aor. _u {yaOohulu} and _i {yaOohilu}, inf. n. as above, He married, or took a wife; (Yoo, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tOh-l↓; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Qt-ahala↓, [written with the disjunctive alif Ait-ahala, like Qt-axaca and Qt-azara and Qtamana, &c.], (Ḳ,) of the measure AftEl. (TA.)

Oahala; (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb;) or Oahila, aor. _a {yaOohalu}; (Ḳ;) or both; (JK;) bihi, (JK,) i. e. biAlr-ajuli, (Ks, Ṣ,) or biAlX-aIoCi; (Mṣb;) i. q. Oanisa [He was, or became, sociable, companionable, friendly, amicable, or familiar, with him, i. e. the man; or he was, or became, cheered, or gladdened, by his company or converse, or by his, or its (the thing's) presence]. (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

2. Oh-l bihi, (Ḳ,) or Oh-lhu, (Ḥam p. 184,) inf. n. taOohiylN (Ḥam, Ḳ,) He said to him OaholFA: (Ḥam:) or he said to him maroHabFA waOaholFA: (Ḳ:) like raH-aba bihi: (TA:) [see OaholN:] IB says that [the first pers. of] the aor. of this verb is with fet-ḥ to the h [contr. to rule: a strange assertion]. (TA.)

Oh-lhu licelika, inf. n. as above; and Mhlhu↓; He saw him, judged him, thought him, or held him, to be worthy, or deserving, of that; to merit it; to have a right, or just title or claim, to it: (Ḳ,* TA:) or he made him to be worthy, or deserving, of that;, &c. (TA.) You say, Oah-alaka Qll-ehu liloxayori [May God make thee worthy, or deserving, of good, good fortune, prosperity, or the like]. (Ṣ.)

4. Mhalaka Qll-ehu fiI Aljan-api, inf. n. UiyhaAlN, May God make thee to enter with thy wife into Paradise: (AZ, Ṣ, TA:) or may God make thee to have a family in Paradise, and unite thee with them [therein]. (TA.)
See also 2.
5: see 1.
8: see 1.

hom.sense: 10.
