AstOhlhu as signifying He was, or became, worthy, or deserving, of it, or he merited it, or he had a right, or just title or claim, to it, is not allowable: (Mṣb,* MF:) not only does J disallow it, but the generality of those before him do so; saying that it is not chaste: in the Fṣ it is said to be of weak authority; and the expositors thereof confirm this assertion, saying that it occurs, but is inferior to other words in chasteness; and El-Ḥareeree asserts it to be erroneous: (MF:) or it is good in this sense; and J's disallowance of it is of no account: (Ḳ:) Az and Z and Ṣgh and others assert it to be good: and Az says, in the T, some have asserted the saying fulaAnN yasotaOohilu Oano yukorama Oawo yuhaAna, as meaning [Such a one] is worthy, or deserving, [of being treated with honour, or of being held in light estimation,] to be erroneous; and AlAisotiYohaAlu to be only from AlUihaAlapu; but I do not disallow it, nor charge with error him who says thus; for I have heard the verb thus used by a chaste Arab of the desert, of the BenooAsad, and there was present a number of Arabs of the desert who did not disapprove his saying: and this is confirmed by the saying in the Kur [lxxiv. 55], huwa Oaholu Alt-aqowaI waOaholu Almagofirapi [explained below: see Oaholu]. (T.)
AstOhl, (JK, Ḳ,) or AstOhl AlOahaAlapa, (Mṣb,) He took the UihaAlapa: (JK, Ḳ:) or he ate the AhAlp: see this word below. (Mṣb, TA.)

entry.sense: OaholN [The people of a house or dwelling, and of a town or village, and of a country: and the family of a man:] a man's cohabitants of one dwelling or place of abode, (Er-Rághib, Kull p. 84,) and of one town or country: (Er-Rághib:) afterwards applied to a man's fellow-members of one family or race, and of one religion, and of one craft or art or the like: (Er-Rághib, Kull:) or, as some say, relations, whether they have followers or dependents, or not; whereas MlN signifies relations with their followers or dependents: (Kull:) or it originally signifies relations: and sometimes is applied to followers or dependents: and signifies also the Oahol [i. e. people, or inhabitants, or family,] of a house or tent: (Mṣb:) or a man's nearer, or nearest, relations by descent from the same father or ancestor; or his kinsfolk; his relations: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to [the Imám] Moḥammad, a man's wife [or wives] and his children and household who are the objects of his expenditure; and thus, any brother and sister, or paternal uncle and son of a paternal uncle, or strange or distantly-related child, whom a man feeds or sustains in his abode: the most particular, or most special, dependents, or the like, of a man: on the authority of El-Ghooree: (Mgh:) [J indicates some of these meanings merely by saying that it signifies] the Oahol of a man, and the Oahol of a house; as also OaholapN↓: (Ṣ:) [see also MlN; in the explanations of which, certain distinctions between it and OaholN will be found mentioned:] the pl. is Oaholuwna, [like OaroDuwna, a form sometimes used for OaraDuwna] (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OahaAlK, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with an additional I [implied by the tenween, and expressed in the accus. case, and when the word is determinate, as in AlOahaAliI,] (Ṣ,) contr. to rule, (Ṣ, Mgh,) like layaAlK, pl. of layolN, (Ṣ,) [and like OaraAD, respecting which and lyaAlK and OahaAlK, see OaroDN,] and MhaAlN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. [of pauc.] sometimes occurring in poetry, (Ṣ,) [like MraADN,] and OaholaAtN and OahalaAtN [as though pls. of OaholapN]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Oaholu Albayoti The [people or] inhabitants [or family] of the house or tent. (Mgh, Ḳ.) But OawoSaI lOaholi bayotihi means the same as AwSI lijinosihi, i. e. He left by will, of his property, to the children of his father, [or his kindred by the father's side,] exclusively of all relations of the mother. (Mgh in art. jns.) [See also Oaholu Alr-ajuli, below.]

Oahola AlquraI The [people or] inhabitants of the towns or villages. (TA.) And Oaholu Albaladi The settled, or constant, inhabitants of the country or town. (Mṣb.) And Oaholu AlHaDari The people of the region, or regions, of cities, towns, or villages, and of cultivated land. (A in art. HDr.) And Oaholu Almadari waAlwabari (Ṣ in art. mdr, &c.) [The people of the towns or villages, or] the inhabitants of the buildings, and of the tents, (Kull,) or deserts. (TA in art. wbr)
[Oaholu Alqubuwri, and AlmaqaAbiri, The people of the graces, and of the places of graves; i. e., those buried therein.]
[Oaholu Aljan-api The people of Paradise.]
[Oaholu Aln-aAri The people of the fire, i. e., of Hell.]
See also OahilapN.

The following is an ex. of Ahl as explained above in the first sentence on the authority of the Ḳ: AlOaholu UilaI AlOaholi OasoraEu mina Als-iyli UilaI Als-aholi a prov. [meaning Kinsfolk are quicker of tendency to kinsfolk than the torrent to the plain]. (TA.) So, too, a saying of a poet cited voce xafoDN. (TA.) [And] Oaholaka waAll-ayola a prov. meaning baAdir Oaholaka waQHocari All-ayola waZulomatahu [Betake thyself early to thy family, and beware of the night and its darkness]. (Ḥar p. 175.) [And] maroHabFA waOaholFA (Ṣ, Ḳ) a saying meaning Thou hast come to an ample, or a spacious, or roomy, place, and to [people like thine own] kinsfolk; therefore be cheerful, or sociable, not sad, or shy: (Ṣ:) or thou hast found, or met with, [an ample, or a spacious, or roomy, place, and] kinsfolk, not strangers. (Ḳ.) [And] OaholFA wasaholFA wamaroHabFA Thou hast come to a people who are [like] kinsfolk, and to a place that is plain, even, not rugged, and that is ample, spacious, or roomy; therefore rejoice thyself, and be not sad, or shy. (Mṣb.)

Oaholu Aln-abiI-i The [family or] wives and daughters of the Prophet, and his son-in-law ʼAlee: or his women; and (as some say, TA) the men who are his Ml; (Ḳ, TA;) comprising the grandchildren (OaHofaAd) and [other] progeny: and so Oaholu Albayoti as used in the Ḳur xxxiii. 33, occurring also [in a like sense] in xi. 76: (TA:) and AlOaholu is conventionally applied to the nearer, or nearest, kinsfolk of the Prophet. (Er-Rághib.)
Oaholu kul-i nabiI-K also means The people to whom any prophet is sent; (Ḳ, TA;) and those who are of his religion. (TA.)
In the phrase MlN Qll-ehi warasuwlihi, meaning The friends, or the like, (OawoliyaMC Ḳ, TA,) and the assistants, (TA,) of God and of his apostle, the first word is originally Oahol. (Ḳ, TA.)
Oaholu Qll-ehi is also an appellation which used to be applied to The readers or reciters [of the Ḳur-án]. (TA.)

Oaholu Alr-ajuli also signifies ‡ The man's wife; (Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as well as his wife and children; (TA;) [so, too, in the present day, Oaholu bayoti Alr-ajuli;] and so, too, Oaholatuhu↓. (Ḳ.) Hence the phrase banaI EalaI Oaholihi [see art. bnI]: (Kull:) and daxala biOaholihi and daxala EalaI Oaholihi [see art. dxl]. (Ḥar p. 502;, &c.)

Oaholu macohabK [The people of, or] those who follow, (Ḳ, TA,) and believe, (TA,) a certain persuasion, or body of tenets. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence,] Oaholu Als-unapi [Those who conform to the institutes of Moḥammad]. (TA.) [And] Oaholu AlOahowaMCi [The people of erroneous opinions;] those whose belief is not that of the class termed Oaholu Als-un-api, but who hare the same qibolap. (TA.) [And] Oaholu AlUisolaAmi Those who follow the religion of El-Islám. (Mgh.) [And] Oaholu AlquroMni Those who read, or recite, the Ḳur-án, and perform the duties enjoined thereby. (Mgh.) [And] Oaholu AlkitaAbi [The people of the Scripture, or Bible: and] the readers, or reciters, of the Mosaic Law, and of the Gospel. (TA.)
Oaholu AlEilomi [The people of knowledge, or science;] those who are characterized by knowledge, or science. (Mṣb.)
Oaholu AlOamori [The possessors of command: or] those who superintend the affairs [of others]; (Ḳ, TA;) like OuluwAlOamri, q. v. (TA.)
Oaholu AlmaraAtibi [The people of exalted stations, posts of honour, or dignities]. (TA in art. rtb.)

Oaholu Alc-im-api (Mgh in art. cm) and Oaholu AlEahodi (TA in art. Ehd) Those persons, (Mgh, TA,) of the unbelievers, (Mgh,) [namely, Christians, Jews, and Sabians, but no others,] who have a compact, or covenant, with the Muslims, (Mgh, TA,) paying a poll-tax, whereby they are secure of their property and blood, (Mgh,) or whereby the Muslims are responsible for their security [and freedom and toleration] as long as they act agreeably to the compact. (TA.)
OaholN also signifies The possessors, or owners, of property: as in the Ḳur iv. 61. (TA.)

OaholN likacaA A person, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and persons, for it is used as a sing. and as a pl., (Ḳ,) having a right, or just title, to such a thing; entitled thereto; worthy, or deserving, thereof; meet, or fit, for it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the vulgar say musotaOohilN↓, which is not allowable: (Ṣ:) or this assertion of J's is of no account. (Ḳ: see 10.) You say, huw OaholN liUikoraAmi He is entitled to be, or worthy of being, treated with honour. (Mṣb.) And huwa OaholapN↓ lik-uli xayor [He is entitled to, or worthy of, all that is good]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.) And OahlapN↓ wud-K He who is, or they who are, entitled to, or worthy of, love, or affection. (Ṣ, Ṣgh.) And hence, in the Ḳur [lxxiv. last verse], huwa Oaholu Alt-aqowaI waOaholu Almagofirapi (TA) He is the Being entitled to be regarded with pious fear, and the Being entitled to forgive those who so regard Him. (Jel.) In the phrase Ohola AlvanaMCi waAlmajodi [0 Thou who art the Being entitled to praise and glory], occurring in a form of prayer, the first word is mansoob as a vocative: and it may be marfooa, as the enunciative of an inchoative suppressed; i. e. Oanota Oaholu [Thou art the Being entitled, &c.]. (Mṣb.)

[Frequently, also, OaholN signifies The author, or, more commonly, authors, of a thing; like SaAHibN and OaSoHaAbN; as in Oaholu AlbidaEi The author, or authors, of innovations; and Oaholu AlZ-ulomi The author, or authors, of wrong.]
OahilN: see OaholiyIN.

hom.sense: OaholapN: see OaholN, in four places:
and see OahlapN.

entry.sense: OahilapN i. q. maAlN [Property; or cattle]: so in the saying Uin-ahumo laOaholu OahilapK (JK, Ḳ) [app. meaning Verily they are sojourners, or settlers, possessed of property, or cattle]: OaholN↓ here signifying HuluwlN [pl. of HaAl-N]. (JK, TA.) [But] Yoo says that humo Oaholu Oaholapi↓ and OahilapK means They are people of the distinguished sort. (TA.)

OaholiI-N A domestic beast [or bird]; a beast [or bird] that keeps to the dwelling [of its owner]; (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;)
contr. of waHoXiI-N; (TA;) as also OahilN↓. (Ḳ.) You say HumurN Oaholiy-apN [Domestic asses]: (JK, TA:) occurring in a trad., in which their flesh is forbidden to be eaten. (TA.)

Oaholiy-apN The quality of having a right, or just title, to a thing; worthiness, or desert; meetness, or fitness; in Pers. sazawaAriI: (Golius, app. from a gloss. in a copy of the KL:) the state, or quality, of meetness, or fitness, [of a person,] for the bindingness of the rights which the law imposes for one or upon him. (TA.)

UihaAlapN Grease: (Ṣ:) or melted grease: (Mṣb:) or fat: or melted fat: or olive-oil: and anything that is used as a seasoning or condiment: (Ḳ:) such as fresh butter, and fat, and oil of sesame: (TA:) or melted fat of a sheep's tail and the like. (JK.) Hence, saroEaAna caA UihaAlapN, a prov., mentioned in art. srE; (Ḳ,* TA;) or, as some say, waXokaAna. (TA.)

MhilN, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [said by those unacquainted with the verb Oahala in the first of the senses explained in this art. to be] a kind of rel. n., (TA,) and maOohuwlN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) A place peopled, or inhabited: (Mṣb:) or a place having people: (JK:) or the former has this signification; and the latter signifies having its people in it: (ISk, Ḳ:) or the former has this last signification: (Yoo, Ṣ:) pl. of the latter maMhilu, occurring in a poem of Ru-beh [app. by poetic licence for maMhiylu]. (TA.) You say qaroyapN MhilapN A peopled, or inhabited, town or village. (Mṣb.) And Oamosato niyraAnuhumo MhilapN Their fires became in the evening attended by many people. (TA.)

hom.sense: maOohuwlN: see MhilN.
variydapN maOohuwlapN [A mess of crumbled bread] having much UihaAlap, q. v. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: mutaOah-ilN Having a wife. (Ḥar p. 571.)

hom.sense: musotaOohilN: see OaholN; latter part of the paragraph.
Also Taking, or eating, UihaAlap, q. v. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: Oawo a conjunction, (M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) to which the later authors have ascribed meanings amounting to twelve: (Mughnee:) a particle which, when occurring in an enunciative phrase, [generally] denotes doubt, and vagueness of meaning; and when occurring in an imperative or a prohibitive phrase, [generally] denotes the giving of option, or choice, and the allowing a thing, or making it allowable. (Ṣ.)

First, (Mughnee,) it denotes doubt. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ.) So in the saying, raOayotu zayodFA Oawo EamorFA [I saw Zeyd or ʼAmr]. (T,* Ṣ, Mṣb.) And jaMCaniI rajulN Oawi QmoraOapN [A man or a woman came to me]. (Mbr, T.) And labiYonaA yawomFA Oawo baEoDa yawomK [in the Ḳur xviii. 18 and xxiii. 115, We have remained a day or part of a day]. (Mughnee.)

Secondly, (Mughnee,) it denotes vagueness of meaning. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ.) Ṣ [it may be used] in the first of the exs. given above. (Mṣb.) And so in the saying, waOan-aA Oawo Uiy-aAkumo laEalaI hudFI Oawo fiI DalaAlK mubiynK [And verily we or ye are following a right direction or in manifest error], (Ṣ, Mughnee,) in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 23]; (Ṣ;) the ex. being in the former Aw. (Mughnee.)

Thirdly, (Mughnee,) it denotes the giving of option, or choice. (T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ.) So in the saying, kuli Als-amaka Oawi QXorabi All-abana [Eat thou the fish, or drink thou the milk]; i. e. do not thou both of these actions; (Mbr, T, Ṣ;) but choose which of them thou wilt. (Mbr, T.) And tazaw-ajo hinodFA Oawo OuxotahaA [Take thou as wife Hind or her sister]. (Mughnee.) And [in like manner] it denotes the making choice. (T.) [So when you say, saOatazaw-aju hinodFA Oawo OuxotahaA, meaning I will take as wife Hind or her sister; whichever of them I choose.]

Fourthly, (Mughnee,) it denotes the allowing a thing, or making it allowable. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Mughnee, Ḳ.) So in the saying, jaAlisi Hasana Oawi Qbona siyriyna [Sit thou with El-Ḥasan or Ibn-Seereen]. (Mbr, T, Ṣ.) And qumo Oawi QqoEudo [Stand thou or sit]: and the person to whom this is said may do [one or] both of the se actions. (Mṣb. [And similar exs. are given in the Mughnee.]) But walaA tuTiEo minohumo MvimFA Oaw kafuwrFA [in the Ḳur lxxvi. 24, And obey not thou, of them, a sinner or a person very ungrateful to God,] means that thou shalt not obey either of such persons: (Mbr, T, Mughnee:) in which case Aw is more forcible than wa; for when you say to a person, laA tuTiEo zayodFA waEamorFA [Obey not thou Zeyd and ʼAmr], he may obey one of them, since the command is that he shall not obey the two. (Zj, T.)

Fifthly, (Mughnee,) it denotes unrestricted conjunction. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) So in the saying, in the Ḳur [iv. 46 and v. 9], Oawo jaMCa OaHadN minokumo mina AlgaAYiTi [And if any one of you cometh from the privy]; (TA;) [where, however, it may also be rendered or, though] meaning wajaMCa; (T, TA;) the w in this explanation being what is termed a denotative of state. (T.) So, too, accord. to AZ, in the expression Oawo yaziyduwna [And they exceeded that number], in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 147]: but see below. (TA.) And so in the words, Oawo Oano nafoEala fiI OamowaAlinaA maA naXaMCu [And our doing, in respect of our possessions, what we will], in the Ḳur [xi. 89]. (T, TA.)

Sixthly, it denotes transition, (Mughnee,) used in the sense of [the adversative particle] balo, (T, Ṣ, M, Mughnee, Ḳ,) in a case of amplification of speech; (Ṣ;) accord. to Sb, on two conditions; that it shall be preceded by a negation or a prohibition, and that the agent shall be mentioned a second time; as in maA qaAma zayodN Oawo maA qaAma EamorNw [Zeyd did not stand: nay, rather ʼAmr did not stand]; and laA yaqomN zaydN Oawo laA yaqumo Eamoruw [Let not Zeyd stand: nay, rather let not ʼAmr stand]. (Mughnee.) Accord. to Fr, (Th, M, Mughnee,) it has this meaning in Oawo yaziyduwna [Nay, rather they exceeded that number], (Th, Ṣ, M, Mughnee,) in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 147, cited above]: (Ṣ:) or the meaning is, or they would exceed [that number] in your estimation: or these words with those preceding them in the same verse mean, we sent him to a multitude of whom, if ye saw them, ye would say, They are a hundred thousand, or they exceed [that number]; (M, Mughnee;*) so that it denotes doubt on the part of men, not of God, for He is not subject to doubt: (M:) or we sent him to a hundred thousand in the estimation of men, or they exceeded [that number] in the estimation of men; for God does not doubt: (Ṣ:) or Aw is here used to denote vagueness of meaning: (IB, Mughnee:) or, it is said, to denote that a person might choose between saying, “they are a hundred thousand,“and saying, “they are more;“but this may not be when one of the two things is the fact: or, accord. to some of the Koofees, it has the meaning of wa: and each of these meanings, except the last, has been assigned to Aw as occurring in the Ḳur ii. 69 and xvi. 79. (Mughnee.)

Seventhly, it denotes division; (Mughnee, Ḳ;*) as in the saying, Alkalimapu QsomN Oawo fiEolN Oawo HarofN [The word is a noun or a verb or a particle]: so said Ibn-Málik: or, as he afterwards said, in preference, it denotes separation (Alt-afriyq) divested of the attribute of denoting doubt and vagueness of meaning and the giving of option or choice; adducing as one of his exs. of this meaning the saying, waqaAluwA kuwnuwA huwdFA Oawo naSaAraI [in the Ḳur ii. 129, And they said, “Be ye Jews” or “Christians”]; because the use of w in division is better; as when you say, Alkalimapu QsomN wafiEolN waHarofN: or it denotes, accord. to some, distinction (Alt-afoSiyl); and the meaning of the ex. last cited, say they, is, and the Jews said, “Be ye Jews,” and the Christians said, “Be ye Christians.” (Mughnee.) It is [said to be] used in this last sense ( that of AltfDyl) in the saying, kunotu Mkulu All-aHoma Oawi AlEasala [I used to eat flesh-meat or honey]; i. e. I used to eat flesh-meat one time and honey another time: and so in the Ḳur vii. 3 and x. 13.

Eighthly, (Mughnee,) it is used in the sense of the exceptive Uil-aA, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) or Uil-aA Oano (M;) and in this case the aor. after it is mansoob, because of Oano suppressed. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) So in the saying, laOaqotulan-ahu Oawo yusolima [I will assuredly slay him or he shall become a Muslim; i. e., unless he become a Muslim]. (Mughnee.[And a similar ex. is given in the M.]) So, too, in the saying,
wakunotu UicaA gamazotu qanaApa qawomK
kasarotu kuEuwbahaA Oawo tasotaqiymaA
[And I used, when I pinched and pressed the spear of a people, to break its knots, or joints, or its internodal portions, (the shaft being a cane,) or, i. e. unless, it became straight]: (Mughnee, Ḳ:*) a prov., of which the author is Ziyád El-Aajam; meaning, when a people behaved with hardness to me, I endeavoured to soften them: (TA in art. gmz:) thus related by Sb, the verb ending it being rendered mansoob by Aw; and thus he heard it from some one or more of the Arabs; but in the original verses, which are but three, it is tasotaqiymu, with refa. (IB and TA in art. gmz.) [And similar to these above are the sayings,] Un-ahu lifulaAnK OawomaA binajodK qarZahu [Verily it belongs to such a one or there is not, i. e. unless there be not, in Nejd, a qaraZap (see art. qrZ)]:
and laMtiyan-aka Oawo maA binajodK qaraZapN [I will assuredly come to thee or there is not, i. e. unless there be not, in Nejd, a qaraZap]; meaning I will assuredly come to thee, in truth. (T.)

Ninthly, (Mughnee,) it is used in the sense of UilaI, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) or UilaI Oano; (Ṣ;) in which case also the aor. after it is mansoob, because of Oano suppressed: (Mughnee:) and in the sense of Hat-aI [which is also syn. with UitaI]. (Fr, T, M, Ḳ.) So in the saying, laOaDoriban-ahu Oawo yatuwba [I will assuredly beat him until he repent]. (Ṣ. [And similar exs. of Aw as explained by Hat-aI are given in the T (from Fr) and in the M and in the Mughnee.]) And so in the saying of the poet,
laOasotasohilan-a AlS-aEoba Oawo Oudorika AlmunaI
famaA QnoqaAdati AlMmaAlu Uil-aA liSaAbiri
[I will assuredly deem easy what is difficult until I attain the objects of wish; for hopes become not easy of accomplishment save to one who is patient]. (Mughnee.)

Tenthly, some say, (Mughnee,) it denotes nearness [of one event or thing to another]; as in the saying, maA OadoriI Oasal-ama Oawo wad-aEa [I know not whether he saluted or bade farewell]: (Mughnee, Ḳ: [but in the CK this ex. is misplaced:]) this, however, is manifestly wrong; Aw being here used to denote doubt, and the denoting of nearness being only inferred from the fact of the saluting being confounded in the mind with the bidding farewell, since this is impossible or improbable when the two times are far apart. (Mughnee.)

Eleventhly, (Mughnee,) it occurs as a conditional, (T, Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to Ks alone; (T;) or rather as a conjunctive and conditional; waUino being meant to be understood in its place; though in truth the verb that precedes it indicates that the conditional particle [Uino] is meant to be understood [before that verb], and Aw retains its proper character, but forms part of that which has a conditional meaning because conjoined with a preceding conditional phrase. (Mughnee.) So in the saying, laOaDoriban-ahu EaAXa Oawo maAta, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) i. e., Uino EaAiD baEoda AlD-arobi waUino maAta [I will assuredly beat him if he live (after the beating) or if he die]: so says Ibn-Esh-Shejeree. (Mughnee.)

Twelfthly, accord. to Ibn-Esh-Shejeree, on the authority of some one or more of the Koofees, (Mughnee,) it denotes division into parts, or portions; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 129, before cited,] waqaAluwA kuwnuwA huwdFA Oaw naSaAraI, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) i. e. And they said, “Be ye, some of you, Jews, and, some of you, Christians:” (TA:) but [IHsh says,] it appears to me that the meaning here is that of Alt-afoSiyl mentioned before. (Mughnee.)

[In the Ḳ it is said to occur also in the sense of Oano: but this is evidently a mistake, app. originating in one of the two principal sources of the Ḳ, namely, the M, in which the same is said, but is exemplified by a phrase in which it is explained by Uil-aA Oano, the eighth of the meanings of Oawo mentioned above.]
See also Oaw-N below.
Oawa in Oawa lamo yarawoA, &c. is [the conjunction] wa with the interrogative A prefixed to it. (Fr, T.)

Oaw-i mino kacaA (T, M) and Oaw-a (M) [Alas, on account of, or for, such a thing!] an expression denoting complaint of distress, or of anxiety, or of grief or sorrow; (T;) or an expression of grief or sorrow; (M;) like Mwi↓ and MwK↓ and OawataAh↓ (Ḳ and TA in art. Awh,) or OawataAhu↓ (CK in that art.,) or Oaw-ataAh↓, or Mw-ataAh↓, (Ṣ in that art., [the h in one copy of which is marked as quiescent,]) and like Mhi and Oawohi, &c. (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. Awh: see Mhi in that art.) AZ says, one says, Oawohi EalaI zayodK [meaning Alas, for Zeyd!] with kesr to the h, and Oaw-ataA↓ Ealayoka [thus without h, meaning Alas, for thee!] with t; an expression of regret for a thing, whether of great or mean account. (T.)

Oaw-N The word Oawo↓ when made a noun. (T, Ḳ.) So say the grammarians. (T.) You say, hechi Oaw-NHasanapN [This is a good Oawo]. (T.) And to one who uses the phrase OafoEalu kacaA Oawo kacaA, (T,) you say, daEi AlOaw-ajaAnibFA [Let thou, or leave thou, the word Oawo alone]. (T, Ḳ.)

Oaw-apN [A moaning (see its syn. MhapN in art. Awh)] is said by some to be of the measure faEolapN, in which the p is the sign of the fem. gender; for they say, samiEotu Oaw-ataka [I heard thy moaning], making it t: and so says Lth; Oaw-apN is after the manner of faEolapN: (T:) you say, Oaw-apF laka [May God cause moaning to thee!], (Lth, T, and Ṣ in art. Awh,) and MhapF laka: [but accord. to J, the former of these is cognate with the latter; for he says that] the former is with the h suppressed, and with teshdeed to the w. (Ṣ in art. Awh, where see MhapN.)
Oaw-ataA Ealayka; and Oaw-ataAh, or Mw-ataAh, or OawataAh, or OawataAhu: see Oaw-i mino kacaA.

Ouw-apN i. q. daAhiyapN [A calamity, a misfortune,, &c.: or, perhaps, very cunning, applied to a man]: pl. Ouwawo; (AA, T, Ḳ, TA; [but in copies of the Ḳ, written OuwawN;]) which is one of the strangest of the things transmitted from the Arabs; the regular form being Ouw-aI, like quw-aI, pl. of quwapN; but the word occurring as above in the saying of the Arabs, maA huwa Uil-aA Ouw-apN mina AlOuwawo [It is no other thing than a calamity of the calamities: or, perhaps, he is no other than a very cunning man of the very cunning]. (AA, T, TA.)
Mwi and MwK: see Oaw-i: and see Mhi in art. Awh.
OawawiI-N and MwiI-N: see MyapN, in art. AI.
Mw-ataAh: see Oaw-i.

1. Mba, aor. yaWuwbu, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. OawobN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UiyaAbN and OawobapN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OayobapN, (M, Ḳ,) I taking the place of w, (M,) and UiybapN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and maMbN [like maMlN], (Mṣb, TA,) He (an absent person, T) returned (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) to his place, (Sh,) or to a thing, (M,) or from his journey; (Mṣb;) as also Ow-b↓, (M,) inf. n. taOowiybN and taOoyiybN; (Ḳ;) and tOw-b↓; (M, Ḳ;) and AYtAb↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAba]; (Ṣ;) and Oay-aba↓, [a quasi-quadriliteral-radical verb, originally Oayowaba,] of the measure fayoEala, (M,) inf. n. Uy-aAbN, (M, Ḳ,) originally UywaAbN, of the measure fiyEaAlN, (M, TA,) or, accord. to Fr, Uiy-aAbN is incorrect, and the right word is UiyaAbN: (TA:) [and if so, Oay-aba is perhaps changed from Oaw-aba, like as OayobapN is from OawobapN; and taOoyiybN is perhaps its inf. n., changed from taOowiybN:] or, as some say, UiyaAbN signifies only the returning to one's family at night: (M, TA:) and tOw-b↓ Oaholahu and AYtAb↓ Ahlh [as well as Mba UilaI Oaholihi] signify he returned to his family at, or in, the night: (T, TA:) or Mba Uilayohimo, (Ṣ,) [or Mbahumo, accord. to a copy of the A, where we find Oubotu baniI fulaAnK,] aor. as above; (TA;) and taOaw-abahumo↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and taOay-abahumo↓, (Ḳ,) I taking the place of w, (TA,) inf. n. mutaOaw-abN and mutaOay-abN, (M,* [in which the two forms of the verb are also given, but with the sing. pronoun of the third pers. instead of the pl.,] and Ḳ,) each in the form of a pass. part. n.; (TA;) he came to them at night: (Ṣ, M,* A, Ḳ:) and Mba AlmaMCa, (M,) inf. n. OawobN, (Ḳ,) signifies he came to the water, to drink, at night; as also AYtAbhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) and tOw-bhu↓: (M:) or, accord. to AZ, taOaw-abtu signifies I came in the beginning of the night. (Ṣ.) You say also, Mbati AlX-amosu, (T, Ṣ, &c.,) aor. taWuwbu, (M,) inf. n. maMbN, (T,) or UiyaAbN [in the CK AayAb] and OuyuwbN, (M, Ḳ,) The sun returned from its place of rising, and set: (Mṣb:) or the sun set; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as though it returned to the place whence it commenced its course; (M;) [or] it is a dial. var. of gaAbat. (Ṣ.) And Mba Uilayohi People came to him from every direction, or quarter. (TA, from a trad.) The poet Sáideh Ibn-El-'Ajlán uses the expression, laMbaka murohafN, meaning A thin sword would have come to thee; in which the verb may be trans. by itself, or the prep. UilaI may be understood. (M, TA.)
He returned from disobedience to obedience; he repented. (TA.) And Mba UilaI Qll-ehi He returned unto God from his sin, or offence, and repented. (Mṣb.)

Mba bihi Uilayohi He made him to return to him, or it; as also Aw-bhu↓ Uilayohi. (M.) And Mba yadahu UilaI sayofihi, (as in a copy of the T,) or biyadihi, (as in a copy of the A, [which is probably here the more correct],) He put back his hand to his sword to draw it: (Lth, T, A:) and AlI qawosihi [to his bow] to draw it: and AlI sahomihi [to his arrow] to shoot it. (A.)
See also 2.
2. Ow-b: see 1, first sentence:
and the same again, near the end.

He repeated, or echoed, the praises of God: thus in the saying [in the Ḳur xxxiv. 10], yaA jibaAlu Oaw-ibiI maEahu 0 mountains, repeat ye, or echo ye, the praises of God with him; [i. e., with David;] (Ṣ,* M, TA;) but some read AuwbiI↓ mEh, meaning return ye with him in praising as often as he returneth therein: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the former reading, the meaning is, 0 mountains, labour ye with him in praising God all the day, until the night: (T:) for

Ow-b, (T, A,) inf. n. taOowiybN, (T, A, Ḳ) also signifies It (a company of men) journeyed by day: (Aboo-Málik, T:) or all the day, (T, A, Ḳ,) to the night, (T,) without alighting to rest: (TA:) tOwyb being the same kind of day-journeying as UisoMdN is of night-journeying: (T, M:) or he journeyed all the day, and alighted at night: (T, Ṣ:) or he journeyed by night: (Mṣb:) or tOwyb (M, L, Ḳ) and muWaAwabapN↓ (Lth, T, L, Ḳ) signify the vying, one with another, of travellingcamels, in pace, or going. (Lth, T, M, L, Ḳ.) A poet says,
waUino tuWaAwibohu↓ tajidohu miYowabaA↓
[And if thou, or they, (meaning camels,) vie with him in pace, or going, thou wilt, or they will, find him to be one that overcomes therein]: so as related by Lth: but as related by others, tuWaw-ibohu. (T.)
3. Mwb, inf. n. muWaAwabapN: see 2, in two places.
5. tOw-b and tOy-b: see 1, in five places.
8. AYtAb: see 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 1. Oay-aba, originally Oayowaba: see 1, first sentence.
Mbu The name of a [Syrian] month [corresponding to August, O. Ṣ.]: an arabicized word. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OawobN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also The returning of the fore and hind legs of a beast in going along: (T, M, A,* Ḳ:) or quickness in the changing, or shifting, of the fore and hind legs in going along: (Ṣ:) and simply quickness, or swiftness. (M, Ḳ.) One says, maA OaEojaba Oawoba yadayohaA How wonderful is the returning [or quick shifting] of her fore legs! (A.) And to one going at a quick pace, one says, AlOawoba AlOawoba [meaning Keep to the quick changing, or shifting, of the legs; a verb being understood: or Trot on! Trot on!]. (A.)

A right, or direct, way, course, or tendency; syn. qaSodN and AisotiqaAmapN. (M [in which these two syns. are mentioned together] and Ḳ [in which another explanation intervenes between them, namely EAdp, as though they were meant to be understood in different senses, which I do not think to be the case].)
A direction: as in the saying, ramaI OawbFA Oawo Oawobayoni [He shot, or cast, in one direction, or in two directions]. (M, A.)

A course, way, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like: (A:) custom. (Lḥ, M, A, Ḳ.) You say, kunotu EalaI Sawobi fulaAnK waOawobihi I was [proceeding] in the course, way, mode, or manner, of acting, &c., of such a one. (A.) And maA zaAla hecaA Oawobahu This ceased not to be his course, way, mode, or manner,, &c.: (A:) or his custom. (Lḥ, M, A.)

A way, or road: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a quarter: (ʼEyn, M, A, Ḳ:) a tract, or side: (ʼEyn, Ṣ:) a place: (Ṣ:) a place to which one returns [like maMbN]. (A, Mṣb.) You say, jaAWuwA mino kul-i OawobK They came from every way, or road, (M, Mṣb,) or quarter, (ʼEyn, M, A,) or tract, or side, (ʼEyn, Ṣ,) and place, (Ṣ,) or place to which one returns. (A, Mṣb.) And OawobaA AlwaAdiI signifies The two sides of the valley. (A.)

Bees: (M, Ḳ:) a quasi-pl. n.: as though the sing. were MYibN: AḤn says that they are so called because of their returning to the mabaMCap, i. e. the place where they hive for the night. (M, TA.) See MYibN.
The clouds. (Ḳ.)
The wind. (Ḳ.)

OawobapN and OayobapN↓ Return; (T, A, Ḳ;) as also UiyaAbapN↓, a subst. from Mba. (Mṣb.) You say, liyahoniYoka Oawobapu AlgaAYibi [May the return of the absent give thee joy]. (TA.) And fulAnN sariyEu AlOawobapi and AlOayobapi↓ Such a one is quick in return. (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ.*)
Return from disobedience to obedience; repentance. (TA in art. Ayb.)
kalaAmN laA Oawobapa lahu Speech, or language, without profit. (A.)
OawobapN is also the sing. of OawobaAtN, which signifies The legs of a beast. (Ḳ, TA.)
OayobapN: see OawobapN, in two places.
Also, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or UiybapN↓, (accord. to the CK,) or MYibapN↓, (accord. to the TḲ,) A noon-day draught or drink. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: UiybapN: see what next precedes.
OawuwbN A she-camel quick in the changing, or shifting, of her fore and kind legs in going along. (Ṣ.)
UiyaAbapN: see OawobapN.
Oaw-aAbN Frequent in returning. (T.)

Frequent in returning unto God, from one's sins; (M, TA;) wont to repent, or frequent in repenting: (Zj, T, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or turning from disobedience to obedience: or (Ṣ, L:) or a praiser of God; (Saʼeed Ibn-Jubeyr, TA;) by which is here meant, in the prayer of the period of the forenoon called AlD-uHaI, when the sun is high, and the heat violent; hence termed SalaApu AlOaw-aAbiyna; which is performed when the young camels feel the heat of the sun from the parched ground: (TA:) or obedient: (Ḳatádeh, TA:) or one who reflects upon his sins in solitude, and prays God to forgive them: (TA:) or one who keeps, or is mindful of, the ordinances prescribed by God, (HafiyZN, [which is thus explained by Bḍ and Jel as occurring in the Ḳur l. 31,]) and does not rise from his sitting-place until he begs forgiveness of God: (ʼObeyd Ibn-ʼOmeyr, T, TA:* [but this is evidently meant as an explanation of Oaw-aAbN together with HafiyZN: see the Ḳur ubi suprà:]) or one who sins, and then returns to obedience, and then sins, and then returns to obedience. (TA.)
MYibN act. part. n. of Mba; Returning: [&c.:] (M, Mṣb:) pl. Ouw-aAbN and Ouy-aAbN and OawobN↓ [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, the last is a quasi-pl. n. (M, TA.)

MYibapN The coming of camels to water, to drink, every night: whence the saying,
laA taridan-a AlmaMCa Uil-aA MYibaho
[Do not thou come to the water, to drink, unless coming to it every night]. (IAạr, M.)
See also OayobapN.

maMbN A place to which one returns: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) a settled, or fixed, abode, or dwelling-place: (TA:) the place to which one is translated, or removed, by death: (Ḳ, TA:) the goal to which the course of life ultimately leads one; or place to which one returns in the ultimate state, or world to come. (T, TA.)
The place where the sun sets. (TA.)
[A day-journey: pl. maMwibu; as in the saying,] bayonahuma valaAvu maMwiba Between them two are three day-journeys. (Ḳ.)
miYowabN [A camel that overcomes in vying with another, or others, in pace, or going]: see an ex. voce Oaw-aba. (T.)

maMbapu AlbiYori [The place where the water flows again into the well to supply the deficiency occasioned by drawing;] the mabaMCap of the well; i. e. the place where the water collects in the well. (TA.)
riyHN muWaw-ibapN, (IB, CK,) or muWaw-abapN, (as in a copy of the M, and in some copies of the Ḳ,) A wind blowing throughout the whole day: (M, Ḳ:) or a wind that comes at night. (IB.)
muWotaAbN: see mutaOaw-ibN, in two places.

mutaOaw-ibN Returning to one's family at, or in, the night; as also muWotaAbN↓: (TA:) or, as also mutaOayibN↓, coming at night: or coming in the beginning of the night: (Ṣ:) [and so muWotaAbN↓, as in the following ex.:]
wamano yat-aqo faUin-a Qll-eha maEohu
warizoqu Qll-ehi muWotaAbN wagaAdi
[And whoso feareth God, verily God is with him; and the supply of God cometh to him at night, or in the beginning of the night, and cometh early in the morning: yat-aqo being here put for yat-aqi, by a necessary poetical licence: see art. wqI]. (Ṣ.)
mutaOay-abN: see mutaOaw-abN.
mutaOay-ibN: see mutaOaw-ibN.

hom.sense: 1. Oawida, aor. yaOowadu, inf. n. OawadN, It (a thing, T, Ṣ, M, or an arrow, AḤn, M) was, or became, of itself, crooked, curved, or bent. (T, Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ.) [See also 5.]
Mda, aor. yaWuwdu, inf. n. OawodN, It (the day) receded, in the evening. (T, L.)
It (the evening, T, Ṣ) declined. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (a thing, L) returned. (M, L, Ḳ.)
Mdati AlZ-ilaAli The shadows returned, and inclined towards the east. (L.)
Mda Ealayohi He inclined towards him; or pitied him. (M.)

Mdahu, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) first pers. Oudotuhu, (M,) or Oudt-uhu, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Aidt-uhu,]) aor. yaWuwdu, inf. n. OawodN, (Aṣ, T, M, Mṣb,) He crooked, curved, or bent, it; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., a stick, (Aṣ, T, L,) or other thing; (L;) as also Ow-dhu↓. (L, Ḳ.)

Mdahu, aor. yaWuwdu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. OawodN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OuwuwdN, (M, Ḳ,) It (a load) oppressed him by its weight; pressed heavily upon him; burdened him. (AZ, T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) And It (a thing, or an affair,) oppressed, distressed, or afflicted, him: (M, L, Ḳ:)
and [in like manner] tOw-dhu↓, (L, Ḳ,) or tMwdhu↓, (T,) as also tMdAhu, (L, Ḳ,) the last formed by transposition (T, L) from the second, (T,) or first, (L,) said of an affair, it pressed heavily upon him; oppressed him. (T, L, Ḳ.) You say, maA Mdaka fahowa liI MYidN↓ What hath burdened [or distressed] thee, it (that thing) is burdening [or distressing] to me. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense:
5. tOw-d It (a stick, T, L, or some other thing, L) became, by an extraneous operation, crooked, curved, or bent; (T, Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ;) as also AnMd↓. (T, Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ: [in the CK faOotAda is erroneously put for faQnoMda.]) El-ʼAjjáj says,
lamo yaku yanoMdu faOamosaI QnoMdaA
[He used not to become bent, and he has become bent], making the pret. to be a denotative of state because qado is meant to be understood, as in the saying in the Ḳur [iv. 92], Oawo jaAWuwkumo HaSirato Suduwruhumo. (Ṣ.) You say also, taOaw-adato fiI qiyaAmihaA She (a woman) bent in her rising, by reason of her heaviness. (T and L in art. wOd.)
see Mdahu.

entry.sense: 6. tMwdhu: see Mdahu.
7. AnMd: see 5, in two places.
Also He became oppressed, or burdened [by a load]. (Mṣb.)
OawidN; (T, M;) or Mwadu↓; fem. OawodaMCu; (Ḳ;) Crooked, curved, or bent. (T, M, Ḳ.)
Mwadu; fem. OawodaMCu: see what next precedes.
MYidN Burdening [or distressing]. (Ṣ.) See 1, last sentence.
maWuwdN Oppressed, pressed heavily upon, or burdened, by a load. (Ṣ.)

maMwidu Calamities: (IAạr, M, L, Ḳ:) as also mawaAYidu, which is app. formed by transposition. (M, L.) Some say that mMwd is pl. of muWoyidN, and derive this word [which see in art. Ayd] from Mdahu, aor. yaWuwdN, meaning “it oppressed him by its weight:” (T, L:) or it has no sing. (IAạr, M.)

Uiwaz-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Uiwaz-apN, (Ṣ,) or the latter is the n. un. of the former, [which is a coll. gen. n.,] (Mṣb,) i. q. baT-N [The goose, or geese; and the duck, or ducks; but Awz- is generally applied to the former of these birds; and bT-, to the latter; agreeably with a statement in the Jm, that baT-N is applied by the Arabs to the small, and Uiwaz-N to the large]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also waz-N, of which the n. un. is waz-apN: (Mṣb:) Uiwaz-N is of the measure fiEal-N: (Mṣb:) [but see what follows:] the pl. is Uiwaz-uwna, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a form which is sometimes used, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and which is anomalous. (Mṣb.) [See also kurokiI-N.]

[Hence,] Uiwaz-N also signifies † Short and thick: (Ḳ:) fleshy without being tall: (Lth, TA:) fem. with p {Uiwaz-apN}. (TA.) El-'Okberee asserts that the O is augmentative, because it is followed by three radical letters: (MF, TA:) but ISd says that it is of the measure fiEal-N, and may not be of the measure UifoEalN, [i. e., originally UiwozazN,] because this does not occur as the measure of an epithet. (TA.) [It seems, however, that Awz- is in this case a subst. used tropically as an epithet, after the manner of many nicknames.]
Also, applied to a man, and to a horse, and to a camel, Firm in make: (AḤei in the Expos. of the Tes-heel, and TA:) or, applied to a horse, compact and strong in make. (TA.)

Uiwaz-aI A manner of walking in which is a moving up and down: or leaning on one side; (Ḳ;) [the latter omitted in the CK;] at one time on the right and at another on the left [like a goose or duck]: (TA:) and the walk of a sprightly horse. (TA.) Az says that it may be of the measure UifoEalaI, [i. e., originally Uiwozaz-aI,] or fiEal-aI; but Abu-l-Ḥasan holds the latter to be the more correct, because it is the measure of many words relating to walking; as jiyaD-aI, and difaq-aI. (TA.)
OaroDN maOowazapN A land abounding with the birds called Uiwaz-. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

MsN [The myrtle;] a certain kind of tree, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) fragrant, (IDrd, M, Mṣb,) and evergreen, abundant in the land of the Arabs, growing in the plains and mountains, and increasing so as to become a great tree: (AḤn, M, TA:) n. un. with p {MsapN}: (AḤn, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) IDrd says, I think it an adventitious word, although used by the Arabs, and occurring in chaste poetry. (M, TA.)

1. Mfati AlbilaAdu, aor. taWuwfu, inf. n. OawofN and MfapN (M, TA) and OuwuwfN, (M,) or OuWuwfN, (TA,) The country, or countries, had therein what is termed Mfap [i. e. a blight or blast or the like, or a pest or plague or the like]. (M, TA.) And Uiyfa AlT-aEaAmu, (Ibn Buzurj, T,) or Alz-aroEu, (Ḳ,) or AlX-aIoCu, with the verb in the pass. form, (Mṣb,) like qiyla, (Ḳ,) The wheat, or seed-produce, or thing, became affected, or smitten, with what is termed Mfap [i. e. a blight, blast, taint, canker, or the like]. (T, Ḳ, Mṣb.) And Mfa Alqawomu, (M, TA,) and OuwfuwA, (Ḳ,) thus in a correct copy of the ʼEyn, (TA,) and UiyfuwA, (Lth, T, Ḳ,) and OufuwA, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK Auf-ifuwA,]) and UifuwA, (Lth, T, Ḳ, [in the CK AufuwA,]) the last, namely, UifuwA, with the A termed mumaAlap, having a quiescent letter [i. e. I] rendered apparent by utterance but not by writing, between it and the f, (T, Ḳ,* [in which is a strange omission, of the words saAkinN bay-anahu All-afoZu laA AlxaT-u as in the T, or saAkinapN yubay-inuhaA Alx as in the TA,] TA,) The people became affected, or smitten, with what is termed Mfap [i. e. a pest or plague or the like]. (Lth, T, M, Ḳ.) Lth says, in this case one says UifuwA, and in one dial. UiyfuwA: (T:) in several copies of his book, in one dial. Ouf-ifuwA, with two distinct f s, of which the former is with teshdeed: but in some copies as mentioned just before. (Ṣgh, TA.)

MfapN [A blight, blast, taint, canker, disease, bane, pest, plague, or the like; any evil affection; an evil; a cause of mischief or harm or injury; anything that is noxious or destructive; a calamity;] i. q. EaAhapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. (Mṣb, [in the Ḳ “or,”]) an accident that mars, or corrupts, that which it affects, or befalls, or smites: (T, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. MfaAtN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See 1.] One says, Mfahu AlZ-arofi AlS-alafu waMfapu AlEilomi Aln-isEyaAnu [The bane of elegance in manners, or the like, is the overpassing the due limits therein, and arrogating to oneself superiority therein, through pride; and the bane of science is forgetfulness]. (T.) And it is said in a trad., Mfapu AlHadiyvi Alkacibu waMfapu AlEilomi Aln-isoyaAnu [The bane of discourse is lying; and the bane of science is forgetfulness]. (TA.) And hence the saying, likul-i XaIoCK MfapN waliloEilom MfaAtN [To everything there is a bane; and to science there are banes]. (TA.)

maWuwfN, (Ks, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally maOowuwfN, (Mṣb,) and maYiyfN↓, (Ibn-Buzurj, T, Ḳ,) Affected, or smitten, with what is termed Mfap; (T, Ṣ, M, &c.;) applied to wheat, (Ks, Ibn-Buzurj, T, M,) or seed-produce, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c. (Mṣb.)
maYiyfN: see maWuwfN.
Ouwqiy-apN: see art. wqI.

hom.sense: 1. Mla, aor. yaWuwlu, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. OawolN (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maMlN (M, Ḳ) and UiyaAlN, which last is used as a subst. in relation to objects of the mind, (Mṣb,) and OayoluwlapN [like dayomuwmapN], (TA,) He, or it, returned; syn. rajaEa; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and EaAda; (T;) [and he resorted; (see an instance voce Uiy-alN;)] Uilayohi to it; (M, Ḳ;) namely a thing [of any kind; the thing, or place, whence he, or it, originated, or came; his, or its, origin, or source; his, or its, original state, condition, quantity, weight, &c.; any place; and a former action, or saying, or the like: see rajaEa, by which, as the explanation of Mla, may be meant to be implied some other significations, here following, which these two verbs have in common]: (M:) and Mla Eanohu he (a man, M) returned, or reverted, from it. (M, Ḳ.)

From Mla as syn. with rajaEa is the phrase, fulaAnN yaWuwlu UilaI karamK [meaning either Such a one returns to generosity, or, as karamN is used in the sense of kiraAmN, is referable to generous, or noble, ancestors]. (TA.) [And hence the phrase,] Mla Uilayohi binasabK [He bore a relation to him, as a member to a head, by kindred], and bidiynK [by religion]. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.) And the saying, in a trad., mano SaAma Ald-ahora falaA SaAma walaA Mla, i. e. ‡ [He who fasts ever, or always, may he neither fast] nor return to what is good. (TA. [In the Mgh, art. dhr, for Ml I find OafoTara; and it is there said that this is an imprecation uttered by the Prophet, lest a man should believe this kind of fasting to be ordained by God; or, through impotence, should become insincere; or because, by fasting all the days of the year, he would do so on the days on which fasting is forbidden. See other readings voce OalaA in art. Alw.])
Hence also the saying, Mlti AlD-arobahu UilaI Aln-afosi, meaning † The blow, or stroke, resulted in destroying life; in slaying, or killing. (Mgh.)
Hence also, Mla AlOamoru UilaI kacaA [The affair, or case, became ultimately reduced to such a state, or condition; came to such a result; came to be thus]. (Mṣb.)

Hence also, Tabaxotu AlX-araAba faMla UilaI qadori kacaA I cooked the wine, or beverage, and it became reduced (rajaEa) to such a quantity. (Ṣ.) And Tabaxahu Hat-aI Mla UilaI Alv-uluvi OawiAlr-ubEi He cooked it (namely nabiyc [i. e. must, or mead, or wort,]) until it became reduced (rajaEa) to the third, or to the fourth: (T:) or, said of the same, (Mgh,) or of medicine, (TA,) Hat-aI Mla Alman-aAni man-aA waAHidFA, (Mgh,) or UilaI man-K waAHidK, (TA,) until twice the quantity, or weight, of a man- became [reduced to] (SaAra) one man-. (Mgh.)
[Hence also, majaAzu AlOawoli The proleptic, or anticipative, trope; as faSiylN applied to “a young camel” before it is weaned, because it is to be weaned.]

[And hence also, app.,] Mla AlX-aIoCu, inf. n. maMlN, The thing [became reduced in quantity or size;] decreased; diminished; or became defective, or deficient. (M, Ḳ.) And Mla laHomu Aln-aAqapi The flesh of the she-camel went away, so that she became lean, or slender and lean, or lean and lank in the belly. (T, Ḳ.)

Mla, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. OawolN (T, M, Ḳ) and UiyaAlN, (M, Ḳ,) is also said of tar, (T, Ṣ, M,) and of honey, (Ṣ,) and of milk, (M,) and of wine, or beverage, (TA,) and of urine, (M,) or of the urine of camels that have been contented with green pasture instead of water, at the end of their being in that state, (T,) and of oil, (M, Ḳ,) and other things, (Ḳ,) as meaning It became thick: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) said of milk, it thickened and coagulated: (M:) said of wine, or beverage, it thickened, and became intoxicating in its utmost degree: (Az, TA:) and said of oil, it attained its full perfume, or sweetness of odour, by being well prepared or compounded. (T.)

maA laka taWuwlu UilaI katifayoka [written in the TA without any vowel-signs, app. meaning ‡ What aileth thee that thou shruggest thy shoulders? lit., drawest thyself together to thy two shoulder-blades?] is said [to a man] UicaA QnoDam-a UilayohimaA waQjotamaEa [when he draws himself together to them, and contracts himself]; and is a tropical phrase: so says Z. (TA.)
Mla mino fulaAnK He escaped, or became safe or secure, from such a one: a dial. var. of waOala: (T, Ḳ:) of the dial. of the Ansár. (TA.)

You say also, Mla, aor. yaWuwlu; (T, Mṣb;) or Oawila, aor. yaOowalu; (Ḳ;) meaning He, or it, preceded; went before; was, or became, before, beforehand, first, or foremost; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and came: (Mṣb:) with this, also, waOala is syn.; and from it [says Az] is most probably derived Oaw-alu, so that its original form is OaOowalu: [or, as Fei says,] hence is derived the phrase, used by the vulgar, AlEaXoru AlOaw-alu with fet-ḥ to the hemzeh [as meaning “the first, or preceding, ten (nights of the month),” for AlOuwalu, pl. of AlOuwlaI, fem. of AlOaw-alu; but this is generally regarded as being originally AlOawoOalu, from waOala]. (Mṣb.)
Mlahu: see 2.

Accord. to Lth, (TA,) Oulotuhu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. OaWuwluhu, inf. n. OawolN, (TA,) signifies I made it (namely, milk, M, or oil, &c., Ḳ) to thicken, (M, Ḳ,) and to coagulate; (M;) the verb being both intrans. and trans.: (Ḳ:) but Az says that it is not known as trans., in this sense, in the language of the Arabs [of the classical ages]. (TA.)

Mla raEiy-tahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yuWuwlu, inf. n. OawolN (Ṣ) and UiyaAlN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of which the simple subst. is UiyaAlapN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) He (a prince or commander, Ṣ, or a king, M, Ḳ) ruled, or governed, his subjects; presided over their affairs, as commander or governor; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and did so well: (Ṣ:) and Mla Ealayohimo, inf. n. OawolN and UiyaAlN and UiyaAlapN, [or this last, as said above, is a simple subst.,] he presided over them; held command, or authority, over them; (M, Ḳ;) namely, a people, or company of men; (Ḳ;) or, over their affairs. (TA.) It is said in a prov., (M,) qado OulonaA waUiyla EalayonaA (T, Ṣ, M) We have ruled and been ruled; (T;) we have presided and been presided over. (M.)

Mla maAlhu, (T, Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyaAlapN, (T, Mṣb,) He put into a good, or right, state, or condition, and managed, or tended, his mAl [meaning cattle]; (T, Ṣ, M,* Ḳ;) as also AYtAlhu↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAlahu], (Ḳ,) inf. n. AiytiyaAlN: (Ṣ:) or he managed his camels, and his sheep or goats, in such a manner that they throve, or became in a good state or condition, by his management. (Mṣb.) Lebeed describes a female singer
bimuwat-arK taOotaAluhu↓ UibohaAmuhaA , (T, Ṣ,) meaning with a stringed lute, (EM p. 169,) which her thumb adjusts; (Ṣ, EM;) from Oulotu, (T, Ṣ,) signifying I put into a good, right, or proper, state, or condition. (T. [But see another reading in the first paragraph {1} of art. AwI.]) You say also, Oulotu AlX-aIoCa meaning I composed, or collected together, the thing, and put it into a good, right, or proper, state, or condition: and some of the Arabs say, Oaw-ala↓ Qll-ehu Ealayoka Oamoraka, i. e. May God compose for thee thine affair: and, by way of imprecation, laA Oaw-ala↓ Qll-ehu Ealayohi Xamolahu [May God not compose for him his discomposed, disorganized, deranged, or unsettled, affair, or affairs]. (T.)

Oulotu AlUibla, inf. n. OawolN and UiyaAlN, also signifies I drove the camels: (M:) or, accord. to the T, I bound the camels' udders with the OaSir-ap (SararotuhaA) until the time of milking, when I loosed them. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Ow-lhu Uilayohi, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOowiylN, (TA,) He returned it (namely, a thing, M) to him, or it; he made it, or caused it, to return to him, or it; syn. rajaEahu: (M, Ḳ: in the CK raj-aEahu:) and Mlahu↓ also signifies the same; syn. rad-ahu. (TA.) You say, Oaw-ala Qll-ehu Ealayoka DaAl-ataka May God restore to thee thy stray; (T,* TA;) cause it to return to thee; (TA;) bring together thee and it. (T.) And Oaw-alotuhu UilaI kacaA I caused him, or it, to come to such a state or condition; brought, or reduced, him, or it, thereto; syn. Say-arotuhu Uilayohi. (T.)
See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places.

taOowiylN also signifies The discovering, detecting, revealing, developing, or disclosing, or the explaining, expounding, or interpreting, that to which a thing is, or may be, reduced, or that which it comes, or may come, to be: (Ṣ, O, TA:) you say, Oaw-alotuhu, inf. n. taOowiylN; and taOaw-alotuhu↓, inf. n. taOaw-ulN; in one and the same sense: and hence the saying of El-Aạshà:
EalaI Oan-ahaA kaAnato taOaw-ulu↓ Hub-ihaA
taOaw-ula↓ riboEiI-i Als-iqaAbi faOaSoHabaA : (Ṣ:) or tAw-al↓ Hub-ahA: (so in a copy of the T: [the former word being, accord. to this reading, a contraction of tataOaw-alu; but this does not altogether agree with what here follows:]) AO says, taOaw-ulu Hub-ihaA means tafosiyruhu wamarojiEuhu: [i. e., the explanation of her love, or of the (poet's) love of her, and the state, or condition, to which it eventually came, is this:] (Ṣ:) it was small in his heart, and ceased not to grow until it became great; like as the little young camel [born in the season called rbyE, or in the beginning of the breeding-time,] ceases not to grow until he becomes great like his mother, (T,* Ṣ,) and has a son accompanying him: (Ṣ:) [or] Ow-lhu and tOw-lhu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former as above, (Ḳ,) when said of language, signify dab-arahu waqad-arahu wafas-arahu [he considered its end, or what it might be to which it led or pointed, and compared one part of it with another, and then explained, or expounded, or interpreted, it]: (M, Ḳ:) hence, [if the explanation in the M and Ḳ be meant to denote three distinct meanings, which I do not think to be the case,] it would seem as though taOowiylN and tafosiyrN were syn.; but accord. to other authorities, they differ: (TA:) [Az says,] accord. to Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, these two words and maEonFI are all one: but tOwyl seems to me to signify the collecting the meanings of dubious expressions by such expression as is clear, or plain, without dubiousness: or, accord. to Lth, it is the interpreting of language that has different meanings; and this cannot be rightly done but by an explanation which changes the expression; as also tOaw-ulN↓: (T:) or the turning a verse of the Ḳur-án from its apparent meaning to a meaning which it bears, or admits, when the latter is agreeable with the Scripture and the Sunneh: for instance, in the words of the Ḳur [vi. 95, &c.], yuxoriju QloHaI-a mina Almay-iti, if the meaning be [thus explained] “He produceth the bird from the egg,” this is tfsyr: and if [it be explained as meaning] “He produceth the believer from the unbeliever,” or “the knowing from the ignorant,” this is tOwyl: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: (TA:) [hence, although it may often be rendered by interpretation, like tfsyr, it more properly signifies the rendering in a manner not according to the letter, or overt sense; explaining the covert, or virtual, meaning; interpreting in a manner not according to the obvious meaning:]
or the reducing a thing to its ultimate intent, whether it be a saying or an action: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or tfsyr signifies the “discovering, detecting, revealing, or disclosing, what is meant by a dubious expression;” and tOwyl, the reducing one of two senses, or interpretations, which an expression bears, or admits, to that which suits the apparent meaning: (L and Ḳ in art. fsr, and TA in that and in the present art.:) or the former signifies the “expounding, explaining, or interpreting, the narratives which occur collected without discrimination in the Ḳur-án, and making known the significations of the strange words or expressions, and explaining the occasions on which the verses were revealed;” and the latter, the explaining the meaning of that which is mutaXaAbihi, [or what is equivocal, or ambiguous,] i. e., what is not understood without repeated consideration. (TA: [in which are some further explanations; but these add nothing of importance.])
[Hence, Ow-l lafoZFA, in grammar, He rendered a word, or an expression, or a phrase, in grammatical analysis, by another word, or expression, or phrase.]
And [hence likewise,] taOowiylN signifies also The interpretation, or explanation, of a dream; the telling the final sequel, or result, thereof: (M, Ḳ:) as in the Ḳur xii. 101. (M.)

It is also used [as a simple subst.] to signify The end, issue, result, or final sequel, of a thing; syn. EaAqibapN; (Bḍ in iv. 62 and xvii. 37;) or maMlN↓; (Jel in the same places;) or marojiEN, and maSiyrN; as in the Ḳur [iii. 5], wamaA yEolamu taOowiylahu Uil-aA Qll-ehu [But none knoweth the end,, &c., thereof, except God]: (AʼObeyd, T:) or this phrase means, but none knoweth when will be the resurrection, and to what the case will eventually come, (T, M,) when the hour shall arrive, (TA,) except God: (T, M:) so says Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ: (T:) and in like manner, [in the Ḳur vii. 51,] halo yanoZuruwna Uil-aA taOowiylahu means Do they wait for aught save the result to which their case will come by the resurrection? (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T, M:) or, the result to which it will come (Bḍ, Jel) in the manifestation of its truth by the appearance of the promises and threats of which it has told? (Bḍ:) in like manner, also, the saying, taqowI Qll-ehi OaHosanu taOowiylFA means The fear of God is best in respect of result; syn. EaAqibapF. (TA.)
5: see 2, in the former half of the paragraph, in six places.

tOw-l fiyhi Alxayora He discovered in him the existence of good, or goodness, from its outward signs: and he sought, or looked for, good, or goodness, in him. (TA.) You say also, taOaw-alotu fiI fulaAnK AlOajora I sought, or looked for, recompense in (or of or from) such a one. (T.)
8: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places.
10. AstMl Alr-uWoyaA He sought the interpretation of the dream, by consideration. (TA in art. swO.)

hom.sense: MlN A man's Oahol [or family]; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. his relations: (Mṣb:) his EaXiyrap [or kinsfolk; or nearer, or nearest, relations by descent from the same father or ancestor;, &c.]; from OawolN as signifying rujuwEN, because recourse is had to them in all affairs: (Ḥar p. 578:) and his household; (Ṣ, TA;) the people of his house: (Mṣb:) and his followers; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) including soldiers: (Ṣ, TA:) and his OawoliyaMC [i. e. friends, and the like]: (Ḳ:) those who bear a relation to him, as members to a head, (mano Mla Uilayohi,) by religion or persuasion or kindred; as in the Ḳur iii. 9 and viii. 54 and 56, &c.: (Ibn-ʼArafeh:) [or in these and many other instances, it may be rendered people:] but in general it is not used save in relation to that in which is eminence, or nobility; so that one does not say, Mlu AlUisokaAfi, like as one says Oaholuhu: (Ḳ:) and it is peculiarly used as a prefix to the proper names of rational beings; not to indeterminate nouns, nor to nouns of places or of times; so that one says, Mlu fulaAnK; but not Mlu rajulK, nor Mlu zamaAni kacaA, nor Mlu mawoDaEi kacaA, like as one says, [Oaholu rajulK, and Oaholu zamaAni kacaA, and] Oaholu baladi kacaA and mawoDiEi kacaA: (TA:) Ks disallows its being prefixed to a pronoun; so that one should not say, Mluhu, but Oaholuhu; but his opinion in this matter is not correct: it is originally OawalN; the w being changed into A, (M,* Mṣb,) as in qaAla [which is originally qawala]: so say some: (Mṣb:) or it is originally OaholN, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) then OaOolN, and then MlN: (Ḳ:) so say some, arguing thus from its having OuhayolN for its dim.: (T, Mṣb:) but accord. to Ks, it assumes the form OuwayolN↓ as a dim.: (T:) or each of these is its dim. (M, Ḳ.) By the Ml of the Prophet are meant, accord. to some persons, His followers, whether relations or others: and his relations, whether followers or not: (Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, T:) or, as some say, his family (Oaholuhu [q. v.]) and his wives: [but it seems to be indicated that what I have rendered “and his wives” is meant as an explicative adjunct to Ahlh:] or, as some say, the people of his religion: (Esh-Sháfiʼee, T:) being himself asked who were his Ml, he answered all pious persons: (Anas, TA:) but in a trad. in which it is said that the poor-rates are prohibited to him and to his Ml, by this is meant those to whom was appropriated the fifth [of the spoils] instead of the poor-rates; and these were the genuine descendants of Háshim and El-Muttalib. (Esh-Sháfiʼee, T.)

yaA lazayodK and yaAla zayodK, accord. to the Koofees, are contractions of yaA Mla zayodK [O family of Zeyd]. (Mughnee, on the letter l; and El-Ashmoonee on the Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, section AlAstgAvp. [See the letter l.])
[See also UiylapN.]

‡ I. q. XaxoSN [meaning The body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, (of anything, as is said in the T,) which one sees from a distance; or, in this case, often, though not always, the person, or self]; (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) of a man: a metaphorical application, from MlN as signifying OaholN and EaXiyrapN; because comprising the members and the senses. (Ḥar p. 578.)

Sometimes, it is redundant, or pleonastic; [being only used for the sake of metre in verse, or to give more force to an expression;] as in the following instance:
OulaAqiI mino tacak-uri Mli layolaI
kamaA yaloqaI Als-aliymu mina AlEidaAdi
[I experience, from remembrance of Leylà, or of Leylà's person or self, the like of what the person bitten or stung by a venomous reptile experiences from the paroxysm of pain occasioned by the bits or sting]. (TA.) [See also another ex., voce jaOobN; and another, voce mizomaArN.]
[Like XaxoSN, it seems to be sometimes applied to Any material thing that is somewhat high, and conspicuous: and hence, perhaps, the signification next following.]
maA OaXorafa mina AlbaEiyri [app. meaning The overtopping, or higher, part, or parts, of the camel]. (M, Ḳ.)
A [tent of the kind called] xayomap. (M.)

The poles of the xayomap; (M, Ḳ;) as also MlapN↓; of which the pl. is MlAtN: (Ḳ:) or MlapN↓ is the sing. of MlN and MlaAtN, [or n. un. of the former and pl. of the latter,] which signify the pieces of wood (xaXabaAt) upon which the xymp is raised, or constructed: and hence Kutheiyir likens the legs of his she-camel to four MlAt of the [wood of the tree called] TaloH. (Ṣ.)
The pieces of wood (xaXab, T, M, Ḳ) of xayom [or tents], (M,) stripped [of the tent-cloths]. (T, TA.)
Also, [app. because rising from the general surface of the ground,] The extremities and sides of a mountain. (M, Ḳ.*)

The saraAb [or mirage]: (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ:) or peculiarly applied to that which is in the first part of the day, (Ḳ,) as though raising figures seen from a distance (XuxuwS), and making them to quiver: (TA:) or that which one sees in the first part of the day, and in the last part thereof, as though raising figures seen from a distance (XxwS); not the same as the srAb: (Ṣ:) or what resembles the srAb: (Mṣb:) or, as some say, that which is in the DuHaI [or early part of the day when the sun is yet low], like water between the sky and the earth, [in appearance] raising figures seen from a distance (XxwS), and making them to quiver; whereas the srAb is that which is at mid-day, [apparently] cleaving to the ground, as though it were running water: Th says, the Ml is in the first part of the day: (M:) Aṣ says that the Ml and the srAb are one: but others say that the former is from the DuHaI [see above] to the declining of the sun from the meridian; whereas the srAb is after the declining of the sun from the meridian to the prayer of the EaSor; and in favour of their assertion they urge, that the former [in appearance] raises everything so that it becomes what is termed Ml, i. e. XaxoS; for the Ml of everything is its XxS; and that the srAb [in appearance] lowers every XxS in it so that it becomes [as though it were] cleaving to the ground, having no XxS: Yoo says, the Arabs say that the Ml is from the gudowap [or period between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise] to the time when the sun is very high, or near the meridian; then it is called srAb for the rest of the day: ISk says, the Ml is that which [in appearance] raises figures seen from a distance (XxwS), and is in the DuHaI [explained above];
and the srAb is that which is upon the surface of the ground, as though it were water, and is at midday: and this, I [namely Az] say, is what I have found the Arabs in the desert to say: (T:) El-Ḥareeree speaks of the glistening of the Ml; app. using this word in the sense of srAb; for it is the latter that glistens; not the former: (Ḥar p. 363:) the word is masc. and fem. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) The phrase yarfaEu QloMlaA, ending a verse (Ṣ, M) of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,) i. e. Edh-Dhubyánee, (TA,) or El-Jaadee, (Ṣ,) [variously cited in the Ṣ and M and TA,] is an instance of inversion; the meaning being yarofaEuhu QloMlu [The Ml raising it]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the meaning is, making the Ml conspicuous more than it would otherwise be; the agent of the verb being a prominent portion of a mountain, which, being itself raised [in appearance] by the Ml, has the effect of doing this. (M.)
See also the next paragraph.
And see OalayaAnN, in art. AlI.

MlapN i. q. OadaApN [i. e. An instrument; a tool; an implement; a utensil: and instruments; tools; implements; utensils; apparatus; equipments; equipage; accoutrements; furniture; gear; tackling;] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with which one works, for himself or for another: it is both sing. and pl.: (M, Ḳ:) or, (Ḳ,) as some say, (M,) it is a pl. having no sing. (M, Ḳ) as to the letter: (M:) [but it is very often used as a sing.:] and the pl. is MlaAtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In the saying of ʼAlee, yasotaEomilu Mlapa Ald-iyni fiI Talabi Ald-unyaA [lit. He makes use of the instrument of religion in seeking the goods of the present world], † science, or knowledge, is meant; because thereby only is religion. (M.)
[A musical instrument;] a lute; a musical reed, or pipe; the [kind of mandoline called] Tunobuwr. (TA.)
The male organ of generation. (TA.)

The bier of a corpse. (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Thus, accord. to some, in the following verse, (Ṣ,* M,) of Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr:
kul-u Qboni OunovaI waUino TaAlto salaAmatuhu
yawomFA EalaI MlapK HadobaMCa maHomuwlu
[Every son of a female, though his health, or safety, long continue, is one day borne upon a gibbous bier: for the bier of the Arabs of the desert was generally composed of two poles connected by a net-work of cords upon which the corpse lay depressed]: (Ṣ, M:) or, as some say, [in a distressing state, or condition; for, they say,] Mlap here signifies Halap. (TA.)
See also MlN, in two places, near the middle of the paragraph.
A state, or condition; i. q. HaAlapN [as mentioned above]: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] MlN↓. (T, Ṣ.) You say, huwabiMlpi sawoCK [He is in an evil state or condition]. (Ṣ.)
I. q. Xic-apN [Straitness; difficulty; distress;, &c.]. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: UiylapN sometimes signifies The relations to whom one goes [or is traced] back in genealogy. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.) [See also MlN.]
You say also, radadotuhu UilaI Uiylatihi I made him to go back, or revert, to his natural disposition: or, to his [original] state or condition. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
Ouwluw, in the gen. and accus. OuwliI: see Ouluw, in art. Alw.

hom.sense: OuwlaI fem. of Oaw-alu: see the latter in art. wOl.
OuwlaI as a pl., and its var. OuwlaMCi; and OuwleYika, or OuwlaMYika;, &c.: see OulaI, in art. AlI.

entry.sense: OawaAlN A certain idol of [the tribes of] Bekr and Teghlib, (Ḳ, TA,) the two sons of Wáïl. (TA.)
OuwayolN dim. of MlN, q. v. (Ks, T, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: UiyaAlN The vessel, or receptacle, of thickening, or thick, milk: (M:) [or, accord. to the Ḳ, this seems to be termed Ouy-alN↓: see MYilN:] or, in which wine (XaraAb), or expressed juice, or what is pressed, or squeezed, so that its juice is forced out, or the like thereof, is made to thicken. (TA.)
[Also an inf. n. of 1, which see throughout.]

entry.sense: UiyaAlapN Rule, or government: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) [accord. to some, an inf. n. of Mla as a trans. verb: accord. to others,] a simple subst. (Mṣb.)
Oaw-alu and its variations, &c., see art. wOl: some, on account of difference of opinion from others respecting its radical letters, have mentioned this word in the present art. (TA.)

hom.sense: Oay-ilN: see Uiy-alN:
and see also MYilN, last sentence.
Ouy-alN: see Uiy-alN:
and see also MYilN, in four places; and UiyaAlN.

entry.sense: Uiy-alN and Ouy-alN↓ (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, the first and third and fourth in art. Ayl) and Oy-ilN↓, (T, Ḳ,) the last on the authority of IAạr, (TA,) but AʼObeyd says that it is Uiy-alN, with kesr, (T,) and this is the approved form, (TA,) The [animal called] waEol: (Ḳ:) or the male waEol; (ISh, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) i. e. the mountain-goat: (Mṣb:) accord. to some, (Ṣ,) what is called in Persian kawazon; (Ṣ, Mgh;) by which word Sh explains the word Uiy-alN: ISh says, it is the animal that is very wide between the horns, and bulky, like the domestic bull: (T:) [see baqaru AlwaHoXi in art. bqr:] and Lth says, it is called thus because it resorts (yaWuwlu) to the mountains: sometimes the I is changed into j: the fem. is of the same three forms with p: (TA:) and the pl. is OayaAYilu [like sayaAYidu pl. of say-idN]. (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb.)
See also MYilN, in two places.

hom.sense: MYilN [act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses: and thus, particularly,] Thickening, or thick; (T, Ṣ, M, TA;) applied to the urine of camels that have been contented with green pasture instead of water, at the end of their being in that state; (T;) or to milk, (Ṣ, M, TA,) and to oil, and other things, such as tar, and honey, and wine, or beverage: (TA:) pl. Ouy-alN↓: (Ṣ, M:) which last word [in one copy of the M written UiylN, but this I think a mistranscription,] signifies also the remains of thickening, or thick, milk; or, as some say, the [seminal] water in the womb: (M:) or this same word (Ouy-alN) has the last of these significations; and also, [as a sing. epithet,] the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph; as also MYilN, applied to milk; (Ḳ;) or to milk thickening, or thick, and mixed; not excessively thick, but in a somewhat good degree, and changed in its flavour: (AḤát, TA:) or it [app. Ouy-alN, as in the TḲ,] signifies the vessel, or receptacle, thereof; (Ḳ;) [a meaning assigned in the M to UiyaAlN;] in which milk thickens: (TA:) Sh says that Uiy-alN↓ signifies the milk of the OayaAYil [pl. of Uiy-alN]; and so says AA: but AHeyth says that this is absurd; and that the right word is Ouy-alN↓, having the signification first explained in this paragraph, i. e. thickening, or thick, milk: En-Naḍr says that Uiy-alN↓ signifies thick urine of she-goats of the mountain; which, when drunk by a woman, excites her venereal faculty: (T:) or this last word is used to signify milk of an Uiy-al, which is said to strengthen in the venereal faculty, and to fatten, as Ibn-Ḥabeeb asserts; and Ouy-alN↓, which he affirms to be wrong, is a dial. var. thereof; and it may also be a quasi-pl. n. thereof: (M:) as a pl. [of MYilN], applied to milk, Muy-alN↓ is extr. in two respects; as a pl., of this form, of an epithet not applied to an animal; and as being regularly Ouw-alN. (IJ, M.)
Uin-ahu laMYilu maAlK and Oay-ilu↓ maAlK Verily he is a good manager, or tender, of cattle, or camels, or the like. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: taOowiylN used as a simple subst. in the sense of EaAqibapN, &c.: see 2, last sentence.

hom.sense: maMlN inf. n. of Mla, in two senses pointed out above. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence, maMluhu UilaI kacaA His, or its, return, or course, or transition, is to such a state or condition.]

Also, [as a noun of place, &c.,] i. q. marojiEN [as signifying A place, and a state, or condition, to which a person, or thing, returns; and, to which he, or it, ultimately, or eventually, comes]. (TA, [where this is given as a signification not mentioned in the Ḳ; so that mrjE is not here used as an inf. n.: it is, moreover, a signification well known.]) See also 2, last sentence.
A refuge: applied in this sense to God. (Ḥar p. 361.)

entry.sense: huwa muWotaAlN liqawomihi muqotaAlN Ealayohimo He is ruler, or governor, of his people; a possessor of dictatorship over them, or of authority over them to judge or give judgment or pass sentence or decide judicially. (A, TA.)
hecaA mutaOaw-alN HasanN [app. This is a good discovery made from outward signs]. (TA, where it immediately follows taOaw-ala fiyhi Alxayora with its explanations given above.)
mutaOaw-ilN: see its verb.
[Sometimes it signifies] Veracious: opposed to mutaqaw-ilN. (Ḥar p. 256.)
Ouwluw, in the gen. and accus. OuwliI: see Ouluw in art. Alw.

hom.sense: OuwlaI fem. of Oaw-alu: see the latter in art. wOl.
OuwlaI as a pl., and its var. OuwlaMCa; and OuwleYika, or OuwlaMYika;, &c.: see OulaI, in art. AlI.
1. Mna, aor. yaWuwnu, inf. n. OawonN, He was, or became, at rest, or at ease; he rested in a journey. (IAạr, T.)

Ounotu, aor. and inf. n. as above, I enjoyed a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
I was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

I was, or became, gentle; or I acted gently: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and I acted, or proceeded, with moderation, without haste or hurry, in pace or journeying: (M:) I went gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) OawonN [the inf. n.] is formed by substitution [of O for h] from hawonN. (Ṣ.) You say, Ounotu biAlX-aIoCi, and EalaI AlX-aIoCi, I was gentle, or I acted gently, with the thing; (M;) and fiI AlOamori in the affair. (Mṣb.) And Ouno EalaI nafosika Act thou gently with thyself, or be thou gentle, in pace or journeying: and proceed thou with moderation, without haste or hurry: (T, Ṣ:) said in the latter sense to one who has become unsteady, or irresolute. (T.) [In like manner,] you say, Oaw-ino↓ EalaI qadorika, meaning Ait-aYido EalaI naHowika [app. Act thou with moderation, gentleness, deliberation, or in a leisurely manner, according to thine ability, or to the measure of thine ability; for qadorN and naHowN are both syn. with miqodaArN]. (T, Ḳ.) And Oaw-inuwA↓ fiI sayorikumo Proceed ye with moderation in your course or pace or journeying. (ISk, T.) And taOaw-ana↓ fiI AlOamori He paused, or was patient, in the affair. (M.)
OawonN also signifies The being weary, or fatigued; like OayonN. (M.) [Whether, in this sense, it have a verb, is doubtful: see its syn. here mentioned.]

Also The putting oneself to trouble, or inconvenience, for the sake of what one may expend upon himself and his family. (M.) And hence, accord. to one [whose name is imperfectly written in the TA], the word maWuwnapN↓, [as being originally maOowunapN,] of the measure mafoEulapN: but others say that it is of the measure faEuwlapN, from maOanotu. (TA.)
Mna Oawonuka↓ and OawaAnuka [and Oayonuka] signify the same. (M.) [See art. Ayn.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1.
AlMna and its vars.: see art. Ayn. [Accord. to some, it belongs to the present art., in which it is mentioned in the Mṣb.]
OawonN: see 1 [of which it is the inf. n.]: and see also what next follows.

OawaAnN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and UiwaAnN↓, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by Ks on the authority of Aboo-Jámiʼ, but the former is the usual mode of pronouncing it, (T,) and OawonN↓, (M,) A time; a season: pl. MwinapN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but Sb says MwnAtN; (M; [so in a copy of that work; app. MwinaAtN, as though pl. of MwinapN;]) and MyinapN is syn. with MwinapN. (AA, T, Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa OawaAnu Albarodi [The time, or season, of cold came]. (T.) And fulaAnN yaSonaEu celika AlOamora MwinapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and MyinapF, (Ḳ, [in the CK MYinapF,]) Such a one does that thing sometimes, leaving it undone sometimes. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And Oatayotuhu MynapF baEoda MyinapK I came to him times after times. (AA, T.) And MwinapF signifies Time after time. (TA, from a trad.) In the saying (of Aboo-Zubeyd, L),
TalabuwA SuloHanaA walaAta OawaAnK , (M,) or UiwaAnK, (L,) [They sought our reconciliation with them, but it was not the time that reconciliation should be sought], accord. to Abu-l- ʼAbbás, the tenween of the last word is not a sign of the genitive case, but is, as in the instance of UicK, because of the suppression of a proposition to which the word should be prefixed, as when you say, jiYotu OawaAna qaAma zayodN I came at the time that Zeyd stood. (M, L.)
[Hence, OawaAnaYicK At that time or season; then; like HiynaYicK.]

hom.sense: UiwaAnN: see OawaAnN:
and see also UiyawaAnN.

entry.sense: MYinN [part. n. of 1:] A man enjoying a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Hence the saying,] riboEN MYin xayorN mino gib-K HaSoHaASK [An easy, or a gentle, journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fourth days is better than a laborious, or quick, journey in which they are watered only on the first and third days]. (TA.) [The fem. is MYinapN: the pl. of which is OawaAYinu and MYinaAtN.] You say, bayonanaA wabayona mak-Fpa valaAvu layaAlK OawaAYinu Between us and Mekkeh are three nights of easy, or gentle, journeying: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and EaXorulayaAl MYinaAtN ten nights of easy journeying. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

UiywaAnN and UiwaAnN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) [each] a foreign word, [i. e. Persian,] (M,) A chamber, or an apartment, (T, Mṣb,) or a large Suf-ap [i. e. porch, or roofed vestibule, or the like], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) similar to an Oazaj [or oblong arched or vaulted structure, or a portico], (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or built in the form of an Oazaj, (Mṣb,) not closed in the front, or face: (T, M, Mṣb:*) [and a palace; often used in this sense in Arabic as well as in Persian: and in the present day, the former, and more commonly liywaAn, which is Persian, is also applied to an estrade; a slightly-raised portion of the floor, generally extending nearly from the door to the end, or to each end, of a room:] pl. of the former, OawaAwiynu, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) because the sing. is originally UiwowaAnN, (Ṣ,) and UiywaAnaAtN; and pl. of the latter, OuwnN. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, UiywaAnu kisoraI [The great porch, or the palace, of Kisrà, or Chosroes, who is called SaAHibu AlUiywaAni]. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Also the latter, [and app., accord. to the Mṣb, the former also,] Any prop, or support, of a thing: (T, Mṣb:) particularly, a pole of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC. (T.)
The UiywaAn of the lijaAm [is The headstall of the bridle; and] has for its pl. UiywaAnaAtN. (T, Ḳ.)
maWuwnapN: see 1, and see art. mOn.
1: see 5.
2: see 5.

5. tOw-h; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Ow-h↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. taOowiypN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Mha↓, inf. n. OawohN; (Ḳ;) He said Mhi or Oawohi, &c. [i. e. Ah! or alas!]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) he moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; (Ṣ, TA;) i. q. tawaj-aEa. (Mṣb.)

Mhi, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) as also MhK, (IAmb, Ḳ,) and MhFA, and MhapF↓, (TA,) and Oawohi↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Oawoha↓, (ISd, Ḳ,) and Oawohu↓, (Ḳ,) and Oaw-iho↓, (Ṣ,) or Oaw-ihi↓, (Ḳ,) and Oaw-aho↓, (Hr, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so in some copies of the Ṣ, but in a copy in the author's handwriting Mw-aho↓, there said to be with medd, and with teshdeed and fet-ḥ to the w, and with the h quiescent, (TA,) [or,] accord. to Aboo-Tálib, Mw-aho, with medd, thus pronounced by the vulgar, is wrong, (T in art. Aw,) and Oaw-aAh↓, and Oaw-uwh↓, [in both of which, and in some other forms which follow, it is doubtful whether the h be quiescent or movent, and if movent, with what vowel,] (TA,) and Mwuwhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or Oawuwhu↓, but said by ISd to be with medd, and mentioned by AḤát as heard from the Arabs, (TA,) and OawataAh↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or OawataAhu↓, (CK,) or Oaw-ataAh↓, and Mw-ataAh↓, (Ṣ, [in one copy of which the h is marked as quiescent,]) and Mway-aAh↓, (Ḳ, TA,) with medd, (TA,) or Oawiy-aAhu↓, (CK,) and Oaw-i (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Mwi, and MwK, (Ḳ, TA,) and waAhFA, and haAhN or haAhu, (TA,) [Ah! or alas!] a word imitative of the voice, cry, or exclamation, of the mutaOah-ih; (Az and TA in explanation of Mhi;) [i. e.] a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) denoting the prolongation of the voice with complaint: (Ṣ, TA, after Oaw-aho or Mw-aho:) sometimes, also, a man says Mhi from a motive of affection, or pity, or compassion, and of impatience: (Az, TA:) [and it is also said that] MhFA is a word expressive of grief or lamentation, or of most intense grief or lamentation or regret; [that] it is put in the accus. case as being used in the manner of inf. ns.; and [that] the hemzeh is originally w: but IAth says, MhFA is a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning, used in relation to evil, like as waAhFA is used in relation to good: (TA in art. Ah:) and Mw-aho and Mwi and MwK are cries uttered to horses, to make them return. (ISh and TA in art. AwI. See 2 in that art. in the present work.)
