entry.sense: Oayona is an adverbial noun, (Mṣb,) an interrogative respecting a place: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [signifying Where? in what place?]: Zj says that it is an interrogative particle, like kayofa: (T:) [ISd says,] it is a noun, because you say, mino Oayona [meaning From what place? whence?]: (M:) [and you say also, UilaI Oayona To what place? whither?]: it is always mansoob, unless you prefix the article to it, saying AlOayonu [which means The place where]: (Lth, T:) it is fem.; but may be made masc. (Lḥ, M.) You say, Oayona zayodN Where, or in what place, is Zeyd? (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And Oayona bayotuka [Where is thy house, or tent?]. (M.) And Oayona yucohabu bika, which may mean Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mṭr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning Oayona yucohabu biEaqolika [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Ḥar p. 574.) [And Oayona hecaA mino caAka and Eano caAka and wacaAka What place does this hold in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what is this in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what has this to do with that? what has this in common with that?]

It also denotes a condition: when you say, Oayona tajoliso Oajoliso [Where thou sittest, I will sit], the sitting must be in one place: and maA is added to it; so that you say, OayonamaA taqumo Oaqumo [Wherever thou standest, I will stand]. (Mṣb.)

It also occurs used as a proper name of a particular place: thus the poet Homeyd Ibn-Thowr speaks of his companions as being biOayona waOayonamaA [app. meaning In certain places: where and wherever those places were, there were my companions]: in which case it is divested of the meaning of an interrogative, and is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender. (M, L. [In one copy of the former, biOan-aI waOayonamaA, which may mean the same; and voce OaI-N, q. v., biOaI-a waOayonamaA.])
UiynN: see OayonN.

Oay-aAna, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) of the measure faE-aAl, or it may be of the measure faEolaAn, (Mṣb,) also pronounced Uiy-aAna↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the latter of the dial. of Suleym, mentioned by Fr, (T, Ṣ,) and by Zj, (M,) is an interrogative respecting a time, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) but only respecting a time not come: (T:) signifying When? (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) at what time? (Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is fem.; but may be made masc.: (Lḥ, M:) and it may be pronounced with imáleh, though not belonging to a class of words regularly subject to imáleh. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xvi. 22 and xxvii. 67], accord. to different readings, Oay-aAna yuboEavuwna or Uiy-aAni↓ [When they shall be raised to life]; (T, Ṣ, M;) i. e. when shall be the resurrection. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, T.) But you may not say, Oay-aAna faEalota caAka as meaning When didst thou that? (T.)

IJ says that, were it syn. with mataI, it would be conditional; whereas it was not mentioned by his colleagues among the adverbs used conditionally, as mataI and Oayona, &c.: but sometimes it has a conditional meaning, though that meaning be not explicit. (M.) A poet says,
Oay-aAna nuWominoka taOomano gayoranaA waUicaA
lamo tudoriki AlOamona min-aA lamo tazalo HaciraA
[When we grant thee security, thou wilt be secure from others than us; and when thou obtainest not security from us, thou wilt not cease to be in a state of fear]. (I’Aḳ p. 300.)
Uiy-aAna: see Oay-aAna, in two places.
MYinN part. n. of Mna in both its senses.
MyinapN: see OawaAnN.

2. Ay-h bihaA, (Ṣ, TA,) and, accord. to some, bihimo (TA,) and bihi, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. taOoyiyhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He cried out to, or shouted to, and called, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) them, namely, camels, (Ṣ, TA,) and, accord. to some, horses, and men, (TA,) and him, (Ḳ, TA,) namely, a camel: (TA:) or Ay-h bh signifies he said to him, namely, a man, and a horse, yaA wayohaAho [Ho! On!]: (AʼObeyd:) and he said to him, namely, a man, yaA Oay-uhaA Alr-ajulu [O thou man]: (Ḳ:) or he called him, yA Ay-hA Alrjl: (IAth:) and he cried out to him, or at him; or drove him away with crying or a cry; namely, an object of the chase. (TA.)

hom.sense: [Oayoha would seem to be a dial. var. of wayoha; for it is said that] Oayohaka is syn. with wayohaka. (Ḳ: [but see wayoha.])
OayohFA: see OayohaAta.
Uiyho, with the h quiescent, is a word used in chiding, or checking; meaning Hasobuka [Sufficient for thee is such a thing;, &c.]. (ISd, Ḳ.)

UiyhFA signifies, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also Ayha, (Ḳ,) a command to be silent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to abstain; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e. Be silent; and abstain, or desist: (TA:) both are used in chiding, or checking: and hiyha is used in the place of Uiyha. (Lth, TA.) You say [also,] UiyhFA Ean-aA Be silent, and abstain from [troubling] us. (Ṣ, TA.) And UiyhaA Ean-iI QloMna Abstain thou from [Troubling] me now. (AZ, TA.)
UiyhFA also occurs as meaning I hold that to be true, and approve it. (IAth, TA.)

Uiyhi, as also Uiyha and UiyhK, is a word denoting a desire, or demand, for one to add, or to give, or do, more; (Lth, Ḳ;) and a desire for one to speak: (Ḳ:) it (i. e. Uiyhi) is an imperative verbal noun, (Ṣ,) indecl., with kesr for its termination: (Ḳ:) you say to a man, when you desire, or demand, his telling or saying more of a [certain] story or subject of discourse, or his doing more of a [certain] deed, Uiyhi, with kesr. to the h; (Ṣ;) [i. e. Tell me, or say, more of this; say on; go on, or proceed, with this; or do more of this;] and QfoEalo Uiyhi [Go on, or proceed, with this; do it]; (AZ;) and for Uiyhi, you say, hiyhi: (Lth:) but when you make no interruption after it, you pronounce it with tenween, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and say UiyhK, (ISk, Ṣ,) which means Had-ivonaA [i. e. Tell us, or relate to us, something]; (Ks, Lḥ, ISk,* Ṣ;*) and for this one says hiyhK, by substitution of one letter for another: (Ks, Lḥ:) or it means zido [i. e. tell, or say, or do, something more]; and haAti [i. e. give, or relate, something]; (Ḥar p. 592;) and takal-ama [i. e. speak]. (Idem p. 419.) In the following saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
waqafonaA waqulonaA Uiyhi Eano Oum-i saAlimK
wamaA baAlu takoliymi Ald-iyaAri AlbalaAqiEi
[We stopped, and we said, Tell us some tidings: inform us (OaxobiriynaA being app. understood) respecting Umm-Sálim: but what is the case (meaning what is the use) of speaking to the vacant dwellings?], he has used the word without tenween, though making no interruption after it, because he intended a pause. (ISk, Ṣ.) Ibn-Es-Seree says, When you say, Uiyhi yaA rajulu, you only command him to tell you more of the subject of discourse known to you and him, as though you said, haAti AlHadiyva [Give, or relate, the story, or narrative, O man]: but if you say, UiyhK, with tenween, it is as though you said, haAti HadiyvFA m-aA [Give, or relate, some story or narrative], because the tenween renders indeterminate: and Dhu-rRummeh meant the tenween, but omitted it through necessity. (Ṣ.) Aṣ says that Dhu-rRummeh has committed a mistake; the expression of the Arabs being only UiyhK [in a case of this kind]: ISd says, the truth is, that it is without tenween when determinate, and with tenween when indeterminate; and that Dhu-r-Rummeh asks the ruins to tell him more of a known story, as though he said, Relate to us the story, or tell us the tidings: (TA:) Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Es-Sarráj says, citing this verse, that Ayh is not known in a case of this kind without tenween in any of the dialects; meaning that it is never conjoined with a following word unless it be with tenween. (IB, TA.)

entry.sense: OayohaA: see what next follows.

OayohaAta i. q. hayohaAta [Far, or far from being believed or from the truth, is such a thing: or remoteness, or remoteness from being believed or from the truth, is to be attributed to such a thing.]: as also OayohaAni↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and OayohaAna↓, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK AayohaAnu,) [and several other dial. vars., for which see hayohaAta,] and OayohaA↓, (TA; and so in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ; in other copies of these, OayohFA↓; [but the former is app. the right;]) with the n [or the t] suppressed, (TA,) which is said in pronouncing [a thing] to be remote [whether in a proper or a tropical sense]: (Ṣ, TA:) Th explains OayohaAni↓ as meaning baEiydN celika AA explains it as meaning baEuda celika, making it a verbal noun; and this is the correct explanation: (TA:) or the meaning is AlbuEodu, [as I have indicated above,] (Ḳ in art. hyh,) but this is only when li is prefixed to what follows it, as Sb says. (TA. [See hayohaAta.])
OayohaAna and OayohaAni: see OayohaAta, in three places.
Oay-ihN Having a strong, or loud, voice; and vigilant, or wary. (Ḥam p. 675.)
Oay-uhaA: see OaI-N; last portion of the paragraph.
